DOC.HEAD: Man Who Accused Reagan Officials of Holding Up Hostage Release Found Innocent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT that Bush was not yet vice president at time of alleged flight.
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury decided Friday that a businessman wasn't lying when he said Reagan-Bush campaign officials asked Iranians not to free American hostages until after the 1980 presidential election. The jury acquitted Richard J. Brenneke of five counts of false declaration to a federal judge in Denver when he made statements describing an alleged 1980 meeting in Paris at which he said the request about the hostages was made. One of the counts involved Brenneke's general description of the meeting. He also was found innocent of making false declarations when he said the meeting was attended by the late CIA director William Casey and by Donald Gregg, now U.S. ambassador to South Korea, and that he and fellow businessman Heinrich Rupp both worked for the CIA. Brenneke was not charged in connection with his statement to the judge that Rupp flew George Bush to Paris in 1980. Brenneke testified Thursday that Bush, who was elected vice president later that year, was not at the meeting he attended and he did not see him in Paris. The unanimous verdict was announced at 5:10 p.m. after five hours of deliberation. Brenneke was embraced by his attorney, Michael Scott, and the two men clasped hands. Outside the courtroom, a smiling Brenneke said, ``We told the truth, we told the truth all along and, by God, it was believed.'' Brenneke was indicted on the false declaration charges after he appeared in 1988 as a character witness for Rupp, who was being sentenced for bank fraud in Denver. In his statements to the judge, Brenneke portrayed Rupp as a friend with whom he worked in Southeast Asia for the CIA proprietary, Air America. He told the judge that he and Rupp had helped arrange the clandestine Paris trip. Brenneke said there were three meetings about the hostages on Oct. 19 and 20 at the Hotel Florida and Hotel Crillion in Paris. Brenneke told the Denver judge he attended one meeting at the Hotel Florida. Under federal law, false declaration to a judge is a stronger charge than perjury, which can involve lies to either a judge or jury. The trial was originally to have been held in Denver but was moved to Portland, near Brenneke's home in West Linn, after he had open heart surgery. In his closing arguments Friday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Thomas M. O'Rourke dismissed as a fabrication Brenneke's description of the secret meeting and its purpose: to sabotage President Carter's re-election campaign by delaying the hostage release. O'Rourke also said Brenneke had lied when he said he worked for the CIA, and when he said those present at the Paris meeting included Casey, who was Reagan's campaign manager, and Gregg, who was also a CIA official assigned to President Carter's National Security Council staff. Iran released the hostages it seized on Nov. 4, 1979, on the day Bush and Reagan were sworn into office, Jan. 20, 1981. Brenneke's defense had been built around the contention that the government would lie to cover its tracks in covert operations and that Brenneke worked for the CIA and the agency wants to keep that secret.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Trip Highlights Church's Decade of Change in Latin America
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II is making another trip to Latin America, where the Roman Catholic church has changed dramatically in the 11 years since he first outlined his vision of its role. The nine-day visit to Mexico, starting Sunday, will underline the changes since 1979, when John Paul set the tone of his papacy toward church activism in the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic region. Maintain your commitment to the poor, the pope told his bishops in Puebla, Mexico, but do not become partisan politicians. In the ensuing years, the church has assumed a greater role in social and economic affairs and gained broader prestige in Latin America, but divisions have emerged between liberal and conservative clergy. From without, the church is increasingly threatened by the aggressive proselytizing of evangelical Protestant churches. It is challenged by the dramatic growth of poverty in a region of vital concern to the Vatican. This is John Paul's 10th trip to Latin America and he also plans to visit Cuba, perhaps in December. Latin Americans make up nearly half the world's 850 million Catholics. The Latin church has influenced Catholicism worldwide with its bold efforts to adapt the gospel to Third World societies. Liberation theology, which links spiritual freedom to liberation from economic and social oppression, was born in Latin Ameria. John Paul has sought to blunt the philosophy's effect. ``Certainly, what I feel in the last few years is what we feel a little in the universal church; it is a moment of what some call conservatism,'' said the Rev. Irineu Wilges, a Brazilian who is the Franciscan order's counselor for Latin America. Despite that conservatism, the Latin American church leadership has transformed itself. Cardinals and bishops, once close to the ruling minority, began condemning political repression in the 1970s, when brutal dictatorships were common. Frequently, the church was the only institution strong enough to stand up to the government. Catholic officials who specialize in Latin America say the church leadership has extended its political role in three ways: _ Encouraging the establishment of democracy, particularly in Brazil and Chile. _ Serving as a mediator between the government and guerrillas, as in Nicaragua and El Salvador. _ Speaking out on problems facing new, fragile democracies, such as land reform, foreign debt and the rights of native Indians. Those actions reflect the church's widespread credibility in Latin America and its effort to grow closer to the poor. ``The people have much more faith in the church than they did 10 years ago,'' said the Rev. Jose Luis Castaneda, a Peruvian who is the Jesuit order's regional assistant for South America. ``I don't know if it's the merit of the church or the disasters of the politicians.'' John Paul has supported the Latin church's ``option for the poor,'' declared at a 1968 conference of bishops in Medellin, Colombia. On trips to the region, the pope has assailed dictatorship, highlighted the foreign debt problem and defended labor unions. He also has condemned liberation theology that uses Marxist analysis and warned clerics to stay out of politics. Action has accompanied his words, particuarly in Brazil, whose bishops have encouraged liberation theology. Brazil has about 100,000 ``ecclesiastical base communities,'' church-sponsored groups that press for political and social change. The Vatican promoted conservatives in Brazil, which has moved the bishops conference to a more centrist position. In 1985 it ordered the Rev. Leonardo Boff, Brazil's most prominent progressive theologian, to maintain ``obedient silence'' for a year. Last year, the Vatican divided the Paolo archdiocese of another progressive, Cardinal Paulo Evaristo Arns, into five smaller dioceses, seriously diminishing his influence. ``It isn't that some people are for helping the poor and some are against,'' Wilges said. ``The church is divided over how to do it.'' Divisions between liberals and progressives have deepened because of the actions in Brazil and similar ones in other countries. Last year, the Vatican ignored the choice of the organization's own leadership in choosing a new secretary-general of the Latin American Confederation of Religious, prompting an outcry from priests and nuns. Religious orders account for about 80 percent of the priests and nuns in Latin America. Their members tend to be more liberal than diocesan clergy and bishops. The Vatican acted after the confederation introduced a Bible-study program for members that the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith condemned as too ``ideological.'' Whatever the internal problems, many church officials say Latin American Catholicism's greatest challenge is from conservative evangelical churches on the outside. Non-Catholics in the region now number more than 30 million, the Latin American bishops conference says. In Mexico, the number of Protestants grew more than 500 percent in 1950-1980, to 2.2 million, according to church figures. In some Mexican states, up to 20 percent of the people are believed to be non-Catholic. Some Catholic officials contend the church's approach to faith has been too political or intellectual. Others claim the evangelical churches receive money from the U.S. government or businesses hoping to hinder church efforts for social change. Officials say greater poverty and ever-growing urban slums create serious problems for the church in spreading its message. Activism on behalf of the poor continues to exact a price, as shown by the murder of six Jesuits by Salvadoran soldiers in November. ``The standard of living is ... lamentably regressive,'' Bishop Dario Castrillon Hoyos, president of the bishops conference, said in a recent report. ``We must therefore ask ourselves what have been the results of the church's effort to raise people's consciences, and of the political commitment of Catholics.''

DOC.HEAD: New Wrinkle for Spring Break: Bring on the Seniors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: They may prefer shuffleboard to six-packs and naps to rap, but senior citizens could become the life of the party in this former college spring break mecca. A hotel operator organizing the first ``Senior Spring Festival,'' which begins Friday, hopes gray-haired sunseekers will flock each year to this seaside city that is attempting to shake off its bawdy image. ``These aren't what I would call party animals,'' said Philip Goldfarb, who put together the weekend activities. ``We're trying to attract an older crowd with events that we think they'll enjoy.'' The estimated 5,000 seniors will boogie on the beach to the tunes of The Four Tops and mingle on board a cruise ship. But there's also an opportunity to pick up some tidbits at seminars on such sobering topics as finance and health. The festivities are scheduled to conclude Sunday with a brunch for grandparents and their grandchildren. ``Don't think of this as something trying to replace the college kids. It's obviously different,'' said Goldfarb. ``We're not talking about bikinis and beer. We're showing that there's options for the elderly to be active and social.'' Jogging along the beach in a Spandex bodysuit, 65-year-old Ellen Witt smiled at the idea of her peers in a party mood. ``Why should the kids have all the fun? You'd be surprised what we can think up,'' she said. Since a police crackdown drove off college spring breakers in the mid-1980s, city officials have been preoccupied with trying to recast Fort Lauderdale as a resort for families and international tourists. But the transformation has been slowed by bureaucracic tangles and resistance from some business owners. A proposal to redesign the seedy beach strip into upscale boutiques and hotels attracted only one bid from a developer, whose multimillion-dollar plan was rejected last week as unfeasible. A ban on alcohol sale at nude dance clubs was passed by the city commission, but business at the establishments remains brisk. Meanwhile, the central Florida theme parks and attractions continue to draw tourists from south Florida beaches. For 1989, the Greater Fort Lauderdale Convention & Visitors Bureau estimated the area received 4.5 million tourists, including a boost from the January 1989 Super Bowl. But early figures for this year indicate a drop in tourist spending. At the same time, the number of college students visiting this spring fell below 20,000, down from a record 350,000 in 1985. Most of the students have adopted Daytona Beach as the new spring break capital, but Key West and the Florida Panhandle are also gaining popularity. ``Spring break is part of Fort Lauderdale's past,'' said Goldfarb. ``We're looking at a different environment.'' Goldfarb says next year's senior festival _ scheduled to coincide with a gerontology conference _ will be expanded to a week and promoted nationally. He predicts up to 10,000 oldsters could attend. And some veterans of the college spring onslaught are wondering what to expect. ``Hey, I'll bring the surfboard and they can bring the beer,'' said Alan Frank, 24, sunning on a seawall with his girlfriend. ``At least they don't have to worry about IDs.'' Warren DiPaulo, 17, thought the concept was ``sweet.'' ``Why not?'' he said. ``Party on, dudes.''

DOC.HEAD: Politics Changing, But Much in South Africa Remains The Same
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: After centuries of racial conflict, South Africa is facing whirlwind change as the government and its opponents negotiate to end white domination and try to find a new way to live together. But even as the country witnesses scenes unthinkable a year or two ago, there are enormous divisions and problems to overcome. For all the rapid political change now under way, much remains the same. The government Wednesday began its first formal talks with the recently legalized African National Congress since the black nationalist group was formed 78 years ago with the goal of ending white-minority domination. But these talks are only to clear the way for full-scale negotiations on a new constitution that would share political power with the country's black majority. For South Africans, the meeting created scenes symbolizing the historic change facing the country. President F.W. de Klerk and his Cabinet smiled and chatted with ANC leaders on the sprawling grounds of an old colonial mansion that represented centuries of white wealth and privilege. Nelson Mandela, released less than three months ago after 27 years in jail, complimented de Klerk on what he was trying to do for South Africa. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok and top security officials posed for pictures with Walter Sisulu and other ANC leaders imprisoned for decades. Both sides talked of ending injustice and oppression and spoke of their hopes for a new, democratic nation. Mandela, in a reference to 350 years of white domination, said the two sides were finally ending a ``terrible tradition of ... master and servant.'' The two sides stressed the need for rapid progress and warned that peace hopes depend on swiftly finding a solution. But the government and the ANC face enormous obstacles in solving the country's divisions. Both sides remain fundamentally divided on key issues. De Klerk says he is committed to ending discrimination, but major apartheid laws, including measures providing for segregated neighborhoods and schools, remain in force. The 28 million blacks have no political rights and the 5 million whites monopolize the country's wealth. De Klerk has repeatedly rejected a simple one-person, one-vote democratic system. He says this would replace white domination with black control and there would be no guarantee for white rights. Government objectives for a new constitution, according to senior officials, include some form of white legislative veto power; a bill of rights and the protection of private property; guarantees for free enterprise; and some form of white and black transitional government with white control of the security forces. The officials also say that along with English, one of the official languages should continue to be Afrikaans, the tongue of the Dutch-descended Afrikaners who account for most of the white population and control the government. The ANC has very different goals. It insists on a full democracy with no special rights for any ethnic or racial group. It is also committed to redistributing wealth to aid the millions of impoverished blacks. Many political observers say the country's economic and social divisions may be harder to solve than its political problems. ``Black political leadership is faced with the fact that the constituency it intends to represent is relatively very poor ... for them politics has to be about economics and wealth distribution,'' said Jan Steyn, head of the Urban Foundation, a private group that focuses on improving black living conditions. White leaders are equally insistent on safeguarding private control of business. Their critics say it would take generations to meet even the most basic needs of the black majority, such as better housing and education, if the economy is not restructured. Leaders on both sides believe the government and the ANC will find some solution because they have no other choice. Both sides have staked much of their credibility on securing an agreement and they are under pressure from black and white extremists who oppose any power-sharing settlement. Government sources, who requested anonymity, say that without an agreement on a transitional government and a new constitution, the influence of right-wing whites is likely to grow. The pro-apartheid Conservative Party won 31 percent of the vote in parliamentary elections for whites last September. White extremists have called for de Klerk's ouster. The ANC faces similar opposition from radical black groups that talk of armed struggle as the only way to end all white control and influence. ANC leaders say many young blacks do not want a peaceful settlement with the government. ``One should understand the very serious predicament of the ANC in regard to the deep suspicion in the minds of millions of young militant blacks who simply do not believe in the sincerity of the government,'' said Beyers Naude, a white Afrikaner cleric on the ANC negotiating team.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Renfrew is the AP bureau chief in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Central American Peacemaker Appeals for Demilitarization
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Outgoing President Oscar Arias said Central America should be demilitarized because the region's limited resources should be spent on tractors instead of tanks. In an interview with The Associated Press, Arias on Wednesday also criticized what he called U.S. efforts to hinder fulfillment of a regional peace plan he drafted in 1987 with the help of other Central American leaders. Arias, who hands power Tuesday to Rafael Calderon, was awarded the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize for authoring the 1987 peace accord. It was seen as crucial to ending Nicaragua's civil war and promoting elections in February in Nicaragua. The U.S.-backed opposition won the vote. ``The decade of the '90s must be the decade of disarmament if we want greater development,'' said Arias, a Social Democrat whose country is the only Latin American nation with no armed forces. ``There is no other way,'' he said while being driven to a ceremony at a cattle breeding center outside San Jose. ``The gap between the rich northern nations and the poor southern ones continues to widen. Rich countries' commitments to poor countries are not increasing, so we must depend more on internal savings. We must dedicate our resources to the satisfaction of our peoples' needs and not to buying arms. ``Costa Rica is the best example. Costa Rica buys tractors while the rest of Central America buys tanks. The tractors produce food. The tanks do not.'' He praised the plan of the new Panamanian government to abolish the army in favor of a civilian-controlled police force. ``I'm pushing that,'' he said. Arias said he had planned to teach at Harvard University for a couple years upon returning to private life but was persuaded by friends, including former President Jimmy Carter, to continue promoting peace. He said he will dedicate himself to working for the Arias Foundation for Peace and Human Progress. ``There is no greater satisfaction for a human being than being able to contribute to ending war,'' Arias said. ``My experience, my condition as Nobel laureate, as author of the Central American peace plan will perhaps permit me to help, to contribute my grain of sand.'' Of U.S. resistance to his peace plan, Arias said: ``Every time I spoke with a U.S. functionary it was for that person to tell me `Look. This isn't working. This is bad. Pull back. Why don't you, the author, declare that the peace plan is washed up?' ``So that they could continue their little Central American war.'' He continued: ``The relationship between the war and drug trafficking did not matter to anyone. Here a horrible cynicism was put into play. There was a double standard in everything. On one hand they were saying drugs were the biggest threat to Central America and that anybody who got involved in drugs must be punished. ``But they closed their eyes when those who were helping the Contras, fomenting war, dealt drugs. And they were on the payroll.'' Arias provided no hard evidence to support the allegation, previously made from other quarters, that U.S. officials supporting the anti-Sandinista rebels dealt in or condoned dealing drugs. ``History will take it upon itself to reveal that this was indeed the case, and that each one receives his just punishment,'' Arias said. The president, who met Monday with a delegation of Salvadoran guerrilla commanders, predicted the civil war in El Salvador will end this year. Asked what he considered his legacy to Central America, Arias said: ``To have achieved that, for the first time in many many years, the people of Central America today all live under democratic systems. ``Also, to have appealed to the sensibility of our people to silence the weapons.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Sandra Day O'Connor received the Bess Wallace Truman Award from the former first lady's daughter, who praised the Supreme Court justice for her dignity under pressure and loyalty to family and friends. Margaret Truman Daniel said she thought O'Connor and Mrs. Truman, both Independence natives, were ``tough cookies'' and might have been friends except from their discrepancy in age and political leanings. O'Connor, 60, the first woman appointed to the nation's highest court, is a Republican. Mrs. Truman, who died in 1982 at age 97, was a staunch Democrat like her husband, Harry Truman. Mrs. Daniels praised O'Connor for her ``obvious intelligence, diligence and accomplishment.'' The award, established earlier this year by an Independence women's group, will be given each year to a nationally recognized woman who has chosen a role appropriate to her time and place in history. ``This has been a treasured experience for me,'' O'Connor said.

Dave Dravecky, who was laid off for nearly a year with cancer in his pitching arm and broke the same arm five days after returning to the San Francisco Giants, will undergo further surgery next week, his publisher says. At the height of his career, Dravecky was diagnosed with a malignant tumor and nearly half of his deltoid muscle was removed in October 1988. He returned on Aug. 10, 1989, leading the Giants to a 4-3 win over against Cincinnati. But on Aug. 15, pitching against the Montreal Expos, Dravecky broke his throwing arm. The 34-year-old retired from baseball last November after a second tumor was discovered in the arm. ``Dave's attitude through all of his ordeals remains consistent,'' Scott Bolinder, publisher of Zondervan General Trade Books, said Thursday. ``He is truly an inspiration to overcoming obstacles and tragedies.'' Dravecky's surgery Tuesday will be performed at Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York. The operation is required to close a wound from a previous operation on Jan. 4 which has not healed because of radiation therapy, Bolinder said. Dravecky's autobiography, ``Comeback,'' has sold more than 100,000 copies since its release April 1, Bolinder said.

James P. Hoffa, son of former Teamsters boss Jimmy Hoffa, won't say if he intends to run in the union's first direct election next year, but supporters are wearing jackets with the logo ``Friends of Hoffa.'' ``I'd vote for him,'' said Mike Bane, chief officer of Teamsters Local 614 in Pontiac. ``Ninety-five percent of the rank and file'' in Pontiac also would support the candidacy, Bane said. Hoffa, a Detroit labor lawyer, said Wednesday the jackets are ``a reaffirmation of the feelings towards the Hoffa contribution to the union.'' He refused to say if he would be a candidate when the 1.6-million-member union holds its elections in June 1991. The elections are part of a 1989 settlement of a lawsuit in which the federal government linked dozens of Teamsters executives to ``a pattern of racketeering,'' including 20 murders. Jimmy Hoffa disappeared in 1975 after being released from federal prison, where he was serving a sentence for mail fraud an jury tampering. He is presumed to have been killed by the mob.

Vibraphone jazz musician Lionel Hampton plans to put a few more cracks in the Berlin Wall during a concert there Sunday. ``I plan to get people there stamping their feet and clapping their hands so hard that enough new cracks in the Berlin Wall will appear to make it easier for future bulldozers to knock it over,'' Hampton said in a statement. Hampton, who is celebrating his 81st birthday with a tour of Europe, also plans to play in Hamburg, West Germany, London, Paris and Zurich, Switzerland.

Nancy Reagan told 15,000 schoolchildren who packed the Rose Bowl for an anti-drug rally they are the ``true pioneers in the fight against drug and alcohol abuse.'' ``The tide is turning in the way young people are thinking about drugs,'' said the former first lady. ``I know that the future of America is in good hands _ the hands of the drug-free generation.'' The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors presented her with a plaque for her anti-drug efforts. The students, clad in T-shirts bearing her ``Just Say No'' anti-drug slogan, were entertained during the 90-minute rally Thursday by off-road racers, the U.S. Marine Corps Band and drug-sniffing police dogs.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Years After His Death, Tito's Deeds Die Too
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: ^With PM-Soviet-Baltics
DOC.TEXT: Ten years after his death, Communist Yugoslavia's founder, Josip Broz Tito, faces a second demise: the almost total negation of his once-vaunted accomplishments. ``The Tito myth, which described him as a giant who achieved only great creations, is now dead in Yugoslavia,'' the state news agency Tanjug said in a commentary for the anniversary of Tito's death today. Formerly revered, Tito's policies are now denounced. Official actions are under way throughout the nation to erase the traces of a personality cult that held sway for almost 40 years. Increasingly, Tito is under attack for his authoritarian style of rule. The ever-fiercer feuds that have pitted Serbs against non-Serbs, and liberals against orthodox Communists, are threatening to tear apart the very country Tito built. Tito earned international recognition in 1948 for taking Yugoslavia out of the Soviet orbit and later making it a nonaligned nation. Since Tito's death at age 87 on May 4, 1980, however, Yugoslavs increasingly have felt that most of their country's current troubles took root during his 35 years of undisputed rule. Tito left Yugoslavia with grave economic and ethnic problems and an impractical, highly decentralized system of collective leadership with diluted responsibilities. The lack of a strong, central authority _ embodied by Tito himself during his lifetime _ has now created two systems within one country, threatening to pull Yugoslavia apart. The two most economically developed of Yugoslavia's six republics, Slovenia and Croatia, have held free elections. Their next step may be secession. The largest republic, Serbia, still advocates Communism. In the past two years, however, it has encouraged nationalism and veneration of its leader, Slobodan Milosevic, over reverence for Tito. The federal government has ordered traffic to stand still as sirens and horns wail Friday at 3:05 p.m., the hour of Tito's death 10 years ago. But even such official respect is waning. The federal parliament is expected soon to abolish a controversial law that makes public attacks on Tito or his policies a crime punishable by up to three years in jail. Serbia formally opened parliamentary discussion of the highly unpopular law, stating that Tito's policies should be evaluated on historical merit and not protected by the ``absurd law ... (which) only maintains his personality cult.'' Serbia's Communist officials and its media have led the attacks on Tito, a Croat. They claim his policies gave Slovenia and Croatia an economic edge at the expense of Serbia. Newly founded parties in Serbia also make attacks on Tito a central part of their platform. In an illustration of the deep anti-Tito sentiments in Serbia, several Tito portraits that the law says must hang in government and public offices have been covered up with calendars and photos of Milosevic. Criticism of Tito in other republics began by centering on his lavish lifestyle. The former leader maintained more than 60 residences and a fleet of luxurious cars and yachts. Increasingly, however, Tito is under fire for punishing opponents. Former inmates of one of modern Europe's most brutal prison camps on Goli Otok (Bare Island) off the central Adriatic coast now appear on television, openly accusing Tito of creating the camp. New publications say up to 5,000 pro-Soviet Communists who opposed Tito's break with Moscow died in the camp between 1948 and the mid-1950s. Even in his native Croatia, Tito is attacked by men he purged as alleged Croatian nationalists in 1971. Several have now returned to politics, doing well in free elections. Official initiatives are under way in Slovenia and Montenegro to return the original names to cities and streets named after Tito following World War II. Plans to erect monuments to Tito in Yugoslavia's main cities have been scrapped, allegedly for economic reasons. The prominent Croatian monthly ``Start'' ironically proposed an alternative project _ a ``Titoland'' amusement park in Tito's native Croatian town of Kumrovec. In another dig at Tito, recent articles and books reveal alleged details of the leader's private life with his wife, Jovanka. Mrs. Broz, who is fighting a court battle with the state over what she claims are her and her late husband's personal belongings, is kept under virtual house arrest in Belgrade, unable to give interviews or appear in public. In a letter printed in the Belgrade Politika daily, Mrs. Broz protested publications about her life with Tito, saying they ``are all a part of a long campaign against my husband and myself.''

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Becoming Narcotics Transit Point
DOC.TEXT: Alaska is becoming a transit point for Asian heroin and South American cocaine being smuggled into the United States and Europe, authorities say. ``Possibly the couriers feel this is a less-traveled route,'' says Fred Thomas, chief agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration office in Anchorage. ``Once they clear customs in Alaska, that's it. Everything going to the Lower 48 is domestic. ``The amount of heroin seized here lately would indicate to me it's a transshipment point,'' he said. Customs agents have intercepted several drug shipments at Anchorage International Airport in recent months, but believe they have staunched just a fraction of the incoming flow of narcotics. The airport, which handles about 250,000 flights a year, is a strategic refueling stop for trans-polar flights between Europe and Asia. Ninety-eight percent of all air cargo going eastward between the two continents stops at Anchorage, and 70 percent of cargo sent from the Lower 48 states to Asia passes through Alaska, says Gina Marie Lindsey, executive director of the Alaska International Airport System. Intelligence reports also indicate that marijuana from Thailand, opium from Pakistan and cocaine from South America are being smuggled in increasing quantities into the United States from Asian ``mother ships'' that transfer their drug cargoes to smaller vessels along Alaska's jagged, remote shoreline, state and federal agents say. In October, two Nigerians were arrested at the airport for allegedly attempting to smuggle in one kilogram of nearly pure heroin. Max Kitchens, head of Customs' enforcement in Alaska, said that seizure is ``just one indication to us they're using Alaska as a transit point.'' Last month, Anchorage police found 45 balloons filled with 9 ounces of heroin inside a toilet at a local jail and suspect it was left there by a Nigerian detained temporarily at the airport by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Apart from passengers who conceal drugs on their bodies or in luggage, cargo shipments are a prime method for smugglers, officials say. Most cargo aircraft passing through Anchorage are foreign carriers, and many are bound for Europe. Last week, 12 pounds of opium from Thailand were found in a Federal Express shipment passing through the airport, Kitchens said. It was addressed to a church in Sacramento, Calif., and discovered during a routine cargo check, he says. The last major offshore drug seizure was in 1984, when authorities found 12.5 tons of marijuana aboard the MV Allison, a seismological survey ship. ``We keep getting intelligence that the same thing is going on,'' Kitchens says. Reports indicate that freighters have been bringing cocaine into the United States via Alaska, he said. Federal and state officials say they cannot possibly keep guard on a coastline dotted with thousands of inlets and islands and stretching from the western Aleutians Islands to south of Ketchikan. That gives smugglers an advantage, Kitchens said. ``They've got so much more resources,'' he said. ``They got more money than we do.'' Such routes are enticing to smugglers facing tightened surveillance along the Mexican border, said Lt. Tom Stearns, commander of the Alaska State Troopers' Bureau of Drug Enforcement. His 23-member special drug squad was set up late last year to coordinate drug enforcement efforts between state and federal agencies. ``If you look on a map _ all the little coves and things _ it's just impossible to cover it,'' Kitchens said. ``There is so much distance and there are so few of us.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: If Mongolia is In, Can Vietnam be Far Behind?
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has been making friendly noises lately toward some countries more accustomed to scorn than sweet talk. Old rivals Iran and Syria are being praised for their role in helping win the release of American hostages. There even is evidence of a thaw with two Marxist countries that Washington has long ignored: Albania and South Yemen. This week, the administration is entertaining the deputy prime minister of Mongolia, Daskiin Byambasuren, the highest ranking official from that country to visit Washington since it entered the Soviet orbit in 1921. Three years ago, the United States and Mongolia were not on speaking terms; now they are talking about a trade agreement. But there's one old foe where the U.S. attitude has been far less accommodating: Vietnam. It was 15 years ago this week that the communist conquest of Vietnam was completed with the collapse of the Saigon government and the humiliating U.S. departure from that country. Vietnam seems ready for the wound-healing process, but the United States has put up a host of imposing barriers. Washington is demanding that Vietnam find a solution to the decade-long conflict in Cambodia and that Hanoi withdraw all its forces from that country permanently. The United States also wants a maximum accounting for more than 2,300 U.S. troops still listed as missing in action in Vietnam. By making normalization subject to onerous conditions, the administration is leaving the impression that it is psychologically difficult for it to make gestures toward the country responsible for America's greatest military defeat. Time magazine chided the administration this week for its tough stance, asserting that ``Washington continues to act as if Hanoi had sent its troops to invade Virginia instead of down the Ho Chi Minh Trail.'' If the administration really were interested in a normal relationship, it could rationalize it easily. A spokesman could explain it this way: ``We are prepared to look to the future instead of the past in our relations with Vietnam. It is logical for the United States to want diplomatic access to the third largest communist country in the world. We believe a diplomatic presence in Hanoi would enhance the possibility of achieving our objectives in that region.'' A Time-CNN poll indicates the administration may be out of step with public opinion on the Vietnam question. Three out of five respondents favor an exchange of ambassadors with Hanoi. But The Wall Street Journal believes administration policy is right on the mark. ``Vietnam remains a bastion of repression and a threat to its neighbors,'' the Journal editorialized. ``It is important to insist that it first become a civilized nation before offering it friendly gestures ... In Asia ... there has been no crackup of communist dictatorships. Neither has there been any significant reduction in the Pacific military might of Vietnam's big brother, the Soviet Union.'' But the state of U.S. relations with Vietnam is not all negative. Hanoi has been far more accommodating lately in providing an accounting of missing servicemen and in allowing former detainees held on political charges to emigrate to the United States. The offspring of American servicemen also are being given permission to emigrate in larger numbers. And there has been a significant expansion in U.S. private humanitarian assistance to Vietnam. Since 1987, the U.S. government has been actively encouraging private groups to send aid to Vietnamese war victims and to children. U.S. officials said that as a result, there has easily been a four-fold increase in the number of U.S. groups involved in these tasks and in the value of the assistance provided. Vietnam's foreign minister, Nguyen Co Thach, wishes the goodwill shown by private Americans would extend to U.S. officials. ``When I meet people from the State Department, their faces never smile,'' he said. ``It is a pity.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Events Mark Anniversary of 1970 Kent State Shootings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs with 2,000 attending march; picks up 6th graf pvs, `Kent State...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Students, townspeople and outsiders flocked onto the Kent State University campus Thursday to view a new memorial near the site where Ohio National Guardsmen fatally shot four students 20 years ago. More than 2,000 people staged a candlelight march on the eve of the memorial's dedication. The marchers walked silently from the rain-soaked Commons, the site of the anti-war protest broken up by National Guard gunfire on May 4, 1970. Earlier about a dozen men, some wearing jackets bearing messages of ``I'm proud to be a vet,'' filed past the abstract memorial of four granite slabs flanked by a walkway and guarded by a student security officer. Others stopped to admire 58,175 daffodils _ one representing each American killed during the Vietnam War. The university planned ceremonies Friday to dedicate the $100,000 memorial to four students who were killed along with nine wounded by guardsmen during the protests against the Vietnam War. Kent State Police Chief John Peach said he expected protests at the ceremonies but did not think they would be disruptive. The protesters contend that students and victims were left out of the planning for the scaled-down memorial to Jeffrey Miller, Sandy Scheuer, William Schroeder and Allison Krause. Peach said there were no plans to seek outside assistance for the university security force of 32 officers. ``I don't anticipate much of a presence of police officers in blue uniforms. We will be using plainclothes officers,'' he said. Speakers scheduled for the memorial dedication included former U.S. Sen. George McGovern; Florence Schroeder, whose son was slain; and Dean Kahler, an Athens County commissioner who was wounded in the protest. The dedication is to be followed by an annual presentation by the student-run May 4th Task Force. Kurt Myers, a sophomore from Newark, Ohio, and a member of the task force, said Thursday that the student protest planners don't want to disrupt the ceremonies. ``It will be a silent protest. We will be there with signs and banners. But there are a lot of us who will want to hear what the speakers at the dedication have to say,'' Myers said. ``A majority of students feel it's important to remember May 4th, but a lot _ especially this year _ seem fed up with so many people coming in, and I think a lot will decide to leave campus early for a long weekend,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Grow Brain Cells in Test Tube for First Time
DOC.TEXT: History's first continuous culture of human brain cells may eventually be used to replace the tissue lost in the brains of people with Alzheimer's disease, stroke or head injury, said a study published today. Dr. Solomon Snyder of Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore said his research team used tissue removed from a child during brain surgery to develop a colony of human brain cells that divide and grow in laboratory dishes. Never before, Snyder said, have scientists been able to coax human brain cells into growing and reproducing in a laboratory. But the new cell line can now be expanded at will through thousands upon thousands of generations, he said. Asked why the brain cells taken from the child were able to divide and grow in the laboratory when so many similar, earlier efforts had failed, Snyder had no answer. ``They clearly had a intrinsic potential to divide more than conventional neurons,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``Just why, we simply don't know.'' Other researchers called the discovery one of ``tremendous significance'' that may cause an explosion of new research and treatment in brain diseases. Although brain cell transplantation is the eventual goal, Snyder said it will take years of laboratory studies before the brain cells can be used on human patients. A report on the research is published in today's edition of the journal Science. Scientists have long been hampered in their study of the brain because human brain cells won't reproduce. Except for very limited exceptions in isolated areas of the brain, humans at birth have all the brain cells they will ever have. If a substantial number of brain cells are damaged by disease, injury or stroke, functions controlled by those cells are lost forever. Snyder said the cultured cells underwent 3{ years of vigorous testing to assure they aren't an abnormal growth such as cancer, but are, in fact, normal brain cells. ``We have every confidence that they will function that way when transplanted,'' he said. ``If they were placed into the environment of the brain, we would expect them to be functional.'' Brains damaged by degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, or by stroke or trauma, may one day be repaired by transplanting cells grown from the brain cells cultured in the Hopkins lab, Snyder said. ``That's what we're working on,'' he said. ``That is our full intent.'' The cells that founded the culture were taken from the brain of an 18-month-old girl who underwent surgery in 1986. The young patient was suffering from seizures and doctors determined that one side of her brain had grown more than the other. Surgeons removed excess brain tissue to correct the condition. Snyder said one of his students immediately placed about a gram of brain tissue into a culture medium. Two small clusters of cells in the specimen survived after 21 days. Researchers treated those cells with hormones to force them to mature and develop into normal neurons. As far as can be determined, Snyder said, the brain cells are normal neurons, except they can divide and multiply. ``If you put them into a hole in the head, they would grow until they fill the head and then just stop,'' he said. Barbara Bregman, a brain researcher at Georgetown University here, said it was premature to suggest that the cell line could eventually be used for brain tissue transplants. But she said the fact that a living culture of human brain cells has been developed ``is very valuable and exciting'' and will enable scientists to conduct brain experiments not possible before. Dr. John Sladek, chairman of neurobiology at the University of Rochester School of Medicine, said the Hopkins research is ``of tremendous significance.'' If further study confirms that the cells are normal neurons, he said, there is a ``real possibility'' of one day using the culture for brain cell transplants in humans. Sladek said that in Parkinson's disease research using animals, ``we already know we can insert new nerve cells into a damaged brain and that those new cells can grow rather vigorously. ... In the case of monkeys, this will reverse the signs of Parkinson's.'' Working with Snyder on the study were Gabriele V. Ronnett, Lynda D. Hester, Jeffrey S. Nye and Karen Connors, all of Johns Hopkins. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Stunt Parakeet Killed Night Before `Tonight Show' Appearance
LaserPhoto LA10
DOC.TEXT: The show business career of Axl the gray-cheeked parakeet came to a crushing end only hours before he was to make his national television debut on ``The Tonight Show.'' David Cota, a San Jose student, said Thursday that his bird Axl was killed when Cota's roommate Chris Potthast fell asleep and rolled on top of the bird in a hotel room provided by NBC. ``The bird was sleeping next to my roommate on the bed, and my roommate fell asleep next to him and rolled over on Axl,'' Cota said. ``I got home about 2 a.m. and I was looking for the bird and I couldn't find him. I woke Chris up and Axl was underneath him, dead. Chris didn't think he would fall asleep.'' The bird, which Cota said had ``a great personality,'' was buried near Universal Studios, Cota said. ``I'm upset and Chris is pretty upset with himself,'' said Cota, who sent ``The Tonight Show'' a videotape of Axl in action to get the prized booking for Thursday's program. ``I was pretty excited. Not too many people make the show.'' Charlie Barrett, a spokesman for the show, said, ``Obviously, the show feels very bad about it.'' Johnny Carson presented Cota with a replacement bird during Thursday night's telecast. The program's talent coordinator, Stephanie Ross, visited Cota and Axl Wednesday afternoon. ``The bird did great,'' Cota said. ``Stephanie couldn't believe it.'' The 1{-year old bird, named after the lead singer in the rock band Guns N' Roses, performed a variety of stunts, Cota said. Axl could roll over, turn around, do a flip on one's finger, stand on his head, put a beer cap in a cup and play dead.

DOC.HEAD: Hashish Destined For Frankfurt Discovered at Beirut Airport
DOC.TEXT: Authorities at Beirut airport arrested several people and seized 400 pounds of hashish hidden in boxes marked as books bound for West Germany, police reported. A police spokesman said the hashish seized Thursday, to be flown to Frankfurt, was valued at about $85,000. ``The hashish was discovered when a customs employee opened one of the boxes shortly before it was to be taken on board the plane,'' a police report said. ``Several people were arrested immediately after the discovery of the shipment,'' the statement said. Police refused to identify the suspects or provide other details. Ports in Lebanon's Christian sector are believed the traditional shipping point for most hashish from Lebanon. However, a three-month battle for control of the Christian enclave has disrupted maritime traffic.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin To Return To Moscow Saturday After Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Soviet political reformer Boris Yeltsin is recovering well from an operation for a slipped disc and should be able to go home Saturday, a hospital spokesman said. The Soviet deputy is now able to walk again and planned to hold a news conference today, the spokesman at Barcelona Hospital said Thursday. Yeltsin ``has raised himself from bed without help and taken small steps around his room,'' according to his latest medical report. Doctors operated on Yeltsin after he suffered sharp back pains just before he was to participate in a debate at a Barcelona television station Monday. He was operated on that day. Yeltsin, who arrived in Spain on Sunday, is a leading reformer who wants to quicken the pace of change in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Lesser-Known Weapons to Fill Gap Left by Canceled Missiles, Artillery
With PM-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States is giving up deploying new land-based nuclear missiles in Europe, but many other, less-publicized nuclear arms already are in the pipeline. Private analysts said Thursday the little-known new weapons, such as a short-range missile fired from submarines, would more than offset the loss of firepower from President Bush's decision not to modernize the land-based Lance missile. ``It's like trading two handguns for an assault rifle,'' said Daniel Plesch, director of the British American Security Information Council, a private arms group. Bush on Thursday also announced cancellation of a modernized 155mm nuclear-tipped artillery shell, although he did not say that existing shells in Europe would be withdrawn. The decisions had been widely anticipated, even though Bush strenuously argued in favor of these weapons last year. West Germany and other NATO allies oppose the weapons. Bush made no mention of the other nuclear weapons already planned for European deployment. Private experts said NATO will be getting more than it's giving up. Already in the American nuclear arsenal in Europe are an estimated 1,400 free-fall bombs carried by the F-111 and other European-based aircraft; about 1,200 artillery shells; 200 depth bombs to kill submarines and 700 aging Lance missiles. The most important new weapon earmarked for European deployment is an air-to-surface nuclear missile that could be carried on the American F-16 fighters based in Europe and the new F-15E nuclear strike aircraft now in production. The leading candidate for an air-to-surface missile is the Short-Range Attack Missile-Tactical, which the Air Force is reported to be developing with a range of about 250 miles. William Arkin, an arms expert with the environmental group Greenpeace U.S.A., said the Air Force wants to start deploying the air-to-surface missile in Europe by 1995 with a total purchase for European use of about 300 missiles. The advantage of an air-to-surface missile is that it would give the air forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization a capability, in the event of a nuclear war, to ``stand off'' from the battlefront and still hit Soviet territory. The United States now has no air-to-surface nuclear missiles in Europe. Britain and France reportedly are cooperating to develop their own missiles of this type. The now-canceled Lance missile, which was to replace the existing Lance arsenal, would not have been capable of reaching Soviet territory. Bush did not say he would withdraw any of the existing Lances, and Plesch said it was possible that NATO could agree to refurbish them to extend their useful lives. The Pentagon has said the Lances are due to become obsolete by the mid-1990s. Among other weapons in the pipeline are more U.S. shorter-range nuclear missiles for deployment on attack submarines based in the North Atlantic and the Mediterranean. Arkin said about 350 of these, called the Tomahawk Land Attack Missile, already have been deployed. Bush's 1991 budget calls for buying 75 more. The Pentagon also is developing new versions of its nuclear gravity bombs and anti-submarine depth bombs. The Soviet Union also has a large short-range nuclear capability, although it is unclear how their deployments may be affected by the demise of the Warsaw Pact as a cohesive military force. The Soviets have urged immediate negotiations to eliminate all shorter-range nuclear weapons in Europe, but the Bush administration has refused. NATO leaders decided last year they would put off any such negotiations until after an East-West treaty is signed to reduce non-nuclear weapons in Europe. Arkin said the Soviets have more than 1,400 launchers for short-range nuclear systems based on land, including about 660 FROG missiles built in the 1960s, 300 SS-21 missiles that are equivalent to the U.S. Lance missiles and about 500 Scud-B missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Jokes and ``Spanglish'' Replace Fear in Amnesty Class
DOC.TEXT: Teacher Milton Evertz leaned down and spoke inches from his pupil Maria's ear: ``Listen to me. Say it just as I'm saying it: `West. West. West. West.''' ``Wet. Wet. Wet,'' she replied, finding the letter ``s'' a challenge for her Hispanic tongue. ``You mean, like, ``mojado?'' asked Evertz, laughing heartily and drawing a smile from Maria as he spoke the Spanish word for ``wet.'' So it goes two evenings each week for the 14 formerly illegal aliens in Evertz's ``amnesty class'' at Hostos Community College in the South Bronx, one of several campuses of the City University of New York offering such courses. For the more than half a million immigrants nationwide who have so far completed these classes _ 100,000 in New York alone _ it's a first chance to emerge from the shadows of American life, to replace daily fear with the refreshing breath of knowledge _ often laced with a joke or two. ``Most have been in this country at least five years. All that time they've been in the shadows. For a lot of them this is a big opportunity _ to learn English without being turned in,'' said Jim Roth, who trains amnesty teachers at CUNY. By day, Evertz's students are factory workers, truck drivers, seamstresses. They came here from the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Colombia, Peru, Central America. At 6 p.m., they gather in a Spartan classroom in a converted trailer surrounded by coiled razor wire to learn English and American civics. Such amnesty classes have been offered nationwide for the last two years at hundreds of community colleges, public schools, churches, charitable organizations and proprietary schools. They exist for the 1.7 million formerly illegal aliens who came forward during the federal amnesty program that lasted for a year beginning May 4, 1987. Those who revealed themselves gained temporary residence status and had 30 months to fulfill requirements for permanent status. Most amnesty classes will shut down around November, the deadline for most to fulfill their requirements for permanent status. The requirements include either demonstrated competence in English and civics, or attendance at least 40 hours of amnesty classes. Critics have cited the near-impossibility of teaching English in 40 hours. But officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which administers the program, and teachers and pupils, think such criticism misses the point. ``Forty hours is not enough to learn English. We can all agree on that,'' said Janet Charney, deputy assistant commissioner of the legalization division of the INS in Washington. ``But the purpose was to get people indoctrinated into the culture, and help them gain some survival skills .. we have found that many have gone on to further study.'' The amnesty classes are ``an aperitif to show these people that they can learn,'' agreed Adolfo Calovini, a teacher at Hostos who speaks six languages and helped develop that school's amnesty curriculum. The classes could hardly be described as rigorous, and the INS allows schools wide latitude in what should be taught. Virtually everyone attending the necessary 40 hours will get a ``certificate of satisfactory pursuit'' required to go from temporary to permanent residence status. The first weeks of the course are spent teaching students English phrases needed for everyday life, ``my name is...'', ``I live at...'', and survival skills like handling telephone conversations. After about twenty hours, the course tackles civics. At Hostos, teachers talk about the history and significance of national holidays like July 4th, Columbus Day and Martin Luther King's birthday. Eventually, the classes will study the basics of the Constitution, the Bill of Rights, and features of government. Roberto Flores, a beer truck driver with a wife and son who crossed the Mexican border illegally in 1981, said he is no longer afraid about his immigrant status. ``It's a very good class. In my job, I must speak English and this helps me,'' he said. But as relaxed as Evertz tries to make his class, fear lingers among immigrants still unaccustomed to dealing with official institutions. Several in Evertz's class looked worried one evening as a reporter scribbled notes and a photographer clicked off shots. ``Don't worry, they're not agents. They're from the TV show, `Lives of the Rich & Famous,'' said Evertz, as his studnts laughed again.

DOC.HEAD: Polhills Celebrate 10th Anniversary
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Freed hostage Robert Polhill says he still feels weak but hopes to leave the hospital as soon as he has enough voice to ``talk my way out.'' Polhill, 55, slipped out of the hospital Thursday to celebrate his 10th wedding anniversary with his wife, Ferial, at a small homecoming dinner. Polhill presented his wife with aluminum roses in honor of their anniversary and followed them with a box of live yellow roses. ``I'm in heaven,'' Mrs. Polhill said. The couple received congratulatory notes from President Bush and from Polhill's favorite singer, Frank Sinatra. They also were greeted by Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., since Polhill is a big fan of the New York Knicks basketball team, for which Bradley once played. Polhill, noting that another freed hostage, Frank Reed, was due to return to the United States today, said, ``I would be very happy to see Frank Reed and I will be happier as the days go on to see the other fellows'' who remain captive in Lebanon. Speaking in a soft, raspy voice, Polhill said he still feels weak but hopes to be released from the hospital ``as soon as I can talk.'' ``I have to be able to talk my way out,'' he said. Doctors at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, where Polhill is being treated, said he has a growth on his vocal cords. The Polhills celebrated their first anniversary together in four years at a reception and dinner sponsored by No Greater Love, a Washington-based humanitarian organization serving as a support group for the hostage families. The dinner at a posh Washington hotel featured Polhill's favorite dessert, an assortment of chocolate dishes including one topped with a chocolate butterfly to symbolize freedom. The dinner guests included Peggy Say, the sister of Terry Anderson, the longest-held Americn hostage in Lebanon. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was seized March 16, 1985, in Beirut. Anderson is one of six Americans among the 16 Western kidnap victims still missing in Lebanon. Polhill was freed April 22 after 39 months in captivity. He was a business professor at the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College when he was abducted by terrorists on Jan. 24, 1987. Polhill, a diabetic, lost 25 pounds while in captivity.

DOC.HEAD: Owners of Huge Pearl Looking for Someone to Shell Out Millions
DOC.TEXT: The biggest pearl in the world weighs 14 pounds, is the size and shape of a human brain, and must have been a pain in the neck of the clam that bore it, say its owners, who expect $25 million for its sale. Variously known as the Pearl of Allah and the Pearl of Lao-Tzu, the natural pearl went on display Thursday and later will be shown to prospective buyers. The Guinness Book of Records says it is the largest of its kind in the world. Part owner Peter Hoffman, a jewelry dealer, said he had been told the pearl was worth from $25 million to $50 million. The pearl's stock is boosted by the romantic legend that says it grew 2,500 years ago when Chinese philosopher-spiritualist Lao-Tzu had a small amulet placed in a clam. People who gaze upon the stone are said to see the images of Buddha, Confucius and Lao-Tzu. The Filipino tribal chief who once owned it declared it a gift from God. A diver is said to have drowned prying it from a clam. Jewelry dealer Peter Hoffman said he and co-owner Victor Barbish might sell the pearl to a museum it they can assure it will be properly insured, safeguarded and displayed. ``I think it's that kind of an item that can do nothing but good if it was on public display,'' Hoffman said. ``Since I first saw it I think I have become a more spiritual person.'' Hoffman and Barbish bought the pearl for $200,000 from the estate of American archaeologist Wilburn D. Cobb in 1980. Cobb received it from a Moslem tribal chief in the Philippines whose son Cobb had treated for malaria. Barbish became entangled in a legal dispute with two other people he sold an interest to, and a court ordered the pearl sold as part of the settlement. According to the legend, the pearl grew to its present size as it was handed down for centuries to Lao-Tzu's descendants. The descendants would periodically replant the gem in bigger clams, allowing it to continue to grow. The pearl and the giant clam that was holding it were lost in a typhoon that hit the Philippines sometime during the Ming dynasty, which ruled China from 1368 to 1644. It was recovered in 1934 by a Filipino diver who reportedly drowned trying to take it away from the clam. Eventually brought to the surface, it became the property of a Moslem tribal chief, who said it resembled the turban-wrapped head of Mohammed. Thus it acquired the name Pearl of Allah.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Sets Hearing for Durenberger
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger says the Senate Ethics Committee is pushing him to settle allegations that he broke Senate rules and federal law in his financial dealings. The Minnesota Republican said Thursday that his attorney had been talking informally with the committee's special counsel, but he declined to give details. The committee voted Thursday to begin two weeks of public hearings on the allegations on June 12. ``It's a matter of wanting to bring this to a head,'' said Durenberger, who agreed to an interview about the investigation for the first time since January. ``Whether the hearing is going to be necessary we'll have to wait until early June to make a decision.'' The ethics panel found in February that there was ``substantial credible evidence'' of violations involving a $100,000 book promotion deal and free limousine service that Durenberger accepted. The committee decided to continue its investigation into Senate reimbursement that Durenberger received for a condominium he partly owned, said Wilson Abney, the panel's chief of staff. Durenberger said he expected the committee to add the condominium deal to the list of possible violations it would pursue at the June hearings. The proceedings would be canceled if Durenberger negotiated an agreement with the committee to settle the case. The committee can recommend any of several different penalties, including censure, expulsion or loss of seniority or responsibility. The panel also could refer the case to the Justice Department for a criminal investigation. Durenberger admits to lapses in judgment but denies any willful wrongdoing. The committee has said it is investigating 113 paid appearances by Durenberger in 1985 and 1986 where the senator arranged to charge fees for speeches and split the proceeds with Piranha Press of Minneapolis, the publisher of two books he wrote. The deal may have broken federal law as well as Senate rules, the committee said. Some of the organizations that invited Durenberger to speak said they considered the appearances standard paid speeches and that his books were never mentioned. Paid speeches count toward the outside earnings limits for members of Congress. The committee also said Durenberger may have broken limits on receipts of gifts by accepting nearly $5,000 worth of limousine trips for personal travel in the Boston area in 1985 and 1986. The committee has been investigating the condominium deal since December, when a newspaper disclosed that he charged the Senate rent when he stayed in his Minneapolis condominium from 1983 to 1989. Durenberger repaid the Senate $11,005 in January after the Rules Committee decided he was not entitled to expenses when he stayed at the condo during congressional recesses.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Busy in the South
DOC.TEXT: For a man who's not running for president, the Rev. Jesse Jackson sure has been busy down South. He was at a conference on blacks and the environment in Atlanta last month and came back for Earth Day festivities. Then he trekked across four Southern states, pitching organized labor among textile and factory workers. The revitalized Georgia chapter of his National Rainbow Coalition has been registering voters on behalf of Democratic gubernatorial hopeful Andrew Young, who was booed by Jackson delegates at the 1984 National Democratic Convention. This week, Jackson is back in Atlanta again at a conference with Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown and Virginia Gov. Douglas Wilder, the keynote speaker at a Saturday banquet. Jackson, who ducked a chance to run for mayor of Washington, D.C., denies his appearances are a prelude to a presidential bid in 1992. But that's what it looks like to political science professor Merle Black of Emory University. ``Everything he is doing is consistent with becoming an active candidate again,'' said Black, who said 1992 is too far away for Jackson's activities to make an impact. ``This is just a way of keeping himself active and visible,'' he said. ``It's not a campaign agenda. It's a freedom agenda,'' Jackson said in an interview. ``Where we once marched and took the steps necessary to end racial inequality by law, we must now end economic inequality by law. There must be a new appraisal of the South.'' Brown sought Thursday to dispel criticism of Jackson's role in Democratic politics, saying it pains him to hear talk of Jackson ``as if he were some kind of impediment'' to the party's success in presidential politics. ``In fact, he's one of the greatest assets to our party. We want to tell the truth about that,'' Brown said. ``He was not the reason we do not have a Democrat in the White House.'' Joe Beasley, interim state coordinator of the Rainbow Coalition, said getting Young elected is his immediate concern. But asked about a possible Jackson presidential bid, he said, ``In my mind, that's always a live option.''

DOC.HEAD: Architectural Firm Picked for Korean War Memorial in Capital
DOC.TEXT: An architectural firm that played a key role in development of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial here will spearhead execution of the Korean War Veterans Memorial, across the Reflecting Pool from the Vietnam site. Retired Army Gen. Richard B. Stilwell, chairman of the Korean War Veterans Memorial Advisory Board, announced Thursday that the Army Corps of Engineers has selected a team headed by Cooper-Lecky Architects of Washington to provide architectural, engineering design and construction administration services. W. Kent Cooper, chairman of the board of Cooper-Lecky, who led the design development team for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, said a sculptor for the Korean Veterans Memorial will be selected by July 1. The design concept calls for 38 statues of heroic size in a medium still to be determined. They will line a path that will ascend from an open plaza near the Lincoln Memorial to a point where an American flag will fly. The site has a view of the Washington Monument and, in the distance, the Capitol. Cooper said the memorial will be roughly the same size as the one to Vietnam veterans. William P. Lecky, president of Cooper-Lecky, said the sculpture is expected to take two to three years to execute. Stilwell, who commanded troops in Korea, said ground might be broken on Nov. 11, 1991, and organizers hope to have a dedication on July 27, 1993, the 40th anniversary of the end of the Korean hostilities. He said about $6 million of a goal of $11 million has been raised. Congress authorized the memorial in 1986. ``Having selected this magnificent site, having selected an equally magnificent, truly heroic design concept of what will ultimately be erected on this site, we are moving directly to the next milestone,'' Stilwell said.

DOC.HEAD: Mail Still Arriving in Memory of Ryan White
DOC.TEXT: More than 50,000 pieces of mail have flooded into Jeanne White's home since her son Ryan died from AIDS. ``We still haven't even gotten the mail open yet,'' Mrs. White said Wednesday, shaking her head, although Phil Donahue and his wife Marlo Thomas hired a secretary to help Mrs. White to sort through the letters. She and the secretary, Shelley Henson, are still opening get-well letters that arrived at Riley Hospital for Children in Indianapolis before White died of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome on April 8. White, 18, became a well-known spokesman for AIDS education after fighting a lengthy court battle to attend public school. ``It's surprising everybody is still calling,'' Mrs. White said. ``I can't believe how many kids he touched.'' Now the favor is being returned from people all over the world. She digs through the piles of mail to read favorite pieces out loud to Henson and displays the large banners sent from school children from across the country. It's a healing process, she said. But Henson finds it difficult. ``I know I probably cry an average of four times a day,'' she said. Mrs. White has been on leave of absence since last fall, when Ryan began suffering more frequent bouts of illness. She said she is considering early retirement to further her son's work in AIDS education. ``I'm not sure what I'm going to do,'' said Mrs. White, who is being helped financially by celebrity friends whom she declined to indentify. About $35,000 has been donated to four funds set up in her son's name, Mrs. White said. The Ryan White Memorial Fund was established to help Mrs. White pay for her son's medical care and funeral. The other funds, for education and other AIDS-related work, are the Ryan White Children's Fund, AIDS Research for Children and the Ryan White Fund, sponsored by the Los Angeles-based Athletes and Entertainers for Kids.
Donations to the Ryan White Fund can be to Post Office Box 40, Noblesville, Ind. 46060.

DOC.HEAD: Promised Shift of Tax Burden to Firms Hasn't Taken Place
DOC.TEXT: A promised $24-billion-a-year shift of federal tax burden to corporations is not materializing and individuals are making up the difference, the government says. But the news is not as bad as it might sound for individual taxpayers. Their share of the federal burden is dropping and they are paying about $24 billion a year more than forecast only because their incomes are rising faster than predicted. Witnesses told the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday that the inability to make precise estimates is chiefly to blame for the fact that corporations are paying less taxes than were anticipated when Congress wrote the landmark 1986 tax overhaul. ``Approximately 58 percent of the shortfall in corporate income tax receipts over the 1987-89 period is attributable to lower-than-expected projected profits,'' Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told the committee. ``Corporate profits are volatile and, therefore, notoriously difficult to forecast,'' Reischauer said. ``The primary reason ... is that pre-tax corporate profits came in below expectations,'' Harvey S. Rosen, deputy assistant secretary of the treasury, agreed. One reason that corporate earnings were lower than expected is that individual incomes rose faster than projected, witnesses testified. Those wage increases gave individuals larger taxable incomes and _ because wages are a deductible expense _ gave corporations less taxable income. Robert McIntyre, director of the labor-funded Citizens for Tax Justice, blamed the tax shortfall on a tendency for corporations to borrow, rather than issue stock, to finance expansion. This borrowing wave was highlighted in the late 1980s by corporate takeovers financed by leveraged buyouts. ``Corporations are sending their profits to bondholders rather than paying dividends to shareholders and taxes to the Treasury,'' McIntyre said. Rosen, the Treasury official, said available evidence suggests little connection between buyout borrowing and the tax shortage. A major goal of the 1986 tax overhaul was to shift about $24 billion a year of tax burden from individuals to corporations. In the 1987-89 period, corporate taxes fell $63 billion short of Congressional Budget Office forecasts and $65 billion below the administration estimate. When the new law was approved, the government estimated that individual income taxes would average $391 billion a year in 1987-89. Collections actually averaged $413 billion a year. The corporate share of income taxes rose from 15 percent in 1986 to 19 percent in 1989, Rosen said, while the individual share dropped from 85 percent to 81 percent. Even so, Reischauer said, corporate taxes have failed to keep pace with economic growth. ``Corporate taxes measured 4 percent of gross national product in 1960; by 1986, the amount had declined to 1.5 percent,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lehder Says Colombian Drug Lords Funded Contras
DOC.TEXT: A former kingpin of the Medellin drug cartel said Colombian drug lords donated about $20 million to the U.S.-backed Contras in Nicaragua. Carlos Lehder Rivas, 40, made his remarks in a broadcast Thursday night of ABC's PrimeTime Live, which interviewed him in the federal prison in Marion, Ill., where Lehder is serving a life sentence plus 135 years. ``We did give a great deal of money to the Contra cause ... I gave. We put up the first time about $10 million to the Contras,'' said Lehder, whose hands were shackled during the interview. ``(In all) around $20 million in cash went to help the Contras.'' Adolfo Calero, a former director of the Nicaraguan Resistance, an umbrella group for the Contras, denied Lehder's allegations. ``We never had one cent from them,'' Calero said in a telephone interview from his Miami home. ``We know where all our contributions came from.'' Lehder was convicted in May 1988 after a 7{-month trial in Jacksonville, Fla., on charges of cocaine smuggling and operating a continuing criminal enterprise. He and others were accused of smuggling some 3.3 tons of cocaine into the United States from Colombia from 1978 to 1980. Lehder also accused John Hull, an American who directed supplies for the Contras from Costa Rica, of cocaine trafficking. Hull, who now lives in the United States, denied the allegations, the news program reported. ``I do know the situation for a fact that John Hull in Costa Rica ... he was talking about 30 tons of cocaine into the United States a year,'' Lehder said. ``Now this is a kingpin.'' Hull, 70, faces charges in Costa Rica ranging from aiding the Nicaraguan Contra rebels to involvement in a terrorist bombing. Costa Rican officials have said they plan to seek his extradition from the United States. A Costa Rican government commission that investigated Contra activity there accused Hull of involvement in a network that ``allowed Colombian and Panamanian drug traffickers to transport drugs to the United States in exchange for arms for the Contras.'' In March, friends of Hull held a news conference in Washington and read a statement from him denying the charges and contending they were based on perjured statements. Hull now lives in Indiana. Lehder also discussed ousted Panamanian dictator, Manuel Noriega, who is awaiting trial in Miami on charges he took money from the Medellin drug cartel to make Panama a safe haven for cocaine smuggling. ``Noriega was always on the payroll of American intelligence, but he was always also on the payroll of the Soviet intelligence, the Cuban intelligence and the Israeli intelligence,'' he said. ``At the same time, he was on the payroll of some Colombian traffickers. He was working every side of the corner.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Irked by Lone Star Flag at London Ambassador's Home
DOC.TEXT: Del. Ben Blaz, D-Guam, admits he's hypersensitive about Old Glory. That's why the scene at the U.S. ambassador's residence in London made his blood boil. There, larger than life, was the Texas state flag for all to see as they drove up to the elegant house now inhabited by Ambassador Henry Catto, a native Texan appointed by President Bush, an adopted Texan. Blaz, a retired Marine Corps general and a nonvoting delegate to Congress, says he's got nothing against the Lone Star State. He just doesn't think its flag should dwarf the Stars and Stripes. ``I'm one of those guys who loves flags,'' said Blaz, who noticed the prominence of the Texas flag when he visited Catto's residence on an official trip last fall. The American flag, meantime, was off to the side and less visible. ``I think we've got the thing reversed,'' said Blaz, who brought the issue to the attention of State Department officials this week at a House committee hearing on embassy buildings. ``It really kind of bothered me.'' Arthur Fort, the assistant secretary of state for administration, told Blaz his message would be delivered to Catto. That was done Wednesday, officials said. Blaz said he didn't know if anything had been done on the flag placement front, but ``I expect it will be.''

DOC.HEAD: Relatives Committed Overwhelming Majority of Child Kidnappings
DOC.TEXT: About 359,000 children were kidnapped in 1988, and the overwhelming majority were abducted by family members, not by strangers, a new study says. ``The size of the family abduction problem really did surprise us,'' said David Finkelhor of the University of New Hampshire, one of the researchers who produced the study for the Justice Department. ``We had expected 25,000 to 100,000. That was the going estimate.'' The researchers estimated that in 1988, 354,100 children were abducted by relatives. As many as 4,600 children were kidnapped by strangers _ 1.4 percent of the total number of abductions _ according to the study released Thursday. However, only 200 to 300 of those cases conformed with a common public perception of how kidnappings occur _ a forcible abduction by a stranger who keeps the child for a long period of time and possibly kills the victim. Such cases include the highly publicized disappearance of 5-year-old Melissa Brannen from a Christmas party in Virginia and the kidnapping by a masked gunman of 11-year-old Jacob Wetterling in Minnesota. Many brief encounters were included among the approximately 4,600 abductions by strangers estimated in the study, based on police records. ``The thousands of rapes of children that occur each year include abduction,'' Finkelhor said in an interview. At any rate, the number could not compare with the 354,100 children abducted by family members. ``It's clear that we haven't paid enough attention to the family abduction problem,'' said Finkelhor, who conducted the study with Gerald Hotaling of the University of Lowell in Massachusetts and Andrea Sedlak of Westat Inc. Finkelhor said such abductions are a reflection ``of how rampant divorce is, how bitter custody fights are.'' Most of the perpetrators were men and most of the victims were ages 2 to 11.
