Few infants or older teens were abducted by family members. Children abducted by parents usually are not harmed physically, but Finkelhor said, ``This is very stressful for kids. It does leave scars.'' The fact that only 1.4 percent of all abductions of children are committed by strangers should not completely reduce parents' fears of strangers, said Ernie Allen, president of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. ``If there are 300 Melissa Brannens a year, that's 10 elementary school classrooms full,'' Allen said. ``That's a tremendous concern.'' The study, required by the 1984 Missing Children Act, also shows that 450,700 children ran away in 1988; 127,100 were ``thrown away,'' abandoned or forced out of their homes by their parents; and 438,200 were lost, injured or otherwise missing, many for short periods of time. In addition, 114,600 children were subjected to possible attempted kidnapping, the study said.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Split Over Weekend Budget Meeting With Bush
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats are variously expressing enthusiasm, indifference and distress over talks that President Bush says may help prevent a political stalemate over the federal budget. Bush announced Thursday that he has invited congressional leaders to a White House meeting Sunday focusing on ``where we go now'' in the slow-moving budget process. ``We've got to move forward, and I've got to find a way to do that,'' he said. The president proposed the meeting in a week in which the Senate Budget Committee and the House have adopted separate, Democratic-written budgets for next year. Each one strips nearly $10 billion from Bush's own military spending proposal for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Congress is supposed to finish its budget blueprint by April 15 but rarely meets that deadline. The document sets non-binding guidelines for the government's fiscal plans and does not require the president's approval. Programs are financed and taxes are raised or lowered in later, separate bills that require his signature. Administration officials and Republican lawmakers have been pressing all year for budget negotiations. They have said that they and congressional Democrats must solve their differences over defense spending, taxes and other areas before serious deficit reduction can be accomplished. Democrats have been split over the idea of talks. Some believe that cooperation with Bush is needed, while others argue that Congress' majority party needs to define its own budget priorities. The two Democratic leaders who will be attending the talks showed little enthusiasm for Sunday's session and volunteered nothing about what they expected to accomplish. ``We have to be prepared to discuss whatever the president wants,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said simply: ``I have said many times that I would meet with the president at his request at anytime about any subject. Yesterday when the president asked me to come to the White House to discuss the budget, I accepted.'' Others showed more zeal for the prospects of negotiations. ``Great idea,'' said Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee. ``I think they could give us more direction about what the president wants to do about the deficit.'' Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, said he saw the session as an important first step toward what could evolve into a full-fledged budget summit later in the year. ``But you can't have a successful summit without everything on the table,'' including the tax increases Bush has opposed in the past, Panetta added. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said that for the session to be successful, Bush would have to convince Mitchell that the administration is ready to move decisively to reduce the deficit. ``I've seen no evidence the administration is seriously interested in reducing this deficit,'' he said. Others expressed disdain for the idea of a summit. Many members of Congress resented the budget negotiations of the past few years, arguing that they end up freezing most lawmakers out of the fiscal process. ``It eliminates many of the cumbersome, clumsy aspects of democracy and replaces them with the efficiency of an edict,'' said Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., a member of the House Budget Committee. ``King George III would have loved it.'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., are also scheduled to attend the meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Political Pressure May Have Changed Decision on Alaskan Causeway
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee is considering whether improper political pressure led the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to reverse itself on an Alaska construction permit sought by the oil industry. The issue involves federal permits for the construction of massive gravel causeways that would connect points along Alaska's North Slope to offshore drilling sites. Two such causeways have been built and requests for additional permits are under consideration or are expected. The oil industry says the causeways _ up to several miles long _ are essential to developing oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Environmentalists say they harm the region's ecology and fish and violate federal clean water laws. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on water, power and offshore energy resources, sought to show at a hearing Thursday that political pressure was put on the Corps over the past 18 months on specific causeway permit cases. Miller said information in internal documents ``starts to suggest a political decision was made .... Rather extraordinary means were taken to see if the decisions could be neutralized.'' The Corps district engineer for Alaska, Col. William Kakel, decided in October 1988 that the 6,600-foot long Niakuk causeway on the North Slope should not be built because of potential harm to fish and water quality in violation of the federal Clean Water Act. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service had said the causeway threatened aquatic habitat. As part of his decision, Kakel suggested that British Petroleum find alternatives to the gravel causeway. He also issued new guidelines on causeway permits that suggested oil companies first look at other ways to work out their problems such as directional drilling or underwater pipes. But four months later, Kakel's guidelines were rescinded and he was told to reopen the Niakuk case. Kakel denied in testimony Thursday that he was pressured by superiors for purely political reasons and said the Niakuk permit case was still active and may be decided soon. His superior, Maj. Gen. Patrick Kelly, director of civil works at the Corps, maintained that Kakel's decision was rescinded only because of procedural problems and not from political pressure or industry lobbying. He said the colonel had no authority to issue general policy guidelines. But Robert Oja, chief of the regulatory branch of the Corps' Alaska district, said pressure from the oil company, which lobbied vigorously in Washington after Kakel made his decision, prompted the reversal. Oja testified as a government ``whistleblower'' which provides him with additional protection against possible retaliation. He said the events surrounding the decision ``convey a strong message about how an industry has systematically and successfully lobbied its self-interests at the expense of the public's trust.'' ``At the very least, this information suggests incidents of abuse of authority, waste and improper command influence,'' he continued, adding that ``a well-entrenched system ... has grossly twisted the regulatory and scientific processes.'' The Fish and Wildlife Service, in a draft recommendation, urged against building the causeway, citing concern about the impact on fish flows, testified Paul Gertler, a former field officer in Alaska and now Fish and Wildlife's coordinator for the Exxon Valdez oil spill. But he said under the direction of senior Interior Department officials, the draft was changed, ``resulting in a letter that omitted all of the service's technical information on fish and wildlife resources and the potential impacts of the causeway ... as well as the service's recommendation that (the Kiakuk) permit ... be denied.''

DOC.HEAD: First Lady's Campus Visit Sparks Feminist Debate
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush's selection as Wellesley College's commencement speaker has divided the campus and alumnae, some of whom question why the college picked a woman known for her husband's achievements. The feminist controversy at the private, all-women's college drew comment Thursday from President Bush, who told reporters his wife's work as a mother and as an advocate of literacy could teach students a lot. Several graduates of Wellesley agreed, but others said she was not the best choice for speaker at the June 1 commencement on the tranquil campus nestled in a corner of this posh Boston suburb. Mrs. Bush dropped out of Smith College, Wellesley's sister school, in 1944 to marry Bush, then a Navy pilot. She said earlier in the week that about 125 Wellesley students who signed a petition against her coming ``were very reasonable'' but would not prompt her to stay away. Mrs. Bush was the second choice of the school's seniors. They first picked feminist writer Alice Walker, who declined. Anne Bernays, who graduated from Wellesley in 1952 and has written eight books, said she was ``very angry'' about the selection of Mrs. Bush, but she said she was angry with the senior class and not the first lady. ``I didn't understand (at first) that it was the senior class who picked her, which is even worse,'' she said. ``Barbara Bush is wonderful, but she was invited to speak at Wellesley because she is married to the president.'' The university named Mrs. Bush as commencement speaker on the 2,200-student campus in mid-March. A protest petition appeared in April. ``To honor Barbara Bush as commencement speaker is to honor a woman who has gained recognition through the achievements of her husband, which contradicts what we have been taught over our years at Wellesley,'' the petition said. Susana Cardenas, a leader of the protesting students, has received threatening phone calls and letters, college officials told The New York Times. In Washington, the president said he and his wife were not bothered by the controversy. ``I think that these young women can have a lot to learn from Barbara Bush and from her unselfishness and from her advocacy of literacy and of being a good mother and a lot of other things,'' he said. Bush was asked if there was any merit to the argument that his wife's accomplishments are related in large part to her marriage to him. ``I can't make an argument with that,'' he said. Mrs. Bush defended her life choices to reporters at a Wednesday luncheon. ``I don't think they understand where I'm coming from,'' she said. ``I chose to live the life I've lived and I think it's been a fabulously exciting, interesting, involved life.'' ``I have enormous respect for Barbara Bush,'' said Susan Estrich, who graduated from Wellesley in 1974 and managed Michael Dukakis' failed bid to defeat Bush for the presidency in 1988. ``I don't think feminism should limit its definition of accomplishment to women who have secured careers entirely on their own. I think there should be tremendous value attached to women who are wives and mothers,'' she said. Nan Keohane, president of Wellesley, said the debate itself serves a purpose _ to publicize disagreements over what feminism is. ``Feminism is very hard to pin down, but it is certainly not anti-family,'' she said. ``What we try to teach is that nobody of either sex should be defining their lives just in terms of making money.'' Nina Budd Scott, who graduated from Wellesley in 1959, said she was angered when she first heard of the selection of Mrs. Bush, but became less so when she learned that the first lady was a second choice after Ms. Walker. ``I'm still not happy with it. I think that there are other people ... who have really achieved a lot,'' Scott said. ``I don't feel hostile about Mrs. Bush, but I just don't feel she's the right person.''

DOC.HEAD: Group of Seven to Address Japanese Yen, Third World Debt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is playing down the lack of progress in strengthening the shaky Japanese yen as economic chiefs from the world's major industrial powers prepare for a weekend gathering. Only a month ago, the so-called Group of Seven promised to work against the weak yen's ``undesirable consequences'' for the world economy and U.S. trade deficit. Nevertheless, the yen's value remains near a three-year low against the dollar. A weak yen tends to hurt the trade deficit by making American goods more expensive in Japan and Japanese goods more affordable in the United States. A senior Treasury Department official, briefing reporters Thursday on condition of anonymity, sought to minimize rate problems by noting the stability of currency markets since the Group of Seven's April 7 meeting in Paris. Coordinated yen buying by major central banks around the world has helped prevent the Japanese currency from falling further. However, the official conceded that U.S. officials ``continue to be concerned about the general level of the yen,'' which by April had fallen more than 10 percent against the dollar since the start of the year. The official said exchange rates will be among the topics covered Sunday when finance ministers and central bank chiefs from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Great Britain, France, Canada and Italy confer in advance of the spring meetings of the 152-nation International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Finance officials also will be wrestling with the politically touchy problem of increasing the resources of the IMF, reviewing progress in easing the crushing $1.3 trillion debt burden on Third World countries and evaluating West Germany's plans to forge a monetary union with East Germany. Some private economists accuse the Group of Seven of minimizing exchange rate problems because they cannot agree on how to fix them. C. Fred Bergsten, a former Treasury official who now heads the Washington think tank, the Institute for International Economics, warned that the U.S. trade gap, which has fallen for the past two years, could soon start growing again. ``I think there's a strange sense of complacency among the G-7 members, except for the Japanese. When officials can't come up with solutions, they tend to deny problems so they don't look ineffective in solving them,'' Bergsten said. However, in a speech to the U.S. Information Agency conference earlier this week, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the yen's decline has been helpful in preventing financial market turmoil in Tokyo from spilling into other stock exchanges around the world. ``The truth of the matter is the system has worked very well. The change in investors' feelings about the Japanese market have translated into a decline of the yen against other currencies but that has to be,'' Brady said. Rather than exchange rates, Group of Seven officials will be spending much of their time wrestling with the increase in IMF resources, known as quotas. The senior Treasury official said IMF members could settle the matter next week and appear to have a consensus for an approximate 50 percent quota increase from $120 billion to $180 billion. The U.S. share of the added $60 billion would amount to about $12 billion. The contribution is a commitment and does not count against the budget deficit. IMF officials warn that 50 percent may not be enough for the fund to meet its growing responsibility in Eastern Europe and continue supporting Third World debtors. But, the Treasury official countered, ``There's no shortage of resources at the moment.'' On the issue of Third World debt, the Bush administration is painting the Brady plan, named after the Treasury secretary, as a success. Introduced in March 1989, it emphasizes debt reduction _ as opposed to new lending _ more strongly than past U.S. strategies. So, far Mexico and the Philippines have concluded final debt reduction agreements with creditor banks. Venezuela, Costa Rica, Chile and Morocco have agreements in principle.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Kicks Off Drive to Assess Future Role
With PM-Baker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NATO has launched its drive to ensure the Western military alliance does not become a rusted relic but instead functions as a key component in new European security structures. NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner told a news conference Thursday that the group ``is taking advantage of the historic opportunity to move beyond confrontation to cooperation.'' He was speaking at the end of a special meeting of foreign ministers of the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. With reduced East-West tensions, NATO is under pressure to reduce its military role and increase its political one. The officials also insisted that a united Germany remain in the Western alliance, but Woerner said NATO does not intend to expand its forces into the current territory of East Germany. Thursday's meeting was the first of a series of high-level discussions that will be capped by a summit of President Bush and other alliance leaders in London in late June or early July. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Bush wants the summit to ``launch an in-depth alliance review'' of its political role, the need for conventional and nuclear forces, and the place of a broader 35-nation forum in Europe's future. ``This will be a very decisive moment in the history of our alliance _ clearly turning toward the future (and) clearly adjusting political tasks and military strategy to changed circumstances,'' Woerner told a news conference. The allies are trying to deflect calls for NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact to be scrapped and replaced by the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which draws in all the nations of Europe, except Albania, plus the United States and Canada. Baker and other ministers insisted that NATO should remain in a new Europe. ``We all agreed, of course, that the alliance will play an essential role ... in Europe's future,'' said Woerner. He said the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe cannot replace NATO. But he said it has ``an important complementary role to play.'' The 35 nations met in 1975 in Helsinki, Finland, to set a course for lessening East-West tensions by promoting human rights and reducing military friction. Since then, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has pressed to expand the role of the organization, known by its initials as CSCE, and hold a summit this year. The Western nations have agreed to attend a summit in Paris, but only if negotiators for NATO and the Warsaw Pact strike a deal to slash troops, tanks and other non-nuclear forces in Europe. They are trying to get an accord by the fall. To prepare for the CSCE summit, Baker offered to host a meeting of all 35 foreign ministers in New York during the opening session of the U.N. General Assembly in late September. Woerner said the NATO allies want preparations for the CSCE summit to begin in Vienna in July. NATO's defense ministers will meet next week outside Calgary, Canada, to discuss their nuclear strategy. They will gather again in late May in Brussels for further talks about military operations. In early June, the foreign ministers hold a twice-yearly meeting in Turnberry, Scotland.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Want Job-Discrimination Bill _ But Not for Themselves
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers are pushing for faster action on a bill to combat job discrimination but are making clear the measure won't apply to what one congressman calls ``the last plantation'' _ Capitol Hill itself. The House Education and Labor Committee voted 21-9 on Thursday against applying provisions of the civil rights bill to congressional staffers, who have long been exempted from the fair hiring measures enacted by their bosses. ``Some say the last plantation is here on Capitol Hill,'' said Rep. Charles Hayes, D-Ill., who nevertheless voted with the majority against extending the bill to cover House employees. The bill would overturn six Supreme Court decisions last year that brought strong protests from civil rights forces. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to fair hiring measures that make it easier for plaintiffs to win discrimination lawsuits against employers. Rep. Steve Bartlett, R-Texas, offered the amendment to extend the measure to House employees. Supporters were mainly Republicans who are critical of the overall bill, while Democrats who support the bill opposed Bartlett's plan. Bartlett offered his measure as Hayes and other lawmakers called for faster action on the bill. Chairman Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., is hoping for final action by the Education and Labor panel on Tuesday. The bill then goes to the House Judiciary Committee. Members of Congress long have been jealous guardians of their own patronage powers, and efforts to establish job protection for Capitol Hill aides generally have been scrapped with little delay. Weakening this traditional system could make the bill less palatable to some lawmakers, and Rep. William Clay, D-Mo., suggested that since Bartlett is an outspoken foe of the measure he might have offered his plan for ``mischievous'' reasons. ``I think it's a question of motivation,'' Clay said. ``I doubt it's the gentleman's intention to modify the bill to the point where he will cast a vote for it ... If he were sincere, he would include the Senate in this as well.'' Rep. William F. Goodling, R-Pa., the panel's ranking Republican, immediately called on Clay to have his words stricken from the record, saying questioning another lawmaker's motives violated a House rule. ``I don't think I want to sit in a situation where we are questioning each other's motives,'' he said. Clay initially refused to back down, but within a few minutes he asked to have his words stricken. Rep. Craig Washington, D-Texas, praised the idea of anti-discrimination safeguards for House employees. But he said it would be wiser to do so with separate legislation that would be free of the ``frailties'' of current law. On the roll call, both Washington and Goodling responded, ``Present.'' Rep. Harris Fawell, R-Ill., told the lawmakers, however, that the same tough penalties in current law that affect employers should also apply to congressmen who discriminate. ``We ought to be subjected individually to multimillion-dollar lawsuits too,'' Fawell declared.

DOC.HEAD: European Balance Of Power Also In Spotlight In Unity Talks
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: German unity won't be the only thing on the minds of the four World War II victors when they sit down Saturday for reunification talks. As in Potsdam in 1945 and Paris in 1919, the European balance of power will be very much at issue. As in those two watershed years, developments in Germany once again are the reason. Foreign ministers of the Soviet Union, the United States, France and Britain will sit with counterparts from both Germanys in a first attempt to iron out the complex strategic problems posed by ending Germany's 41-year-old division. Saturday's round at the West German Foreign Ministry will likely be the first of many. German unification is the ostensible theme of talks, dubbed ``two-plus-four'' because of the two Germanys and four Allies. However, the stakes involve all of Europe. NATO insists it still has an important role in Europe and wants a united Germany as a member. But the Soviets are worried about the implications of losing East Germany as their most important military ally, especially since their influence across Eastern Europe is rapidly waning. James A. Baker III, the U.S. secretary of state, said this week the Soviets should not have a say in whether a united Germany belongs to the Western military alliance. But Baker said he will listen to the views of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze when the two meet in Bonn for the two-plus-four talks. ``There will be, indeed, a very full and complete discussion of that issue, because that is one of the foremost issues right now that separate the alliance from the position of the Soviet Union,'' Baker said. The United States and West Germany have offered a solution. A united Germany would belong to NATO. But Soviet troops would remain temporarily on East German soil, while NATO troops keep out of that territory. Moscow has rejected that idea, suggesting a compromise that the West rebuffed: making a united Germany a member of both the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact and NATO until alternative security structures can be set up within Europe. Western diplomats worry the Soviets will try to widen the agenda of the two-plus-four talks to include disarmament matters and to embrace Moscow's hopes of setting up brand-new security structures within Europe. Broadening the agenda could slow the unification process. Both West Germany and the United States have tried to allay Soviet worries about unification. Washington said Thursday it had scrapped plans to modernize short-range nuclear missiles based in West Germany. West Germany has said the Soviet Union's security interests will be guaranteed. It seems to be offering the Soviets economic incentives to make up for the loss of East Germany as their biggest trading partner. Conference participants hope to defuse widespread concerns in Europe that a stronger Germany could again pose a threat to countries overrun during the two world wars. The six nations have already agreed to invite Poland to the talks when its western border is discussed. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl earlier this year caused a furor by refusing to guarantee a united Germany would not try to reclaim land ceded to Poland after World War II. Kohl has since reversed himself, but Poland will still be taking part in the talks at some point to press home its concerns. After both world wars, Germany was at the center of international talks that helped shape the future of Europe. In July 1945, the leaders of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union met in Potsdam, now in East Germany, and carved up vanquished Germany. In January 1919, 27 nations gathered in Paris to try to make sure Germany would never again threaten Europe after the carnage of World War I. The result was the Treaty of Versailles, which exacted huge reparations from Germany and aggravated German bitterness that helped Adolf Hitler rise to power. The West Germans want speedy results from the new talks, especially now that the two Germanys have agreed to merge their two economies by July 2. They say they would to finish the talks by fall to make way for all-German elections and full unification next year.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Urges Thornburgh to Revamp `Hate Crimes' Hotline
DOC.TEXT: The Senate sponsor of a law to curb ``hate crimes'' against minority groups is calling on the Justice Department to expand a newly established hotline to include all victims of unlawful acts of bigotry. ``I firmly believe that the hotline should be open to all those victimized by hate and prejudice,'' Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said Thursday in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. He sent his letter as a spokesman for the Justice Department's community relations service, which operates the hotline, confirmed that it does not record information concerning crimes involving the victim's sexual orientation. Spokesman Daryl Borgquist, said, however, that the hotline has not turned away calls from victims of crimes linked to their religious affiliation. ``I have heard that people who have been victimized because of their sexual orientation or religion have already been told that the hotline cannot assist them,'' Simon told Thornburgh. He said he was troubled by the report and urged Thornburgh to extend the hotline to handle all of the types of cases that would be covered under the hate crimes measure signed into law by President Bush on April 23. The hotline was not part of the legislation; establishing it was an administration initiative. Under the law, the government must compile statistics on crimes of bigotry and publish them along with the annual Uniform Crime Reports. Borgquist said the hotline would not accept information from homosexuals who were victims of hate crimes because the 1964 Civil Rights Act that created the community relations service set its target as problems related to ``race, color or national origin.'' Sexual preference was not included in the ``mandate'' and thus the service could not act in the case of hate crimes against them, he said, recommending that victimized homosexuals notify the FBI. An operator who answered the hotline number when it was called by The Associated Press on Thursday said it did not accept information about hate crimes based on either sexual preference or religious affiliation. Asked if the hotline would accept information about crimes that represented clear acts of anti-Semitism, she said that such matters would not fall within the limits. ``It may be that the operator who told you that didn't have as much training as somebody else,'' Borgquist said. He said the hotline was being operated on Thursday by employees of the service's immigration and refugee office and that they had received less training than those who answered the phones on other days. A spokesman for the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, which notified news organizations of the practice, criticized the Justice Department for the decision. ``Its an outrage,'' Robert Bray said. ``It amounts to the revictimization of gay people.'' Bray said his organization had also contacted the offices of Reps. Gerry Studds and Barney Frank, D-Mass., two openly homosexual members of Congress, to obtain help in changing the policy.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Invoked Fifth Amendment, Documents Show
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when asked whether he had used drugs in the previous five years, according to court papers. Barry, facing a June 4 trial on cocaine possession and perjury charges, invoked his constitutional right in a letter a year ago to the U.S. attorney's office. The letter followed two appearances by Barry before a federal grand jury on Jan. 19 and Jan. 24, 1989. ``I have been advised by my attorney ... of your desire to pose a further question to me'' on ``whether I have used within the past five years any illegal drug,'' said Barry's Jan. 25, 1989, letter. ``On advice of counsel, I elect to assert my Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination,'' said the mayor. The government released Barry's letter Thursday in opposing the mayor's motion to suppress Barry's earlier grand jury testimony. That testimony led to three felony perjury charges, and the mayor also is accused of five misdemeanor counts of possessing cocaine. In his grand jury testimony, Barry asserted that he wasn't aware of drug use by an associate, Charles Lewis, and that the mayor and Lewis hadn't given each other cocaine. Lewis now is the government's chief witness against Barry. A conviction on any of the perjury charges would bar Barry from holding office or seeking re-election. Neither Barry nor his spokeswoman, Lurma Rackley, were immediately available to comment on the documents. Meanwhile, the District of Columbia Democratic party defeated a resolution Thursday night that would have asked Barry not to seek re-election. The proposal, voted down 29-23, declared Barry's leadership ``in question'' and requested that he ``announce that he will not seek renomination in 1990.'' Barry has not publicly disclosed his future political plans. However, he has made numerous campaign-style appearance since his return to the city from seven weeks of treatment for substance abuse. Sources close to the mayor said Barry intends to run for a fourth four-year term. In a letter to Williams, Barry called the resolution ``undemocratic'' because it ``undermines the right of the voter to decide.'' Barry also said the party's action ``would have little influence on my decision about my political future.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Democrats, Republicans Offer Contrasting Plans
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democrats and Republicans are laying out sharply contrasting proposals to change the way their campaigns are financed, with each party seeking to protect the current advantages it enjoys. Democrats on Thursday unveiled a package to slash in half the amount of money candidates now raise and spend on campaigns by imposing ceilings, with a lure that the government would pick up part of the remaining tab. Republicans, claiming it is the source of money rather than the amount spent that is corrupting politics, had announced a proposal Tuesday to outlaw political action committees and effectively prohibit unions from underwriting campaigns. Both parties embrace proposals to encourage candidates to rely more on small contributions of less than $100, $250 or $1,000 from in-state donors. However, critics said the plans leave large loopholes for raising so-called special interest money through national and state party organizations. The Democratic plan, for example, would outlaw PAC contributions to individual candidates but still allow the two national parties to raise up to $5 million from such sources and their House and Senate campaign committees even more. And state party organizations under both plans could still raise large amounts _ via direct-mail drives and from wealthy individuals in case of the GOP and, for Democrats, through those sources plus unions and PACs. ``Does it need to be improved? Of course it does,'' said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, a group that advocates total federal financing of campaigns. ``But to me, it's a giant step.'' Under the Democratic plan, about 70 percent of a federal candidate's general election campaign expenses _ but none of the costs for primary races _ would be paid by the government from money raised through a proposed $3 checkoff on income tax returns. Through the checkoff, taxpayers could voluntarily designate $3 of the refunds they are due, or add $3 to the taxes they owe, for a special government account to finance congressional races. Since the middle 1970s, tax returns have included a checkoff that allows taxpayers to designate $1 of their owed taxes to a fund for financing presidential campaigns. The new ceilings that Democrats are proposing on Senate campaigns are about 20 percent higher than in a previous Democratic package reported out of the Senate Rules Committee two months ago. Covering both primary and general elections, the new limits would range from $1.9 million in small states to slightly more than $10 million in the most populous, California. ``We're not going to get hung up on the percentages or the specific amounts,'' said Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., the chief author of the package. ``Everything is negotiable from our point of view, except that we have to have some limit on overall spending.'' Republicans reacted with disdain to the proposal. Sen. Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the party's point man on the issue, said the combination of public financing and campaign ceilings would sharply curtail the GOP's ability to regain control of Congress. ``Including House races, taxpayers would pick up a $400 million tab each election cycle for an incumbent's protection bill,'' McConnell said. ``Unless you're a sitting governor or a movie star, no challenger is ever again going to win a political race.'' Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., said Democrats embraced a bigger role for public financing after rejecting it earlier out of a sense of vulnerability in the wake of recent campaign financing scandals. The biggest of those is the ``Keating Five'' senators under investigation by an ethics panel for interceding with savings and loan regulators on behalf of Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating Jr. after accepting $1.3 million in campaign gifts from him. ``What we're all willing to trade off is the vulnerability of having a well-funded legitimate opponent _ because with public financing, that's a guarantee _ versus the vulnerability of having our reputations ruined and not being able to defend ourselves,'' Biden said.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Denies Cuban Claim of Potential US Military Attack
DOC.TEXT: The State Department calls ``totally false'' Cuba's claim that the United States is planning a large-scale military attack against the Caribbean nation. A dispatch from the Cuban government news agency Prensa Latina from Havana, monitored in Mexico City on Thursday, said Cuba had mounted large-scale defense measures to repel any U.S. intrusion into Cuban territory from the U.S. naval base at Guantanamo on Cuba's southeastern coast. An effort called ``Operation Shield,'' comprising a squad of armored cars, a squadron of Soviet-made T-54 tanks, artillery units and an anti-aircraft unit composed of women, had been deployed in ``an energetic movement of defense forces,'' the report said. Reports reaching Washington said Cuba also called up military reserves, cancelled leaves and launched MiG-29 jet fighters in response to the opening of U.S. military exercises off the eastern end of the island near Guantanamo. The State Department acknowledged that military exercises are under way, but described them as ``routine.'' Cuban claims about the possibility of a U.S. attack on Cuba are ``totally false and appear designed to muster anti-American sentiment among the Cuban people and to draw attention away from Cuba's very real internal difficulties,'' said State press officer Adam Shub. Shub said the exercises being carried out are called Ocean Venture, Global Shield and Defex. Ocean Venture is a combined exercise involving the Army, Navy, Marines and Coast Guard and is a routine readiness drill, he said. Global Shield is another readiness training exercise coordinated through SAC. Defex is a routine defense reinforcement-evacuation exercise. No additional details were available, but Cuban accounts have said that Defex involves the evacuation of civilian personnel from the Guantanamo Base. Prensa Latina quoted the Cuban Army as saying there were 18 U.S. ships at Guantanamo instead of the usual six, including two tank-landing transports. The dispatch said reporters watching through the base fence could see C-130 transports unloading equipment. Pentagon sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said some exercises began last week and would last two weeks, involving seven warships, Marines, Air Force and Army units, elements of the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C., and support elements from Guantanamo. The U.S. Navy has operated from that base for several decades despite objections from the Cuban government that the American presence is illegal. Every ship in the Atlantic Fleet is required to undergo refresher training at the base every three years or after a major overhaul. Cuban officials have been expressing concern for the past several days about the exercises.

DOC.HEAD: President Cristiani Predicts Direct Talks With Rebels In Days
DOC.TEXT: President Alfredo Cristiani said the government and leftist rebels, communicating through a U.N. mediator, will likely hold direct talks in the coming days. Cristiani said Thursday that Alvaro de Soto, special envoy of U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez del Cuellar, was working with the two sides to draft an agenda. The Salvadoran president was to meet again today with de Soto, who is acting under an agreement the two sides reached in Geneva in April in efforts to end a 10-year-old civil war that has killed an estimated 72,000 people. ``We believe that we can advance rapidly,'' he told reporters at the presidential offices. ``Once the direct talks are begun this will become more dynamic.'' He predicted that face-to-face meetings could begin in a week and a half. De Soto, who arrived Wednesday, met with Cristiani and political leaders to discuss their positions. In a proposal the mediator gave Cristiani on Wednesday, the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front guerrillas offered to lay down their weapons and take part in upcoming legislative and municipal elections if the military gets rid of some of its far right officers and undertakes political reforms. Cristiani warned that if the United States cuts military aid to El Salvador, he could be forced to seek assistance elsewhere to make up for the deficit. But he did not say where. He said another alternative in the event of an aid cut would be a reduction in spending for social programs, which would hurt the poor. He did not give any details. A new aid package for El Salvador is being considered on Capitol Hill. The Bush administration wants $375 million for El Salvador next year, including $90 million in military aid. However, the United States has indicated that continued aid will be linked to El Salvador's response to the slaying of six Jesuit priests at Central American University in November. A colonel, three lieutenants and five soldiers were charged in the killings. Cristiani admits the killings were carried out by the miltary, but critics complain the investigation should reach higher. The State Department has said Secretary of State James A. Baker III would send a congressional report criticizing the Salvadoran probe of the killings to Cristiani and make it clear that ``the resolution of this case will be one important element in determining the nature of future U.S. assistance.'' El Salvador said Tuesday it hopes the case will go to trial within 90 days. In addition to pressuring the Salvadoran government to make progress in investigating the Jesuit deaths, the United States has called for good-faith negotiation with the rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Acting Head of Russian Church Chosen to Replace Deceased Patriarch
DOC.TEXT: Elders have chosen the patriarch of the Ukraine to head the Russian Orthodox Church until a permanent replacement is decided for the late Patriarch Pimen, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported today. The church's Holy Synod early today chose as Pimen's acting successor Metropolitan Filaret of the Ukraine. Radio Moscow reported today that a permanent patriarch will be selected within six months by the Local Council, made up of all metropolitans, archbishops and bishops, as well as representatives of the clergy and laity. Pimen, a pious monk who presided over the church during years of repression and a recent reawakening, died Thursday at the age of 79 after a long illness. Pimen had served as patriarch of the church since 1971, leading tens of millions of believers under a government that has been officially atheist since the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917. Critics said Pimen was too much under control of the Kremlin, but his supporters said that he preserved the spiritual integrity of the church in hard times. The new patriarch will face the challenge of rebuilding the church under relaxed political controls. The Soviet parliament sent a telegram, signed by Vice President Anatoly Lukyanov, expressing condolences to the church over the loss of Pimen, who over the years had actively backed Kremlin ``peace initiatives'' and arms control proposals. Radio Moscow said a funeral was planned Sunday at the Monastery of the Trinity and St. Sergius in Zagorsk, 45 miles from Moscow. Pimen is likely to be remembered as a pious monk who complied with the will of Soviet authorities before relious tolerance increased under Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who took power in 1985. Pimen appeared to be a devout clergyman who could change with the times, becoming a cleric during a period of harsh repression under Josef Stalin, and rising through the church during the anti-clerical campaigns of Nikita S. Khrushchev and the less oppressive rule of Leonid I. Brezhnev. ``He followed the Khrushchev line on closing churches and never contradicted any party orders,'' said Alexander Ogorodnikov, a religious dissident released from prison under Gorbachev. ``But at the same time, he was trying all the time to keep Russian church from declining to heresy,'' said Ogorodnikov.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Chief, Vegetarians Search Scriptures in Dietary Row
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with comment from speaker of House, letter to Times on cattle's stomachs; pickup graf 8 pvs `For its...'
DOC.TEXT: British carnivores and vegetarians are chewing over the scriptures in an argument about whose diet enjoys divine sanction. Britain's agriculture minister, John Selwyn Gummer, started the flap by declaring that ``the Bible tells us that we are masters of the fowls of the air and the beasts of the field, and we very properly eat them.'' ``If the Almighty had wanted us to have three stomachs (like cattle), I am sure he could have arranged it, but he chose to make us omnivores instead,'' Gummer told cheering members of the International Meat Trade Association, who were gathered Tuesday at Butchers Hall in London. Gummer, a member of the Church of England's governing General Synod, declared himself fed up with ``deeply undemocratic food faddists'' who make a religion of their diets. The minister's comment provoked a gristly reaction in many quarters _ starting with his grasp of biology. ``For many years I have understood that cattle have four stomachs,'' Edward Bullen of St. Albans said in a letter in Friday's editions of The Times. Joyce d'Silva, an official for Compassion in World Farming, said Thursday that Gummer had ignored Genesis 1:29 ``in which that same Almighty tells man to eat `every herb-bearing seed ... and every tree, in which is the fruit of a tree yielding seed; to you it shall be for meat.''' Gummer ``was selectively using the Bible. I thought if he could do it, then we could do it,'' she said. Her organization advocates humane slaughter of animals and the abolition of intensive ``factory farming.'' Bernard Wetherill, the speaker of the House of Commons, jumped into the fray Thursday by taking issue with Gummer. He cited Romans 14:19-21 that says, ``For meat destroy not the work of God.'' For its part, the Vegetarian Society found inspiring reading in Isaiah _ and none more vivid than the third verse of chapter 66: ``He that killeth an ox is as if he slew a man; he that sacrificeth a lamb, as if he cut off a dog's neck; he that offereth an oblation, as if he offered swine's blood.'' Linda Farmer, assistant to the society's manager, also pointed approvingly to the first chapter of Daniel, in which the prophet ``purposed in his heart that he would not defile himself with the portion of the king's meat.'' After 10 days, it was recorded, Daniel and his companions ``appeared fairer and fatter in flesh than all the children which did eat the portion of the king's meat.'' A recent poll by The Realeat Co., makers of the ``VegeBurger,'' indicated that 10 percent of those surveyed said they were avoiding red meat or eating no meat at all. ``I want to see more articles about the sensible 90 percent who are still eating meat,'' Gummer said. Tony Gordon, executive director of the International Meat Trade Association, had no Bible verses to offer. He said Gummer's speech ``was all fairly light-hearted.'' ``But of course the vegetarians, some of them, have reacted with horror _ perhaps with less sense of humor than most meat eaters would have,'' Gordon said Thursday. The meat industry is especially unhappy with the Humberside local council in northeastern England, which has banned beef from school lunches because of concern about ``mad cow disease.'' The disease, which attacks the brain, has resulted in the destruction of more than 11,000 cattle, but the government says there is no significant danger to humans. Jane Brophy, a research officer at the Vegetarian Society, offered several biblical citations in support of her diet. However, Matthew 3:4, which tells of John the Baptist eating locusts and wild honey, was not among them. ``No,'' she said with a laugh, ``we're not recommending that.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Crack Down on Refugee Camp in Hong Kong, Two Injured
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 police firing tear gas raided a detention camp for Vietnamese refugees today and hauled away about 200 boat people after a week of escape attempts at the overcrowded compound. Several hundred detainees put up barricades of iron rods and bedding to block police. Authorities in riot gear fired more than 100 canisters of tear gas after some boat people attempted to attack with homemade weapons, said police spokesman E'man Kwong. Two police were the only people injured, he said. The crackdown came a day after the top U.N. refugee relief official in Hong Kong said that Whitehead camp has turned into an out-of-control ``monster.'' The official, Robert Van Leeuwen, said overcrowding, combined with the despair of many detainees who fear they may never resettle, had helped create the problem. About 1,200 police backed by armored vehicles moved in about 5 a.m. today. The helmeted police joined about 300 other security officers in a search for homemade weapons, which typically consist of spears, knives and axes made of iron bars. They took away the estimated 200 Vietnamese as suspected troublemakers. Those refugees were transferred to other detention centers in this British colony for investigation by security officials, authorities said. In addition, 10 Vietnamese were arrested as police searched Whitehead dormitories for the homemade weapons. ``The main purpose (is) to restore law and order in the camp and boost morale,'' Kwong said. He said it took about an hour to secure the camp and searched continued throughout the day. The search uncovered about 2,500 weapons, Kwong said. The camp has been housing more than 22,000 boat people. Early Thursday, police fired tear gas into Whitehead to stop an escape attempt by about 50 Vietnamese. On Sunday, about 100 boat people cut through fences and escaped from the camp. About 55,000 Vietnamese boat people are in Hong Kong camps awaiting resettlement overseas or repatriation to Vietnam. Under a policy adopted in 1988 to stem the tide of arriving Vietnamese, refugees do not qualify for resettlement if they fled their homeland for economic reasons. The vast majority of detainees affected by the new law are expected to face forced repatriation to their Communist homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Inquirer Loses $34 Million Libel Judgment
DOC.TEXT: A former city prosecutor won a record $34 million libel suit against The Philadelphia Inquirer in a case that stemmed from newspaper stories written 17 years ago. A Common Pleas Court jury on Thursday awarded $2.5 million in compensatory damages and $31.5 million in punitive damages to lawyer Richard A. Sprague, a former first assistant district attorney. The decision was the largest award ever against the news media, surpassing the $28 million won last month by a heart surgeon against a San Antonio television station. The judgment was more than seven times the $4.5 million verdict that the Inquirer had successfully appealed from the first trial in the case. Sprague sued in 1983 over articles dating to 1973 that questioned his actions and decisions as a prosecutor. His attorney, James E. Beasley, said the jury's verdict sent a message to investigative reporters ``not to destroy somebody's reputation.'' Inquirer executive editor and president Eugene L. Roberts Jr. said the newspaper would appeal the decision. The award amounts to about one-third of the newspaper's net worth, said the Inquirer's attorney, Samuel E. Klein. Roberts said the newspaper would be able to stay in business if the judgment stands, ``but we would be crippled.'' The Inquirer has won 17 Pulitzer Prizes in the last 16 years, many of them stemming from investigative stories. A libel case observer said Thursday the huge award stood little chance of surviving an appeals challenge. ``Based on the trends, one would have to assume that this award cannot stand up on appeal,'' said Henry Kaufman, general counsel of the Libel Defense Resource Center in New York. Kaufman said only two libel judgments of more than $1 million have been affirmed on appeal. ``I am a very strong advocate of First Amendment rights,'' said Beasley. ``What I don't tolerate and I don't think society should tolerate is the use of investigative reporters or the power of the press for a personal vendetta. And that is what developed here.'' He said Greg Walter, one of the reporters involved in the stories, had threatened to ``get and destroy'' Sprague, who had prosecuted Walter in 1972 for taping a conversation without the other person's knowledge. Walter has since died. Roberts, the newspaper's president, complained that the judge eliminated 13 witnesses who would have helped the paper's case, and rejected an investigative report by a former state attorney general that supported the Inquirer story. ``I am confident that however long it takes, the Inquirer will prevail,'' said Roberts. ``Most of our case never got to the jury.'' Judge Charles P. Mirarchi Jr. Mirarchi said Sprague required a ``preponderance of evidence'' to prove statements defamed him and had to meet the tougher standard of ``clear and convincing evidence'' to prove falsity, actual malice and damages. Sprague sued over articles that he said implied he was involved in an illegal wiretapping incident, an allegation he denied, and questioned his role in a homicide case involving a son of a friend, former state police commissioner Rocco Urella. An eight-week trial resulted in the verdict for Sprague in 1983. The state Supreme Court in June 1988 ordered a new trial, declaring reporters have an absolute right to invoke the state Shield Law in refusing to identify confidential sources during legal proceedings. In the original trial, Judge Charles A. Lord ruled the law did not apply in the case and excluded all testimony about information from unidentified sources.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Boomlet Taxes Little School
DOC.TEXT: Eight years ago this village of 250 families in the foothills of the Berkshires had its own baby boom when 29 women gave birth, two to twins, and three others adopted children. Now the youngsters are in school and townsfolk are struggling to come up with the money to educate them. ``It was the first time in the history of the town that goes back over 200 years that there had been so many babies,'' said Karen Barshefski, the town's Parent Teacher Organization president, who was one of the new mothers in 1982. ``Yankee Magazine even came out and took our picture.'' ``We have a tax (limit) override vote on Saturday and I can't even think about what we will do if that doesn't pass,'' said Selectwoman Julia Sharron, who doubles as town librarian. School costs, up more than $130,000 over last year, make up nearly one-third of the town's $1.7 million proposed budget, she said, and the state has cut back on its help to schools and towns as its own money problems have worsened. Mrs. Barshefski has spent the past several Saturdays with other mothers campaigning for the override, but she's pessimistic about the outcome. ``We rely a lot on volunteer help like most small towns and we have cut back as much as we can, even when it comes to keeping up the roads,'' Mrs. Sharron said. ``But the kids have to get an education. The most important thing anyone can give a child is education.'' The baby boom has overwhelmed the community's five-room school, with 92 students in kindergarten through fourth grade. Last year residents remodeled the basement and moved the kindergarten and the library there to make room for a second first-grade class. And as Worthington's enrollment zoomed _ by nearly one-third in the last five years _ it was also called on to finance a larger share of the regional school district's budget that encompasses seven towns, said Duane Wynan, assistant superintendent. The regional school system's costs are split among the towns, based on the number of schoolchildren who attend from each town. Worthington's baby boom came just about the same time the state's voters approved Proposition 2{, which limits communities to raising tax levies 2.5 percent annually until they reach 2.5 percent of assessed valuation. And like many small towns with small budgets, Worthington soon felt the pinch. Over the past several years, its 1,200 residents have approved three overrides of the tax limit. Saturday's vote would add $12.50 to the $89.60 bill of a homeowner with a house assessed at $100,000.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix byline indentation
The Pope is Big Business in Mexico As Visit Nears
DOC.TEXT: The church doesn't like it but never mind, street vendors are everywhere in the capital hawking T-shirts and medallions, comic books and posters for the upcoming visit of Pope John Paul II. He arrives Sunday for an eight-day visit. The Roman Catholic Church had asked that Mexicans not commercialize the pope's second visit to this country, but the papal image is showing up on key rings and beachwear anyway. Salesmen blare recordings of hastily-written pope songs over portable tape players to advertise their wares. Vendors around the capital's Guadalupe Basilica, Mexico's holiest shrine where the pope will visit, are to be moved out today, officials said. On Mexico City's Reforma, one of two main streets bisecting the capital, a T-shirt vendor displays an item welcoming the pope between two others proclaiming in large type, ``I Got Drunk in Mexico.'' Cardinal Ernesto Corripio Ahumada, the head of the church in Mexico, says people are selling bogus tickets that supposedly admit the bearer to religious events where the pope will be. ``Not only the Vatican but the Episcopal Conference of Mexico has insisted that this visit not be commercialized, Corripio said. Newspaper ads offer gold and silver coins with the pope's image, which also can be found on porcelain plates, plastic bottles and candy. ``Nearly a million street vendors and a similar number of establishments and commercial centers have transformed in recent weeks faith into fanaticism,'' said the government newspaper El Nacional. The pope trade also is brisk in the provinces he will visit.

DOC.HEAD: Three Former Lawmen Convicted of Murding Black Inmate
DOC.TEXT: TYLER, Texas _ Prosecutors said they would seek life prison terms for three white former guards convicted of beating a black prisoner to death on Christmas Day 1987. An all-white jury was to begin hearing testimony today to decide sentencing for former Hemphill Police Chief Thomas Ladner and former Sabine County sheriff's deputies Billy Ray Horton and James M. Hyden. The same jury found the men guilty Thursday of murdering Loyal Garner Jr. on Dec. 27, 1987. The three men face terms of 5 to 99 years. In Texas, the sentencing phase of a trial can take days. ``There's no question that justice was done in this case for Loyal Garner Jr. and for his family,'' Smith County District Attorney Jack Skeen said. Garner, a 34-year-old father of six from Florien, La., died of severe head injuries after his arrest on drunken driving charges two days earlier. Garner's widow, Corrinne Garner, cried quietly as the verdict was announced. His mother, Sarah Garner said, ``I'm glad. I hope it's over.'' The verdict caught many by surprise. The three were acquitted in July 1988 of having violated Garner's civil rights. While that case was pending, the men were indicted on murder charges. Defense attorneys tried to stop the murder trial, contending the charges constituted double jeopardy. A federal judge last month ordered the trial to proceed. Defense attorneys promised an appeal. ``It's double jeopardy. They tried them exactly twice for exactly the same crime,'' said John Seale, Ladner's attorney. Former U.S. Attorney John Hannah, who was special prosecutor in the civil rights trial, said he was not surprised by the verdict. ``I thought with a fair judge and an impartial jury and a competent prosecutor that it was a foregone conclusion,'' he said. ``There wasn't a day come that I didn't look up to heaven and talk to God about it,'' Garner's mother said.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Reed Reportedly Beaten During Escape Attempt
DOC.TEXT: During 42 months of captivity, Frank Reed endured the psychological pain of being told his mother had died and the physical pain of being badly beaten when he tried to escape, his daughter said. It was only after he was released Monday that Reed learned his mother was still alive, his daughter, Marilyn Langston, said Thursday. The wounds from his beating still ache, she said. Reed, 57, was scheduled to arrive at Andrews Air Force Base today and spend a few more days undergoing tests at a military hospital before continuing home to Massachusetts, a U.S. State Department spokeswoman said. In a telephone conversation early Wednesday, Reed said his Islamic captors told him his mother, 91-year-old Leota Sprague, had died, Langston said said. ``He was told she had passed away,'' Langston said in a telephone interview from her home in Malden. ``He didn't know she was alive until he was released. We were able to tell him she was very much alive.'' Reed's mother shares an apartment in Malden with Reed's wife, Fahima, and the couple's 9-year-old son, Tarek. Langston said she would fly to Washington today to meet her father. In a telephone call early Wednesday, Reed told Langston he had tried to escape his captors but was quickly caught and badly beaten for the attempt. ``He told me he'd been beaten. He did try to escape and they'd beaten him very badly,'' Langston said. On Wednesday evening, Langston tied a yellow ribbon around a tree in front of her home. On the house she hung a large banner reading, ``Free at last, Frank Reed, April 30, 1990.'' She said Reed was denied medical attention for his wounds and is still recovering from them. Reed said he had tried to escape alone, but it was unclear when during his captivity he had made the attempt, she said. Langston said she had previously heard of the beating in news reports from the French hostages who had been released in 1988. Reed expressed concern about what he would do following his return to the United States, she said. ``He's concerned about what will happen now,'' she said. ``He feels his school is gone, and he's wondering about the future.'' The founder of a private school in Beirut, Reed was abducted on Sept. 9, 1986 and spent 3{ years in captivity. He was the second American hostage to be freed in nine days. Robert Polhill, freed April 22, went through the same battery of medical tests and questioning last week that Reed is currently undergoing. In his first public statement since his release Monday, Reed told reporters outside a military hospital in West Germany that he had believed he was the last hostage to be released and he was angry that other Americans are still being held. Reed, a native of Malden, said he spent several years in captivity with hostages Terry Anderson, Thomas Sutherland, John McCarthy and Brian Keenan. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was abducted on a Beirut street in March 1985. He is the longest-held hostage.

DOC.HEAD: Twister in Texas; Rain Over South-Central United States.
DOC.TEXT: A tornado touched down in northeast Texas early today and thunderstorms threatened more flooding in Texas and Oklahoma. Frost warnings were posted overnight for Vermont and northeastern New York. Frost and freezing temperatures were also expected over lower Michigan. The National Weather Service forecast snow over the mountains of New Mexico, the San Luis Valley and Sangre de Cristo ranges in Colorado and the White Mountains in Arizona. More than 6 inches of snow covered the higher elevations Wednesday in New Mexico. Five inches fell at Alpine, Ariz., and 10 inches at Beaverhead, Ariz. A twister early today damaged several houses and injured six people in Paris, Texas. Thunderstorms hit the water-logged Dallas-Fort Worth area. ``Not since 1922 have we had rain like this,'' said forecaster Ed Delgado in Fort Worth. ``We have seen some lakes rise in water level by four feet overnight, and there is more rain in the forecast.'' Much of north-central Texas received 2 to 3 inches of rain on Wednesday, and flash flood warnings were posted over a large portion of the state. Flood watches were posted overnight for portions of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri and Tennessee. Oklahoma City received drizzle today, and there was rain in St. Louis. Almost 5 inches of rain fell Wednesday near Heavener, Okla. The high for nation Wednesday was 100 at Fort Stewart, Ga. DOC.HEAD: Calls For Patriotism On Anniversary Of Democracy Movement
DOC.TEXT: China today marked the 71st anniversary of its first democracy movement, criticizing last May's pro-reform rallies and appealing to young people to devote themselves to communism. The Communist Youth League and other official groups organized functions to commemorate the ``May 4th Movement,'' but there were no reports of unauthorized student activities. Last year, on the 70th anniversary of the movement, about 100,000 students and supporters surged into Tiananmen Square for a peaceful rally seeking greater freedom, an end to official corruption and a free press. The demonstration was one of the high points of the seven-week democracy movement that ended on June 4 when the military stormed Beijing and seized Tiananmen from the students who had occupied it. The government has since suppressed any further student unrest through a harsh campaign of ideological education and intimidation. The party's official People's Daily, in a front-page editorial today, said the message to be learned from the ``May 4th Movement'' is that ``the spirit of patriotism is to be devoted to the cause of socialism and the socialist modernization of the motherland.'' In an indirect reference to last year's student demands for rapid democratic reform, it noted that ``in a greenhouse, you cannot grow trees which reach to the sky.'' Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin, in a speech to about 3,000 invited youths Thursday, also stressed that last year's student movement was different from that of May 4, 1919. In 1919, several thousand college students gathered at Tiananmen Gate to demand democracy and modernization. Their protest sparked an intellectual movement that included the creation and expansion of the Communist Party. Jiang said the 1919 campaign was a ``great anti-imperialism and anti-feudalism movement'' whereas student activists in 1989 ``bound themselves with foreign hostile forces and conducted activities harmful to the motherland.'' Officially organized events today included the start of a youth festival and Communist Youth League-sponsored entertainment at a park adjacent to the Forbidden City. Invited youths watched fashion shows, hair styling, singing and band performances. There were booths selling clothing and food and a hall for dancing. Tiananmen Square was open to the public, but large numbers of police patrolled the square and its environs. What became known as the May 4th Movement began as a protest of the Versailles Treaty that ended World War I. China's warlord government agreed to treaty clauses that endorsed Japan's seizure of parts of China during the war. Although the treaty was the immediate spark that caused the protest, the main slogans of the students were democracy and science, by which they meant modernization. The government now is choosing to eliminate the democracy angle and stress the anti-imperialism and science aspects of the movement.

DOC.HEAD: Rain East Adds to Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered across broad sections of the eastern half of the nation today but much of the West was fair. Flooding continued Thursday in north-central Texas, which has recorded its wettest spring since 1922. Hundreds of people were forced from their homes in Texas, southern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. Among the spots reporting serious flooding were the Trinity River in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, the Sabine river in east Texas, the Blue River in southern Oklahoma and the Red River along the Texas-Oklahoma line. A flash flood watch was posted for all of Arkansas except the extreme southeast portions. The western part of the state had as much as 10 inches of rain in the past two days. West Tennessee also was under a flash flood watch for an area between the Mississippi River and the Tennessee River, which includes Memphis. Thunderstorms were widespread Thursday afternoon in eastern Texas and western Oklahoma. Thunderstorms also were scattered across Indiana and Kentucky. Snow moved out of Colorado but was falling in northwest Kansas. Rain and thunderstorms were scattered Thursday across east central Wyoming, large sections of Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma, eastern Texas and into the Deep South and Midwest. Rain also was scattered across the Northeast early today. Fair weather prevailed on the West Coast, in the desert Southwest and in the Northwest. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 98 degrees at two California locations, Borrego Springs and Palm Springs. DOC.HEAD: Parliament Elects Conservative Candidate Caramanlis
DOC.TEXT: Parliament today elected elder statesman Constantine Caramanlis as the fifth head of state since democracy was restored in 1974 after a military dictatorship. Caramanlis, 83, a six-time prime minister and former president, won 153 votes of the 299 cast. He needed a simple majority in the 300-member Parliament to be elected to a five-year term in the largely ceremonial post of president. In the first round of voting Monday, he fell short of the required 180 votes. Caramanlis returns to the post which he established and held from 1980 to 1985. He was backed chiefly by the governing conservative party's 150 deputies. The socialists and the Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress did not support Caramanlis, who founded the governing New Democracy party in 1974. Prime Minister Constantine Mitstotakis expressed satisfaction with Caramanlis's election. ``With the great respect he enjoys both at home and abroad, Caramanlis will help the country at this time of crisis,'' said Mitsotakis after the voting. The conservative government recently announced a series of economic austerity measures in a bid to cope with high inflation and rising deficits. Caramanlis was Greece's first prime minister after a 1967-74 military dictatorship, overseeing the return to democracy and establishing the presidency after holding a referendum that abolished the monarchy. He became the republic's third president in 1980, resigning in 1985 shortly after the socialist government at the time reneged on a promise to support his bid for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: Johnson & Johnson Heir Dead at Age 63
DOC.TEXT: Stage and screen producer Mary Lea Johnson Richards, who with her siblings contested the will of their father, Johnson & Johnson heir J. Seward Johnson, has died at age 63. Ms. Johnson died Thursday at Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh, where she recently underwent a liver transplant, hospital spokesman Frank Raczkiewicz said. Ms. Johnson, who used her maiden name, lived in New York. She and her husband, Martin Richards, formed The Producer Circle Co. in 1976 with Robert Fryer and James Cresson. The company's stage shows won 22 Tony Awards and a Pulitzer Prize and included ``Sweeney Todd,'' ``Crimes of the Heart,'' ``La Cage Aux Folles'' and ``Foxfire.'' Their films included ``The Boys From Brazil,'' ``The Shining,'' and ``Fort Apache, the Bronx.'' Ms. Johnson was born in New Brunswick, N.J., the eldest of six children of the heir to the pharmaceutical fortune. In a bitter, three-year court battle, she and her siblings contested the will in which their father left nearly his entire estate to his third wife, Polish-born Barbara Piasecka-Johnson. The children also claimed their father was not mentally competent when he signed the will in 1983, a few weeks before his death at age 87. J. Seward Johnson had said he cut his children out of his will ``not for any lack of affection'' but because he set up multimillion dollar trust funds for them in 1944. A day before the case was to go to a jury in 1986, the children agreed to a settlement that gave them a total $42.5 million, plus $20 million to the Harbor Branch Foundation, a Florida oceanographic institute founded by their father. Barbara Piasecka-Johnson got $300 million in the settlement. Piasecka-Johnson last year offered to invest $100 million in the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, where the Solidarity trade union was born. That deal has failed to move forward, however. Besides her husband, Mary Lea Johnson is survived by her siblings, J. Seward Johnson Jr., Elaine Wold, Diana Firestone, James Johnson and Jennifer Johnson Duke; six children, Eric, Seward, Roderick, Hillary, Alice and Quentin; and nine grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Trouble starts with a capital `T' and that rhymes with `C' and that stands for Coyote. As in Coyote Cafe. So when police chief Gene Shaw caught wind that the cafe was going to open this summer, the news rubbed him the wrong way. When the restaurant's owners applied for a liquor license, Shaw asked the New York State Liquor Authority not to grant one. A coyote is a ``varmint,'' he said. ``The name coyote is synonymous with trouble.'' Stephanie Kanellos, an owner of the cafe, said she was angered by the chief's action, but agreed to change the name to Cactus Cafe. Shaw withdrew his objection to the liquor license after that.

The Lawrence County Council is going to jail, but only for a visit. The three commissioners plan to try out a new $5 million county jail May 29. The jail is nearing completion in downtown Bedford. ``Since the council represents the voters of Lawrence County and is spending that kind of money I think we should make sure we are receiving ultimate value for that $5 million,'' said Council President Jack Cummings. The 80-cell jail also includes the sheriff's new offices and new county court facilities. Sheriff Jerry Ross said his wife, Charlotte, who is the jail chief matron, will get a chance to try out kitchen equipment when she prepares breakfast for the council. ``I think it's a good idea,'' the sheriff said. ``It will give the elected officials an idea of what it takes to operate that jail and maybe they will get an idea on how much help it's going to take and maybe we can find some of the bugs before we put the inmates in it.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Soccer Fans Riot After Uzbek Game is Canceled
DOC.TEXT: Soccer fans in a Central Asian city rioted when a game was canceled, looting and setting fire to scores of buildings, official media said today. At least 44 people were reported injured. The independent news service Post Factum claimed an intoxicated mob killed the director of the soccer stadium and burned the structure down in the violence Wednesday. But the other reports did not confirm that. However, the reports said the fans, many intoxicated, looted and set fires across Andizhan, a city in the Fergana Valley of eastern Uzbekistan. The reports could not be independently confirmed because communications with Andizhan were cut. The area is plagued with severe unemployment, with 80,000 jobless among the Andizhan region's population of 1.6 million. Last summer, more than 100 people were killed in ethnic clashes between Uzbeks and another Turkish ethnic group, the Meskhetians, in the nearby city of Fergana. The soccer rioters attacked the Andizhan regional Communist Party headquarters and the city prosecutor's office, as well as 125 other buildings, 79 stores and 36 homes, the official Tass news agency reported. They set fire to 13 stores, 46 workshops and dozens of homes. They also destroyed 18 institutions, including libraries, reported Pravda, the newspaper of the Communist Party. Interior Ministry troops restored order, the reports said. The violence began when 10,000 fans waiting in mid-afternoon heat were told a visiting team from the Uzbekistan republic's capital of Tashkent had failed to show up for a game, Pravda said. When officials announced the game was canceled, the crowd began to throw rocks and beat the chairman of the soccer club, the newspaper said. Fans set fire to two police cars and an automobile that was to be a door prize, Pravda said. The injured included 13 Interior Ministry troops, 10 policemen and 11 civilians, Tass said. In its report, Post Factum said the crowd, armed with automatic weapons, rampaged through neighborhoods of Russians, Armenians and Jews, leaving the Armenian quarter smoldering. The news service also quoted an unidentified member of the visiting team as saying the game was canceled not because the team failed to appear, but because the attacks were planned.

DOC.HEAD: Sanitation Show Boasts Spiffy New Garbage Trucks, Jewelry for Garbagemen
DOC.TEXT: At a gathering of garbagemen, models in cocktail dresses circled spiffy white garbage trucks, while tie-dyed salespeople hawked jewelry for sanitation workers. Last month's Earth Day has Americans excited about a mundane task _ throwing out the trash. And it was easy to see at Waste Expo '90 that garbage is not only chic, but good business. The annual convention of the National Solid Wastes Management Association, drew more than 10,000 people this week to the Georgia World Congress Center. They attended seminars like ``Women in Waste'' and ``Backyard Basics: How Composting Can Improve Your Bottom Line.'' They looked over the latest gee-gaws for their industry, from the Cram-A-Lot Compactor Sentry System to computer software to recycler-friendly garbage trucks. Amid all the glitz and glamour you never associated with garbage, there was a common theme: Recycling is a good idea, and a good business. ``If we have another Earth Day, everybody's going to be doing this,'' said Jerry Andregg as he stood next to a fancy white garbage truck with four compartments for four separate kinds of garbage and a plastic masher in the middle. ``It's helped our business out,'' he said, ``it'' being Earth Day. ``And it's raised people's awareness _ how important it is to start recycling.'' You know those big buckets that school-cafeteria mayonnaise come in? Well, with color-coding, a hole for rainwater to drain out of and a snazzy logo on the front, a company called Plastican makes them into bins for household recyclables. ``Everyone wants to do it,'' said Plastican's Doug McGee, ``it'' being recycling. ``But everyone's trying to figure out how to do it.'' That's what Thomas Higgins figures. He brought with him plenty of clear _ rather than colored _ plastic garbage bags. ``The most effective way to run a curbside recycling program is to pick up the material in a clear bag,'' said Higgins, manager of Hefty Recycling Opportunities for the Mobil Chemical Co.'s Consumer Products Division. The idea, he said, is that homeowners don't want 17 recycling bins cluttering up the garage, and cities don't want to pay the garbageman to dawdle at the curb, putting the brown beer bottles in one place, the clear juice bottles in another place and the newspapers in a third place. The answer: clear garbage bags. Over at the Dempster display, John L.
