Thomas, vice president for sales, showed off a gleaming white garbage truck with a side-loading window-box gizmo that dumps different kinds of garbage in the correct place in the truck. ``Earth Day has really brought it into focus,'' Thomas said. ``This (recycling) is the answer to our disposables problem. ``So many of our landfills are filling up. We're running out of landfill space. One way to extend landfill life is to put less in them,'' he said. ``We're the only company with 14-karat jewelry for sanitation, from $115 to $5,000 _ in stock!'' said Jimmy Brett, who's hawking stuff while his brother Saul was back in New York, minding the store. Saul Brett Inc. makes gold-colored garbage-can tie tacks and gold-and-diamond garbage-truck pins for the valued sanitation employee, or the supportive sanitation spouse. ``No one,'' Brett says, ``does it like we do.''

DOC.HEAD: CDC: Drug-Resistant Strains of Gonorrhea Increases
DOC.TEXT: Penicillin-resistant gonorrhea more than doubled from 1988 to 1989 and its treatment will require more expensive drugs, federal researchers say. A survey of 21 clinics that treat sexually transmitted disease found penicillin-resistant gonorrhea increased 131 percent in the one-year period, the national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday. Tetracycline-resistant gonorrhea increased by 23 percent in the same period, the survey found. During the study period, the national gonorrhea rate of infection remained basically unchanged, with three cases reported in every 1,000 Americans. ``The traditional _ and admittedly inexpensive _ therapies for gonorrhea, penicillin and tetracycline, really in many situations are not going to be the appropriate drugs for treating gonorrhea in 1990,'' said William Whittington, a CDC specialist in sexually transmitted diseases. The CDC survey found gonorrhea strains susceptible to two typically more expensive drugs, ceftriaxone and spectinomycin. Ceftriaxone or similar treatment ``remains an integral component of the strategy for gonorrhea control,'' the CDC said. In the survey, 20 male gonorrhea patients were tested each month for drug resistance. Resistance to penicillin, which occurred in 3.2 percent of the study cases in 1988, increased to 7.4 percent in 1989, the CDC said. Resistance to tetracycline, which occurred in 4 percent of the study cases in 1988, increased to 4.9 percent in 1989, the CDC said. ``Significant'' increases in penicillin resistance were reported at seven clinics: Atlanta; Birmingham, Ala.; Boston; Long Beach, Calif.; Philadelphia; San Antonio and San Diego. Penicillin-resistant cases made up 32 percent of the cases in the Long Beach clinic last year. Significant increases in tetracycline resistance were reported in Birmingham, Denver, St. Louis and West Palm Beach, Fla., while decreases were observed in Atlanta and Baltimore. The highest rate of tetracycline resistance last year, 20 percent, was in Philadelphia. Nationwide, 738,160 cases of gonorrhea were reported last year. So far this year, 215,011 cases have been reported, down slightly from 216,088 at the same point in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Police Raid Hospital Morgue To Seize Worker's Body
DOC.TEXT: Clamping down further after a week of labor unrest, police raided a hospital morgue early today to seize an activist's body from militant workers, news reports said. Police arrested 149 of the workers in the action in Changwon, about 210 miles south of Seoul, the reports said. Authorities said they mounted the raid at the request of the dead worker's family, who they said opposed a large funeral planned by the militant workers. The worker killed himself Thursday. Meanwhile, Hyundai company officials in Seoul said about half the 100,000 workers at their 13 subsidiaries in the city of Ulsan were back to work today. Police on Saturday stormed the company shipyard to drive out workers on a three-day occupation strike. Hyundai officials said they expected further improvement after 27,000 workers of the Hyundai Motor Co., the nation's largest automaker, today voted to return to work Monday. The vote ended a week of nationwide sympathy strikes protesting the raid on the nearby Hyundai shipyard. In today's action, about 600 riot police charged into the hospital in the southern industrial town of Changwon before dawn, took the body of the dead worker and returned it to his family for burial, news reports said. The national news agency, Yonhap, said about 200 militant workers guarding the morgue were overpowered by police wielding clubs and shields. The shipyard strike in Ulsan, about 200 miles southeast of Seoul, has revolved around workers' demands for the release of four previously jailed union leaders. Officials feared the death of the labor activist, 28-year-old Kim Young-il, might be used to stir up more trouble. Kim, a labor activist at the Tongil Industry Co. in Changwon, leaped to his death from a two-story building at his plant Thursday after dousing himself with paint thinner and setting it ablaze. Yonhap said he left letters complaining of a hard life and protesting police suppression of labor activity. Hyundai officials said the Ulsan shipyard, the largest in the world, will be open Monday if workers holed up at the top of an 240-foot crane come down. The workers took refuge there during Saturday's raid. Fifteen workers, saying they were sick, came down today and were arrested by police. News reports said 50 to 250 workers remain on the crane.

DOC.HEAD: Driftnet Fishing Boats Spotted Bearing North Korean Flags
DOC.TEXT: Five driftnet fishing boats spotted in unauthorized areas are marked with North Korean flags, which would signal a new player in an international fray over use of such nets and high seas salmon fishing, authorities said. North Korea has no diplomatic ties or fisheries treaties with the United States. ``We're trying to establish whether they are in fact North Korean and if they are North Korean, why they have suddenly appeared out there this year,'' said Coast Guard Capt. David A. Wirth, in Juneau. ``We have never seen them before,'' he said. ``We don't know why they're there.'' The Coast Guard is tracking the ships with aircraft, Wirth said. The ships were spotted Tuesday by a Coast Guard plane, officials said Thursday. They were fishing about 400 miles southwest of Kiska Island near the end of the Aleutian chain, in waters where driftnets likely would intercept salmon from North America. While most driftnets ostensibly are set for squid, critics say they illegally snag millions of dollars worth of U.S. and Canadian salmon. The critics liken the floating nets, stretching as long as 30 miles, to strip-mining of the sea. The ships flew North Korean flags and had North Korean markings on their smokestacks and bows, Coast Guard officials said Thursday. Four similar ships were spotted in the same area April 22 and 24, the Coast Guard said. It's possible the North Korean insignia is a disguise by vessels from other nations that could be pirating salmon in violation of agreements with the United States, Wirth said. Or the ships may be North Korean on contract with other nations, he said. The United States has negotiated treaties with South Korea, Japan and Taiwan prohibiting the taking of North American salmon by driftnets. It has a tentative agreement with the Soviet Union to cooperate to stop illegal salmon fishing in the North Pacific. U.S. officials have asked the Soviet Union for help in investigating the ships. ``Our government called in the Soviet fisheries attache (Wednesday) and requested assistance,'' said Bill Woolf, fisheries aide to U.S. Sen. Frank H. Murkowski, R-Alaska. ``We hope the Soviets will do their best to dissuade the North Koreans _ if indeed these ships are theirs _ from high seas salmon fishing, at best, and at the very least to assist us in gathering information on the extent and duration of this fishery, and if they have information on where the product is going,'' Woolf said. Coast Guard photographs show the five ships ``appear to be new and are very well kept up, with gobs and gobs of sophisticated electronics,'' Woolf said. ``They're not typical of the usual Japanese and Taiwanese driftnet fishing vessels, which see some pretty rough usage,'' he said. Photographs also show fish on the ships' decks. The ships may be violating the 1976 Magnuson Act, which in part protects fish spawned in U.S. rivers, said Henry Mitchell, executive director of the Bering Sea Fishermen's Association in Anchorage. ``U.S. law says our fish, spawned in U.S. rivers, are under our protection when they are out at sea,'' Mitchell said.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Executes Killer of Two Police Officers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4-7th grafs, `It took...' with 7 grafs to add description of death and final statement, explain source of flame, interruption in electrocution. CORRECTS spokesman's name to Macmaster sted MacMaster. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `He described...'.
DOC.TEXT: A killer who described himself and his girlfriend as a ``modern-day Bonnie and Clyde'' was executed in Florida's electric chair today for shooting two officers 14 years ago. Jessie Joseph Tafero was electrocuted at 7:13 a.m. at Florida State Prison, eight hours after the U.S. Supreme Court denied a stay of execution, exhausting his last appeal, the governor's office announced. Tafero, 43, was the 22nd person put to death in Florida since 1979 and the 124th to die in the United States since the Supreme Court restored states' rights to execute prisoners in 1976. It was a year to the day since Florida's previous execution. In a final statement, Tafero complained that last-minute motions filed on his behalf this morning with a federal judge and a state Circuit Court judge apparently were ignored. ``I'd like to say that the death penalty as applied by the states is very arbitrary and capricious,'' he said. The executioner interrupted the standard two-minute, 2,000-volt electrical cycle because of the smoke and flames when a wet sponge on Tafero's head caught fire, said state Corrections Department spokesman Bob Macmaster. But he said the prison's chief medical officer, Dr. Frank Kilgo, believed Tafero died quickly. Fewer than a dozen death penalty opponents demonstrated in silence with a candlelight vigil in a pasture outside the rural prison. Their posters said ``Kinder, Gentler?'' and ``Civilization's Finest Hour?'' Four supporters of the death penalty peered through heavy fog, watching the prison for a signal from departing reporters that Tafero was dead. Tafero's day began with a Mass at 1 a.m. celebrated by a Roman Catholic priest from the Cathedral of St. Augustine. He also was visited during the night by five attorneys and his mother, Kathleen Tafero, said Macmaster. He described Tafero as ``quiet ... a little concerned about the event, of course.'' The killings occurred Feb. 20, 1976, when a state trooper and a visiting Canadian constable checked on a car parked on the highway where Tafero, his girlfriend Sonja Jacobs, her two children and traveling companion Walter Rhodes Jr., were sleeping. Trooper Phillip Black died from gunshot wounds to the head and neck, while constable Donald Irwin of Kitchener, Ontario, received fatal wounds to his right eye and shoulder. Both men were 39. Tafero, Ms. Jacobs and Rhodes were convicted on murder charges. Rhodes got three concurrent life terms, while Tafero and Ms. Jacobs were sentenced to death. Ms. Jacobs' sentence was commuted to life in prison in 1981. A letter in Tafero's file describes the reaction of Black's young son, Christian, when he learned at school that his father had been killed. ``His grief was so strong, so unresolved and so overwhelming for this little boy, that none of us knew how to help him,'' wrote elementary school teacher Claudia R. Jacobowitz. An only child, Tafero was born in Jersey City, N.J., and moved to Dade County at the age of 10. His father was a comedian and car salesman and his mother was a housewife. Court records show a considerable juvenile record beginning at age 13. He quit school at age 16 after the ninth grade. In 1967, he was convicted of assault with intent to commit rape, breaking and entering and robbery. He spent six years in prison. In a 1984 interview, Tafero said his arrest and sentencing with Ms. Jacobs made them feel like ``modern day Bonnie and Clyde.'' The couple had an infant daughter, Cristina Tafero, at the time of the shootings. She lives in New York with guardians and recently visited Tafero in prison. The Supreme Court voted 7-2 not to stay the execution. Justices William Brennan and Thurgood Marshall, who oppose the death penalty, dissented. Earlier Thursday, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta turned down Tafero's request for a stay, after U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt in Miami refused to issue a writ of habeas corpus in the case. Executions have been a hot political issue in this gubernatorial reelection year. Gov. Bob Martinez's political advertisements stress that he has signed 122 death warrants since taking office, and 26 this year.

DOC.HEAD: Lenore G. Chandler, Los Angeles Philanthropist
DOC.TEXT: Philanthropist Lenore Gantt Chandler, an original contributor to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the city's Music Center, has died at age 97. Mrs. Chandler died Saturday of natural causes. A native of Texas, she was the widow of Ralph J. Chandler, a shipping executive and nephew of Harry Chandler, second publisher of the Los Angeles Times. Ralph Chandler died in 1966. The Chandler family was a major force behind the drive to give a home to the performing arts in Los Angeles with the construction of the $34 million Music Center, which opened 25 years ago. It includes the Mark Taper Forum and the Ahmanson Theater, and houses symphony, chorale, ballet and drama companies. Mrs. Chandler had lived in Los Angeles since her marriage in 1921. A son, Ralph II, died in military service during World War II. Mrs. Chandler is survived by a son, Andrew; two grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren. Services will be private.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Pushing for Quick Move to Private Ownership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with talks resuming, West German lawmaker saying relatively large East German accounts should be investigated, EDITS to conform; pickup 16th graf pvs, `Social Democrats...'
DOC.TEXT: West Germany should not give its currency to relatively rich East Germans without investigating whether their wealth came from crooked dealings by the old Communist regime, a West German politician said today. Otto Graf Lambsdorff said higher bank accounts should be investigated before the East German marks are ``automatically exchanged'' for West German marks as part of an economic merger that is to go into effect on July 2. Lambsdorff, leader of the Free Democrat Party that is the junior governing partner in the government of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, made his comments to reporters in West Berlin. Teams of experts from both countries resumed talks in East Berlin today on the logistics of merging their economies, particularly with finding a way to convert East Germany's state-owned land and enterprises to the private sector. Under an agreement reached earlier between the nations, most East German savings accounts of up to 4,000 marks will be traded at a 1-1 rate for West German marks. Most accounts higher than that will be traded at a 2-1 rate. Lambsdorff said a ceiling, which he did not specify, should be set for larger accounts. He said these should be investigated to make sure they were ``honestly acquired'' and not amassed illegally by, for example, members of the now-disbanded secret police. Members of the feared secret police and officials of the former regime of ousted hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker are believed to have large holdings in East German currency. Lambsdorff also repeated comments made by several West German officials on Thursday that East Germany must quickly convert its public property to the private sector. Virtually all enterprises and land are owned by the state under the socialist system now being phased out after four decades in power. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said Thursday that private ownership of property and industry was crucial to creating a market economy that would spawn the jobs and income necessary to offset the loss of huge social subsidies. He said many details have to be worked out, but that private ownership is needed to cope with the widespread joblessness expected in East Germany as the country is forced to compete in the free market. ``From July onwards every company that's active in West Germany can also become active in East Germany,'' Haussmann said in Bonn, the West German capital. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said he wanted an ``appropriate legal basis'' established for the purchase of land, enterprises and government-run media by foreign concerns. He said Thursday he would block the ``uncontrolled'' acquisition of such government-owned assets by West Germans and foreigners. The latest unification talks follow the agreement on conversion rates for changing East German marks to West German marks. Social Democrats in the government of de Maiziere, who leads the conservative Christian Democrats, sharply criticized the plan. East German Finance Minister Walter Romberg said the agreement still does not give adequate protection to people earning low incomes and fails to include a mechanism to protect people when rents and livings costs rise in the free market. East Germans now are dependent on subsidized food, housing and jobs. ``A law that adjusts for social shortcomings in East Germany .. . is of essential significance,'' Romberg said in Bonn, where he met with West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel. Some East Germans want guarantees that prices and rents will not rise at a vastly sharper rate than their wages. Kohl's government says the influx of new Western businesses will raise living standards in East Germany. The agreement would convert East German wages, pensions and small savings accounts at a 1-1 exchange to the West German mark. It also would convert debts owned by East German factories _ estimated at 200 billion East German marks _ at a 2-1 rate. Those debts now will be worth 100 billion West German marks, or $60 billion, but with Western interest rates. Some economists have said that the debts should be forgiven entirely to allow the factories to get a fresh start in the free market.

DOC.HEAD: Government Continues Dolphin-Swimming Permits
DOC.TEXT: The government has decided to allow people and captive dolphins swim together for at least another year. Permits for three Swim-with-the-Dolphis programs in Florida and one in Hawaii have been extended through the end of 1991, the National Marine Fisheries Service announced. The permits had been scheduled to expire April 30. However, for the time being no new permits will be issued and no new dolphins may be captured for use in these programs, the agency said. Permits for the programs were first issued in 1985. The Marine Fisheries Service reports that it has received hundreds of letters from environmentalists concerned about the health and safety of the dolphins involved. The extension of the permits will require that the operators give the dolphins additional rest periods, increased security and a means of escape from the swimming public. The service said it has found no evidence that dolphins in these programs suffer any more health problems than dolphins on public display in aquariums. However, officials plan to monitor these programs during the coming year to determine if they should be allowed to continue and if other permits should be issued. The fisheries service is a part of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Student Group Says Chinese Official Has Defected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be topped after 10:30 a.m. news conference
DOC.TEXT: An official who handled student affairs at the Chinese Embassy here has defected and is seeking political asylum in the United States, a spokesman for a student organization said today. The spokesman, Qing Xiao of the Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars, said Xu Lin, 33, a third secretary at the embassy, defected Wednesday night out of sympathy with the students' goals. Qing said Xu applied to the Immigration and Naturalization Service for asylum on Thursday. Duke Austin, an INS spokesman, declined comment. He said it was the service's policy to make no comment on asylum applications unless the person seeking asylum personally made his action public. Qing said Xu would hold a news conference today. Qing said Xu first contacted the State Department and was told to make his application to the INS. State Department press officers were in a staff meeting and not immediately available. Wu Zurong, first secretary in the press office at the Chinese Embassy, said he was not familiar with Xu's reported defection but would check. The student federation, based in Washington, was formed last year to protect the rights of an estimated 40,000 Chinese students in the United States. It also says it seeks to promote democracy in China. After the Chinese crackdown on demonstrators in Tiananmen Square last June, Xu helped Chinese students in the United States renew their passports, Qing said. He also said Xu avoided reporting on student activities to government officials. Some Chinese diplomats in the United States and elsewhere defected after the June crackdown.

DOC.HEAD: Attackers Fire at Guard in Failed Bombing Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with shots fired at guard, other details, comment by British officials in Germany and London. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Three men planting explosives near a British military barracks today fired at a guard before fleeing their bungled bombing attempt, officials said. Investigators later found 65 pounds of the high-powered explosive Semtex in three satchels outside a housing block at the British army's Langenhagen Barracks in Hanover, British military officials said. It was not known who was responsible. A Ministry of Defense spokesman in London said: ``We cannot say the men were IRA at this moment in time. All we can say is that they were terrorists.'' The Irish Republican Army has been blamed for numerous attacks against British military installations in West Germany over the past few years. The IRA has waged a campaign to drive the British from Northern Ireland and unite the Protestant-dominated province with the overwhelming Roman Catholic Irish Republic. According to police, a civilian guard making the rounds with a security dog noticed three suspicious people on the barracks grounds about 2 a.m. Three shots were fired by the people, said a British military spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the guard was not injured. Col. Henry Day, Chief of Public Information for the British Forces in Germany, said the attackers had cut a hole in the barracks' perimeter fence. He told British Broadcasting Corp. radio that 70 soldiers were moved from the building. ``It was Semtex, with a wire timing device,'' Day said. He said one satchel contained 10 blocks of explosives, and the second nine blocks. He said he had no details on the third.

DOC.HEAD: Smithsonian Botanist Mason Hale Dead at 61
DOC.TEXT: Mason E. Hale, an internationally known Smithsonian Institution botanist, has died of cancer at age 61. Hale, who worked for the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History, had published more than 150 studies, including five books on lichens, which grow as alga and fungus on rocks, trees and soil. He died Monday at his Arlington, Va., home. A memorial service was held Tuesday. In one study, Hale's research found that lead accumulation in lichens showed a noticeable increase as a result of emissions from cars crossing a bridge over the Potomac River. The lichens were found on a Potomac island near Washington. During his 33 years at the Smithsonian, Hale built the National Museum of Natural History lichen collection into the world's third largest through gifts, exchanges and his world travels. A native of Winstead, Conn., Hale received a bachelor's degree from Yale University and master's and doctorate degrees from the University of Wisconsin. He taught at the University of Wichita in Kansas and at the University of West Virginia before he was hired as a curator in the Museum of Natural History's botany department. Survivors include his wife, Beatrice Hale; two daughters; a son; his mother and two brothers.

DOC.HEAD: North Texas Struggles Against Worst Flooding Since 1922
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 2nd to UPDATE with Oklahoma and Arkansas flooding. Adds 2 grafs at end with Arkansas damage, precautions.
DOC.TEXT: Skies were clear early today in northern Texas and a dry spell forecast for the next few days was likely to alleviate the worst flooding in the region in more than half a century. There was no rain early today but areas that were heavily flooded in the region could still experience problems, forecasters warned. They said that May is the region's wettest month. Any more heavy rain in the next couple of weeks is likely to cause substantial flooding, said meteorologist Skip Ely. For the first time in 33 years, water gushed over the spillway at Lake Texoma Dam into the Red River, which forms the Texas-Oklahoma state line. At least 100 people were evacuated from homes east and west of the lake in southern Oklahoma. The flooding extended downstream to Arkansas, where authorities were giving out sandbags and preparing emergency shelters today. Heavy rains damaged hundreds of homes and left at least three dead in the Fort Worth area on Wednesday. ``There is still water moving out there, and moving water is dangerous,'' said Alton Bostick, emergency management coordinator for Fort Worth and Tarrant County. ``People should not drive into it. They don't know the depth and if there are no barricades around, they should be very cautious.'' In Dallas, the Trinity River crested Thursday night at 47 feet, 17 feet above flood level, its deepest level since 1949. As much as 7 inches of rain fell from late Wednesday to early Thursday in some areas. Vice President Dan Quayle said while touring south of Dallas on Thursday that if Gov. Bill Clements applies for federal aid for other areas, he will find ``a very cooperative president.'' President Bush signed a disaster declaration Thursday for four counties hard-hit in flooding last week. Country officials in Dallas and Fort Worth were expected to begin applying for federal relief funds today. Boats, cars and even dump trucks were used to evacuate people stranded on doorsteps and rooftops. Many roads were flooded, including four feet of water over the C.F. Hawn Freeway, a main north-south artery in Dallas. ``We took people off rooftops, off of cars. Some of the homes are totally under water,'' fire department spokeswoman Carolyn Garcia said. The tail end of the storms Thursday spawned two tornadoes that caused minor damage near Nacogdoches. Earlier in the day, a tornado struck the outskirts of Paris, about 100 miles northeast of Dallas. Eight people suffered minor injuries and two businesses and 16 homes were damaged, officials said. Eagle Mountain Lake north of Fort Worth was expected to reach record levels Saturday morning. ``It is higher than '81 and just short of 1957 when it got to 10 feet over the spillway. The all-time high for Eagle Mountain was 11 feet over in 1942,'' said Mike Williams of Tarrant County Water Control and Improvement District No. 1. ``On Lake Bridgeport, this is largest amount we've ever had.'' The Brazos River continued a ``slow and steady'' rise but was expected to crest late today barring any additional rain, said Fire Marshal Mike Paschal. Hundreds of people along the Brazos were evacuated Wednesday for the second time in two weeks. ``Right now, they're still evacuated,'' Paschal said. ``A few are going back during the daylight hours to get what they can salvage.'' In Arkansas, authorities estimated recent flood damage to roads and bridges at $7 million. Gov. Bill Clinton authorized use of 75 Army National Guardsmen for sandbagging along the Arkansas River at Fort Smith, on the Oklahoma line. After thunderstorms moved across the state from the west Thursday night, the river was forecast to crest well above flood stage beginning today at Fort Smith and extending through Monday downstream at Pine Bluff.

DOC.HEAD: Press Gets Limited Protection Against Compelled Testimony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-14, bgng `Applying those...', to CORRECT spelling of Bertero sted Bertrero. Picks up 15th graf, `The Supreme...'.
DOC.TEXT: The California Supreme Court has ruled reporters can be required to testify in a criminal case if their testimony would help the defense. The decision Thursday involved a Los Angeles Times reporter and photographer who had refused to testify in a weapons possession case, citing the state's ``shield law.'' The law protects reporters from being held in contempt of court or jailed for refusing to disclose news sources or unpublished information. The court unanimously concluded that the 1980 law protects observations made during news gathering, in addition to undisclosed, confidential notes or tapes. But the court also ruled the law cannot be used to violate a criminal defendant's constitutional right to a fair trial, and that testimony can be compelled if there is a ``reasonable possibility the information will materially assist (the) defense.'' Applying those standards, the court said reporter Roxana Kopetman and photographer Roberto Santiago Bertero must testify about whether they saw or heard a man agree to a search of his jacket when he was arrested by Long Beach police in 1987. Officers said they found illegal brass knuckles in the jacket, but the evidence will be excluded if the search was without consent. Rex Heinke, lawyer for Ms. Kopetman and Bertero, said a U.S. Supreme Court appeal would be considered. The court did not resolve one important question, whether a prosecutor has a similar ability to compel a reporter's testimony. But Justice David Eagleson, who wrote the opinion, said the court did not have to decide that issue in this case. Heinke said the ``logical implications'' of the decision were that the media could not be compelled by the prosecutor in a criminal case, or by either side in a civil suit not directly involving the press. ``If those are the implications, then it's a substantial victory for the press, although not in this particular case,'' he said. Albert Menaster, the Los Angeles public defender who sought the testimony, said the ruling was a victory for his client ``but I do not consider it a loss for the press.'' He said the court had set reasonable standards for balancing the rights of reporters and defendants. Ms. Kopetman and Bertero were riding with Long Beach police in September 1987 when they saw officers question and search Sean Patrick Delaney, 21. The newspaper's article four days later mentioned the incident, but did not say whether Delaney consented to the search of his jacket pocket, the crucial issue for a still-pending charge of possessing brass knuckles. Ms. Kopetman and Bertero refused to testify, citing the shield law. They were held in contempt of court and that decision was upheld by the 2nd District Court of Appeal, which said the law did not apply to observations of public events. The Supreme Court disagreed with that conclusion, saying ``unpublished information'' protected by the law included non-confidential observations. But the court said the reporters' shield was overcome in this case by the defendant's need for the testimony. ``Delaney's personal liberty is at stake,'' Eagleson wrote. ``The reporteres are not being asked to breach a confidence or to disclose sensitive information that would in any way even remotely restrict their newsgathering ability. ``All that is being required of them is to accept the civic responsibility imposed on all persons who witness alleged criminal conduct.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-HUD Official Providing More Detail on Pierce
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with Gilliam testimony; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: An imprisoned former Housing and Urban Development official testified today that former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. directed federal grants to friends, including a ``down and out'' former campaign manager. DuBois L. Gilliam said Pierce ordered one $350,000 grant because his friend and former political manager, Sam Singletary, needed help. The grant was arranged despite the lack of a request from a city that was to benefit from the project, and a lack of experience by Singletary and his partner, who applied for the grant as a non-profit private group, Gilliam said. The grants, along with others Gilliam described, were from the department's technical assistance program, with money coming from the secretary's discretionary program. Gilliam testified that virtually all the money from that program was distributed based on political connections _ and that he and Pierce both expressed surprise when they discovered that one applicant for a grant on their approved list had no political connections. The committee chairman, Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., said the program ``was administered politically, as a cross between a slush fund and a political action committee.'' ``The whole scheme is so incredible, so unreal,'' Lantos said. Gilliam said he traveled to Camden, N.J., to meet with the mayor to persuade him that HUD intended to provide the $350,000 grant to Singletary's group if he would go along with the project, which was intended to help the city with community development projects. He said Pierce ``indicated he wanted to help Mr. Singletary get some funds. He was down and out ... And I did so. ... He told me to fund the project.'' Gilliam also told congressional investigators that he directed a grant to another group because of its connection to a brother of Pierce. He did not identify the brother, but committee staff director Stuart Weisberg identified him before the meeting as Burton Pierce. Gilliam said Pierce called him about the $257,000 project and ``told me he wanted to get the project funded.'' A Republican, Pierce was appointed a New York state judge in 1959 and lost an election bid for a full term as judge in 1960, said Weisberg, staff director of Lantos' House Government Operations subcommittee on employment and housing. Gilliam was appearing for a third day before the panel, which has spent more than a year investigating fraud, influence-peddling and political favoritism at HUD Reagan administration. Gilliam, a former deputy assistant secretary of HUD, pleaded guilty to abusing HUD programs and accepting illegal gratuities. He is serving an 18-month sentence at the federal prison in Lompoc, Calif., and has been testifying under a grant of immunity from further prosecution. In two previous days of testimony, Gilliam has said that he, Pierce and others manipulated programs to direct federal grants and lucrative subsidies to friends, sometimes before any formal applications were made. ``The determining factor in awarding technical assistance grants was on the particular people behind each project, rather than on the quality of the project,'' Lantos said. While the secretary had discretion to direct grants under the technical assistance programs, Weisberg said basing decisions on politics could be considered an abuse of the program and against the intent of Congress. Gilliam's testimony has contradicted Pierce's sworn statement to the subcommittee a year ago that he was not directly involved in deciding who got HUD grants, Weisberg said. ``The technical assistance program is probably the one program that Pierce was most involved in _ the one that was most political,'' he said. Paul L. Perito, a lawyer for Pierce, attacked Gilliam's credibility, calling him ``an admitted cheat and liar.'' ``Mr. Pierce denies all allegations of wrongdoing and improper conduct,'' Perito said. After testifying once in May 1989, Pierce invoked his constitutional rights against self-incrimination and refused further testimony. Special prosecutor Arlin Adams, appointed by a federal court to investigate Pierce, said he would have no comment on Gilliam's testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Pounded In Local Elections But Averts Predicted Rout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with new Thatcher, Kinnock quotes, latest election totals; Picks up 15th graf, `A computer ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Labor Party has trounced Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives in local elections, making its best showing since she came to power 11 years ago, tallies showed today. But the Conservatives averted the rout forecast by opinion polls. And Mrs. Thatcher maintained that despite a big 11 percent swing against the government, she had the basis for winning a fourth term in 1991 or 1992. ``We've lost some we hoped to hold ... but we have a very good basis on which to go forward and win the next general election.'' She was speaking a day after the poll at a news conference at Waddesdon Manor, northwest of London, with visiting French President Francois Mitterrand. Neil Kinnock, leader of the Labor Party, said the results showed broad support for his party throughout England. ``That is the spread of support that we need which makes me forecast that we are certain to win the next election,'' Kinnock said. For the first time since James Callaghan's Labor government lost power to Mrs. Thatcher in 1979, the socialist party made significant gains in the Tory heartlands of the prosperous south. The Conservatives, in deep trouble over the economy and the so-called poll tax that prompted nationwide protests, lost control in a clutch of previously safe southern English towns, including Portsmouth, Torbay and Gillingham. But the Conservatives performed strongly in London. They held two key boroughs, Wandsworth and Westminster, which have set the lowest poll tax rates in the country and are lauded by Mrs. Thatcher. One sore loss for Labor was its loss of control to the Conservatives in the London borough of Ealing, where Kinnock makes his home. The governing party failed to gain ground in north England and remained virtually shut out in Scotland. After 196 of 201 councils were declared, a tally by the British domestic news agency, Press Association, showed the Tories lost 355 seats and gained 143, while Labor notched up 431 gains and 120 losses. The centrists and minor parties, except the Scottish nationalists, all had net losses. With incomplete results in, Labor had made 10 gains to control 89 councils. The Conservatives, who had controlled 60 councils, lost 12 and gained four. The third-running centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party lost three and gained two. No party had overall control in the rest. A computer analysis by the British Broadcasting Corp. showed an 11 percent swing in popular voting against the government since 1987, when Mrs. Thatcher began her third term. That margin would be enough to give Labor a comfortable win in a general election. The latest Gallup poll published today in London's pro-Conservative newspaper The Daily Telegraph showed just 23 percent of voters satisfied with her performance. It was the worst rating for any British leader since opinion polling began about 50 years ago. But some commentators predicted the local election results would lessen speculation Mrs. Thatcher will retire or be ousted as party leader before the next election in 1991 or 1992. In a key result, the Conservatives retained control with a hugely increased majority of the south London borough of Wandsworth. It set the lowest per-capita tax in the country: $243 per person compared with an average of $580. Wandsworth's Labor leader, Fiona McTaggart, called the low tax a ``bribe that's worked for them.'' The tax, which replaced a local property tax April 1, is officially known as a community charge but is dubbed a poll tax. It is widely viewed as unfair because everyone in the same district pays the same, regardless of income. Instead of just 17 million homeowners being liable, all 38 million adults must pay, with rebates for the 9.5 million poorest. Mrs. Thatcher says it is fairer for everyone to pay, and she expected Labor councils would be blamed for high bills. However, most households are paying more and blaming her. The poll tax raises about one-fourth of the $37.7 billion needed for local services including education, police, subsidized housing and garbage collection.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Angered by Exclusion from U.S.-Canadian Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf to UPDATE with scene on reservation this morning. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `But Indian...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XMAS2
DOC.TEXT: Indian leaders on both sides of a gambling dispute were furious at being excluded from a meeting where U.S. and Canadian officials discussed setting up a new Mohawk government. During a 3{-hour meeting Thursday in Montreal about 30 U.S. and Canadian officials discussed creating one Mohawk government to replace three fractious councils now governing the reserve straddling the U.S.-Canadian border. ``This meeting today was designed to work out all the options to stop the fighting,'' said Harry Swain, Canada's deputy minister of Indian affairs. ``Everything that was said occurred with the knowledge and blessing of the Mohawk people on the reserve, and we will take our findings back to them immediately.'' New York state troopers today continued to occupy the reservation, stopping residents for identification as they walked or drove through the territory. At least three state police cars were stationed at most intersections, and the reservation was quiet except for traditional morning chants. But Indian leaders on the reservation were angry. ``If, in fact, they want to do this with the proper recognition of the sovereignty of the people, then they must do it in a coordinated community-wide fashion,'' said Harold Tarbell, an anti-gambling spokesman in the Canadian town of Cornwall. ``That's the problem, the people are not consulted about decisions made for their benefit,'' said Francis Boots, a spokesman for the Warrior Society, a pro-gambling group. A nine-month conflict over the operation of lucrative gambling casinos on the 28,000-acre reservation culminated this week in two shooting deaths. The victims were one gambling supporter and one gambling opponent. After the shootings Tuesday, Canadian and U.S. security forces moved into the reservation. The Warrior Society, a self-proclaimed security force that patrols the American side of the reservation, describes the police as ``foreign'' armies, and wants them to leave. Many of the other Mohawks approve of the operation if it results in peace. The three Mohawk governments are the Mohawk Indian Nation, which includes Mohawks on both sides of the border; the Mohawk Tribal Council, on the American side, and the Band Council on the Canadian side. Swain said Canadian and U.S. police will remain on the reservation until they are sure no more shooting will erupt. But some reinforcements from the Canadian army started pulling away Thursday night, said Maj. Gerald Baril of the Canadian National Defense headquarters in Ottawa. He said two military helicopters will remain on standby until at least the end of the week. Residents went about their business Thursday under the eye of the security forces. More than 1,000 people remained camped out in dormitory rooms of a government training college in Cornwall. Other refugees were taken in at National Guard facilities on the New York side. But some were determined not to leave their homes. ``Most of us here in the neighborhood have stayed,'' said Bonnie Bradley, who lives with her parents, two children and two nephews. ``I don't feel terrorized by this. I'm not part of either side, so I have no reason to watch my back. But I wish it were over. I do wish it were over.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Fines Officers of Collapsed Insurance Company $115.5 Million
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge levied a $115.5 million penalty against officers of the collapsed Champion Insurance Co., but warned state officials that they may have difficulty collecting the money. Alabama officials said they would work with their counterparts from Louisiana to try to get the money from what was once Alabama's fourth largest auto insurance company. Champion went into liquidation in June 1989, leaving behind pending auto insurance claims from 10,000 customers. Champion officers have been indicted on charges of siphoning off $37 million from policies. At Thursday's court hearing, Montgomery attorney Charles Crook, representing the state government, said the large penalty in a civil case against Champion would be a deterrent and show other insurance companies ``that these matters are policed.'' ``That is if you ever collect,'' U.S. District Judge Robert Varner told the attorney. The penalty imposed by Varner was the highest judgment allowed by the civil court provisions of federal racketeering laws. The judgment is triple the state government's anticipated loss from Champion's demise _ $38.5 million. The Eicher family that ran the insurance company based in Baton Rouge, La., has had its assets frozen. ``We'll be working with the Louisiana liquidators in taking appropriate actions to locate assets and enforce the judgment,'' Crook said after the hearing. ``I realize some practical difficulty with whether assets of that amount are available.'' Alabama Attorney General Don Siegelman said the judgment does not mean Alabama will immediately receive the money. But he said, ``Payment of claims is the responsibility of Champion and I intend to do everything within my power to make sure that responsibility is honored.'' Gov. Guy Hunt said the ruling ``should be a message to any company that is should be fair and straightforward with the people of Alabama.'' The $115.5 million is in addition to separate criminal theft charges against 64-year-old John Eicher and six other family members and former officers of Champion. They were indicted by a Montgomery County grand jury in March.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf of 2nd item, bgng On a, to CORRECT vote; picks up 3rd graf, The Democratic
DOC.HEAD: Blood Banks to Routinely Screen for Hepatitis C
DOC.TEXT: Blood bank agencies say they will start routinely screening blood donations for hepatitis C, the most common serious infection spread by blood transfusion. The American Association of Blood Banks, the American Red Cross and the Council of Community Blood Centers announced in a joint statement Thursday that blood will be screened using a new test licensed Tuesday by the Food and Drug Administration. By some estimates, about 7,500 to 20,000 of the 4 million Americans receiving blood transfusions annually develop acute hepatitis C. Officials said the new test could halve that number. Jon MacPherson, executive director of the Council of Community Blood Centers, said the groups also suggest that patients who have received blood transfusions within the last 20 years consider being tested for hepatitis C. Hepatitis C, formerly called hepatitis non-A, non-B, is thought to be caused by a virus called HCV. It infects from 150,000 to 200,000 Americans annually. Only 5 to 10 percent of these cases are attributed to blood transfusions. Other sources are thought to be shared drug needles and, some studies suggest, sexual relations. The source of at least half of the hepatitis C infections, however, is unknown. Symptoms for most patients are mild and the disease usually is not diagnosed. There is no generally available treatment. For 10 to 20 percent of the patients, hepatitis C can be serious, leading to life-threatening liver disease, or cirrhosis.
DOC.HEAD: Greater Political Freedom for Federal Workers Advances
DOC.TEXT: The Senate has disregarded a threatened veto by President Bush and moved toward allowing the nation's 3 million federal civil service and postal workers to participate more in party politics. On a 67-30 vote, Democrats on Thursday defeated an amendment by Senate Republicans aimed at derailing a bill to remove most restrictions on political activities by federal employees imposed by the 1939 Hatch Act. The Democratic bill would revise the law to lift prohibitions that bar federal civil service employees from holding office in political parties, working in campaigns or soliciting campaign dollars from fellow workers. However, it would continue prohibitions on federal workers running for public office, soliciting campaign funds from the general public or engaging in political activities while on the job. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the current restrictions ``illogical and unnecessary.'' The Republican amendment by Sen. William Roth, R-Del., would have substituted the proposed changes with an order directing the Office of Personnel Management to ``simplify and clarify'' what Roth acknowledged are confusing regulations under the law.
DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Will Test Stamp Sales at ATMs
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service is planning to sell polyester postage stamps through automatic teller machines at banks in a six-month test beginning May 18 in Seattle. Spokesman Art Shealy announced Thursday that the stamps will be test-marketed in a joint venture by the Postal Service and Seafirst Bank, first at about 15 Seattle locations and then at other Seafirst branches in Washington state. Shealy said the sheets of stamps were designed to resemble currency so that they can be dispensed the same way cash is dispensed through the machines. He said the sheets, each with a dozen 25-cent stamps, would cost $3 apiece, debited against the customer's bank account. The stamp is designed to be self-adhesive, requiring no licking, Shealy said. ``We think it answers quite a large portion of the public's request for a more convenient stamp,'' he said. ``It is humidity-resistant so they don't stick together. It is really a stamp of the future.'' If the Seattle test is a success, Shealy said, the stamps will be tried out nationwide in the spring of 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Former Wife Says She Found Bowie, Jagger in Bed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS graf on end with effort to get comment from Bowie spokesman. Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: The former wife of singer David Bowie says she once found her husband in bed with Rolling Stone Mick Jagger. Angela Bowie, who has been divorced from the creator of ``Ziggy Stardust'' for 10 years, appeared on ``The Joan Rivers Show'' today and said she had caught Bowie ``in bed with men several times. In fact, one of the best times I caught him in bed with Mick Jagger.'' The studio audience hooted and hollered, and Miss Rivers shouted ``all right!'' Exhorted by shock-humor radio personality Howard Stern, Ms. Bowie said the discovery didn't please her, but there was nothing she could do about it. She did not interrupt, she said. ``I made breakfast,'' she said. Ms. Bowie did not say when the incident occurred. Nor did she offer any details. She agreed that Bowie had dumped her, but denied that she was bitter or angry at him. The Bowies were divorced in February 1980. The Daily News reported that under the terms of the divorce, Ms. Bowie received $700,000 over 10 years, under the condition that she not speak publicly about her husband. That gag order expired April 1, according to the News. Ms. Bowie made several references while on the show to a settlement with her former husband that she implied may be forthcoming. In the early part of the show, Ms. Bowie skated around questions from Ms. Rivers, who had said at the opening that her guest was ``ready to dish and I mean down and dirty dishing about her ex.'' When Ms. Bowie was not forthcoming _ ``I actually don't like kissing and telling,'' she said _ she was led off camera. Ms. Rivers and Stern, her next guest, ridiculed the departed Ms. Bowie for failing to spill her guts, and she returned to the studio. Bowie has told interviewers in the past that he is a bisexual. Jagger has made no such statement. Calls to Bowie's spokesman, Bernard Docherty, in London did not go through; the telephone is disconnected.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Say Appeal Coming on Dowaliby Conviction
DOC.TEXT: Defense attorneys say they will appeal the conviction of a man found guilty of murdering his 7-year-old stepdaughter and hiding her body in the woods. Prosecutors ``did not prove their case beyond a reasonable doubt,'' said Ralph Mecyzk, an attorney for convicted murderer David Dowaliby. ``The jury did not separate the enormity of the crime from the evidence. ``Everything the state gave them, they swallowed.'' A Cook County circuit court jury convicted Dowaliby on Thursday after almost 14 hours of deliberations over three days. Prosecutors contended Dowaliby and his wife, Cynthia, murdered the girl in her bedroom in September 1988, dumped the body and faked evidence to convince police that Jaclyn had been abducted by a home invader. The defense contended that the intruder came in through a basement window while the family slept. ``It's an enormous victory for Jaclyn Dowaliby and for all children abandoned by their parents who have only the system to protect them,'' said assistant state's attorney Patrick O'Brien. ``The evidence won the case.'' On Tuesday, Judge Richard Neville acquitted Mrs. Dowaliby for lack of evidence. Dowaliby was taken to the Cook County Jail after Neville revoked his bond pending a hearing on Monday. Mrs. Dowaliby was given a chance to say goodbye to her husband before he left the courtroom. ``She was extremely disappointed,'' said Lawrence Hyman, Mrs. Dowaliby's attorney. ``She is resigned in her determination to battle to free her husband. She says he husband is as innocent as she is, and she is ready to show the appellate court that the jury verdict was wrong.'' Dowaliby, 33, was convicted of killing Jaclyn on Sept. 10, 1988, at the family's suburban Midlothian home and dumping her body in a wooded area behind an apartment complex in nearby Blue Island. Her body was found four days later. Sentencing was set for June 4. Dowaliby faces imprisonment of 20 to 80 years, lawyers said. O'Brien would not say whether the prosecution would press for the maximum.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Mandela, de Klerk Announce `Important Breakthrough' in Historic Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with joint statement by de Klerk and Mandela, new quotes; Picks up 8th graf, `The government ...'
DOC.TEXT: The government and the African National Congress announced today they had made an ``important breakthrough'' by agreeing to work together to end political violence in South Africa. President F.W. de Klerk and ANC leader Nelson Mandela, looking relaxed after three days of historic talks, told a news conference they had made major progress toward creating a normal political climate that would clear the way for bringing blacks into the national government. ``I regard what is contained in this document as an important breakthrough in the peace process,'' de Klerk said. The two sides issued a joint communique outlining steps to end political violence and remove remaining obstacles to full-scale constitutional negotiations. ``The government and the ANC agree on a common commitment towards the resolution of the existing climate of violence and intimidation from whatever quarter as well as a commitment to stability and to a peaceful process of negotiations,'' the joint statement said. The communique said a working group would report by May 21 on ways to overcome remaining obstacles to constitutional negotiations. But de Klerk told reporters no date had been set for further talks between the two sides. The two leaders said the three days of talks, the first ever between the ANC and the government, had been an important step forward. They praised each other's sincerity and determination to find a peaceful solution to South Africa's racial divisions. ``I look to the future with confidence,'' de Klerk said. Mandela was equally positive, saying the most striking feature of the negotiations had been there ``cordiality.'' ``We have had discussions on sensitive matters in a spirit of conciliation and understanding,'' Mandela said. The joint statement outlined five steps to be taken to try to settle remaining ANC demands for full-scale negotiations. The steps include establishment of the working group to actually handle practical matters; the granting of temporary immunity from prosecution for political offenses for selected top ANC officials; a government review of existing security legislation; and the establishment of channels of communication between the two sides to halt violence. The declaration said the government committed itself ``to work towards the lifting of the state of emergency'' _ a key ANC demand. ``In this context the ANC will exert itself to fulfill the objective contained in the preamble,'' the communique stated. The state of emergency has been in effect since June 1986. The ANC says the emergency is used by police to suppress political activity and peaceful dissent. The government says it wants to lift the emergency, but that it remains necessary to combat black factional fighting that has claimed more than 600 lives this year. The ANC is seeking amnesty for its estimated 15,000 exiles and the release of all prisoners convicted of politically motivated crimes. So far, de Klerk has released some political activists convicted of acts that did not involve violence and offered temporary immunity to ANC officials involved in the talks. Legislation that could provide amnesty to exiles and prisoners is under consideration in Parliament. The government is demanding the ANC renounce its largely ineffective guerrilla campaign. De Klerk also wants the ANC to assist the government in ending the political violence in the southeastern province of Natal and elsewhere. De Klerk has been reluctant to grant outright pardons to ANC guerrillas accused or convicted of violent attacks for fear of a white backlash. Many whites are unhappy with the government's rapid reforms and still regard the ANC as a terrorist group. If the two sides reach agreement on holding constitutional negotiations, white and black leaders warn such discussions will be difficult and prolonged with major differences to be resolved. The government insists that any new constitution extending political rights to the country's 28 million blacks must include guarantees to safeguard the interests of the 5 million whites and other minorities.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Forces Help Get Gacha
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military personnel participated in the air assault that killed cocaine kingpin Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha at a ranch on the Colombian coast Dec. 15, New York Newsday reported today. President Bush and the Colombian government have denied such involvement. Newsday, citing several unidentified U.S. government sources, reported that U.S. forces helped plan the assault and three or four U.S. military personnel helped operate the two helicopters that carried it out. Rodriguez Gacha, his son and several bodyguards were killed by gunfire from one of the helicopters as they tried to flee. One of the helicopters was fired on first, and Newsday reported that the commanding officer, identified by one source as an American, gave the order to fire back. Rodriguez Gacha, 42, was one of the most powerful of the Colombian cocaine bosses. At a news conference Thursday, Bush repeated administration denials of U.S. military involvement: ``U.S. troops in Colombia? No. That's the answer.'' Newsday said the head of the Colombian federal police, Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, denied U.S. involvement in an interview in Bogota last week. Newsday said it had information from more than six sources about a U.S. role in the mission, including an Army Special Forces staff member, three other defense sources, a House aide and a Senate aide who said he was briefed by Pentagon officials. The Senate aide said he was told that ``a handful'' of U.S. special operations troops participated with a much larger contingent of Colombians, and that the U.S. role was pre-eminent, Newsday reported. Another source said the Colombian presence was characterized as ``window dressing.'' ``Officially we say they did it, but in fact we did it,'' a congressional source said, according to Newsday. A source described as having close ties to U.S. intelligence said four Spanish-speaking Americans operated the radios and sophisticated electronic tracking equipment aboard the two helicopters, while Colombians manned the on-board machine guns. At least one of the helicopters belonged to the U.S. Southern command, based in Panama, and the source said Americans had operational control of the mission, Newsday reported. One source identified one of the Americans as an Army officer assigned to the CIA, it said. Sources said the mission was covert, with American involvement protected by ``plausible deniability,'' meaning it was to be carried out in a fashion that would enable U.S. officials to say they were unaware of it, the report said. Citing two congressional sources, it said the House and Senate intelligence committees were notified of the operation through a presidential ``finding'' that declared the mission was in the national interest.

DOC.HEAD: 23 Suspected Kurdish Guerrillas Killed
DOC.TEXT: Security forces killed 23 suspected Kurdish guerrillas in two clashes in southeastern and eastern Turkey, the Anatolia news agency reported Friday. The dispatch said three village guards were also killed during the fighting Thursday. Anatolia said 17 guerrillas were killed in Sirnak township near the Iraqi border in one of the largest anti-guerrilla operations in the region since fighting started in 1984. It added that security forces seized seven machine guns and a rocket launcher. In a clash in Dilekli village of Yuksekova township, local guards fired on a group of Kurdish guerrillas, killing one, the report said. Three guards were killed. Anatolia also reported that security forces killed five guerrillas in the eastern province of Kars. No other details were given. The guerrillas belong to the Kurdish Labor Party, a Marxist group fighting to establish an independent nation in Turkey's southeastern provinces. The group has camps in neighboring Syria, Iraq and Iran, security officials say.

DOC.HEAD: Student Protest of New Premier in Third Day
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of students opposed to the selection of a military general as Taiwan's new premier disrupted a parliamentary session Friday, and hundreds more protested for a third day in a downtown park. About 500 college students were participating in the park rally, which began after President Lee Teng Hui chose Defense minister Hau Pei-tsun to be premier. Shouting pro-democracy and anti-military slogans, the students held a sit-in and listened to speeches. Hundreds of riot police monitored the demonstration. Earlier, a session of the lawmaking Legislative Yuan was disrupted when about 60 students clashed with police inside the building. The students unfurled banners that read ``Oppose Military Interference'' and ``Hau lacks popular support.'' Two students suffered minor injuries during the brief scuffle, witnesses said. President Lee's selection of Hau, Taiwan's only four-star general, as head of the Cabinet has sparked heated debates in the legislature. Opposition lawmakers criticized the move as a step backward for democracy. But Lee said Friday he believed Hau, 71, would bring political stability and social order to Taiwan. In a meeting with lawmakers, Lee described his decision as ``strong medicine'' to cure the island's soaring crime rate and worsening economy. Hau was appointed defense minister last year after being chief of the 500,000-member armed forces for eight years.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Erupts in Uzbek Town After Soccer Game Canceled
DOC.TEXT: Soccer fans angered by cancellation of a game looted and set fire to scores of buildings in a city in Uzbekistan during rioting that injured at least 44 people, news reports said Friday. The fans, many intoxicated, ran wild through the city of Andizhan in the Fergana Valley of eastern Uzbekistan on Wednesday. The Andizhan region, with a population of 1.6 million, is plagued by severe unemployment. Jobless number 80,000. Last summer, more than 100 people were killed in ethnic rioting between Uzbeks and another Turkish ethnic group, the Meskhetians, in the nearby city of Fergana. In the latest violence, rioters attacked the Andizhan regional Communist Party headquarters and the city prosecutor's office, as well as 125 other buildings, 79 stores and 36 homes, the official Tass news agency reported. An official at the party headquarters, reached by telephone, said it was too noisy to hear the caller because the walls and windows were missing. He refused to say anything more. The mob set fire to 13 stores, 46 workshops and dozens of homes, and destroyed 18 institutions, including libraries, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said. Interior Ministry troops restored order. The violence began when 10,000 fans waiting in afternoon heat were told a team from Tashkent, the Uzbek capital, had failed to show up for the game, Pravda said. The crowd began throwing rocks and beat up the chairman of the local soccer club, the newspaper said. Fans set fire to two police cars and to a car that was to have been given away in a drawing at the game, Pravda said. The injured included 13 Interior Ministry troops, 10 police officers and 11 civilians, Tass said. Pravda put the injury toll at 44. The independent news service Post Factum said the mob killed the stadium director and burned the stadium to the ground. However, Pravda and a spokesman for the republic's legislature, Eduard Tsoy, said there were no deaths. Tsoy also denied the stadium was destroyed. Armed with automatic weapons, the crowd rampaged through neighborhoods of Russians, Armenians and Jews, leaving the Armenian quarter smoldering, Post Factum said. The news service also quoted an unnamed member of the out-of-town team as saying the game was canceled because riots were planned for Andizhan that day. The reports could not be confirmed immediately because communications with Andizhan were cut. Akilov Said-Ali of the grass-roots political group Berlik in Tashkent said that Berlik members at the stadium tried to prevent violence by standing between the fans and the police. He said many of them were injured and that the local Berlik leader suffered two broken legs. Said-Ali and Tsoy said Adizhan was quiet Friday. Post Factum also said a large number of Moslems from the Fergana Valley traveled to Tashkent on Thursday to demand the retirement of the Central Asian mufti, 37-year-old Mohammadsadyk Mamayusupov. The group blames him for the Andizhan riots, the news service said. It did not elaborate. Said-Ali said the mufti met with representatives from Andizhan and other cities Thursday and set up a commission to look into their complaints. But he did not know any details. Mamayusupov was named mufti last year after his predecessor was accused of failing to lead a religious life. Mamayusupov moved quickly to win government approval for the opening of new mosques. Last year, there were only 200 mosques sprinkled across the five Central Asian republics. The republics _ Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Kirghizia, Turkmenia and Tadzhikistan _ occupy an area half the size of the continental United States.

DOC.HEAD: Cargo Plane Crashes While Trying to Land, Killing One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3-4th grafs, `Audra West...', to UPDATE with names of dead, injured crew member. Picks up 5th graf, `Jack Barrker...'.
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine cargo plane crashed and caught fire today as it attempted to land at the airport, killing one man and critically injuring another, authorities said. The plane was carrying packages from Raleigh to Wilmington when it crashed at the New Hanover County International Airport, said Jean Nipper of United Parcel Service. Audra West, spokeswoman for New Hanover Memorial Hospital, said two people were brought to the hospital, one dead on arrival and the other in critical condition. The plane belonged Tar Heel Aviation of Jacksonville, N.C., a charter service. Charles Brown, a pilot with Tar Heel, identified the dead crew member as co-pilot Darryl Banks, 24, of Trenton, N.C. The survivor is pilot David Sloan, 26, of Cinquapin, N.C., Brown said. Jack Barker of the Federal Aviation Administration in Atlanta said the Nomad 24 cargo plane attempted an instrument landing, but reported a missed approach. After the pilot turned back, the plane stalled and crashed about 7:30 a.m. Brenda Coffey of the county emergency services office said the plane crashed on a runway and caught fire.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Security Forces Kill 7 in Border Clash
DOC.TEXT: Indian security forces killed seven suspected Moslem militants as they crossed from Pakistan into India today in violence that left at least nine people dead in Jammu-Kashmir state, police and witnesses said. Indian news reports said 13 people died but the conflicting numbers could not immediately be reconciled. Militants and security forces clashed throughout the day in Srinagar, the capital of the state, and at least 10 people were wounded, witnesses said. The firefight occurred in the Ori sector, 93 miles north of Srinagar, security sources said. Indian troops killed seven men on the spot and wounded two others as they passed into India, the sources said on condition of anonymity. Troops captured five AK-47 automatic weapons, one rocket launcher, three anti-personnel mines and other weapons, they said. India accuses Pakistan of providing weapons and training to Moslem separatists in Kashmir. Pakistan denies the charge and accuses India of trying to crush a movement for self-determination. In Srinagar, a shootout between Moslem militants and security forces near a bazaar killed one police officer, Chief Constable Ali Mohamed. News reports said security forces killed a suspected militant during a village raid in the southern part of the state. The deaths brought to at least 326 the number of people killed since Jan. 20 when the Indian government began the crackdown on the separatist movement in the strategic state. Today's clashes in Srinagar included several bomb blasts. The crisis over Kashmir has heightened long-standing animosity between India and Pakistan. Both countries claim the mountainous region, which is split between them along a contested frontier where Indian and Pakistani troops face each other. The dispute flared into war in 1948 and 1965. On Thursday, a powerful right-wing Indian political party urged India's army to attack the alleged bases in Pakistan to ``clean out the terrorists.'' Jammu-Kashmir is the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. About 64 percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslems. Nationwide Moslems comprise only 12 percent of India's population of 880 million, while Hindus make up 82 percent. Meanwhile, 15 Sikh extremists impersonating government troops lured six Hindu men out of their homes in an remote Punjab village and shot them to death, a senior police official said today. The gunmen wore uniforms of the paramilitary Border Security Force when they arrived in Kotli Suratmallian. All 15 escaped, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Bullfighters Protest Hiring of Spaniards
DOC.TEXT: About 15 members of the French bullfighters' union occupied a chamber at Nimes City Hall on Friday, protesting that Spaniards were getting too many of the jobs at an upcoming bullfight festival. The sit-in began Thursday evening and was still in progress at midday Friday. The protesters demanded a meeting with the director of the city's stadiums, Simon Casas. Casas is the former president of the bullfighters' union and now administers the bullfight programs. According to the protesters, French bullfighters were given only two of about 30 jobs at the upcoming Pentecost festival, which is to consist of 13 separate bullfight programs between May 27 and June 4. The festival has drawn about 400,000 visitors annually in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Punishes University Because of Professor's Views
DOC.TEXT: The mayor has provoked a debate over academic freedom by refusing to give a new building to a university because one of its teachers questioned the existence of Nazi gas chambers. The professor, Bernard Notin, was suspended from teaching law courses in March but continues to teach economics at state-funded Jean Moulin University, named for the Lyon-based leader of the French Resistance. Notin's suspension came after an anti-racism organization filed a complaint regarding an article he wrote that challenged widely accepted accounts of the Holocaust. Mayor Michel Noir told reporters Thursday his refusal to transfer a publicly owned building to the university for new classroom space did not constitute interference in campus affairs. He said he merely wanted the university council to follow regulations which call for it to ``convene and deliberate'' if a teacher poses serious problems for the university. Noir said last weekend it was ``out of the question'' the city would provide new facilities to the university ``if Notin and other falsifiers of history continue to teach there.'' Notin has insisted on his right to freedom of opinion and said he has not used the classroom as a forum for his controversial views. The president of the university, Pierre Vialle, issued a communique saying the school as a whole should not have to bear responsibility for a controversy involving an individual. Noir, a member of the center-right Rally for the Republic party, was praised by a local leader of the governing Socialist party, Jean-Jack Queyranne. ``The freedom of research and expression at universities cannot serve as an alibi for those who insult the history and the memory of our people,'' Queyranne said. Bruno Gollnisch, a deputy for the extreme-right National Front in the European Parliament, said his party did not endorse Notin's views but was concerned about Noir's reprisal. ``If the revisionists are wrong, which is very possible, it nonetheless seems that one is less and less free to speak about all aspects of World War II,'' Gollnisch said.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Keep Everglades Blaze Out of Preserve
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with situation today, backfires beginning, recasts to put stress on canal being last barrier to preserve, picks up 7th graf, `The blaze ...; SUBS 11th graf, `Seminole Indians ..., to delete now-redundant first reference to Dempsey.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: A canal was the last barrier today separating the sprawling Big Cypress National Wildlife Preserve from a 25,000-acre Everglades fires that had already jumped one waterway, fire officials said. Crews concentrated on keeping the 4-mile-wide line of fire from crossing the L-67 levee and sweeping into the drought-parched preserve west of Miami. ``We have the potential of this burning into Big Cypress and some critcal land out here, some nice trees, and that could cause a problem,'' said state forest ranger Jim Taylor. The fire leaped across the L-67 canal Thursday but was pushed back. ``It did jump, but then we managed to get a helicopter out there and dump a couple of buckets of water on it,'' state Division of Forestry duty officer Peter Karayeanes said. ``We managed to put that one out and we just have the fire on the east side of the L-67 levee.'' L-67 is part of the statewide canal system built early in the century to drain off swamplands in southern Florida. State ranger Gene Dempsey said crews started backfires today to make sure the blaze stayed on the east side of the canal. Calmer winds late Thursday allowed them to take the night off. But firefighters were still concerned about the preserve. ``We feel very confident that we can keep the fire from going over the levee. We did it yesterday, and I think we can do it again.'' He said there are very few animals affected by the fire. Alligators are in the canals, and all other large animals such as deer and the endangered Florida panther have been living by water because of the severe drought. ``We have a few snakes and rodents scurrying away, but that's about it.'' The blaze, one of three outside Miami, did not threaten any inhabited areas. Another fire, in Everglades National Park about 27 miles southwest of the city, scorched 10,500 acres by late Thursday afternoon. Firefighters were confident they could control it, said park spokeswoman Darlene Koontz. Investigators determined the Everglades fire was man-made. ``With the conditions that we have out there, with the ecosystem in somewhat stress, we just really want to encourage people to be careful with fire,'' Koontz said. Seminole Indian firefighters spent Thursday battling a smaller blaze on their reservation in Broward County. After burning 800 acres, that fire appeared contained, Dempsey said. Fires are a normal part of the Everglades ecology, said park spokeswoman Pat Tolle, but this this year's fires worry environmentalists because the region's 20-month drought has left the region extremely dry. And the state is undergoing a heatwave. Normal high temperatures for this time of year in the Tampa Bay area are around 85 degrees. But temperatures hovered at 93 there Thursday and forecasters predicted highs to stay in the 90s at least through the weekend. Florida Power Corp. has called on its 1.1 million customers to conserve energy. ``We want everyone to understand that it's tight,'' utility spokesman Ray Blush said Thursday in St. Petersburg. The utility serves parts of the Gulf Coast and central Florida. Gov. Bob Martinez asked electric customers statewide to set thermostats at 78 degrees or higher and take other conservation steps to avoid the blackouts that affected much of Florida over Christmas.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Latvia's Parliament Declares Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with parliament also dropping `Soviet Socialist' from the republic's name, more color; Picks up 9th graf, `Members of ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: Latvia's parliament adopted a declaration of independence today, launching the Baltic republic's secession from the Soviet Union 50 years after it was forcibly absorbed by Moscow. The Supreme Soviet voted 138-0, with one abstention, to pass the measure, which calls for independence after an undetermined transition period. Fifty-seven anti-independence deputies refused to vote. When the results of the vote were announced via loudspeakers to a crowd of several hundred people outside parliament, a loud cheer went up. Then, those inside and outside the hall began singing ``God Bless Latvia,'' the republic's national anthem. The measure that made Latvia the last of the three Baltic republics to formally break with Moscow had needed a two-thirds majority, or 132 votes, to pass. The neighboring republic of Estonia has taken a similar step. The third Baltic republic, Lithuania, declared full independence on March 11, and the Kremlin since has imposed an economic blockade on the republic. The deputies also voted to drop the words ``Soviet Socialist'' from the republic's name, making it simply ``The Republic of Latvia.'' Two deputies walked out of the session during the vote, including Alfreds Rubiks, Latvia's Communist Party chief who earlier in the day had warned of mass demonstrations and strikes by non-Latvians if the measure had passed.
