As the time for the vote approached, young girls in gold headbands and bright pink skirts sang Latvian folk songs outside the Supreme Soviet building beneath red and white Latvian flags held aloft by pro-independence demonstrators. The Supreme Soviet, or parliament, put the independence declaration on the agenda despite complaints by some deputies that they were being rushed into a dangerous decision. The parliament is dominated by the grassroots Latvian People's Front. Members of the Latvian opposition complained they first saw the draft declaration only this morning. ``We are physically unable to give an answer today on this document,'' Sergejs Diemans told fellow legislators. ``Time must be taken to study it carefully.'' Deputy Leonids Alksnis warned that if the declaration passed, as expected, Moscow would apply heavy pressure on Latvia to rescind it. ``If we pass this declaration, Moscow will do the same thing to Latvia'' as it did to Lithuania, Alksnis said. Other deputies objected that Latvians had wanted to restore their independence for 50 years. In the end, the lawmakers voted 139-56 to address the measure today. ``This is our last possibility to survive, and we are going to take advantage of it. That is why we demand independence,'' said writer Alberts Bels. Scores of protesters from the non-Latvian population gathered on Cathedral Square with signs demanding the republic not copy Lithuania. A pro-independence rally was scheduled for later in the day. Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis advised his neighbors Thursday on a visit to Riga to ``be strong and have courage.'' He said Latvians, if they moved more slowly than Lithuania on the path to secession, would be ``trudging through a jungle.'' However, Latvia's ethnic balance is more delicate than Lithuania's and could slow steps toward independence. In Lithuania, 80 percent of the 2.8 million people are ethnic Lithuanian, but about 54 percent of Latvia's population of 2.7 million people are Latvian. Most of the rest are ethnic Russians, many of whom oppose independence. In the past year, Latvia has copied within months, and sometimes weeks, Lithuania's steps toward independnce. In December, it abolished the Communist Party's guaranteed monopoly on power; in February it condemned the 1940 act that formalized its annexation by the Soviet Union; and last month a large segment of its Communist Party broke from the Moscow-based Soviet party. Anatoly Gorbunov, who was re-elected president of Latvia during the parliamentary session, backed independence in a nomination speech Thursday. ``I believe that the renewal of a legally sovereign nation must be accomplished,'' he said, declaring it a ``normal way of life for all the residents of Latvia.'' Gorbunov, a 48-year-old former Communist Party functionary skilled at negotiating with Moscow, won 153 votes out of 196 cast.

DOC.HEAD: At Waste Expo, Garbage is Good
DOC.TEXT: The man with the two boxes of trash bags looked out of place amid the models in cocktail dresses, the stack of truck tires and the tie-dyed salespeople from The World's No. 1 Jewelry Company Serving The Sanitation Industry. ``I'm not trying to sell Cinch-Saks,'' Thomas W. Higgins confided. ``I'm trying to sell an idea.'' Higgins' idea _ clear Hefty Cinch-Saks _ might seem a trifle mundane. But last month's Earth Day somehow has Americans excited about a mundane task _ throwing out trash. And that has people very excited at Waste Expo '90, the annual convention of the National Solid Wastes Management Association. More than 10,000 people are at the Georgia World Congress Center, attending seminars _ like ``Women In Waste'' and ``Backyard Basics: How Composting Can Improve Your Bottom Line.'' They're looking over the latest new gee-gaws for their industry, including the Cram-A-Lot Compactor Sentry System, computer software and recycler-friendly garbage trucks. (Garbage trucks, it should be noted, look mighty strange when they are (a) clean and (b) surrounded by models in cocktail dresses.) ``If we have another Earth Day, everybody's going to be doing this,'' said Jerry Andregg, standing next to the Kann Curb Sorter garbage truck, a fancy white job with four compartments for four different kinds of garbage and a plastic masher in the middle. ``It's helped our business out,'' he said, ``it'' being Earth Day. ``And it's raised people's awareness _ how important it is to start recycling.'' ``The awareness here is nothing but recycling,'' said Doug McGee of Plastican. You know those big buckets that joint compound and school-cafeteria mayonnaise come in? Well, with color-coding, a hole for rainwater to drain out of and a snazzy logo on the front, Plastican makes them into bins for household recyclables. ``Everyone wants to do it,'' McGee said, ``it'' being recycling. ``But everyone's trying to figure out how to do it.'' That's what the guy with the Cinch-Saks figures. ``The most effective way to run a co-mingled curbside recycling program is to pick up the material in a clear bag,'' said Higgins, manager of Hefty Recycling Opportunities for the Mobil Chemical Co.'s Consumer Products Division. The idea, he explained, is that homeowners don't want 17 recycling bins cluttering up the garage, and cities don't want to pay the garbageman to dawdle at the curb, putting the brown beer bottles in one place, the clear juice bottles in another place and the newspapers in a third place. The answer: the clear garbage bag. Maybe, um, a clear Hefty Cinch-Sak? ``It's up to our marketing guys to get their share of the market,'' Higgins said. Over at the Dempster display (``a Waste-Quip company''), John L. Thomas, vice president for sales, is showing off the Recycle One, a gleaming white garbage truck with a side-loading window-box gizmo that dumps different kinds of garbage in the correct place in the truck. ``Earth Day has really brought it into focus,'' Thomas said, adding that recycling ``is the answer to our disposables problem.'' ``So many of our landfills are filling up,'' he said. ``We're running out of landfill space. One way to extend landfill life is to put less in them.'' Dempster and the other exhibitors at Waste Expo '90 have their biggest ever audience to pitch to; the convention's attendance of 10,000-plus is a record for the show. Some of them may need a few garbage trucks; others may need office trash cans or shredding machines. But Saul Brett Inc. wants to sell something to all of them. ``We're the only company with 14-karat jewelry for sanitation, from $115 to $5,000 _ in stock!'' said Jimmy Brett, who's hawking stuff while Saul's back in New York minding the store. The Brett company makes decals for garbage cans and garbage trucks. They've plastered the convention with signs and buttons bearing the ``DRUGS ARE GARBAGE'' message the company believes in. They make gold-colored garbage-can tie tacks. They even make some spiffy gold-and-diamond garbage-truck pins for the valued sanitation employee, or the supportive sanitation spouse. ``No one,'' Jimmy said, ``does it like we do.''

DOC.HEAD: Memorial Dedicated 20 Years After Campus Shootings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with official putting crowd size at 4,000, sted 1,000; recast. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Former Sen...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XKSU1, LaserColor XKSU3
DOC.TEXT: Thousands gathered solemnly in the rain today to hear calls for peace and reconciliation at the dedication of a memorial to four students killed in an anti-war protest 20 years ago at Kent State University. ``We do appreciate what has been done and who did it,'' said Florence Schroeder, mother of Bill Schroeder, one of the four students killed on by Ohio National Guardsmen on May 4, 1970. Mrs. Schroeder said she was convinced the death of her son and three other students helped to shorten the Vietnam War by increasing public opposition to American involvement in it. ``He absolutely did not die in vain,'' Mrs. Schroeder said at a news conference. Despite a steady rain, some 4,000 gathered for the midday dedication, according to a crowd estimate by Kent State Police Chief John Peach. Many Kent State students were not even born when the killings occurred. Gov. Richard Celeste said the 1970 shootings should serve as a source of learning rather than as a focus of bitterness. ``To those who suffered from that tragedy 20 years ago, I am sorry,'' Celeste said. ``It's time to turn the tragedy at Kent State of May 4, 1970, into a calling to peacemakers.'' The $100,000 granite memorial is the most ambitious attempt by the university to commemorate the dead and wounded. But about 200 student activists who wanted a larger memorial built and more student involvement in its planning waged a silent protest march during the dedication. The protesting students stood near the white tent, where ceremony participants spoke. Some of the students held up their arms, fists clenched or displaying the peace sign, and many others held up handmade signs reading ``Whose May 4th is it anyway?'' and ``Don't minimize student death.'' Thursday evening, some 2,000 people attended a candlelight ceremony to mark the deaths of Schroeder, Jeffrey Miller, Sandy Scheuer and Allison Krause. Nine other people were wounded in the shootings. Former Sen. George McGovern, keynote speaker at the dedication, called the incident ``the most tragic episode in American foreign policy history.'' The 1972 Democratic presidential candidate, who ran unsuccessfully against then-President Richard Nixon, said before the ceremony that the Kent State shootings and the death of two Jackson State University students in Mississippi 10 days later helped focus public attention on the war and opposition to it. He said the deaths touched ``a common note of humanity.'' At the dedication, McGovern called for U.S. reconciliation with Vietnam and the re-establishment of diplomatic ties. ``The war in Vietnam is unfinished,'' he said. ``The killing has stopped but the arrogance that produced it survives and so does the agony, the guilt and the separation.'' Until now, the shootings were marked only by a gravestone-size slab erected in 1971 in a corner of a parking lot where the tragedy occurred. The lack of a memorial reflected continuing political differences over an event that brought the Vietnam War home. Some viewed the shootings as an unprovoked act of state violence; others said unpatriotic protesters had finally gotten what was coming to them, although many of the victims were bystanders rather than activists. Campus police said they would maintain a discreet presence at the hilltop memorial site to keep order, but did not expect a disruption. To mark the anniversary of the shootings, a 12-hour candlelight vigil, an annual tradition, began at midnight on this 824-acre campus of 23,000 students. The vigil followed a cross-campus candlelight march by more than 2,000 people, most of them students. Hundreds of students milled around the scene. At each spot in a parking lot where a student died, a student stood this morning, roped off and encircled with candles. Kent State freshman Michelle Suttman of Madison said the reaction on campus to the anniversary was mixed. ``There's been a lot of indifference,'' she said. ``This is finals week.'' University President Michael Schwartz went to Kent State trustees with a proposal for a memorial eight years ago. Earlier suggestions for a memorial never got off the ground, university spokeswoman Janet Thiede said. Some veterans groups objected to the idea of a memorial and some people felt the smaller marker and the university's peace studies center were sufficient commemoration. The university originally said it would build a larger memorial but scaled back the plan when it failed to raise $1 million it needed. Some students and survivors complained the university's fund-raising effort was halfhearted. Student critics said university officials were not interested in calling attention to the shootings. Last month the university announced creation of four full-time scholarships in the names of the four dead students. The memorial was designed by Bruno Ast, a Chicago architect who was selected in a competition. Ast designed the memorial without calling for the names of the victims to be included, but he said he had no objections to last week's decision by the university to add a separate square granite slab with the names. The lack of the victims' names on the memorial had been a persistent sore point among students and survivors who wanted a more elaborate memorial. The anniversary didn't interest all segments of this campus community 40 miles southeast of Cleveland. ``They are not letting old wounds heal,'' senior Chuck Bulick of Mentor said Thursday. He called the shootings ``unfortunate, terrible,'' but said he also had read that student demonstrators had been unruly and had thrown rocks at Guardsmen called to restore order after fire destroyed an ROTC building. Most students' accounts of the shootings said the National Guardsmen, sent in by then-Gov. James A. Rhodes, were not threatened by the protesters when they opened fire.

DOC.HEAD: Bizarre Series Of Mishaps Mar London Theater Productions
DOC.TEXT: Falling scenery, curtains that won't go up and revolving stages that refuse to turn have caused a series of mishaps in London theaters in the last 10 days, prompting a safety investigation. The latest incident occurred Thursday night at a gala opening at the Royalty Theater of ``A Clockwork Orange.'' The curtain refused to go up for the second half of the Royal Shakespeare Company production. The star-studded audience downed free drinks offered by the embarrassed management as stage staff struggled for 15 minutes before getting the curtain to go up. On Monday, the Stephen Sondheim musical ``Sunday in the Park with George'' at the Lyttelton Theater was halted in mid-performance when a wooden tree, part of the scenery, fell from a hook as it was being carried off the stage. It narrowly missed an actor. Performances at the Lyttelton were canceled the next day. ``It is an extremely complicated set. It has simply been bad luck, but we can take no chances,'' said a theater spokesman. It was the second mishap to hit the musical. On April 23, an iron bar fell, but nobody was injured. On April 24, a hydraulic jack at the Olivier Theater broke down, preventing the revolving stage from turning. The play ``The School for Scandal'' was canceled in mid-performance when stage staff failed to get it working again. The comedy was playing to a packed house. Tickets were refunded. The actors' union Equity said in a statement this week that a working party comprising representatives of the union, stage staff and theater managers had been set up to investigate safety on stage as a result of the incidents.

DOC.HEAD: Lenin Plaques to Be Removed From Prague Walls
DOC.TEXT: All plaques associcated with the ``totalitarian regime'' of Communism, including two depicting Soviet founder Vladimir I. Lenin, will be removed from Prague city walls, the state news agency CTK said Friday. The removal was ordered by the city council just days after several streets and squares bearing names associated with Communist heroes, anniversaries and symbols were ordered renamed. CTK said the city council also ordered the removal of a statue of Julius Fucik, a Communist journalist executed by the Nazis in Berlin in 1943. The council also ordered the renaming of a historic exhibition ground bearing Fucik's name.

DOC.HEAD: As the Wall Crumbles, So Does Architect's Plans
DOC.TEXT: Marvin Cantor is a victim of German unification. Cantor's architectural firm spent two years designing plans to build a Washington embassy for East Germany. As he was drawing the last walls, the first crack was made in the Berlin Wall. East Germany, rapidly advancing toward union with its neighbor to the west, soon will cease to exist. Without a country, who needs an embassy? West Germany has a sprawling embassy on a verdant hill in northwest Washington. The East Germans have occupied one floor of an office building on the city's Embassy Row since establishing diplomatic relations with the United States in 1974. But the East Germans always viewed their quarters as temporary and sought an embassy building befitting their position as the nub of the Warsaw Pact and a major economic power in the Soviet bloc. In the early 1980s, the East Germans leased a lot in a planned complex of some two dozen embassies on International Drive, where several governments _ including Ghana and Israel _ already have moved. After another period of inactivity, East Germany commissioned Cantor's firm in early 1988 to design the new embassy offices, or chancery building as it's known in diplomatic parlance. Cantor completed the blueprints late last year. The East Germans were pleased, he said. The building would cost $6 million to $8 million to build and would occupy about 45,000 square feet. A full political union of the two Germanys is expected next year, but the sisters already have agreed on a treaty merging their economies. In a sign of things to come in Washington, the two embassies _ once separated by several miles of real estate and four decades of rival ideologies _ will hold their first joint function Monday with a screening of a television documentary on composer Johann Sebastian Bach. The final decision on the fate of the embassy project is still before the newly elected non-Communist government _ the first, and probably last, East Germans will know. ``It has to be reviewed,'' said Peter Janz, first secretary of the East German embassy. He said a decision was expected soon. Cantor believes that once the new government resolves the myriad pressing problems bedeviling the logistics of unification, it may suggest to West Germany that his plans be modified for an annex or consular section for the embassy of the unified Germany. ``Maybe that's just wishful thinking,'' he said. Either way, he has nothing to worry about. First, he expects to be paid. Second, for every country dropped from the U.S. diplomatic roster, a new one is tacked on. Cantor could be commissioned to build an embassy for Mongolia, which recently established diplomatic relations with the United States.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 3:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls for New Strategy in `New and Changing Times'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits throughout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, calling for ``a new Western strategy for new and changing times,'' said today he hopes an agreement on reducing troops and conventional arms in Europe can be signed this fall. Once such an agreement is reached, U.S.-Soviet talks should begin as soon as possible, aimed at reducing the number of short-range nuclear weapons stationed throughout Europe, Bush said in prepared remarks for the Oklahoma State University commencement ceremonies. On changes taking place within the Soviet Union, Bush said: ``President (Mikhail S.) Gorbachev has made profound progress in his country, reforms so fundamental that the clock cannot be turned back.'' But, Bush added, ``neither can we turn the clock ahead, to know for sure what kind of country the Soviet Union will be in years to come.'' Bush said that the Western alliance must plan for a less-militarized Europe that plays down the current focus on imminent war. ``We are entering a new age of freedom in a time of uncertainty, but great hope,'' Bush said. Looking forward to the NATO meeting he proposed for early this summer, Bush said: ``The alliance must join together to craft a new Western strategy for new and changing times.'' The U.S. role, he said, will be to support Europe militarily as long as the allies want. However, in light of democratic changes sweeping Eastern Europe, the political focus of NATO will increase and the military aspects will be different, Bush said. ``If the Soviet withdrawal continues and our arms-control efforts are successful, we must plan for a different kind of military presence focused less on the danger of an immediate outbreak of war,'' he said. He made the comments a day after announcing he is scrapping plans for upgrading battlefield nuclear weapons that are stationed mostly in West Germany. Bush said he wants NATO members to develop objectives for new arms control talks on U.S. and Soviet reductions of other short-range missiles. Bush, who in the past has only said that an agreement on reducing conventional forces in Europe should be completed by the 35 nations with an interest in Europe by the end of this year, today said he hoped it could be signed ``this fall.'' Elaborating on his call Thursday for a complete review of NATO's mission, Bush said he wants a June or July summit of alliance members to: _Assess the future of U.S. nuclear forces in Europe. _Begin preparations for U.S. -Soviet Talks on reducing short-range nuclear missiles. _Set objectives for follow-up negotiations once the treaty is signed to reduce U.S. and Soviet conventional forces in Europe. _Develop NATO goals for the future of the 35-nation pact called the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which includes Eastern European nations as well as members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``Our enemy today is uncertainty and instability,'' Bush said in stating a continued need for NATO's military role. ``The alliance will need to maintain a sound collective military structure with forces in the field backed by larger forces that can be called upon in crises,'' he said. Uncertainty centers around the future of Soviet change and motivation, including how Gorbachev handles the Lithuanian breakaway move, he said. ``The only noble answer lies in the dialogue that results in unencumbered self-determination for Lithuania,'' Bush said. The president told the Oklahoma students he would use a series of commencement addresses this year to talk about democratic change in the world. Bush on Thursday announced he was abandoning an upgrade of the short-range Lance missile and cancelling plans to further modernize nuclear artillery shells in Europe. ``As democracy comes to Eastern Europe and Soviet troops return home, there is less need for nuclear systems of the shortest ranges,'' the president said at a news conference Thursday. He also called for a summit meeting of the 16 NATO nations to ``launch a wide-ranging NATO strategy review for the transformed Europe of the 1990s.'' ``This summit should address first the future political mission of the alliance, reaffirming its crucial role in managing and stabilizing the transformation of Europe,'' he said. ``The revolutionary changes transforming Europe are moving us from the postwar era to a new era in history beyond containment'' of Warsaw Pact forces, Bush said. Bush's announcement that he would not replace the 700 aging Lance missiles with a more powerful version came in the face of waning enthusiasm in Congress and Europe for the modernization. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher lauded the president's announcement, saying, ``This shows the alliance takes into account the changed conditions in their full totality.'' Bush also told reporters that he sometimes worries about the domestic staying power of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, who will visit Washington May 30-June 3 for a superpower summit. ``I do from time to time worry about a takeover that will set back the whole process'' of reform in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mills Goes Coed After 138 Years As Women-Only College; Students Stage Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with women staging new protest. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `At an off-campus...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Barbara Bush-Commencement, Bjt
LaserPhoto OAT1 of May 3
DOC.TEXT: Angry Mills College students blockaded buildings today during a raucous demonstration one day after trustees voted to admit undergraduate men at the exclusive women's institution. Several hundred students took part in the blockade, surrounding major buildings at the college, including the administration building and the president's home. Trustees, faced with declining enrollment and revenues, voted Thursday to accept men as undergraduates rather than dip heavily into the school's $70 million endowment. They announced their decision on Mills Common and were jeered by some students yelling ``Traitors!'' During today's protest, some students parked cars in front of campus buildings, honking horns and setting off car alarms in a bid to disrupt classes. ``We're trying to shut down the operation of the college until they reverse their decision,'' said Esther Barragan, a senior economics major. ``We're not going to take this lightly.'' The noisy demonstration brought Mary Metz, the school's president, out of her home about 9 a.m. The students, with radios at full blast, were shouting, ``We will not accept this!'' Metz spoke with some students, agreeing to meet with them this afternoon or on Saturday. However, she said, Thursday's decision by the trustees to admit men would not be reversed. She acknowleged that the demonstration had disrupted classes and school administration. Many women at Mills said they would not return next year because of the trustees' vote, ending 138 years as a female enclave. Current undergraduate enrollment is about 775. ``I can't believe they would ignore us like that,'' Amy Hutto, one of the undergraduates who shaved their heads in protest, said Thursday. ``I haven't gone to class all week because this was on my mind. I'll strike now. I don't know if I ever want to go back.'' Protesters, and some experts on women's education, said that coeducational programs can exclude women from opportunities because men tend to be more aggressive in the classroom. Trustees had been considering the move for more than a year. Enrollment in Mills' 33 undergraduate programs is down 4.2 percent from three years ago and more than 20 percent below the 1,000 students needed to balance the $24 million annual budget, said economists at the school, where the tuition is almost $12,000. Men are already admitted as graduate students. ``If Mills is to maintain academic quality and financial strength in the long run, it must increase its undergraduate enrollment to at least 1,000,'' board chairman Warren Hellman said, amid screams that nearly drowned him out. ``The trustees believe coeducation will enable Mills' excellent undergraduate academic program to reach more students,'' he said. Metz predicted that 20-30 men would enroll the first co-ed semester. She said efforts would be made to let women continue taking leadership roles and not be dominated by male students. At an off-campus news conference later, Hellman said 32 members of the 35-member board took part in the vote and an ``overwhelming majority'' were in favor of coeducation. About 60 percent of the board members are women. Most teachers had opposed the plan to admit men to the college, the only single-sex college in Northern California. Two women's colleges are located in Southern California and there are 94 nationwide. There were 298 women's schools 30 years ago. ``The whole environment on a campus changes when men are admitted, no matter how hard the school tries to prevent that,'' said Peter Mirijanian, director of communications for the Women's College Coalition in Washington D.C. ``Male students are taken more seriously and women suffer.'' Wheaton College in Massachusetts went co-ed three years ago, and a Harvard study last year showed men now dominate the classroom. Analysis of videotaped classes at Wheaton showed that men made up 10 percent of the classroom but did a quarter of the speaking, according to the study by Catherine Krupnick. ``You ask `What's the meaning of life?' and four hands will shoot up, most of them male,'' she said. ``College catalogues should carry warnings: The value you receive will depend on your sex.'' But at Colby-Sawyer College in New London, N.H., which decided to go coeducational last year, spokesman Byron Champlin said less than 10 percent of women interested in colleges look at women's schools. Janette Robinson, 21, of Duxbury, Mass., who will graduate from Colby-Sawyer this month and was among the most vocal coeducation opponents last year, said accepting men wasn't such a bad idea after all. ``The people who were strongly against it have already graduated, so I think the men will be fairly well accepted on campus,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Diplomat Seeking Asylum in U.S.
LaserPhoto WX14
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese diplomat said Friday that he has defected to the United States because he supports the pro-democracy movement in China. ``Many democracy activists in China now are being persecuted and arrested, and my situation would not be different,'' Xu Lin, who dealt with Chinese students in the United States, said at a news conference. Xu said his application for political asylum was ``in process.'' Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, declined to say whether an application had been received. Wu Zurong, first secretary in the press office at the Chinese Embassy, said he was not familiar with the defection. Xu said at the news conference that he was the fifth person connected with the Chinese Embassy here to defect since the June 4 crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. Xu, who said he left the embassy Wednesday night, would not disclose the whereabouts of his wife and daughter because he was concerned for their safety. He said he was assigned to Washington for a four-year tour in July 1988. In March, he said, he was told that his tenure would be shortened by two years. He said he has supported the student movement by helping students in the United States renew their passports and avoiding reporting their activities to authorities. ``Since June 1989, one year after my arrival, China has stepped backward into tragedy and totalitarian repression,'' Xu said. ``Today, the opportunity for reform does not exist.'' Liu Yongchuan, president of the Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars, praised Xu's action. ``His defection is to demonstrate that he has totally lost confidence in the current Chinese government, and that he can no longer tolerate to serve this regime,'' Liu said. ``We believe that Mr. Xu's action represents the wish of the majority of Chinese government officials.'' The student federation, based in Washington, was formed last year to protect the rights of an estimated 40,000 Chinese students in the United States. It also says it seeks to promote democracy in China. Xu said 70 people had defected since the Tiananmen Square crackdown.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Meets Shevardnadze to Discuss Germany, Arms Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Baker-Shevardnadze talks, new quotes; Picks up 4th graf, `Baker also ...'
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III today tried to convince the Soviet Union that a united Germany's membership in NATO would not upset the delicate East-West balance in Europe. Baker met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who said he was pleased by U.S. plans to cancel new short-range nuclear missile deployments in West Germany. Shevardnadze also said he and Baker had a ``very constructive and useful conversation'' about arms control issues. But, Shevardnadze told reporters, they had not settled any of their differences over restricting long-range nuclear missiles during their 3{-hour session. Baker said: ``We'll just have to wait and see.'' He was referring to the talks he was to hold with Shevardnadze on such sticking points as air- and sea-launched cruise missles in Moscow on May 16-19. Earlier in the day, Shevardnadze flatly ruled out NATO membership for a united Germany. Baker met today with Chancellor Helmut Kohl before beginning his talks with the Soviet Union over Germany's future and lagging arms control talks. The Baker-Shevardnadze meeting came a day after the United States announced it will not modernize short-range nuclear missiles in Europe or deploy new ones. The Western allies announced they will meet in London in late June and hold a 35-nation summit, including the Soviet Union, by the end of the year in Paris. Baker also offered to consider withdrawing some of the short-range Lance missiles now based in West Germany if the Soviets drop their objections to NATO membership for a united Germany. In comment late Thursday in Tass, Vladimir Bogachev, the official Soviet news agency's military analyst, said: ``Let us hope that, accepting in principle the Soviet proposal for talks on tactical nuclear weapons and suspending modernization of Lance missiles and nuclear artillery, Washington does not at the same time intend to give a go-ahead for the deployment of more dangerous air-based nuclear missiles in Europe.'' New U.S. air-to-ground missiles, if mounted on tactical aircraft such as the F-111B fighter-bomber, would be capable of striking targets well inside Soviet borders, Bogachev wrote. Shevardnadze called the U.S. arms-reduction announcement a ``good decision,'' but also noted that the Soviets were the first to propose eliminating short-range nuclear weapons. ``We had proposed it a long time ago and offered it,'' he said. ``We have already almost completely destroyed this class of rockets.'' Behind Thursday's decisions is a determination by the allies to respond to the historic political change sweeping Europe and finding a new role for NATO after 31 years of eyeing the Red Army suspiciously over an East-West divide that is now melting away. But the 35-nation summit depends on completion of a treaty to reduce troops, tanks, airplanes, helicopters and artillery in Europe. NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner on Thursday accused the Soviets of ``foot-dragging'' in the negotiations in Vienna. Baker, meanwhile, said at a separate news conference in Brussels Thursday that ``the negotiations have not proceeded as rapidly as we would have thought,'' but deferred making a judgment until he saw Shevardnadze later today. Baker arrived in Bonn today and met with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and Kohl. Shevardnadze also met with Kohl, just minutes after Baker departed. No details were immediately available. Baker's meeting with Shevardnadze was expected to focus primarily on arms control and be followed by more intensive talks in mid-May in the Soviet Union. By then, Baker said, ``we'll know a lot more.'' The talks also hold the key to how President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will address reducing armories during their summit beginning May 30 in Washington. Another projected treaty to set limits on long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines is also running into obstacles at the negotiating table in Geneva. Bush and Gorbachev would like to at least initial a framework agreement on key issues, but officials on both sides are skeptical of meeting the deadline. Baker and Shevardnadze will meet again Saturday with the foreign ministers of Britain, France and the two German nations to discuss one of the trickiest obstacles to creating a united Germany _ figuring out how to keep it from disrupting the European balance of power. There are widespread concerns in Europe that a stronger Germany could again pose a threat to countries overrun during the two world wars. The Soviet Union has consistently ruled out NATO membership for a united Germany. ``We consider a unified Germany as an important factor of stability and peace in Europe,'' Shevardnadze said today. ``For such a giant to belong to one bloc, one alliance ... will not create conditions for stability.'' The Soviets have called for a neutral Germany. The United States and its NATO partners view membership in the alliance as the best insurance policy. At their meeting Thursday, they agreed Germany would not have nuclear or chemical weapons and insisted that a united Germany belongs in NATO. In a move that appeared aimed at allaying Soviet security concerns, the foreign ministers supported allowing Soviet troops to remain in East Germany after unification during a transition period. Until now, East Germany has served both as a loyal Soviet military ally and a buffer against U.S. nuclear missiles and troops in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Ban Asked on Cigarette Vending Machines
DOC.TEXT: New York City's health and consumer chiefs urged lawmakers to ban cigarette machines. Health Commissioner Woodrow A. Myers Jr. and Consumer Affairs Commissioner Mark Green spoke at a City Council committee hearing Thursday on two bills designed to keep children away from tobacco. One bill would prohibit free distribution of cigarettes in the city; the second would ban cigarette machines from places where minors might have easy access to them. Melinda Sidak of the Tobacco Institute told the hearing her trade association considers smoking ``an adult practice.'' But she opposed the bills, saying 80 percent of vending machines are already in places inaccessible to children, such as industrial plants, bars and cocktail lounges. She said the industry opposes giving free cigarettes to people under 21, but noted that the bill would prohibit free samples to adults as well. Since October, at least 20 Minnesota cities have prohibited or restricted the machines. And a measure pending in Congress would ban them in any location accessible to people under 18.

DOC.HEAD: Relentless Volcano Finally Shuts Down Beach Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with church loaded onto truck. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Civil defense...'.
DOC.TEXT: Seven years after it began gobbling homes, creeping lava from the Kilauea Volcano cut through the heart of this beach town today, threatening the general store and forcing congregants to move a church. A swift-moving finger of lava barely bypassed the Kalapana Store and Drive-In and came to within little more than 100 yards of the Star of the Sea Church before it was loaded onto a flatbed truck for transfer to a safer place. Workers had to use a bulldozer to raise a corner of the foundation after the historic church, known as the ``painted church'' because of the brightly colored murals inside, refused to budge. County civil defense chief Harry Kim said the church would be taken a mile out of town, where homes evacuated from Kalapana sit. Church officials have yet to decide where to relocate the church. Earlier, he had said that efforts to move the church were delayed because authorities were busy tending to three homes full of belongings that the lava unexpectedly cut off. Civil defense officials kept worried and grieving residents at a safe distance today. The officials had sealed off the community Thursday as the lava flow headed directly for the center of town. ``It is a community coming to death,'' the church's Sister Mary Helen said. ``The immediate loss is a loss of community. Something we've loved all through the years is going.'' At the heart of the community since 1963 was the store and drive-in owned by 82-year-old Walter Yamaguchi, who cleaned off shelves and stopped serving hot foods under an order to close. Jim Halpin, who lived in the Kalapana Gardens subdivision for nearly six years and watched his home destroyed last week, said he would move back as soon as officials let people return, something that could take years because the lava has to cool. He stopped at Yamaguchi's store to say goodbye. ``Walter's like everybody's uncle,'' he said. ``I came to say goodbye and get that last container of chocolate milk.'' Two homes were destroyed Thursday, bringing to 131 the number burned since Kilauea started its present eruption Jan. 3, 1983. No more homes were destroyed by the unpredictable flow by early today. George Hook, owner of a construction company that offered to relocate the church for free, said it will be taken to a clearing just outside of town and remain there until church officials decide on a new location. Members of another church, Kalapana Mauna Kea Congregational Church, across from Star of the Sea, voted not to relocate, saying to do so would nullify their faith in God. ``If we move it, it will defeat the whole purpose of our Christian faith,'' said Bernice McKeague, church moderator. ``Our people will be here to watch it go. This tiny church is a witness to the world because the foundation is strong and we stand on that foundation.'' This morning lava was abutting a rock wall surrounding the church, and authorities told the congregation they could not go inside. ``The book is closed. We open a new book today,'' McKeague said.

DOC.HEAD: Cadets Reprimanded for Cheating on Exam
With PM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Seven of 18 senior Army ROTC cadets at Oklahoma State University cheated on an examination, but still will be commissioned, officials said. Four of the seven will graduate today at ceremonies addressed by President Bush, according to Lt. Col. Conrad McHugh, head of the university's Department of Military Science. The four will be commissioned at ceremonies later in the day that Bush won't attend. McHugh said three of the seven cadets still have some college requirements to meet before graduation and commissioning. ``The seven are being given an administrative letter of reprimand that goes in their official file,'' McHugh said. McHugh said the decision by the commanding general of the 3rd Army ROTC region to allow the students who cheated to be commissioned was ``even-handed.'' He declined to release the cadets' names. The investigation began about 10 days after a March 20 test on the military justice system when a cadet said there had been cheating. The one-hour test had been unmonitored, as is normal under the seniors' honor code. A three-day closed hearing weeded out the cheaters, McHugh said. ``They have the right to decline to testify, but everyone came forward and talked,'' McHugh said. McHugh said after commissioning, some of the cadets will go into the U.S. Army, the Army Reserve, the Army National Guard.

DOC.HEAD: Man Jailed After Trying to Pay Fine With Pennies
DOC.TEXT: A penny saved may be a penny earned, but Gary Wagner only earned time in jail when he tried to use pennies to pay a $441 fine. He spent three hours in the Wood County Jail for contempt. County Magistrate Charles ``Ed'' Plum levied the fine early this year after Wagner pleaded guilty to battery after shoving a neighbor. Monday was his deadline for paying the fine, and he showed up lugging 12 canvas bags filled with pennies. The magistrate on duty, Margaret Monroe, told Wagner he had to collect the pennies into rolls of 50. After they argued awhile, Monroe called Plum into the courtroom, and he told Wagner the same thing. When Wagner again refused, Plum cited him for contempt and fined him $150. Wagner, 33, refused a third request to put the pennies into rolls. Plum hit him with a 10-day jail term, saying it would give him time to wrap up the change. Wagner's parents paid the $441 three hours after he was jailed. Plum dropped the contempt charge and additional fine.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Poised to Sweep Out Remaining Communists
With AM-Baker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germans on Sunday will vote in local elections that likely will remove vestiges of Communist control and virtually complete the revolution that began a year ago. The balloting will turn over to local hands the obedient bureaucracies that were carefully controlled by the former Stalinist leadership. ``Now must the self-reliance of the communities be realized,'' said Wolfgang Berghofer, the mayor of Dresden and a former Communist who is seeking to retain his post. The balloting also may provide a gauge of the current mood toward German unification, a process that is speeding toward completion. There have been widespread protests in recent weeks by workers afraid that their factories will close when forced to compete with Western commerce. Experts met in East Berlin on Friday to continue talks on merging the economies of the German states, and the superpowers prepared for talks Saturday in the West German capital on the international implications of a united Germany. The elections will probably mean the end of work for hundreds of former Communists still holding power on the local level. ``It's similar to the old de-Nazification campaign after the war,'' said Heinrich Vogel, a political analyst with the West German Institute for Eastern and International Studies in Cologne, West Germany. ``This is going to be a long-standing moral issue with this society.'' While elected leaders may be thrown out, Vogel said Friday that many of the bureaucrats running city departments may be retained. Many cannot be replaced because of their knowledge, he said. The local balloting follows the country's first free national elections on March 18 and will complete a cycle that began a year ago. The last local elections were held May 7, 1989, when the Communist leaders claimed that nearly 99 percent of the voters chose candidates from Communist-approved parties. The small protests that traditionally followed such results did not end as in past years and instead evolved into the popular revolt that exploded in mass demonstrations in October. The rallies led to the fall of four decades of hard-line socialism and the opening of the Berlin Wall in November. Now, the retooled and renamed Communist party is having trouble finding candidates to compete in the elections. Near the cities of Erfurt and Dresden, there are no candidates. The Communist party, now called the Party of Democratic Socialism, still finished third in the national elections and is likely to do well in East Berlin, a stronghold of support. ``It takes enormous bravery to run as a candidate for the PDS,'' said party leader Gregor Gysi. Candidates for the conservative Christian Democratic Union of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, and the left-leaning Social Democrats, are likely to capture most local posts. Although the Social Democrats have joined de Maiziere's broad governing coalition, they favor more social guarantees to protect East Germans from skyrocketing prices and the loss of subsidized housing and food. More than 12 million voters in 7,800 cities, districts and other municipalities are eligible to vote in the elections. Candidate lists in many communities are huge and run the gamut. Sixty-two parties and more than a quarter-million candidates are registered to run. In the city of Rostock, 20 candidates from the German Beer Drinkers Party alone are seeking election to the city council. Perhaps the most interesting elections are in Leipzig, where the protests against Communism began last year. In a true precursor to a united Germany, the Social Democrat candidate for mayor, Hinnrich-Lehman Gruber, has been allowed to run even though he is a city council member in the West German city of Hanover.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Contributor Convicted of Illegal Cranston Donation
DOC.TEXT: A businessman has been convicted of making an illegal donation designed to aid the 1986 re-election campaign of Sen. Alan Cranston. Michael Goland, 43, also was acquitted Thursday on four misdemeanor counts of conspiracy and making false statements. The jury deadlocked on a felony charge of making a false statement. ``I am pleased for the acquittal,'' Goland said outside court. ``I'm incredibly upset for the one I was found guilty on.'' U.S. District Judge Ronald S.W. Lew set sentencing for July 16. Goland, whose first trial ended in a deadlocked jury last July, could receive up to one year in jail and $360,000 in fines. Goland was convicted of secretly paying $120,000 for a television advertisement for Senate candidate Edward B. Vallen of the American Independent Party. Prosecutors said the effort was part of an eleventh-hour campaign designed to divert votes from Cranston's Republican opponent, Rep. Ed Zschau. The California Democrat won the election with 3,646,672 votes, or 49.29 percent. Zschau received 3,541,804 votes, or 47.87 percent. The contribution was illegal because the television commercial it produced falsely claimed at the end that it was financed by the Vallen for Senate Committee. No such committee existed. Goland insisted that an aide failed to fix the discrepancy, and he was not aware of it. No evidence was presented at trial that showed Cranston knew of the 1986 plan. The senator also was not implicated in election law violation charges brought against Goland. Goland is a supporter of Israel and had backed Cranston because of the senator's record of support for that country.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf of 2nd item to CORRECT to Nations' sted Nation's
DOC.TEXT: Entertainer Olivia Newton-John decided to throw a little dirt of her own to counter neighborhood complaints that the 6,000-square-foot mansion she is building in Malibu constitutes an environmental disaster. ``Dirt and garbage have never been dumped on the beach or in the ocean,'' the singer said Thursday in a statement. ``Any materials that were temporarily placed during construction were native to the beach, i.e. sand.'' Neighbors suing Newton-John and her husband, Matt Lattanzi, claim that trees and plants have been ripped out and beach cliffs destroyed to make room for the $2 million estate. ``This la an environmental tragedy because trees died for the paper that was used to spread false accusations against me,'' said Newton-John, the Australian-born entertainer who serves as the United Nations' goodwiwsuit representsll ambassador for the environment. Residents who live along the Malibu coastline, however, charge that Newton-John's construction crews have dumped tons of dirt into the ocean and turned the water's edge a murky brown.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Prime Minister Criticizes Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, with editing.
DOC.TEXT: The visiting prime minister of Lithuania criticized President Bush today for doing nothing more than calling for ``good faith'' negotiations in her country's independence showdown with the Soviet Union. ``Simply making statements that there should be cooperation and urging Lithuania to sit down at the bargaining table is not sufficient at this time, when the Soviet Union is interfering in Lithuania's relationships with Western countries,'' Kazimiera Prunskiene said a day after meeting with Bush. However, Mrs. Prunskiene said it was too early to ask the United States to impose economic sanctions against Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in an effort to prod him toward accepting Lithuanian independence. She also said she did not favor granting trade favors to the Soviets. Doing that, she said, ``would be providing implicit support for their actions.'' Mrs. Prunskiene called for the United States to grant formal diplomatic recognition to Lithuania. Such a move, she said, ``would be a logical consequence'' of the longstanding American position that it does not recognize the Soviet annexation of her country. She said the refusal of Western nations to recognize an independent Lithuania now is ``the main factor'' in the Soviets' refusal to accept Lithuania's secession as an accomplished fact. Mrs. Prunskiene made her comments and replied to questions at an appearance at the National Press Club. She backed away from calling on the American government to punish the Soviets economically, saying, ``We would hope the imposition of economic sanctions would be held in reserve as a threat to encourage sitting down at the negotiation table, but we are not looking for a situation where the Soviet people are forced to suffer.'' On Thursday, in a meeting with Bush in the Oval Office, Mrs. Prunskiene failed to budge the president from his hands-off stance. Bush has limited himself in the dispute between the Soviets and the tiny breakaway republic to expressions of hope that the issue can be ironed out in peaceful negotiations. He has expressed confidence that ultimately Lithuania would be free. Mrs. Prunskiene visited the National Archives today to look at America's Declaration of Independence, and she said that seeing it made her think it would be a mistake for her people to back down now from their own declaration. The prime minister found many sympathetic listeners as she made the rounds Thursday in Washington. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., took her by the hand and led her across the Senate floor. And members of the Young Americans for Freedom, accustomed to demonstrating against communism, shouted outside the Heritage Foundation headquarters in support of a woman who until three months ago was a rising star in the Communist Party, a member of the Supreme Soviet. ``Freedom yes, Gorby no,'' they chanted. ``Lithuania, don't give in.'' As she must have anticipated, Bush refused to recognize the new democratic government in Lithuania as an independent country. And the president refused anew to apply economic pressure on Gorbachev to call off his embargo, designed to make Lithuania abandon its secessionist notions. Instead, after the two met for 45 minutes Thursday in the Oval Office, Bush called again for ``good-faith dialogue,'' stressed his abhorrence of ``intimidation,'' and reminded his guest that the United States has never recognized ``the forcible incorporation of the Baltic states into the U.S.S.R.'' Mrs. Prunskiene, 47, introduced as ``a courageous woman from a courageous country,'' told the conservative Heritage Foundation she got the impression that the president at least was not ``indifferent'' to Lithuania's plight. ``I made it clear to President Bush that the Lithuanian nation is awaiting basic support from him,'' she said. Everywhere she sought to drive home one point: ``You do not have to choose between Lithuania and Gorbachev.'' She argued that Gorbachev would be strengthened by the existence of an independent Lithuania. It would help him ``overcome the reactionary forces which oppose not only independence for the Baltic states'' but his reforms as well, she said. Mrs. Prunskiene said she told Bush the same thing _ ``It was not an either-or choice, either Lithuania or Gorbachev.'' In any event, she said, ``Even the world's darling does not have the monopolistic right to decide the fate of other nations.'' Through all her rounds, she heard disagreement in public only once. It fell to a liberal Democrat, Rep. Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts, to espouse support for the position ``the Bush administration has wisely pursued.'' He said it would be wrong to punish Gorbachev for the sins of Stalin. ``America has a commitment to the principle of national self-determination,'' Markey told Mrs. Prunskiene at a meeting of the U.S. Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a human rights monitor. ``On the other hand, Americans also want Gorbachev to succeed in his program of reforms,'' Markey said.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Says Economy Should Give Democrats Foot Up in '92
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon, a veteran political prognosticator, says that only serious trouble in the economy would give Democrats a chance to recapture the White House in 1992. And, said Nixon in a television interview aired Friday night, the Democrat who best could challenge George Bush if the economy turns sour is New York Gov. Mario Cuomo. The interview, one of a series the former president has done this week to promote his new book, was broadcast on public television stations. Nixon said Bush is popular because of a ``mistake-free administration.'' The Democratic opposition, he said, is the weakest in 50 years. ``Cuomo would be able to seize on the haves vs. the have-not issue more effectively than any of the other Democrats because of his appeal,'' Nixon said. ``Cuomo has high intelligence. He has heart, or at least he appears to have, and that's what matters.'' Nixon called Cuomo a demagogue on foreign policy, a term he also applied to Richard Gephardt, the House Majority Leader. ``He's hurt himself by demagoguing on the Japanese issue,'' Nixon said about Gephardt, who has been the most outspoken foe of Japanese trade practices. ``He sounds as if he doesn't really mean it because he goes so far in doing so. I think he's losing some of his basically Democratic constituency as a result.'' Nixon said he seldom offers advice to Bush because ``there's nothing that you appreciate less than having well-intentioned (people), even former presidents, calling and saying, `Why don't you do this, why don't you do that?' ``The president's problems are basically not primarily with his enemies, they're with his friends, who think they know how to run the thing better than he does.'' As he did in his book, Nixon talked about Watergate, but said: ``I really think that 18 years of Watergate is enough. I really haven't got anything to add to it.'' Nixon said he hadn't changed his mind, either, about the news media. ``I am a conservative,'' he said, ``I was probably one of their favorite pin-up boys. They'd have a photograph of me over the press club bar and they'd throw darts into it.'' He has no doubts, he said, that members of the news media lean to the left in their reporting. ``I treasure my good relations with many members of the press. They are not slobs, as some people think. They are not inaccurate, as many people think ... but the press is generally biased.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain, France Announce New Cooperation in Defense, Security
DOC.TEXT: Britain and France, which have jealously guarded the independence of their nuclear forces, announced Friday they will forge closer links in security and defense matters. The French and British defense ministers later announced they were looking at the possibilities of cooperation on unspecified nuclear programs. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Francois Mitterrand of France spoke at a news conference during the annual Anglo-French summit. It was held a day after President Bush announced that short-range Lance missiles in Germany, which will become obsolete in 1995, will not be replaced. Mrs. Thatcher, who had favored a new Lance missile, said Bush's decision increased the importance of modernizing the present ``free-falling nuclear bombs ... to a missile from air-to-ground.'' Mitterrand endorsed Bush's decision on the Lance, ``which is the position I had in fact called for myself in 1988.'' He said France wants to link modernization or reductions in nuclear weapons to concrete results from Vienna talks on reducing conventional forces. ``Both of us as independent nuclear deterrent powers _ the only two in Europe ... we feel we should cooperate more closely on security and defense matters,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``We have asked our foreign and defense ministers to supervise a program of enhanced cooperation on these issues with particular emphasis on future security arrangements in Europe,'' she said. ``No field is precluded from such cooperation,'' said Mitterrand. ``Let's move forward. We will not overnight achieve coordination as complete and as full as I would wish, but we will move forward.'' Britain and France have not included their nuclear arsenals in the superpower arms reduction talks. Both countries maintain they need nuclear weapons as an essential minimal deterrent, and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in recent years has not pressed the issue. Mrs. Thatcher said her talks with Mitterrand focused on the situation in the Soviet Union and East-West relations. Mitterrand told reporters he shares Bush's fears for the stability of the Soviet government, saying he detects ``certain elements of fragility, things that could become dangerous.'' Bush told reporters Thursday that he sometimes worries about Gorbachev's staying power and the possibility of a ``takeover that will set back the whole process'' of reform in the Soviet Union. But Mitterrand said: ``We aren't gambling on his failure. ... the hypothesis that we're definitely working on is the continuation of the renovation process that we very much hope for, and that we hope will succeed.'' Mrs. Thatcher avoided direct comment on Bush's fears. ``President Gorbachev has done wonders. He has brought about a complete transformation in East-West relations and I think has been the first person to have the courage to see that the Communist system would not work for the Soviet Union,'' she said. ``I personally both hope and expect that he will continue as President Gorbachev of the Soviet Union,'' she said. Both leaders expressed hope that the crisis over Lithuania, the Soviet republic that declared its independence from Moscow, will be resolved at the negotiating table. ``We still think that the situation can best be resolved by continued discussions and we hope those discussions are coming near to being brought about,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. She added that she planned to meet Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene when she comes to London. The leaders met at Waddesdon Manor, a stately home 30 miles northwest of London. Defense secretaries Tom King of Britain and Jean-Pierre Chevenement of France also met Friday and agreed to expand their program of joint military exercises beyond 1992 and look at the possibilities of cooperation on a future frigate. A French helicopter regiment will join in British army field exercises in Germany in September 1992 and other exercises. An exchange of helicopter pilots is also being established, they announced.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Earmarks Additional Funds for Refugees
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has authorized an additional $7 million for a United Nations group that channels assistance to Palestinian refugees, the State Department said Friday. Richard Boucher, deputy spokesman for the department, said more money was needed because the number of refugees has been increasing. The donation brings the total U.S. contribution for 1990 to $57 million in support of education and vocational training programs as well as medical and relief services for more than 2 million Palestinian refugees. The U.N. Relief and Works Agency administers the aid.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Spotted Owl Plan Would Mean More Violence, Divorce, Suicide
DOC.TEXT: A government report says efforts to save the rare northern spotted owl from extinction could lead to social upheaval in the Pacific Northwest, including increased rates of violence, divorce and suicide. The study anticipates the environmental effort would cause workers to relocate, real estate values to fall and rural areas to unite to ward off environmentalists. Timber harvests on federal lands in the Northwest would be cut nearly in half by 1995, costing the region at least 13,000 jobs if a proposed owl recovery plan is adopted, the U.S. Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management said in a study released Thursday. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is to decide by June 23 whether to list the northern spotted owl as an endangered species. The report focused on the economic impact of a proposal by a panel of government scientists led by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas to protect the owl's forest habitat. However, the study also addresses the ``social and other impacts'' of significant harvest reductions in the Northwest's timber-based communities. The report said communities will pull together at first ``as common adversity is confronted in response to the collective perception that jobs and livelihood are being sacrificed to protect old-growth timber.'' But it said tensions will rise as jobs become more scarce. This ``will stem from a rift in these communities between those who already have found work and those who have not.'' ``In severe cases of community dysfunction, increased rates of domestic disuptes, divorce, acts of violence, delinquency, vandalism, suicide, alcoholism and other social problems are to be expected,'' the report said. Forest Service Chief F. Dale Robertson has indicated that if the spotted owl is listed as endangered, the service may adopt the Thomas proposal as its recovery plan for the species. The looming economic upheaval has Northwest lawmakers scrambling to find alternatives to the committee's recommendations. Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., said the Forest Service report ``makes clear the outrageous and unnecessary hardship to families that will occur if the Thomas report is adopted.'' ``The only way to save our rural communities dependent on the harvest of public timber is to interject human values into a process that has thus far ignored them,'' he said. ``Listing the spotted owl as an endangered species is going to be catastrophic to all Oregonians, not just those living in rural communities,'' said Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment in 11 Major States
With AM-Unemployment Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the April unemployment rates for 11 large states as reported Friday by the Labor Department: _California, 5.4 percent, up from 5.2 percent in March. _Florida, 5.7 percent, up from 5.2 percent. _Illinois, 6.1 percent, up from 5.5 percent. _Massachusetts, 5.5 percent, up from 5.4 percent. _Michigan, 7.3 percent, up from 7.2 percent. _New Jersey, 4.9 percent, up from 4.7 percent. _New York, 4.9 percent, down from 5.0 percent. _North Carolina, 3.8 percent, up from 3.4 percent. _Ohio, 5.9 percent, up from 5.5 percent. _Pennsylvania, 5.7 percent, up from 5.2 percent. _Texas, 6.4 percent, up from 5.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Party Wins Local Elections, But Tories Do Better Than Expected
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Labor Party rejoiced Friday in sweeping local election victories, but Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took comfort that the results were not as devastating to her Conservatives as expected. And some analysts predicted Mrs. Thatcher was now more secure against possible challenges to her leadership of the Conservative Party. Millions of voters protesting soaring home loan rates and an unpopular new local tax deserted the Conservatives in the nationwide local vote Thursday. But while pre-election polls showed Mrs. Thatcher with a 20-point deficit, the actual swing against the government was only 11 percent. Share prices rose on the London stock exchange, reflecting relief by big business. In the most important trend for Labor, the party posted significant gains in the prosperous and heavily populated south for the first time since Mrs. Thatcher ousted a Labor government in 1979. ``That is the spread of support that we need which makes me forecast that we are certain to win the next election,'' said Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. But in London, the Conservatives performed well. In a particularly sore loss for Kinnock, the Tories wrested from Labor the west London borough of Ealing, where Kinnock lives. ``I am sure Neil's residence in Ealing is extremely welcome to his immediate neighbors,'' snapped Bryan Gould, a Labor campaign manager, ```but I don't think it is a big factor in terms of people's voting preferences.'' And the Tories held with increased majorities two other key boroughs, Wandsworth and Westminster. These councils have set the lowest local tax rates in Britain under the new municipal tax system. Labor has accused them of rigging the tax amounts to bribe voters. The Conservatives remained virtually shut out in Scotland and performed badly in northern England, losing the industrial city of Bradford. ``We've lost some we hoped to hold ... but we have a very good basis on which to go forward and win the next general election,'' declared Mrs. Thatcher. She said the party had ``confounded the polls.'' With results declared from all but one of the 201 councils contested, Labor gained 300 seats. The Conservatives lost 191 seats, and the centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party lost 48. Apart from the Scottish Nationalists and the tiny Green party, other minority parties all had net losses in the some 5,000 seats contested. Labor had control of 110 of the councils contested, up from 97. The Conservatives had 51, down from 60. The centrists had 17, down two. No party won a majority in the rest. A computer analysis by the British Broadcasting Corp. showed Labor with 42 percent of the vote, enough for a comfortable general election victory, and the Conservatives with 31 percent. The centrists, performing far better than their single-figure showing in polls, got 18 percent. The rest was scattered among minority parties. BBC political correspondent John Cole said the better-than-expected result for Mrs. Thatcher's party ``will fortify her leadership against the assault that is going on.'' ``All have some cause to be grateful for the results. All have some cause to be anxious,'' said Cole. Speculation had increased, as Mrs. Thatcher's ratings slid over the past 12 months, that the party would attempt to ditch her this autumn. But most analysts now believe the next election, up to two years away, remains wide open and will depend heavily on how the economy performs. At present the outlook is bleak. Interest rates are at 15 percent and have failed to curb inflation, which is expected to hit double-digit figures next month. Government officials hinted that the new tax, known as the poll tax, will still be amended although not changed in principle. The tax has caused a national furor. It is widely perceived as unfair because local councils divide the charges for local services equally among all adults, regardless of income. It replaced the previous property tax system, under which only 17 million homeowners paid for local services such as education, police, and garbage collection. All 38 million adults are liable for the new tax, with rebates for the 9.5 million poorest. Mrs. Thatcher introduced the new system thinking that it would prove to voters that local councils dominated by Labor were bigger spenders. However, the average local tax has worked out to $580, one-third above government targets. Instead of Labor councils getting blamed for the bills, Mrs. Thatcher is taking the blame.

DOC.HEAD: Syria-Egypt Warming Won't End Other Enduring Rifts in Arab World
DOC.TEXT: Presidents Hafez Assad and Hosni Mubarak met this week to cement a spectacular reconciliation between Syria and Egypt after a 12-year rift. The meeting was friendly, but the two countries differ fundamentally on how to bring about an Arab-Israeli peace. And Mubarak made only halting progress in his efforts to end the feud between Syria and Iraq. The welcome given to the Egyptian president in Syria would have been unthinkable over the last decade, when Syria was vilifying Egypt as a traitor to the Arab cause for signing the Camp David treaty with Israel. The two countries resumed relations in December. Of the 17 Arab nations that cut ties with Cairo in the wake of Camp David, only Libya holds out. Egypt is trying to get Middle East peace negotiations going. Sometimes in concert with the United States, Egypt has been advocating a separate path to peace involving direct Israeli-Palestinian negotiations that could lead eventually to an international parley. Mubarak told reporters that ``the crux of the problem is the Palestinian problem. If there is an active role for the Palestinians, President Hafez Assad will never miss the train.'' But there would have to be some agreement between Assad and PLO leader Yasser Arafat, who are bitter enemies. Assad regards Arafat's recognition of Israel's right to exist as an unnecessary concession, born of weakness. He wants to build up his armed forces to achieve ``strategic parity'' with Israel and negotiate from a position of strength. Syria is the only Arab state that has not recognized the independent Palestinian state announced at the Palestine National Congress session in November 1988, and it blocked Damascus-based Palestinians from attending. Arafat has been in the vanguard of Arab leaders who have been pushing for an Arab summit in Baghdad to discuss the surge in Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel. But Assad is also a foe of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and there is little chance Assad would travel to Damascus unless Syrian-Iraqi relations improve. Assad told Egyptian reporters that great differences remain between Damascus and Baghdad but that ``time and effort'' might heal them. Mubarak expressed hope that he might ``persuade'' Assad to attend a summit in Baghdad. Assad, however, expressed surprise that Baghdad was being discussed as a summit venue without prior consultation, and Syrian official sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Assad remained skeptical about the proposed arrangements for a summit. Crown Prince Abdullah bin Abdel Aziz of Saudi Arabia was due in Damascus on Saturday on a trip aimed at trying to reconcile Syria and Iraq. Abdullah in the past played a similar role in mending ties between Jordan and Syria. Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq announced that his country would officially invite Assad to attend the summit, but the date and the precise agenda remain vague. In addition to the feuds between the Iraqi and Syrian wings of the Arab Baath Socialist parties in the two countries, Syria was the only Arab country to side with Persian Iran in its 1980-88 war with Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Reed Returns Home, Greeted By Polhill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs
DOC.TEXT: Freed hostage Frank Reed returned home to the United States today after 42 months in captivity and rejoiced, ``I am unchained and unblindfolded.'' Reed's plane was greeted by another recently freed hostage, Robert Polhill. The two men embraced on the tarmac, and Reed whispered, ``We're going to get the rest of them out, aren't we.'' The release of Reed and Polhill left six Americans and nine other westerners still held in captivity in Lebanon. ``Of course it feels wonderful,'' Reed said in a brief statement that left many of his welcomers in tears. He thanked all those who worked and prayed for his release _ including the Americans still held hostage for refusing ``to let me give up.'' ``Thank you for all your love and concern and yes for your tears, for I cry with you that this tragic affair will end soon. Amen, amen, amen,'' he said. Reed was released by his captors on Monday and has been undergoing medical tests in Wiesbaden, West Germany. He is expected to face further medical tests in the next several days. The release of Reed and Polhill left six Americans and 10 other westerners held hostage in Lebanon. Associated Press correspondent Terry Anderson, kidnapped in March 1985, is the longest held. President Bush, who met with Polhill earlier in the week, said Thursday that he would be willing to make a goodwill gesture toward Iran as long as it did not appear to be negotiations for the release of the remaining hostages. Before departing West Germany, the 57-year-old Reed said Britain should do more to free two of its citizens still held captive in Lebanon. ``They are my best mates, those guys, we're going to get them out,'' Reed said of Brian Keenan and John McCarthy shortly before he left the U.S. Air Force hospital in Wiesbaden to begin his journey back to the United States. Asked if he thought the British government should be doing more to win the release of McCarthy and Keenan, Reed replied: ``You bet they should be.'' He did not elaborate. Ending a two-day official visit to Finland, Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati said today that Israel must free ``several hundred Lebanese hostages'' before any steps are taken to free any of the 16 remaining Western hostages seized in Lebanon, who are believed held by pro-Iranian groups. ``The other side has to take practical steps ... to influence Israel and the Phalangists,'' he said, referring to a Christian Lebanese group once allied with Israel. ``Especially the United States and Britain can persuade Israel to release these abducted people,'' Velayati said at a news conference. However, he said ``no deals had been done'' for the release of the two Americans. He said Iran had not even been involved in any talks with the United States. During his 42 months of captivity, Reed's Islamic captors falsely told him that his 91-year-old mother, Leota Sprague, had died, his daughter Marilyn Langston said Thursday in a telephone interview from her home in Malden, Mass. ``He was told she had passed away,'' Langston said. ``He didn't know she was alive until he was released. We were able to tell him she was very much alive.'' In a telephone call Wednesday, Reed also told Langston he had tried to escape his captors but was quickly caught and badly beaten for the attempt. ``He told me he'd been beaten. He did try to escape and they'd beaten him very badly,'' Langston said. In the southern Lebanese city of Sidon, the International Committee of the Red Cross today displayed 75,000 letters of support for two kidnapped Swiss relief workers, Elio Erriquez, 24, and Emanuel Christen, 34. The pair was abducted Oct. 6. Reed, 57, said Wednesday he had spent much of his 42 months of captivity in the company of McCarthy and Keenan. Reed said he was held with two Americans as well _ Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press and the longest-held hostage, and educator Thomas Sutherland. Anderson was kidnapped on March 16, 1985; Sutherland was seized on June 9, 1985. Keenan was abducted on April 11, 1986, and McCarthy was kidnapped six days later. Reed has said repeatedly since his release on Monday that he is angry that people he was held with are not yet out, and that he will work to help win their freedom. He told reporters that in Washington he would be meeting with relatives of Keenan and McCarthy. Reed spoke briefly to reporters shortly after emerging from the Wiesbaden hospital, where he had been undergoing medical tests and debriefings by a special U.S. State Department team seeking clues about Western hostages in Lebanon. With Reed were his Syrian wife, Fahima, and their son, Tarek. Reed lost 60 pounds in captivity during which he was kept blindfolded and bound, but is otherwise in basically sound health, doctors have said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Spurns Reported Gadhafi Offer on Disputed Plant
DOC.TEXT: The United States has rejected a reported offer by Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi to dismantle a plant the Bush administration contends was designed to produce poison gas, the State Department said Friday. Gadhafi has said the plant produces pharmaceuticals and, according to diplomats, he offered to dismantle the facility if Western countries agreed to replace it. ``I'd like a free pharmaceutical plant, too. This is not a pharmaceutical plant; this is a chemical weapons facility,'' State Department deputy spokesman Richard n asked about the reported offer. ``Gadhafi built it, GadhBoucher said wheafi should dismantle it. We're not attracted by the offer.'' The Rabta plant was said to have been damaged by fire in late March, shortly after Gadhafi reportedly made the offer. The United States initially said the blaze caused heavy damage to the plant, but later news reports said U.S. officials had decided the fire was a hoax. A review of satellite photographs reportedly showed that burn marks were painted on the building, apparently in an effort to head off any U.S. military action against the facility.

DOC.HEAD: Oldest Iceberg Breaking Up
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year odyssey is coming to an end for the oldest known drifting iceberg, which is beginning to break up in the South Atlantic, the government said Friday. The iceberg, once twice the area of Washington, D.C., was first sighted in 1978. Since then it has drifted some 5,700 miles, almost entirely around Antarctica, according to the Joint Ice Center operated by the Navy and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The iceberg was last sighted southwest of the Falkland Islands in February, according to Navy Capt. Tom Callaham. He said satellite studies show that the berg is now breaking up in a region known as the ``screaming fifties.''
