That portion of ocean, near 50 degrees South latitude, is famed for its rough weather and powerful winds.

DOC.HEAD: Train Wreck in Mexico Kills At Least 6, Red Cross Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new death toll indicates six dead, sted of 40, reason for discrepancy, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A passenger train derailed and plunged into a dry riverbed in the southern state of Oaxaca, killing at least six people, the Mexican Red Cross said today. The organization originally gave a death toll from Thursday night's crash of at least 40. Ana Maria Tovar, director of the Red Cross in Oaxaca, today blamed the discrepancy on the magnitude of the wreck, the isolation of the area and that the crash occurred at night. A news release from the Mexican National Railroad put the toll of the second-class train, The Oaxacan, en route from Oaxaca to Mexico City at seven dead and 20 injured. The train was near capacity, carrying about 200 passengers, according to Oaxacan station chief Jose Velasco Altamirano. Red Cross workers said there were six bodies in the morgue at Cuicatlan, the village near where the wreck occurred, and none in Oaxaca, about 220 miles south of Mexico City. Red Cross workers continued today to search the wreckage for further victims. There were no reports of foreigners among the victims. The wreck happened in the mountains near the state capital of Oaxaca. Municipal officials in Cuicatlan said 10 injured were taken there. Red Cross workers in Oaxaca said hospitals there had about 25, some in serious condition. The Red Cross said the train plunged into a dry riverbed. Velasco Altamirano said the entire train _ two engines, two passenger cars and one freight car _ left the tracks. Velasco Altamirano said the victims were evacuated by railroad handcar and one freight train because of the remoteness of the area. He blamed the wreck on an apparent brake failure.

DOC.HEAD: Departing Bailout Boss Says Heavy Costs Coming From S&L Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Departing savings and loan cleanup boss L. William Seidman said Friday that ``real pain'' is yet to come in the bailout and urged patience with his successor. ``All the evidence to date is that the costs will exceed those originally estimated,'' he told a House Banking Committee task force on the S&L bailout. ``We are operating now in markets where interest rates are going up and property values are going down,'' he said. Panel members lavished praise on the 69-year-old regulator, who is often at odds with the administration and is being nudged out as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. The FDIC insures bank and thrift institution deposits; the RTC conducts the S&L bailout. At Seidman's suggestion, President Bush is turning to William Taylor, the Federal Reserve Board's director of bank supervision, to take over the position. Panel members welcomed the prospect of Taylor's appointment cautiously, but questioned whether he would match Seidman as an independent voice. Seidman asked them not to judge Taylor's performance too quickly. ``Don't be impatient. This is a long, hard job. It isn't going to be accomplished anytime soon,'' he said. ``The real pain of what's taking place, on everything from increased government borrowing to the effect on real estate markets, is still being felt. I think it is very important that no one expect by this time next year we'll all feel great,'' said Seidman. However, Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of the task force, said, ``I worry about the independence of the FDIC and the RTC. I worry about future policy decisions driven by political spin control.'' And Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., berated the administration for its willingness to let Seidman go. He said Taylor, despite his ability, would fail without stronger administration support. ``I think the administration ... should be on its hands and knees begging you to stay. The messenger shouldn't be blamed for the bad news,'' Schumer told Seidman. ``Mr. Taylor's talents will be wasted and the country will suffer unless this administration ... (makes) this crisis a top priority. The president can't do it if he treats Bill Taylor with the same resounding indifference as he did Bill Seidman,'' said Schumer. Vento's panel focused on the slow pace of the sale of real estate, loans, securities and other assets of failed thrifts. Seidman acknowledged that real estate sales of $2.1 billion, leaving a $16.4 billion portfolio, have been ``not as much as we would have liked.'' However, he said the agency is preparing policy changes that would allow it to sell property at auction and at a discount from appraised values. He warned, though, that the requirement that the agency appraise nearly all of its assets could greatly slow the bailout. Some appraisals, in areas where appraisers are flooded with business, are taking up to a year. ``I think we have to be very careful and apply common sense ... or appraisals alone will stop this whole process,'' Seidman said. Seidman was backed by former FDIC Chairman Irvine H. Sprague, who said appraisals were little better than ``guesstimates'' and that ``by far the cheapest approach is to get what you can quickly.'' ``The alternative is an ever increasing carrying cost, ever multiplying fees to attorneys, appraisers and accountants, and an ever growing bureaucracy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Militant Workers Clash With Police in Labor Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Militant workers and students hurling rocks and firebombs fought street battles with riot police in three cities Friday, but labor unrest around the country showed signs of easing, reports said. Police reported some arrests and injuries in protests in Seoul, Ulsan and Kwangju but gave no overall figures. In the southern industrial city of Changwon, police raided a hospital morgue and seized the body of a labor activist guarded by militant workers. In Ulsan, 200 miles southeast of Seoul, an estimated 2,000 workers clashed with riot police at several places. Police fired tear gas to disperse the workers who charged in groups of 50 to 500. Labor unrest in Ulsan appeared to ease considerably after 27,000 workers of the Hyundai Motor Co., the nation's largest auto maker, voted Friday to reopen their assembly lines Monday. Widening labor protests turned violent a week ago when about 12,000 police stormed the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard, the world's largest, to quell a three-day strike demanding the release of jailed union leaders. Workers of several dozen plants in Ulsan and other industrial regions staged sympathy strikes. Hyundai officials in Seoul said about half of the 100,000 workers at their 13 subsidiaries in Ulsan were back to work Friday. They said they expected further improvement in the situation after the anti-strike vote at their car plant. The officials said the shipyard also would be open Monday if workers perched atop a 240-foot crane come down. The company said 5,000 management personnel were working at the shipyard Friday to prepare to resume operations. The workers climbed the crane during the police raid on the shipyard last week and threatened ``extreme action'' unless their demand for the release of jailed workers was met. Police spread nets and air mattresses around the base of the crane. Outside Seoul's Sogang University, about 1,000 radical students, hurling rocks and firebombs, fought fierce street battles with riot police, denouncing alleged government suppression of labor movement. ``Down with (President) Roh Tae-woo,'' yelled the students from about a dozen schools in the capital. Before clashing with police, the students burned a U.S. flag, lashing out at what they called Washington's imperialistic support of the Roh government. In the southern provincial capital of Kwangju, about 700 students, throwing firebombs and rocks, clashed with riot police after a campus rally protesting the police raid on the Hyundai shipyard, the national news agency Yonhap said. In Changwon, a port city 212 miles south of Seoul, about 600 riot police charged into the hospital before dawn, took the body of the dead worker and returned it to his family for burial, Yonhap said. The agency said about 200 militant workers guarding the morgue were overpowered by police wielding clubs and shields. Police arrested 149 workers, it said. Officials feared the death of Kim Young-il, 28, might be used to stir up more trouble. Police in Changwon said their raid was at the request of the dead worker's family, who opposed a large ``political'' funeral planned by militant workers. Radicals in the past have kept the bodies of workers or dissidents against the wishes of their families or held large public funerals as anti-government protests. Kim, a labor activist at the Tongil Industry Co. in Changwon, jumped to his death from a two-story building at his plant Thursday after dousing himself with paint thinner and setting it ablaze. The worker left suicide notes complaining of a hard life and alleging police surveillance of his labor activity.

DOC.HEAD: North Texas Struggles Against Worst Flooding Since 1922
LaserPhoto DN5
DOC.TEXT: Water receded Friday from many north Texas areas that were hit by the worst rainfall in almost 70 years, but at least one neighborhood was evacuated as runoff kept floodwaters high. In Oklahoma, rains that closed dozens of highways, forced the evacuation of hundreds of people and caused at least one death abated. And flooding along the Arkansas River forced communities in Arkansas from Fort Smith to Pine Bluff to take precautions in attempts to limit damages. Texas' death toll from this week's storms rose to five with the discovery Friday of the body of a 77-year-old woman whose truck was swept into a Collin County creek. Ten Texans have died in flooding during the last two weeks. Police also included a man who died Thursday when he fell into a rain-swollen creek while trying to check on water lines. Besides the four flood deaths this week, officials in San Antonio said the rain contributed to the death of a man who apparently lost control of his vehicle Thursday on a slick, wet road. Officials evacuated the Sandy Lake Lodge mobile home park in Carrollton that was awash in overflow from the Trinity River. But throughout the river basin, the Trinity was receding at a rate of about an inch an hour, said Carlo Bravo, an engineer with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. ``Relatively speaking, that's very fast,'' he said. The Trinity invaded homes from Fort Worth to Dallas and drove hundreds of people to shelters. It crested Thursday night at Dallas at 47 feet _ 17 feet above flood level and its highest mark since 1949. Flooded roads snarled rush-hour traffic for a second day in Dallas and Fort Worth. North Texas has had 22.06 inches of rainfall in the first four months of 1990, the most since 1922. As much as 7 inches of rain fell within 24 hours in some areas. At Lake Texoma in Oklahoma, water gushed over the spillway at a depth of 2 feet, and at least 100 residents were evacuated. Most of the danger appeared to be in Bryan and Marshall counties. ``We're knee-deep in evacuating people on the upstream side of the dam,'' said Johnny Shepherd, civil defense director in Bryan County. ``It's flooding now. Some have had water just at the base of their home for days, and now they're packing their suitcases.'' Mike McCoy, a U.S. Army Corps of Engineers spokesman in Denison, Texas, said the lake is expected to crest Monday at 644 to 645 feet, which would break the record of 643.18 set in 1957. McCoy said it would take about 60 days for levels on the massive lake along the Oklahoma-Texas line to return to normal without any more rain. He said the area already had exceeded the average annual rainfall of 32 inches. Nearly 50 highways have been closed or will be closed, most of them in southeastern Oklahoma, state Transportation Secretary Neal McCaleb said Officials believe that to be a record number of highway closings. The forecast called for the rain to end this weekend, but some lakes and rivers were expected to continue rising until Sunday. In Arkansas' Faulkner County in the state's central section, this weekend's Toad Suck Daze festival was moved from the Toad Suck Park along the river to downtown Conway. The Army Corps of Engineers closed the park and employees began evacuating the park Thursday. Trey Schroeder, a spokesman for Gov. Bill Clinton, said the governor authorized the use of 75 Army National Guardsmen for sandbagging along the Arkansas River at Fort Smith. A duty officer, Philip Doyle, said sandbags were used in the Treasure Hills subdivision north of Conway where some homes were threatened by Cadron Creek. Sandbagging also was under way at Dardanelle and in Perry County, he said. Asked if conditions were expected to worsen, he said: ``If it does, we're up that well-known creek.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Housing Official Says Pierce Directed Grants Based on Politics
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS one graf after 18th graf, bgng Weisberg said, to ADD Pierce lawyer's denial; picks up 19th graf pvs, Gilliam described
DOC.TEXT: Former HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. relied on political ties to decide discretionary housing grants and once ordered money to help a ``down and out'' former campaign manager, an imprisoned former aide said Friday. DuBois L. Gilliam concluded three days of testimony about abuse in the Reagan administration's Department of Housing and Urban Development by describing Pierce as deeply involved in funding decisions under one program where politics was virtually the only qualification examined. ``Secretary Pierce _ when he wanted something done, he would tell you to get it funded,'' Gilliam said. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., chairman of the House panel investigating the HUD scandals, called Gilliam's testimony ``credible.'' He said Gilliam had contradicted assertions Pierce made under oath before the committee on May 25, 1989, that he had not been involved in deciding who received HUD grants. The former deputy assistant secretary is serving a prison sentence for abuse of HUD programs and testified under a grant of court grant of immunity. ``We established the fact that contrary to his testimony, Mr. Pierce personally directed the funding of a very large number of projects,'' Lantos said. ``... Mr. Pierce did favors for friends and political allies on countless occasions.'' But Pierce's attorney Paul L. Perito angrily accused Lantos and other committee members of ``defaming my client'' while protected by congressional immunity. He said Gilliam's testmony was not credible and ``doesn't amount to a loaded water pistol.'' Perito said Pierce's denial of involvement applied only to the Section 8 moderate rehabilitation program, the first to be publicly implicated in allegations of abuse. The grants Gilliam testified about Friday were under the secretary's discretionary fund. ``My client was never asked, `Did you personally make decisions in your own discretionary fund,''' Perito said. ``Had he been asked he would have said, `Sure I did. It was my discretionary fund.''' Congressional investigators contended Pierce's year-old statement was a broader assertion. Some members of the panel have urged that special prosecutor Arlin Adams be permitted to broaden the scope of his investigation of Pierce to include perjury before Congress. It now is confined to Section 8 program activities. Pierce's May 1989 appearance before the committee was at the start of the panel's HUD investigation, and he appeared without a lawyer. Pierce refused later subpoenas to testify, invoking his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. In his final testimony, Gilliam asserted Pierce ordered projects receive federal grants under HUD's community development technical assistance program. He said he did not believe Pierce or other top aides received gratuities or kickbacks. Gilliam has admitted taking some $100,000 in gratuities while at HUD. Gilliam said Pierce ordered him to provide a $350,000 grant to a private group in which his friend and former political manager, Sam Singletary, was a partner. He said Pierce wanted to help Singletary because ``he was down and out. ... And I did so. ... He told me to fund the project.'' The grant was arranged even though Singletary and his partner lacked experience and the city that was to benefit from the project, Camden, N.J., did not request it. Although the secretary had discretion to direct grants under the technical assistance programs, committee staff director Stuart Weisberg said basing decisions on politics could be considered an abuse of the program and against the intent of Congress. Weisberg said Singletary was a close friend of Pierce's who had run his unsuccessful election campaigns for a New York state judgeship in 1959 and 1960. Lantos said Singletary was indicted in 1985 on state charges involving a job training program receiving state money. Perito, in response, denied Pierce was close to Singletary and said Pierce ``had virtually no knowledge of any of this ... He simply approved a routine funding recommendation in the usual and customary way.'' Gilliam described meetings held with himself, Pierce and executive assistant Deborah Gore Dean in which they would would discuss the political sponsors of each applicant _ and often not mention the merits of a project. ``I would give him the name of the company and the political sponsors,'' Gilliam said. ``Boom, boom, boom _ and that's the way we would conduct the meeting.'' Lantos said the program was ``a cross between a slush fund and a political action committee.'' In another case, Gilliam said he directed a grant to another group because of its connection with a brother of Pierce. He offered few other details. Perito denied Pierce ever directed a grant to his brother.

DOC.HEAD: Sea Lion Exiled to California Returns to Seattle Fishery
DOC.TEXT: l Island on March 21. It and five other sea lions had been captured near Seattle's Ballard Locks on March 12. The animal was last tracked at San Miguel Island on April 3, Alabaster said. Some sea lions migrate north in the winter to Puget Sound, and some have discovered that the fish ladder at the Ballard Locks offers abundant, easy meals. The sea lions have devastated the run of wild steelhead that head past the locks to spawn in streams that feed Lake Washington. Scientists have tried several schemes to discourage the sea lions, including trapping, firecrackers and bopping them with blunt arrows shot from crossbows. The free ride home for the six animals was an experiment to see whether they would return to Puget Sound within the same season after being relocated to their Channel Islands rookeries, NOAA said in a statement. ``We wanted to find out if they would come back, and we did,'' Alabaster said. ``Now we have an idea how long it takes.'' Each of the animals had a radio transmitter glued to its back. Until now, only one animal, No. 42, had been recorded north of the Channel Islands. It was detected April 6 near Big Sur, south of Monterey, Calif., NOAA said. National Marine Fisheries Services spokesman Joe Scordino said No. 22 probably will turn around and head back south. The steelhead run is over and the fish ladder at the locks is closed for maintenance. Scordino said scientists aren't sure why No. 22 made the swim north, since this is the time of year when sea lions usually leave Puget Sound to return to California.

DOC.HEAD: Once Ailing Astronaut Cleared for Flight
DOC.TEXT: Next month's mission of space shuttle Columbia will include an astronaut who was kept off a practice countdown last week because of an unspecified medical condition, NASA said Friday. Samuel Durrance, 46, a research scientist at Johns Hopkins University, will help operate a $100 million astronomical observatory known as Astro during the mission, which will last nine or 10 days. Launch is targeted for May 16. ``Durrance's medical condition has been evaluated and resolved to the satisfaction of the NASA aerospace medicine board, clearing the way for his participation,'' the agency said in a statement. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration refused to elaborate on Durrance's problem. It will be the first shuttle flight for Durrance, who has been training for the mission for about 10 years. Much of that time has been spent helping in the design, construction and testing of the Astro observatory. Durrance and payload specialist Ron Parise were selected as part of the seven-member crew because of their knowledge of the payload. Had his medical problem kept him off next month's flight, Durrance would have been considered only for future Astro-related missions, said NASA spokesman Jeff Carr.

DOC.HEAD: Top Adviser Says `Stalinist,' `Czarist' Protesters Insulted Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Stalinists, czarists and other ultra-rightist protesters insulted Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders during the May Day parade, forcing them to leave the festivities, a top adviser said Friday. Alexander Yakovlev, speaking at a news conference, also dismissed reports in Europe suggesting the Soviet army was mobilized Feb. 25 to try to overthrow Gorbachev or pressure him to toe the military's line. The unofficial May Day demonstration that followed the traditionally well-orchestrated workers' parade Tuesday brought tens of thousands of protesters onto Red Square in an outpouring of discontent from both left and right. Gorbachev, who tapped his fingers in apparent impatience, and the other leaders left their perch atop the Lenin Mausoleum after enduring the protest for about 20 minutes. ``The leadership left Red Square because of political considerations, because we do not agree with that ultra-right political position that was demonstrated by those people,'' Yakovlev said. He made no mention of the criticism from those who complained that Gorbachev's reforms have not been radical enough. Yakovlev is widely considered to be an architect of the reforms. ``I saw Stalin portraits, Nicholas II portraits,'' he said. ``Slogans were heard that Ceausescu's destiny is in store for some people. That was really unfortunate. Anybody would treat these slogans as an insult.'' The Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown and executed in December. ``To us, with our tragic history, it is not admissible that some people would have a chance to turn back the course of history, back to the abyss,'' he added. Yakovlev's comments came in a lengthy question-and-answer session with Soviet and foreign journalists at a meeting sponsored by Interfax, a Soviet news agency. Asked about reports published in Europe that the army was mobilized Feb. 25 to pressure Gorbachev or even overthrow him, Yakovlev labeled them rumors and said there are ``no grounds'' to support them. He denied there were military movements that day. It was widely reported at the time, however, that thousands of troops, many in riot gear, were brought into Moscow to ensure that a mass demonstration that day did not get out of hand. The troop movements, mostly of soldiers from the Interior Ministry's internal security forces, were widely viewed as a government effort to deter people from participating in the gathering, which authorities repeatedly warned might be violent. ``There is no basis to the claim that Gorbachev had to somehow change his policies in response to that pressure,'' Yakovlev said. ``We do not see any grounds to suspect our army, to think that they are hatching some kind of plans against the party, against the leadership. We do not believe that this is the case.'' Asked repeatedly about Lithuania, he did not retreat from the Kremlin's position that the breakaway Baltic republic must freeze, suspend or reverse its March 11 independence declaration before the Soviet Union will ease its economic blockade and open negotiations. ``Any negotiations begin from the beginning, not from the end,'' he said. Yakovlev met last month with Lithuanian lawmakers in what was billed as a strictly unofficial ``conversation'' but was seen at the time as a possible precursor to negotiations. It apparently led nowhere. Asked about the redeployment of military forces in Europe as a result of the reunification of Germany, Yakovlev said some redistribution will be necessary, but he would not favor surrounding Germany with a deterrent force. ``It would be highly undesirable, even inadmissable, to have some grouping of forces emerging around Germany,'' he said. ``I believe that Germany has had its share of fighting. I believe Germany has had enough of wars, as all of us have.'' ``The Soviet people still retain some psychological concerns'' as a result of their devastating wars with Germany, he said. ``They are somewhat guarded in their attitude because we have experienced too many tragedies, but we believe that new relations will emerge in Europe, and revenge or other such feelings will be prevented through joint efforts.''

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Criticizes Inaction by West
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's prime minister said Friday that White House policies merely urging good-faith negotiation to resolve the Baltic republic's independence crisis are an inadequate response in the face of Soviet economic warfare. ``Simply making statements that there should be cooperation is not adequate at this time when the Soviets are interfering in Lithuania's ties with other countries,'' Kazimiera Prunskiene said in a blunt comment just a day after her unofficial Oval Office meeting with President Bush. Mrs. Prunskiene also urged the United States not to grant favored trade status to the Soviet Union. ``Now that Moscow has imposed an economic blockade, it wouldn't be logical to grant most favored nation (tariff) status. It would be providing implicit support for their actions.'' However, in a shift of position, she said it was too early to ask the United States to impose economic sanctions against Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in an effort to prod him toward accepting Lithuanian independence. ``We would hope the imposition of economic sanctions would be held in reserve as a threat to encourage sitting down at the negotiating table, because we are not looking for a situation where the Soviet people are forced to suffer,'' she said. Vytatus Landsbergis, president of Lithuania's parliament, has harshly criticized Bush's recent decision to defer possible sanctions, saying it was reminiscent of Western appeasement of Nazi Germany immediately before World War II. Mrs. Prunskiene said after her Thursday meeting with Bush that she would not have used such a comparison, but that Landsbergis had spoken in his zeal for Lithuanian independence. The prime minister failed to persuade Bush to change his stance on the secessionist republic. Mrs. Prunskiene, in comments Friday at the National Press Club, suggested that guarantees of Lithuanian independence should be both political and economic. Lithuania wants quick diplomatic recognition from the United States and other nations, and Mrs. Prunskiene said the refusal of Western capitals to do so is the main factor in the Soviet refusal to accept Lithuania's secession. Diplomatic recognition should be the logical consequence of the policy of many of these nations during the last 50 years to recognize the forced incorporation of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia into the Soviet Union, she said. The republic also seeks ``concrete political support'' to enable it to enter the world economic market, she said, adding that Lithuania does not seek handouts or direct assistance. The May 30 Bush-Gorbachev summit in Washington may prove crucial for Baltic independence, she said. ``I think they have a chance to make decisions which are of critical importance to the future of Europe and bring to a final close World War II.'' But she said it was important for the United States and other Western governments to move decisively in the few weeks remaining before Bush and Gorbachev meet. ``I would hope that when Gorbachev comes to the United States this question (of international guarantees for Lithuania) will not have been left hanging, but that something will have been done about it.'' Mrs. Prunskiene began her second busy day in Washington with a pilgrimage to the National Archives for a firsthand look at the Declaration of Independence. ``It occurred to me that America was very fortunate that the Declaration of Independence of the United States was never suspended and that you enjoy true democracy,'' she said. ``For that reasons, for us to suspend our declaration of independence would be contrary to the spirit of democracy I find here in the United States.'' On Saturday, Mrs. Prunskiene was scheduled to address a Lithuanian youth congress before beginning her journey home. Spokesman Mark Johnson said Mrs. Prunskiene had been invited to stop in London for talks with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, but that final arrangements had not been made.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Church Moved as Lava Flow Advances
LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Star of the Sea Church was moved as a lava flow burned through the heart of this picturesque beach town Friday, more than seven years after Kilauea Volcano began its latest eruption. The flow picked up speed and advanced more than 200 yards overnight, but so far it has bypassed the Kalapana Store and Drive-Inn and the Kalapana Mauna Kea Congregational Church. It was moving behind both structures, and was beginning to rise along the Congregational Church's wall that abutted a meeting hall. But civil defense officials said they were more concerned about three homes in danger of being cut off from road access before residents could remove their belongings. The wooden Roman Catholic Church _ also called ``the painted church'' _slowly made its way down Beach Road, which crews had cleared of utility poles and overhanging tree branches. An elderly native Hawaiian woman pleaded with workers and civil defense officials not to move the church. Church officals decided last week to save its hand-painted wall murals. ``How can you move it? How can you move it?'' the woman screamed at workers for a construction company that volunteered its services. Others echoed similar sentiments. ``How can you call it Star of the Sea Church if they put it on a mountain?'' asked Kapena Kamahele, whose family has a long history in Kalapana. Workers toiled throughout the night to prepare the church for relocation. It was taken about a mile out of town, where it will stay until church officials decide where to move it. Civil defense ordered members of the congregational church who had spent the night in the building to evacuate Friday morning. ``The book is closed. We open a new book today,'' said Bernice McKeague, church moderator. The congregation held a prayer vigil Thursday night and watched as the lava built up in a gully behind the church. Long before the present flow arrived, church members voted never to move the church, saying it would be hypocritical of their faith. The church, originally built along the seashore in 1823, was destroyed by an earthquake, tidal wave and lava in 1868. The earthquake sunk the land the church was located on, and a few years later it was rebuilt at the site where Star of the Sea is located. Erosion prompted the congregation to move again across the street to its present location, McKeague said. ``She packs a real history,'' McKeague said. So far, Walter Yamaguchi, owner of the Kalapana Store and Drive-Inn since 1963 has been correct in maintaining that his store would be spared. He has been making daily offerings to Hawaiian volcano goddess Pele. ``Madame Pele will never take me,'' the 82-year-old man said. He added that he left some supplies in the store to sell once he is allowed to open again. Of increasing concern to authorities is the threat to public health when the lava begins to flow into the ocean, which it eventually will do if it continues its present path. When lava hits the water, it creates sulphuric acid, a harmful toxic substance known in volcano country as ``laze.'' Officials have not disclosed plans on how they will deal with that. To date, 131 homes in the community on the island of Hawaii have burned since the eruption began on Jan. 3, 1983.

DOC.HEAD: President's Son Agrees to Testify Before House Panel
With AM-FDIC Chairman, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Neil Bush, the president's son, said Friday that he had agreed to testify before the House Banking Committee about the failure of a Colorado thrift on whose board he served. The panel, chaired by Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, is looking into the December 1988 collapse of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. The connections among Silverado and other failed S&Ls _ including Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and the junk bond operation of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. financier Michael Milken _ are being examined. The committee has scheduled two hearings. Thrift regulators are expected to testify May 22, while Bush and and other Silverado board members are scheduled to appear May 23. ``I have agreed to participate and will continue to cooperate with Congress, the Office of Thrift Supervision and any other agencies involved,'' Bush said in a statement released through his attorney's office. The thrift office has alleged that loans by Silverado to Bush's business partners, developers Kenneth Good and Bill Walters, were a conflict of interest for Bush. Neil Bush was on the S&L's board from October 1985 until August 1988. In January, regulators began disciplinary procedures against Bush that could result in a lifetime ban from the financial institutions industry. Bush has denied any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: What a trip, man! The Lava Lite, a fixture in psychedelic pads in the '60s, is 25 years old. During the past quarter-century, the flowing, glowing lamps were praised by the American Institute of Architects and seen on the U.S. president's desk in the movie ``Amazon Women on The Moon.'' ``People feel the way about their Lava Lites that other people feel about their pets,'' said Christopher Baldovin, marketing director for Haggerty Enterprises, the Chicago-based company that began making them in 1965. ``It's like watching fish, but you don't have to feed them.'' In the last two years, more Lava Lites were sold annually than when they were introduced, even though the price has doubled to about $50, Baldovin said. Customers include former hippies who can finally afford one and teen-agers not yet born when they were introduced. Retailers nationwide said demand for the lamp has steadily grown since sales dropped to their lowest point in 1983. Although the company also manufactures The Wave, a fluid-filled rectangle that simulates wave shapes while rocking slowly on a motorized base, the Lava Lite is by far the company's most famous product. A lanternlike glass chamber lit from the bottom, the lava (a goop of 11 non-toxic substances discovered by accident by English inventor Craven Walker) gurgles slowly to the top, then settles gently back at the bottom, where the cycle begins again. Lava Lite owners are fiercely loyal. Haggerty customer service representative Jean Bartyzel said that the day after Northern California's Oct. 17 earthquake, she was swamped with calls from distraught customers whose lamps had broken during the quake. Even the American Institute of Architects praised Lava Lites. An institute official quoted in The Washington Post said their ``kinetic structural elements constitute an intriguing relief from hard-edged rectilinearity.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moved on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders at Safeco Corp.'s annual meeting didn't show much reaction to disappointing first-quarter profits, but they applauded a plea to allow male employees to wear non-white shirts. ``For 28 long years, I have been needlessly white,'' Jack Hepfer, a recently retired Safeco lawyer, said of the 67-year-old dress code. Hepfer cited Hawthorne Dent, founder of the Seattle-based insurance company, as having said in 1955 that there was ``nothing the matter with colored shirts.'' After all, Hepfer said, ``The Berlin Wall came down.'' But the white-shirts-only policy didn't. Safeco Chairman Bruce Maines defended the rule at Wednesday's annual meeting and company president Roger Eigsti refused to change it. ``The white-shirt rule is a plain, straight, pragmatic rule. It's a part of our thing. It's part of our personality,'' said Maines, who owns 30 white shirts. The company reported first-quarter profits of 89 cents a share, down from $1.04 a share in the first three months of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Stickney As FEMA Director
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said on Friday he will nominate Wallace Stickney, an associate of White House chief of staff John Sununu, as director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Stickney has been a commissioner of the New Hampshire Transportation Department since 1985. Earlier, he was special assistant for environmental affairs in New Hampshire from 1983 to 1985 when Sununu was governor of the state. Stickney's nomination to run the government's disaster relief organization was announced after Bush delivered the commencement address at Oklahoma State University. Bush said that once Stickney is confirmed by the Senate, he will be appointed to the board of governors of the American National Red Cross.

DOC.HEAD: Private Companies Make Corn Sale To Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Private exporting companies have sold the Soviet Union an additional 600,000 metric tons of U.S. corn for delivery this year under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Orders since Oct. 1, the beginning of the agreement's new year, now total about 13.9 million tons of corn, 3.3 million tons of wheat, 342,300 tons of soybeans and 1.2 million tons of soybean meal. In addition, sales of barley total 7,300 tons. The current long-term agreement expires on Dec. 31 and a five-year pact to replace it has been tentatively approved by U.S. and Soviet negotiators. Meanwhile, the latest sales raised the total for 1989-90 delivery to almost 17.2 million tons, the announcement said. In 1988-89, sales were a record of more than 21.7 million tons, including more than 16.3 million tons of corn and nearly 5.4 million tons of wheat. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 39.4 bushels of corn or 36.7 bushels of wheat or soybeans. The 600,000 tons of corn would be about 23.6 million bushels. The new sales were made by unidentified private exporting companies, which are required to report large sales to the department. No selling prices or further details were released. Corn prices have been averaging about $2.65 per bushel at the farm level, according to USDA's five-day average. Thus, the latest sale could have a farm value of about $63 million.

DOC.HEAD: Tafero Executed for Killing 2 Officers 14 Years Ago
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 1-2 with 3 grafs to RECAST, UPDATE with reax from governor, lawyer. INSERTS 4 grafs after 7th, `Despite the...,' to give quotes.
DOC.TEXT: A man who murdered two police officers 14 years ago was put to death Friday by three jolts in the electric chair that produced flames, sparks and smoke from his masked head. Jessie Joseph Tafero's lawyer described the execution as ``torture'' and Florida Gov. Bob Martinez immediately requested an investigation of the technical problems in carrying out the sentence. Tafero, 43, condemned for the shooting deaths of Highway Patrol Trooper Phillip Black and visiting Canadian constable Donald Irwin, died at 7:13 a.m. at Florida State Prison near Starke. In a 1984 interview, Tafero likened himself and Sonya Jacobs, his girlfriend and co-defendant, to a ``modern-day Bonnie and Clyde.'' They were denied permission to marry after both were condemned to die. When a black-hooded executioner turned the switch for the first time at 7:07 a.m., flames rose 6 inches from the hood covering Tafero's face and scalp. The executioner then interrupted the standard two-minute, 2,000-volt electrical cycle, and prison officials later determined a wet sponge on Tafero's head caught fire, said state Corrections Department spokesman Bob Macmaster. Prison Superintendent Tom Barton, who usually shows no emotions in the clinical atmosphere of Florida executions, had a pained look on his face. Despite the repeated jolts, Dr. Frank Kilgo, the prison's chief medical officer, believed Tafero died quickly. Macmaster quoted Kilgo as saying, ``I believe he was unconscious the minute the current hit him.'' Mark Olive, an Atlanta attorney who represented Tafero, said Martinez should ask for an independent investigation and suspend further executions until the technical problems have been resolved. ``The state cannot bring a person to justice by torturing them,'' said Olive. ``Torture, is per se, cruel and unusual punishment.'' The governor instructed Department of Corrections officials to prepare a report on the execution. But he defended the use of the death penalty, recalling that Tafero coldly took the lives of two officers 14 years ago. ``It is unfortunate that this incident affected the execution, but it is far more unfortunate that it took 14 years to bring to justice a man who killed two police officers,'' Martinez said. Tafero was the 22nd person put to death in Florida and the 124th nationally since the U.S. Supreme Court restored states' rights to execute prisoners in 1976. Tafero's execution was Florida's first in exactly a year. In a final statement, Tafero complained that last-minute motions filed on his behalf with a federal judge and a state Circuit Court judge apparently were ignored. ``I'd like to say that the death penalty as applied by the states is very arbitrary and capricious,'' he said. Outside the prison, four supporters of capital punishment peered through heavy fog, watching from a pasture across the road for a signal that Tafero was dead. About a dozen death penalty opponents conducted a silent, candlelight vigil. A protest march, which organizers believe will draw about 400 people, will begin outside the prison Saturday and continue until May 19 in Atlanta. The 39-year-old officers killed by Tafero were shot to death when they checked a parked car at an Interstate 95 rest stop near Fort Lauderdale on Feb. 20, 1976. Tafero, Ms. Jacobs, her two children and traveling companion Walter Rhodes Jr. were sleeping when the officers approached. Shots were fired when Tafero struggled outside the car with the officers. Black died from gunshot wounds to the head and neck; Irwin, of Kitchener, Ontario, received fatal wounds to his right eye and shoulder. Tafero, Ms. Jacobs and Rhodes were convicted of first-degree murder. Rhodes testified for the prosecution and received three concurrent life terms. Ms. Jacobs' death sentence was commuted to life in prison in 1981. Early Friday, Tafero met with his mother, Kathleen Tafero of Miami, and a Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Robert Baker, celebrated Mass for the condemned inmate. Tafero then placed a telephone call to Ms. Jacobs, the mother of their daughter, Christina.

DOC.HEAD: Kent State Dedicates Memorial to 1970 Student Shootings
LaserPhoto XKSU13, LaserColor XKSU12
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people lit candles in the rain Friday to dedicate a memorial to four Kent State University students who were slain by Ohio National Guardsmen during an anti-war protest 20 years ago. About 4,000 people huddled beneath umbrellas on a parking lot near the site of the shootings, which took place on May 4, 1970, and marked a tragic rallying point for those who opposed American involvement in the Vietnam War. Most of the people in the crowd placed lighted candles on the hilltop granite memorial. Some placed their candles amid the 58,175 daffodils planted on the nearby hillside for each American killed in the war. About 200 students nearby waged a silent protest by raising clenched fists and holding up handmade signs bearing messages of ``Whose May 4th is it anyway?'' and ``Don't minimize student death.'' Some held up two fingers, V-shaped, in the peace sign popularized during the anti-war movement. Some Kent State students have contended the university's $200,000 memorial is too little, too late. Former U.S. Sen. George McGovern, the keynote speaker, said the memorial should encourage reconciliation between the United States and Vietnam, which do not have diplomatic relations. ``The war in Vietnam is unfinished,'' the unsuccessful 1972 Democratic presidential candidate said. ``The killing has stopped, but the arrogance that produced it survives, and so does the agony, the guilt and the separation.'' McGovern drew applause when he said the nation should never pursue military action counter to the public sentiment. ``It's important to our democracy that military operations should be halted if they run counter to the wishes of the American people.'' Florence Schroeder, mother of slain student Bill Schroeder, thanked the university for building the memorial. The memorial, on 2{ acres adjacent to the parking lot where the students were killed, includes a granite plaza with four pylons similar in shape to elongated gravestones. A smaller, waist-high marker, was erected in honor of the slain students in 1971. ``We think this is a fine memorial,'' Mrs. Schroeder told the crowd. Although she and her husband, Louis, participated in the ceremony, the families of two other slain students _ Allison Krause and Jeffrey Miller _ did not show up, university spokeswoman Janet Thiede said. The parents of the fourth victim, Sandra Scheuer, were on campus but did not speak at the ceremonies. Ms. Krause's mother, Doris Krause of Monroeville, Pa., had said she did not plan to attend because she believed the memorial should have been bigger and built earlier. The memorial was designed by Chicago architect Bruno Ast, and was scaled down from a proposed $1 million memorial. The university said it was unable to raise the money. Dean Kahler, who was paralyzed from the waist down when he was wounded in the shootings, said he has forgiven the guardsmen but added that the memorial's message was important. ``The injustices that were committed here should never be forgotten,'' he said. Kahler, now an Athens County commissioner in southeast Ohio, said he ``could not be an angry, bitter man.'' He was the only student disabled by his wounds. Gov. Richard Celeste read the dead students' names and said each time, ``I am sorry.'' ``I felt disbelief that we had turned our weapons on our own children.'' The governor at the time of the shootings was James A. Rhodes, who ordered the National Guard to restore order on the campus after an ROTC building was set on fire in protest against the U.S. invasion of Cambodia. He later signed a statement along with National Guardsmen expressing regret. Mrs. Schroeder said she did not accept Rhodes' contention that the statement did not amount to an admission of guilt. ``Their signatures betray them,'' she said. Shortly after the shootings, a Portage County special grand jury found that the guardsmen acted in self-defense and exonerated them of criminal charges. In March 1974, a federal grand jury in Cleveland indicted eight guardsmen on charges of violating the civil rights of the dead and wounded students. A judge later dismissed the charges for lack of evidence. University President Michael Schwartz said Rhodes and the guardsmen involved in the shootings had not been individually invited to the dedication. But he said an open letter the university published as full-page advertisements in newspapers was an invitation to all Ohioans. The office of the Ohio adjutant general, which oversees the guard, said it had no comment or statement on the anniversary. Schwartz said the Kent State community felt a kinship with Chinese students who were attacked by the military during a demonstration in Tiananmen Square in Beijing last year. ``Those students were seeking democracy. Our students were practicing it,'' he said. Wu'er Kaixi, a Tiananmen Square demonstration leader who later fled China, was invited to the Kent State events and took part in a candlelight vigil early Friday.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of President Bush's commencement address Friday at Oklahoma State University: You know, when graduates of my vintage were sitting through ceremonies like this right after the second World War, we faced a world of changes, full of potential and new possibilities. And Barbara and I got into a red two-door Studebaker _ you still drive those, don't you, around here? But nevertheless, we drove from Connecticut down to West Texas. I have often wondered how far I'd have gone if I'd made it on up to Oklahoma. Post-war America was ready back then in 1948 for peace and prosperity. But while the free world was recovering, the nations of Eastern Europe were being ``consolidated'' behind an Iron Curtain. And so began four decades of division in Europe _ 40 long years of suspicion between two superpowers, the Soviet Union and the United States. And today, you also graduate at the end of an era of conflict _ but a contest of a different kind _ a cold and abstract war of words and walls. And now Europe, and the world, have entered a new era _ the age of freedom. And I hope you'll forgive me if I use this great forum, at your great university, to handle a subject of a very serious nature. It may be a little longer than you want to hear. I remember the graduation at Yale University, my school, the man giving the graduate speech got up and he said, ```Y' is for youth.'' And he talked about 25 minutes. ```A' is for altruism.'' Another 32 minutes. ```L' is loyalty.'' He brushed that one off in 20 minutes. ```E' is for excellence.'' And when he finished there was one kid out here in the audience. Everyone else had fled. He looked like he was praying. And the speaker said to him, ``Well, I'm glad you're saying a prayer. What are you praying for, son?'' He said, ``I'm praying to God and giving thanks that you didn't go to Oklahoma State University.'' So, I _ but I want you to bear with me because I'll be reflecting on the power and potential of democratic changes in several of these commencement addresses that I make this year. And I begin today, my very first, at your great university, with a few words on _ few words on the changes and America's place in the new Europe. A few of you may be wondering what a continent 4,000 miles away has to do with you _ your class and you. Throughout our history, great upheavals in Europe have forced the American people to respond, to make deep judgments about the part we should play in European affairs. This has been true from the time of the French Revolution and the war which followed it, to World War I and the flawed peace which ended it, on to the Second World War and the creation of the postwar order. And I believe that now we are poised at another such moment, a critical time in our strategic relationship with our neighbors across the Atlantic. Many of the graduates of America's class of 1916 have wondered why the faraway war making headlines in their newspapers would have anything to do with them. And they might have agreed with President Wilson, who that year said ``We are not interested'' in the causes of war, in ``the obscure foundations from which its stupendous flood has burst forth.'' But a year later those classmates, and their country, were swept up in the torrent, carrying them to the horror of the trenches in France. And yet after the war, we again turned away from active involvement in European affairs. And instead, we sponsored a treaty to outlaw war and then, as the outlaws gained strength, the United States passed new neutrality laws.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: New Round in Escalating Cigarette Export Dispute
DOC.TEXT: America's reputation as a maker of live-saving medical miracles is being tarnished with a new image as an exporter of disease and death, critics of the nation's cigarette exports said Friday. ``Free trade is not a license to export lung cancer or ride roughshod over the anti-smoking laws of other nations,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., told a hearing of the Labor and Human Resources Committee he chairs. Kennedy sided strongly with critics of the industry in a growing debate over whether the U.S. government should continue seeking expanded foreign markets for American cigarettes. The House has scheduled committee hearings later this month on legislation to prohibit such trade promotion and to require on U.S. brands sold abroad the same health warning that appears on cigarette packages in the United States. Friday's hearing was the first airing of the issue in the Senate, where legislation has not yet been proposed. The government's success in opening markets to U.S. cigarette brands in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan and a current effort in Thailand drew strong praise and support from witnesses representing the cigarette industry and tobacco-growing states and in a letter earlier this week from House members to Ambassador Carla Hills, the U.S. trade representative. Their message was that the dispute is not a health issue but a question of fair trade, of gaining equal rights for U.S. brands to be sold to people who will continue to use a legal product, tobacco, regardless of what country it comes from. ``Millions of people around the world smoke and will continue to smoke whether or not American cigarettes are available,'' said Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., one of several legislators testifying from tobacco-growing states. Tobacco was one of the few U.S. exports earning a surplus _ more than $4.2 billion _ last year to help offset the $109 billion U.S. trade deficit, he said. Accusing the Thai government of hypocrisy, McConnell charged that it is protecting its tobacco monopoly and planning to expand its own exports yet ``has the audacity to ask us not to export cigarettes to Thailand'' for health reasons. Dr. Prakit Vathesatogut, director of the Thai Anti-Smoking Coalition, displayed to the committee shirts and caps bearing the Marlboro and Winston brand names, which he said are handed out in Thailand, and Thai advertising depicting smoking as part of a youthful American image. ``In the modern-day equivalent of the Opium Wars, our government is aiming to unleash the Marlboro Man on the Thai citizenry,'' said Rep. Chet Atkins, D-Mass., a sponsor of the House legislation. The Opium War between Britan and China was fought from 1839 to 1842 over the right of British traders based in India to ship opium to China. China, which sought to ban the import of opium, lost, and was forced to permit the opium trade for decades.

DOC.HEAD: STILLWATER, Okla.: ...neutrality laws.
DOC.TEXT: Another generation of Americans sat in the bright sun of commencement ceremonies at colleges all across the country, thinking war in Europe would somehow pass them by. But when war came, they paid an awful price, a horrible price, for America's isolation. And then when the war ended, those students who no longer questioned our role in the future of Europe, they no longer asked what Europe had to do with them, because they knew the answer: everything. About a year ago, in Germany, I defined the kind of Europe our country is committed to: a peaceful, stable Europe, a Europe what I call whole and free. Today that goal is within our reach. We're entering a new age of freedom in a time of uncertainty but great hope. Emerging democracies in Eastern Europe are going through social, political, and economic transformations shaking loose stagnant, centralized bureaucracies that have smothered initiative for generations. And in this time of transition, moving away from the post-war era and beyond containment, we cannot know what choices the people of Eastern Europe will make for their future. The process of change in the Soviet Union is also still unfinished. It will be crucial to see, for example, whether Moscow chooses coercion or peaceful dialogue in responding to the aspirations of the Lithuanian people and nationalities within the Soviet Union. The only noble answer lies in a dialogue that results in unencumbered self-determination for Lithuania. President Gorbachev has made profound progress in his country, reforms so fundamental that the clock cannot be turned back. And yet neither can we turn the clock ahead, to know for sure what kind of country the Soviet Union will be in years to come. And for the sake of the future we share with Europe, our policies and presence must be appropriate for this period of transition _ with a constancy and reliability that will reassure our friends, both old and new. My European colleagues want the United States to be a part of Europe's future and I believe they're right. The United States should remain a European power in the broadest sense _ politically, militarily, economically. And as part of our global responsibilities, the foundation for America's peaceful engagement in Europe has been, and will continue to be, NATO. Recognizing in peace what we learned from war, we joined with the free nations of Europe to form an Atlantic Community, an enduring political compact. Our engagement in Europe has meant that Europeans accept America as part of their continent's future, taking our interests into account across the board. Our commitment is not just in defense; it must be a well-balanced mix of involvement in all dimensions of European affairs. Because of our political commitment to peace in Europe, there hasn't been a war on the continent in 45 years. Think of your history books _ not a war on the continent in 45 years. This long peace should be viewed through the long lens of history then. Europe has now experienced the longest uninterrupted period of international peace in the recorded history of that continent. Now the alliance _ the alliance is now ready to build on that historic achievement and define its objectives for the next century. So the alliance must join together to craft a new Western strategy for new and changing times. Having consulted intensively with Prime Minister Thatcher recently there in Bermuda and President Mitterrand in Key Largo in Florida and Chancellor Helmut Kohl up in Camp David, and by telephone or cable with NATO Secretary General Woerner and all of my other allied colleagues, I am calling for an early summit of all NATO leaders. Margaret Thatcher, one of freedom's greatest champions of the last decade, told me that, while NATO has been fantastically successful, we should be ready now to face new challenges. The time is right for the alliance to act. The fundamental purpose of this summit should be to launch a wide-ranging NATO Strategy Review for the transformed Europe of the 1990s, and to my NATO colleagues, I suggest that our summit direct this review by addressing four critical points: one, the political role that NATO can play in Europe; two, the conventional forces the alliance will need in the time ahead, and NATO's goal for conventional arms control; three, the role of nuclear weapons based in Europe and Western objectives in new nuclear arms control negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union; and, four, strengthening the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe _ CSCE _ to reinforce NATO and help protect democratic values, in a Europe that is whole and free.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Rate Climbs to 5.4 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS one graf after 6th graf pvs, Bond markets, with today's Dow Jones figure; picks up 7th graf pvs, In April
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate climbed to 5.4 percent in April, its highest level in more than a year, the government said Friday in a report analysts called a disturbing sign the economy could slip into recession. There was paltry growth in the number of U.S. jobs for the second straight month, and the total actually would have declined if not for the hiring of temporary census workers. ``The report indicates the bottom dropped out of the labor market in April. It speaks more toward a possible recession than a rebounding economy,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. Added Robert Dederick of the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago: ``I don't think we can say the economy is toppling over a cliff, but it is not showing any signs that it's backing away from the cliff, either, so there's that danger.'' Bond markets rallied in response to the report. Traders took weaker-than-expected employment _ a report running counter to recent indications that the economy was picking up _ as a sign the Federal Reserve would not boost interest rates to slow things down. The government reported last week that the economy grew at a 2.1 percent rate in the first three months of the year, twice as fast as some private analysts had predicted. On Wall Street, stocks rose 14.19 points, although brokers said the unemployment report also raised some fresh doubts about the outlook for economic growth and corporate profits in coming months. In April, the civilian jobless rate as measured by a household survey was up from the 5.2 percent registered in March. Before that, the unemployment rate had held steady at 5.3 percent for nine months. The last time the jobless rate reached 5.4 percent was January 1989. The number of new jobs created edged up only slightly, with a net gain of 64,000. That included the government's hiring of 78,000 workers for the 1990 census. The job growth figure is derived from a separate survey of business establishments and is generally considered a more reliable indicator of economic activity than the household survey on unemployment. The nation's factories, in a slump for months, continued to falter as manufacturing jobs fell by 22,000. It was the 12th decline in 13 months. ``The manufacturing sector is continuing to bleed workers ... it's starting to have a debilitating affect in other areas as well,'' Dederick said. The manufacturing pinch is starting to spill over into areas such as business services, which includes such jobs as caterers and security guards, Dederick said. That sector suffered a 13,000 job loss last month. The biggest payroll drop in April came in construction, with a seasonably adjusted fall of 99,000 jobs. Construction jobs had been inflated early in the year by unusually warm weather. Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, noted that job growth was robust in the first two months of the year as about 700,000 new jobs were created. That means that since January, the economy has produced an average of 175,000 new jobs a month, she said. A year ago at this time, the economy had produced a monthly average of 200,000 jobs, while the 1988 average for the first four months was 275,000. Ms. Norwood said the slowdown is ``not particularly surprising after more than seven years of business expansion.'' Meanwhile, the service sector, which has been carrying the economy, added 179,000 jobs, bolstered by the hiring of temporary census workers. Labor costs, which have been speeding upward and are blamed for worsening the nation's inflation problems, continued to increase, although moderately, the report showed. Average hourly earnings rose to $9.95 from $9.92, at least partly because of the April 1 increase in the minimum wage from $3.35 an hour to $3.85. Overall, total civilian employment declined slightly to 118.1 million in April. The jobless numbered 6.8 million, up from the 6.5 million out-of-work Americans in March. Many economists had predicted the nation's unemployment rate would eventually creep up this year. Since mid-1988, the rate has ranged between 5 percent and 5.5 percent, the lowest range since the early 1970s. Some analysts said Friday's report was not a sign of a sudden collapse. ``I think the numbers are finally catching up with reality. It looks to me as though we have slow but positive growth,'' said Cynthia Latta of DRI-McGraw Hill. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the April jobless rate was 5.3 percent, up from 5.1 percent in March.

DOC.HEAD: STILLWATER, Okla.: ...and free.
DOC.TEXT: Now, the first task the NATO summit should consider is the future political mission of the alliance. As military threats fade, the political dimension of NATO's work, always there but seldom noticed, becomes more prominent. And so at the NATO summit we should look for ways to help our German friends sustain freedom and achieve German unity, something which we and our allies have supported for over 40 years. And we should reaffirm the importance of keeping a united Germany as a full member of NATO. The alliance needs to find ways to work more closely with a vigorous European Community that is rightly asserting its own distinct views. And in Eastern Europe, governments once our adversaries are now our partners in building a new continent. And so we must also talk about how to encourage further peaceful democratic change in Eastern Europe and inside the Soviet Union. But even as NATO gives more emphasis to its political mission, its guarantee of European security must remain firm. You see, our enemy today _ if you think about, what's the enemy today? Our enemy today is uncertainty and instability. And so the alliance will need to maintain a sound, collective military structure with forces in the field, backed by larger forces that can be called upon in some crisis. And which brings me then to the second task for the NATO summit, a review of how the alliance should plan its conventional defenses. While we need to recognize that it will take some time before the Soviet military presence is gone from Eastern Europe _ before those Soviet troops are taken out of Eastern Europe, and before the major reductions contemplated by both sides can be implemented _ we need to develop our strategy for that world now. Obviously, as I look at the equation, Soviet actions, what the Russians do, will be critical. And yet even after all the planned reductions in its forces are complete, even if our current arms control proposals are agreed to and implemented, the Soviet military will still field forces dwarfing those of any other single European state, armed with thousands of nuclear weapons. Militarily significant US forces must remain on the other side of the Atlantic for as long as our allies want and need them. And these forces demonstrate, as no words can, the enduring political compact that binds America's fate with Europe's democracies. If the Soviet withdrawal continues and our arms control efforts are successful, we must plan for a different kind of military presence focused less on the danger of an immediate outbreak of war. And we must promote long-term stability and prevent crises from escalating by relying on reduced forces that show our capability and our readiness to respond to whatever may arise. The Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty, which we have proposed, would be the most ambitious conventional arms control agreement ever concluded. And we must finish the work on this treaty soon, and plan to sign it at the CSCE summit this fall. But at the NATO summit, we need to look further ahead, preparing follow-on negotiations after the conclusion of the CFE treaty. And the NATO summit should develop the Alliance's objectives for these talks. And third, the NATO summit should also assess the future of US nuclear forces in Europe. As democracy blooms in Eastern Europe, as Soviet troops return home and tanks are destroyed, dismantled, there is less need for nuclear systems of the shortest range. And the NATO summit should accelerate ongoing work within the Alliance to determine the minimum number and types of weapons that will be needed to deter war _ credibly and effectively. In light of these new political conditions, and the limited range and flexibility of these short-range nuclear missile forces based in Europe, I've reviewed our plan to produce and deploy newer, more modern, short-range nuclear missiles to replace the Lance system that's now in Europe. We've almost finished the R&D, research and development work for these new missiles. But I've decided, after consultation with our allies, to terminate the follow-on to Lance Program. I have also decided to cancel any further modernization of US nuclear artillery shells deployed in Europe.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Latvian Lawmakers Vote for Independence, But Break to Be Gradual
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with dancing in the streets of Riga, later Gorbunov comment. Picks up 16th pvs, `Two deputies...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: Latvian lawmakers voted for independence Friday but plotted a more cautious break from the Soviet Union than neighboring Lithuania. Latvians greeted the declaration of independence with tears, a chorus of the republic's traditional anthem and dancing in the streets. The 138-0 parliamentary vote, 50 years after Moscow seized the three Baltic states on the Soviet's western border, put Latvia on a similar secessionist path with Lithuania and Estonia. However, unlike Lithuania's independence declaration of March 11, the vote by Latvia's Supreme Soviet called for a gradual break with the Soviet Union. Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov said he was already thinking about the next step: negotiations with Moscow. ``Everything is ahead,'' he said. ``This is only the very, very beginning.'' Gorbunov later was asked at a news conference what reaction he expected from the Kremlin. He said he could not predict what Moscow would say, but he added that the Latvian government had tried to make it clear in the declaration that there is ``no cause to close the door on dialogue and start setting ultimatums.'' Fifty-seven anti-independence lawmakers refused to cast ballots. Even so, the measure had no problem achieving the two-thirds majority needed for approval. After the vote was announced, Latvians inside and outside the hall broke into a chorus of ``God Bless Latvia,'' the republic's traditional anthem. A cheering crowd showered emerging lawmakers with roses, pansies and daffodils. The deputies also voted to drop the words ``Soviet Socialist'' from the republic's name, making it simply ``The Republic of Latvia.'' ``I waited my whole life for this,'' said Ilma Kaminska, 65, who said she remembered when Latvia was forcibly annexed by Joseph Stalin in 1940. ``I believed, I always believed,'' she said tearfully. The bill, proposed by the pro-independence Latvian People's Front that dominates the parliament, proclaimed the start of an unspecified period of transition to full independence. In the interim, it calls for negotiations with Moscow. The neighboring republic of Estonia took a similar step March 30. Lithuania, which declared full independence seven weeks ago, is now suffering a Kremlin-imposed economic blockade of oil, natural gas and other raw materials. Friday evening, tens of thousands of people gathered on the banks of Riga's Daugava River, long a national symbol for Latvians. With the setting sun glinting on the river, red and white Latvian flags fluttered above the singing crowd. ``My people, you are free! Live and act like a people who deserve to be free,'' said Dainis Ivans, chairman of the Latvian Popular Front. Hours later, scores of people danced in the streets of central Riga. Scattered fireworks exploded in the night sky. Two deputies walked out of the session during the vote, including Alfreds Rubiks, Latvia's Communist Party chief, who earlier in the day warned that ethnic Russians and other non-Latvians living in the republic opposed the measure. ``They will express themselves in mass demonstrations and political strikes in all the cities,'' he said. The party chief also said anti-independence forces would appeal to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to impose presidential rule, and said there ought to be a popular referendum on the independence question. Members of Latvia's opposition complained they were not given enough time to study the declaration. Some warned that Moscow would respond to the move with heavy pressure to rescind it. ``If we pass this declaration, Moscow will do the same thing to Latvia'' as to Lithuania, said deputy Leonids Alksnis. Other speakers, however, cast the declaration as a means to avoid being overwhelmed demographically. Latvians are close to becoming a minority on their own territory. ``This is our last possibility to survive, and we are going to take advantage of it. That is why we demand independence,'' said writer Alberts Bels. In Lithuania, 80 percent of the 3.8 million people are ethnic Lithuanians. But only about 54 percent of Latvia's 2.7 million people are ethnic Latvians. Most of the rest are ethnic Russians, many of whom oppose independence. A day earlier, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis had advised his neighbors to ``be strong and have courage.'' On Friday, his deputy prime minister, Algirdas Brazauskas, reported that the economic embargo was making life in Lithuania ``more difficult,'' and appealed for ``substantial aid'' from abroad. Latvia has followed Lithuania's lead on many issues. In December, it abolished the Communist Party's guaranteed monopoly on power; in February it condemned the 1940 act that formalized its annexation by the Soviet Union; and last month a large segment of its Communist Party broke from its Moscow-based parent. The independence measure adopts four articles from the republic's 1922 constitution: establishing an independent and democratic republic, the historic territory of Latvia, giving power to the people, and establishing a sovereign Latvian parliament. It also recognizes the legitimacy of Soviet laws that do not contradict the republic's own laws. The deputies drafted a message reassuring Gorbachev that a declaration of independence ``only opens the door to a transition period _ a period of honest dialogue and a working out of mutual interests.'' But they added that ``the people of Latvia have no stronger desire than to restore its democratic statehood. It never reconciled itself to the loss (of statehood) and will never give up this goal. ``We are hoping, Mikhail Sergeyevich, for your governmental understanding of Latvia's choice since we believe the road of changes for you and the nation that was started by you will remain unchanged in the future.'' Gorbunov, who was re-elected president of Latvia on Thursday, said in his nominating speech that Latvia could not expect help from the West. ``The world, on account of 5 million Baltic people, is not going to risk what has been done in the area of arms control and by Mikhail Gorbachev,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: STILLWATER, Okla.: ...in Europe
DOC.TEXT: Now, these _ there are still short-range US _ and many more Soviet _ nuclear missile systems deployed in Europe, and we're prepared to negotiate the reduction of these forces as well as a set of arms control _ new set of arms control talks. At the NATO summit, I will urge my colleagues to agree on the broad objectives for these future US-Soviet negotiations and begin preparations within the alliance for these talks. I would also like to suggest that these new US-Soviet arms control talks begin shortly after the CFE treaty on conventional forces has been signed. In taking these steps, the United States is not going to allow Europe to become ``safe for conventional war.'' There are few lessons so clear in history as this: Only the combination of conventional forces and nuclear forces have ensured this long peace in Europe. But every aspect of America's engagement in Europe _ military, political, economic _ must be complementary, and one place where they all come together is in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, an organization of 35 states of Europe and North America. The CSCE is already a beacon for human rights and individual freedoms, and now it must take on a broader role. And so, the fourth task for this NATO summit I'm calling for is to reach common allied objectives for the future of CSCE itself. It can help the victorious forces of democracy in Eastern Europe secure their revolutions, and _ as they join the commonwealth of free nations _ be assured a voice in the new Europe. And the CSCE should offer new guidelines for building free societies, including setting standards for truly free elections, adopting measures to strengthen the rule of law, and pointing the way in the needed but painful transition from centralized, command economies to the free markets. The CSCE can also provide a forum for political dialogue in a more united Europe. And I agree with those who have called for regular consultations among senior representatives of the CSCE countries. We should consider whether new CSCE mechanisms can help mediate and settle disputes in Europe. And I believe my Allied colleagues and I should agree to take up these new ideas at a CSCE summit later this year, in conjunction with the signing of the treaty I talked to you about, that conventional force treaty, the CFE treaty. In Eastern Europe, in this hemisphere, the triumph of democracy has cast its warm light on the face of the world like a miraculous dawn. But the outcome of this struggle for freedom is not ordained, and it's not going to be the work of miracles. All of you who graduate here today are part of a historic decision for America's engagement in the future of Europe. And I am convinced that our work to protect freedom, to build free societies, will safeguard our own peace and prosperity. The security of Europe and the world has become very complex in this century. But America's commitment to stability and peace is profoundly clear. And its motivation derives from the strength of our forefathers _ from the blood of those who have died for freedom _ and for the sake of all who would live in peace. And as you leave this great university, every voice, every heart's commitment to freedom, is important. There's a story, about man trying to convince his son that in the struggle for freedom, every voice counts. And they stood in a valley, watching the snow fall on a distant mountain. It might have been a day like today. But they stood there _ ``Tell me the weight of a snowflake,'' the man said. ``Almost nothing,'' answered the boy. As the snow swirled around them, up on the mountain they saw an avalanche whose thunder shook the earth. ``Do you know which snowflake caused that?'' the old man asked. ``I don't,'' answered the boy. ``Maybe,'' said the man, ``like the last snowflake that moves a mountain in the struggle for freedom, a single voice makes a world of difference.'' America's mission in Europe, like millions of individual decisions made for freedom, can make a voice, can make a world of difference. The cry for freedom in Eastern Europe, in South Africa, right here in our precious hemisphere to our south, was heard around the world in the revolution of 1989. And today, in this new age of freedom, add your voices to the thundering chorus. It's a great honor for me to have been at this University. Thank you very much. God bless you, and God bless the United States of America. Thank you all. Thank you so much. Thank you.
DOC.HEAD: END TEXT
Mexican Train Wreck Outside Oaxaca Kills Six
DOC.TEXT: A train carrying about 200 passengers left the rails and fell into a dry riverbed in mountainous Oaxaca state in the south, killing at least six people and hurting at least 40, the Mexican Red Cross said Friday. Oaxacan station chief Jose Velasco Altamirano said the entire train _ two engines, two passenger cars and one freight car _ left the tracks Thursday night, apparently because of brake failure.
