The train was bound from the state capital of Oaxaca city to Mexico City, a trip of about 220 miles, when the derailment occurred at Cuicatlan village. No foreigners were reported aboard.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 200 Skulls Found Near Rebel Camp in Peru
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 human skulls have been found in caves near a guerrilla camp high in the Andean mountains, but authorities said they did not know who the dead were. A medical examiner who accompanied an army patrol to the caves said some of the victims had died violently, and in the past two years, but that other remains might be hundreds of years old. Army sources said some of the bones may be those of rebels fatally wounded in clashes with the military and the police. Others may be those of guerrillas who tried to desert or of peasants kidnapped from nearby villages. The caves are located 14,200 feet above sea level, 20 miles north of this Andean city. Ayacucho is the birthplace of the Maoist-inspired Shining Path guerrilla movement and rebels control much of the surrounding countryside. The skulls and other human bones were found last month by a civil defense group on the lookout for Shining Path rebels. Near the caves the group found 200 sticks of dynamite, medicines, knives, and rebel propaganda. A military patrol from Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima, went to investigate the group's findings. The patrol, accompanied by an Associated Press reporter, returned to Ayacucho Friday. The medical examiner, speaking on condition of anonymity, said many of the bones in the two caves were quite old, and could have been placed there hundreds of years ago. He said he was unable to count the exact number of skulls of recent origin. But some of the recently dead apparently were killed by bullet or machete wounds, the examiner said. More than 18,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path began its armed insurgency 10 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav Police, Demonstrators Clash on Tito Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Police clubbed demonstrators Friday and hauled some off to jail during protests over observing the 10th anniversary of the death of Josip Tito, the founding father of Communist Yugoslavia. Police also broke into a school and detained pupils who ripped Tito pictures off the wall and destroyed them. The incidents took place as factory sirens wailed at 3:05 p.m. _ a signal to mark the hour of Tito's death on May 4, 1980, at age 87. Passers-by mostly ignored the sirens and teen-agers continued enjoying their ice cream. In previous years, Yugoslavs stood still and observed a minute of silence. This time police fought members of the Serbian Radical Party in Belgrade, arresting people who kept yelling, ``Down with the Communists! Out of Serbia!'' Shouts against hard-line Serbian Communist leader Slobodan Milosevic also were heard. No official word came on the number of arrests or possible injuries, but witnesses said some police action was brutal. Protesters tore up and threw in the air old 500-dinar banknotes bearing Tito's image _ now almost worthless following 2,500 percent inflation. Police forced a photographer taking pictures of demonstrators being pushed into a police van to expose his film to light. Demonstrators were seen pulling off a Marshal Tito street sign in downtown Belgrade. The main street of every city, town and village in Yugoslavia is named after Tito. About 200 Radical Party members and other Yugoslavs opposed to continuing public veneration of Tito unfurled a Serbian flag in front of Parliament and carried a placard reading, ``Exterminate the evil'' (communism). For almost 45 years, Tito has been officially revered for his role in fighting the Nazis in World War II, for his break with Moscow in 1948, and for guiding Yugoslavia into the non-aligned movement in the 1960s. But now, many Yugoslavs feel their current ethnic, economic and political troubles took root during Tito's rule, They blame the weak, decentralized leadership system he bequeathed for many of the problems. Parliament is expected to decide soon to annul a law that makes it a criminal offense to criticize Tito or his policies. Criticism of Tito has centered recently on his authoritarian style of rule. He is now openly charged with setting up a death camp on an island off the central Adriatic coast in which more than 5,000 pro-Soviet Communists died after Tito took Yugoslavia out of the Soviet orbit. In his native Croatia, Tito is criticized by those he purged as nationalists in 1971. Several are successfully returning to politics now that Croatia and Slovenia have embraced multiparty systems and free elections. In Serbia, which still advocates Communism, nationalism has grown over the past two years, fueling criticism of Tito, the Croat. Serbs allege that Tito's rule gave Croatia and Slovenia, the two most developed of Yugoslavia's six republics, unfair economic advantages. Serbia's Communist Party, staking its fate on the popularity of Serbian President Milosevic, on Friday promised free, democratic elections in Yugoslavia's largest republic within six months. In Slovenia, Croatia and other parts of Yugoslavia, several peaceful, memorial gatherings were held to commemorate Tito, particularly in the armed forces, the state Tanjug news agency reported.

DOC.HEAD: Students Blockade Women-Only Campus to Protest Vote to Admit Men
DOC.TEXT: Enraged students took control of Mills College on Friday, staging sit-ins and blockades they vowed would continue until the exclusive women's school reverses a decision to admit men. The noisy but non-violent demonstrators conducted a sit-in at the office of Mills President Mary Metz and shut down classes at the normally quiet, tree-lined liberal arts college. Most teachers supported the disruption, which could last until the May 20 graduation. Students, wearing signs demanding the resignation of board of trustees chairman Warren Hellman, even drove Metz from her home about 9 a.m. with blaring horns and music and cries of ``We Will Not Accept This.'' ``We're shutting them down,'' said Thomlyn Gingell, a sophomore art history major. ``We haven't been listened to. Maybe this will make them listen.'' But administrators, who couldn't get to their offices because of student blockades and sit-ins involving several hundred of the 777 undergraduate women, said the board of trustees wouldn't change its mind. The board, citing declining enrollment and revenues, voted Thursday night to accept men as undergraduates, bringing an end to Mills' 138-year policy of admitting only women. ``No one was happy with the decision, but we believe that life goes on,'' said Metz, who agreed to meet with students Friday and again Tuesday to discuss the decision to go co-ed. ``I don't believe the board will reverse itself,'' she said. ``I hope this grieving starts the healing process.'' While students protested, members of the Mills College Alumnae Association held what they described as a ``wake'' at the group's campus office. After the trustees' vote, the alumnae group decided to consult an attorney to see if Mills students can sue the school to keep from going co-ed in the fall of 1991. Marge Thomas, of the graduate class of 1963, said alumnae don't believe they can get the trustees to reverse their decision, but that maybe the board will approve waiting to go co-ed until after the 1990 first-year students are graduated. ``They came here to go to a women's college and they should be allowed to finish in a women's college,'' Thomas said. Many women at Mills said they would not return next year because of the trustees' vote. ``I can't believe they would ignore us like that,'' said Amy Hutto, one of a handful of undergraduates who shaved their heads in protest. Enrollment in Mills' 33 undergraduate programs is down 4.2 percent from three years ago and below the 1,000 students needed to balance the $24 million annual budget, economists at the school said. Tuition at Mills is almost $12,000. Mills is the only single-sex learning institution in Northern California. Two women's colleges are located in Southern California and 94 remain nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk, Mandela Announce Agreement to Work for Political Peace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf pvs `In Washington' to UPDATE with Tutu comment; pick up 11th pvs, `This week's...'
DOC.TEXT: The government and the African National Congress said Friday they will work together for the first time to stop political violence and clear the way for talks on ending white-minority rule. President F.W. de Klerk and ANC leader Nelson Mandela, looking relaxed and confident after the three days of talks, said the preliminary discussions were an important step toward giving South Africa's black majority a share of power. ``It is the realization of a dream for which we have worked patiently and consistently,'' Mandela said after the first talks ever between the ANC and government. In a joint communique, the sides said a ``working group'' will be created to try to end obstacles to full negotiations on changing the constitution. In a major clause, the communique said the government ``reiterates its commitment to work toward lifting'' the nearly 4-year-old state of emergency. The lifting of the emergency is one of the ANC's demands before constitutional negotiations can begin. The communique indicated the delegations made progress on most other issues as well. Among them, it said the government will consider ``urgently granting'' temporary immunity from prosecution to ANC executive members in exile. This would enable them to return to South Africa to help end political violence. The granting of immunity to ANC exiles has been another demand of the African National Congress. ``I regard what is contained in this document as an important breakthrough in the peaceful process we want to take place in South Africa,'' de Klerk said. He said no agreement had been made on further talks, but the working group would report by May 21 and both sides hoped for quick progress. In Washington, the United States hailed the ``courageous decision'' by the sides to work toward further talks. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, in London to receive an award, warmly welcomed the outcome of talks. ``We are very thrilled with the way things seem to have developed,'' the Nobel laureate said, smiling broadly. ``I think the way things have gone has exceeded our highest hopes.'' This week's talks were an attempt to clear obstacles standing in the way of formal negotiations on changing the constitution to give the black majority a voice in national affairs. In addition to lifting the state of emergency, the ANC wants the release of all political prisoners and the return from exile of top ANC officials without fear of prosecution. The state of emergency has been in effect since June 1986, and the ANC says it is used by police to suppress political activity and peaceful dissent. The government says it wants to lift the emergency, but that it remains necessary to combat black factional fighting that has claimed more than 600 lives this year, many in the southeastern province of Natal. The communique stressed the need to end that political violence, which pits rival Zulu factions against each other. The government also has demanded the ANC renounce its largely ineffective guerrilla war. ``The ANC will therefore look into the question of the armed struggle and take appropriate decisions,'' Mandela said. While the two sides appear to have made progress, both stressed that extremely difficult and long negotiations lie ahead before there can be any hope of a peaceful settlement. De Klerk has rejected majority rule for South Africa's 28 million blacks and says there must be safeguards for the 5 million whites and other minorities, including veto power over government decisions. The ANC insists it wants full democracy with no special privileges for any group. The two leaders, who shook hands and smiled in front of news cameras, disagreed during the news conference on several issues, including apartheid and international economic sanctions. Asked if apartheid was dead in South Africa, Mandela replied, ``I must tell you what I have told the state president and his delegation: that 27 years ago when I went to jail I had no vote and 27 years thereafter I still have no vote and that is due to the color of my skin.'' De Klerk released Mandela in February after he had served 27 years of a life term for sabotage and plotting the overthrow of the government. De Klerk responded that talks would be needed before blacks would get to vote. ``While apartheid is going in South Africa, the anti-apartheid movements are keeping it alive,'' he said without further explanation. But Mandela also was quick to praise de Klerk, saying, ``I have not the slightest doubt that the state president means what he says. And I have no doubt whatsoever about their (the government's) integrity,'' he said. Mandela said the ANC would not ask the international community for more economic sanctions against South Africa, but he also said there would be no call to ease or end the sanctions. De Klerk said sanctions were not in the interests of South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Agency Chief Shakes Up Top Jobs
DOC.TEXT: The acting chief of the Drug Enforcement Administration wants to shift some top deputies in a personnel shuffle that would include transfer for a man considered a competitor for the top job. Acting DEA Administrator Terrence Burke is preparing to formally propose the changes to the Justice Department, DEA spokesman Frank Shults said Friday. Shults said the proposed changes would be normal rotations and would not reflect a change in policies. The most visible change proposed by Burke would shift David Westrate from assistant administrator in charge of operations to assistant administrator for planning and inspection. Westrate, one of the DEA's chief spokesmen on Capitol Hill, was Burke's boss until Burke was named deputy administrator of the DEA last year. Burke has become acting administrator since the retirement of former Administrator John C. Lawn. The Bush administration has not yet nominated a permanent replacement for Lawn. But both Westrate and Burke are among those being considered for the job, according to Justice Department sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Westrate has held the job directing DEA's worldwide operations since August 1985, and has generally spoken for the DEA at congressional hearings. Replacing Westrate as operations director would be Stephen H. Greene, who has been Westrate's deputy for about a year, said Shults. Greene was also Burke's replacement when Burke became deputy administrator to Lawn. Peter F. Gruden, who has been assistant administrator for planning and inspection for several years, would become the special agent in charge of the Washington field office, Shults said. The chief of the Washington field office, Ronald J. Caffrey, would replace Greene as the deputy assistant administrator for operations under Burke's reorgnization. ``Our agents normally rotate to different jobs every two to three years,'' Shults said. ``Executives don't rotate that often because there aren't that many jobs available for them.'' Shults said these latest moves ``don't mean anything'' in terms of change in DEA policy and are not meant to be critical of anyone's performance. Westrate did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

DOC.HEAD: 200 Stage Armed Protest in Armenia
DOC.TEXT: About 200 armed men surrounded a Communist Party building in the Armenian capital of Yerevan for hours Friday, but dispersed peacefully after presenting a list of political demands, authorities and witnesses said. No injuries were reported. The building houses the city party committee. News photographer Garo Lachinian said by telephone that the crowd of mostly young men carried weapons ranging from flintlocks and knives to Kalashnikov assault rifles and that some took to nearby rooftops while the rest surrounded the building in downtown Yerevan. Members of the group called themselves the Armenian National Army and presented a list of demands to party officials, said Ashot Manucharyan of the Armenian National Movement. Manucharyan emphasized that his group was not connected with the militants and disagrees with their tactics. The militants' demands ranged from withdrawal of all Soviet troops from Armenia to a multiparty system in the republic and a six-month postponement of May 20 legislative elections, Manucharyan said in a telephone interview. On April 15, crowds attacked the KGB headquarters in Yerevan with stones, torches and flare guns. That assault was said to have been triggered by the arrest of Armenians on charges of stealing weapons from a military unit. At least one person was killed and another was badly wounded. Manucharyan said the militants organized in January, when many firearms were stolen during ethnic clashes between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in the two Caucasus republics. Gevorg Oganesyan, a spokesman for the regional party Central Committee, said some armed men entered the building Friday and ordered everyone out except for regional party officials, who were presented with a list of their demands. Col. Grant Avakyan of the Armenian Interior Ministry said the men left after talking with the party and local police, but kept their weapons. He said the incident lasted about six hours. The men also want Soviet troops withdrawn from Nagorno-Karabakh, a predominantly Armenian enclave within the republic of Azerbaijan, said Dela Avetisyan, duty officer of Armenpress news agency in Yerevan. Riots and attacks against KGB, government and party buildings have occurred often in the southern Soviet Union in the past year. Some attacks are aimed clearly at seizing arms, and others at forcing force political change.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives of British Hostage Travel to Washington
With AM-Hostages-Reed, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hostage Brian Keenan's two sisters flew to Washington Friday to meet freed American hostage Frank Reed, who was held with their brother and telephoned them to let them know Keenan was well. The women said they wanted to hear more about the condition of Keenan, who was abducted April 11, 1986, while walking to work at the American University of Beirut. Keenan, an English teacher, holds dual Irish and British citizenship. Reed, who was freed Monday, telephoned Brenda Gillham and Elaine Spence on Thursday to tell them he had seen their 39-year-old brother last Saturday. ``We want to meet the man in person, shake him by the hand and thank him for the news that he brought us,'' Mrs. Gillham told reporters as the sisters changed planes at London's Heathrow Airport en route from their Belfast home to the United States. ``He has said that Brian is still strong-willed, so his character doesn't seemed to have changed,'' Mrs. Gillham said. The sisters said their five-day visit will include meetings with other families of hostages. Mrs. Spence said she and her sister ``want to know if Brian has talked about home and the family and we want to ask Frank what we can do next to try to get Brian out.'' Reed arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington Friday, after several days' rest at a U.S. military hospital in Wiesbaden, West Germany. Upon arrival, he paid tribute to all hostage relatives, including Keenan's sisters, saying that because of them, ``I am unchained and unblindfolded.'' Mrs. Spence said she believed the Irish government was working hard for the release of her brother, adding: ``I just hope this is the start of a process which will bring them all home.'' Reed said he had been held for six months with Keenan and British journalist John McCarthy. He said both men were well despite being chained and blindfolded. Before leaving West Germany, Reed said Britain should do more to free the two. ``They are my best mates, those guys, we're going to get them out,'' he said. McCarthy was kidnapped on his way to Beirut airport to leave the country on April 17, 1986. Keenan and McCarthy are among 16 Westerners held hostages in Lebanon. Six are American, including Associated Press correspondent Terry Anderson, kidnapped in March 1985 and the longest held.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Oppose Barry Motions
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors in the drug trial of Mayor Marion Barry argued Friday that they should not have to provide his lawyers with copies of regulations that govern drug investigations or all the fine details of the case against him. In another development in the case, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson set May 25 for a pre-trial hearing on a series of motions by the mayor seeking dismissal of the eight criminal charges against him. Barry's lawyers say he is the victim of prosecutorial ``overreach'' by a U.S. attorney's office that violated government regulations in an FBI sting operation leading to the mayor's arrest. Barry was arrested Jan. 18 after being videotaped smoking crack cocaine in a room of a Washington hotel. He is accused of five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about involvement with drugs. In one of their motions, the mayor's lawyers said the government had violated its own procedures in the arrest and demanded that the goverment produce its regulations for undercover drug operations. In a court filing Friday in reply, the government said Barry should not be given the regulations. ``Even if there were a violation of an agency regulation _ and the government vigorously denies that there was _ it would not entitle'' Barry ``to any relief unless'' his constitutional rights were violated, said prosecutors. Disclosing the guidelines ``could compromise ongoing and future undercover operations if the confidential aspects of law enforcement investigative techniques were publicly disclosed,'' they wrote. Barry seeks specific times of his alleged possessions of cocaine, amounts of cocaine and descriptions of narcotics paraphernalia, far more detail than the government is required to produce before trial, said the prosecutors in opposing Barry's motion for a bill of particulars of the charges against him. Barry ``has been informed of all tangible evidence, provided copies of all laboratory reports, provided copies of his grand jury testimony and given access to all of the Government's evidence'' that is required by federal court rules, said the government. Prosecutors noted a court case which concluded that if defendants ``were given the minutiae they seek, the slightest discrepancy between the particulars and the evidence at trial would open the door'' to an attempt to confuse the jury. In a 1979 case, an Internal Revenue Service agent obtained incriminating evidence against a defendant in a manner that violated IRS regulations. The Supreme Court refused to suppress the evidence, prosecutors in the Barry case noted in their filing. The high court ruled that it could discourage the development of additional law enforcement safeguards to apply the existing regulations too rigidly.

DOC.HEAD: Stars Gather for Lennon Memorial Concert
DOC.TEXT: International pop stars gathered in John Lennon's native city of Liverpool on Friday to rehearse the Beatles songs they will perform at a memorial concert for the slain star. Terence Trent D'Arby, Kylie Minogue and Wet Wet Wet will join such '60s and '70s rockers as Joe Cocker and the Moody Blues in a Saturday concert that will be televised in Britain. The program will be re-broadcast around the world in October as part of a 50th birthday tribute to Lennon. The surviving former Beatles _ George Harrison, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr _ are not attending, but McCartney and Starr have prepared filmed contributions. Yoko Ono, Lennon's widow, said of the three surviving Beatles: ``They will be with us in spirit.'' Lennon was shot to death in New York City on Dec. 8, 1980, when he was 40. The confessed killer, Mark Chapman, is serving a life prison sentence. Concert proceeds are to go to the Spirit Foundation, a charity for environmental projects that Yoko Ono and Lennon founded. The organizers said they hoped for a turnout of 45,000. Tickets are $41.

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Boy's Leg Saved in Special Surgery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Surgeon chief is cq in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A 7-year-old boy who faced amputation of his leg because of a congenital defect will likely regain full use of the limb following a complicated bone graft and leg-stretching process, his surgeon said Friday. Josh Ellison, who underwent eight hours of surgery on Tuesday, was recovering at The Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan after the second half of the two-part process was completed, Dr. Andrew Weiland said. ``He's a tough little kid. He's doing great, doing just fine,'' said Weiland, surgeon chief at the hospital. ``He should end up with a fairly normal, functioning left leg.'' Without the procedure, the boy unquestionably would have lost his leg, Weiland said. ``He's amazing,'' the boy's mother, Kate Ellison, said from his hospital room. ``It's already hard to keep him down. He wants to get out and do whatever.'' The Cabool, Mo., boy was born with congenital pseudarthrosis in the left leg _ a localization of the disease which afflicted the Elephant Man. The ailment caused his left tibia, or shin bone, to bend rather than grow straight. When he was eight months old, he suffered a fractured leg because of the illness and underwent several unsuccessful operations in Missouri. His right leg was 3{ inches longer than his left before this most recent treatment began in February. ``We were told they would have to amputate, but we didn't want to hear it,'' said Mrs. Ellison. ``We tried to find someone who could help Josh.'' They were directed to Weiland, an expert in microvascular bone grafting. In this procedure, a bone, the surrounding tissue and its blood supply are transplanted to another part of the body, where microsurgery reconnects all the blood vessels. Josh was brought to New York in February to begin the first phase of treatment, the Ilazarov procedure to lengthen the leg. Every day for two months, Mrs. Ellison turned three dials surgically attached to her son's leg to stretch it out. The device lengthened his leg by one millimeter per day, and when Josh arrived for the surgery on Tuesday the legs were almost the same length, Weiland said. Doctors took a bone from his right leg and implanted it where the diseased bone had been. If everything continues to work out, Mrs. Ellison will bring Josh back to Missouri on Monday. He will spend the next three months wearing a splint to support the transplanted bone, with Weiland expecting to see the boy for a check-up this summer.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawks Bury a Casualty of Reservation Gambling War
DOC.TEXT: Singing ``Give Peace a Chance,'' Mohawks traveling in a cortege of bullet-pocked cars on Friday buried an Indian killed in a factional battle over gambling on their reservation. In other developments, one faction claimed to have deposed the tribal government in the Canadian sector of the St. Regis Indian Reservation, which straddles the U.S.-Canadian border. A federal mediation effort was beefed up, and New York Gov. Mario Cuomo proposed creation of a internal police force for the reservation, which is largely unhindered by outside authority. Many Indians say the land is exempt from state and federal law. Factions on the reservation have been battling for weeks over the future of casino gambling and bingo on the reservation. New York state and Canadian police moved in Tuesday to restore order after a clash that killed two Mohawks, one on each side of the gambling dispute. The warring factions laid aside their differences Friday long enough for the church funeral of gambling opponent Matthew Pyke, 22, who was shot dead in a crossfire Tuesday on the Canadian side of the reservation. Reporters were given rare access to the reservation to watch some 500 mourners walking in rows seven-to-10 wide, holding hands. The cortege was led by 40 Mohawks wearing clan beads, embroidered shirts and other traditional Indian dress. The procession began on the U.S. side of the reservation and ended at St. Regis Catholic Church on the Canadian side. Mohawks barred reporters from crossing the border to the church. A woman in the front row carried a framed picture of Pyke, while mourners at the rear of the procession sang ``Give Peace a Chance,'' the anti-war song by the late John Lennon. A procession of about a dozen cars followed, some bearing the scars of the gambling violence. One was missing all its windows except the windshield because the others had been shattered by gunfire. ``We're putting aside our anger for the day,'' said Eddie Gray, who walked in the procession. ``It's a day for mourning.'' Four hours after Pyke was killed, the body of gambling supporter Harold Edwards Jr., 32, was found near the same spot. No arrests have been made in the killings. Members of the pro-gambling Warrior Society, a self-appointed reservation security force, said they observed two hours of silence in honor of Pyke, though he worked on the on opposing side in the gambling dispute. ``It's our traditional belief that we have total respect for the dead,'' said warriors supporter Minnie Garrow. Violence has flared occasionally on the 28,000-acre reservation since last July, when the FBI and state police raided casinos on Indian land. Mohawks who oppose gambling say the casinos breed crime. Supporters say the gambling halls are an economic boon for the reservation, where about 9,000 Mohawks live. In other developments Friday, Warriors said the 12-member Band Council, which governs the Canadian side of the reservation, had been voted out of office. An interim council was sworn in Thursday, said Stanley Cohen, a lawyer for the Warriors. Some had criticized the council when its leader last week ordered evacuation of 500 women, children and elderly because of the violence. They accused him of trying to make the violence seem worse than it was. Chief Mike Mitchell, who heads the Band Council, could not be reached for comment Friday on whether the interim council had superseded his own. The Canadian government still recognizes Mitchell's council, said Ron Boivin, a spokesman for the Canadian Indian affairs department. Gov. Mario Cuomo _ under fire from some Indians for sending in state police _ said in Albany that he would press for creation of an independent Mohawk police force on the reservation. Cuomo had been urged by some Mohawk factions and the Canadian government to intercede. In Washington, the Justice Department announced it had dispatched a specially assembled mediation team. The team was expected to arrive Saturday to buttress the efforts of one federal mediator already there, said Grace Flores Hughes, director of the department's Community Relations Service.

DOC.HEAD: Breeden: Milken Testimony Before Congress Could Complicate Case
DOC.TEXT: Congressional testimony by convicted junk bond dealer Michael Milken before he is sentenced could complicate the government's massive securities fraud investigation, Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said Friday. The House Energy and Commerce oversight and investigations subcommittee voted Tuesday to subpoena Milken, who pleaded guilty last month to six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million. If Milken receives immunity from the panel, nothing he says at a congressional hearing could be used against him in state or federal courts. ``I think we'll try to work with Congress to make sure they understand the status of the case as they consider what hearings they wish to have and when they want to have them,'' Breeden told reporters during an informal session in his office. ``If you had immunized testimony before ... the plea agreement and the settlement becomes irrevocable on the date of sentencing, then it does create potential for introducing complications into the case,'' said Breeden. The subpoena must be approved by the full House committee before Milken is called to testify before Congress, something he refused to do two years ago. Milken, once head of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. department that dealt in high-risk, high-yield junk bonds, faces up to 28 years in prison when he is sentenced in New York on Oct. 1. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of both the committee and subcomittee, said in a statement issued through his office: ``We're aware of the concerns of the SEC and others and will work closely with them to avoid major complications. However, the subcommittee intends to continue to perform its duties and oversight with vigor.'' On other topics, Breeden said it was ``premature at this point'' to say what impact a recent appeals court decision in New York overturning the insider trading conviction of ex-stockbroker Robert Chestman would have on SEC enforcement efforts. He said the SEC was studying the decision to determine whether to appeal it and what implications it has for pending cases and settlements already reached. ``We're certainly not going to get into renegotiating settlements at a preliminary stage,'' said Breeden. In settling civil and criminal charges with the SEC and the Justice Department, Milken agreed to testify truthfully before grand juries and at trials or court proceedings stemming from ``any Drexel-related activities.'' If Milken fails to comply with those rules he can be prosecuted for perjury and obstruction of justice and jailed for contempt of court. The agreements do not mention congressional testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Thunderstorms East Of Mississippi, Sunny in the West
DOC.TEXT: Strong thunderstorms developed east of the Mississippi River on Friday and extended from Illinois through Mississippi to coastal Texas, but the sun shone throughout much of the West. Showers and thunderstorms also fell from the Ohio Valley to Virginia and North Carolina. Late Friday morning, a thunderstorm in north-central Kentucky produced hail an inch in diameter at Harned. Light rain and drizzle extended from Iowa and northern Missouri to northern Ohio and lower Michigan. A few light showers also developed ahead of an upper level weather disturbance crossing the northern Plains. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunshine abundant in the western half of the country. Strong, gusty north winds blew from the southern Plains to the middle Mississippi Valley Friday afternoon, and blustery north winds ushered cool air into the nation's midsection. Temperatures rose into the 70s and 80s in the Southeast, while readings were only in the 50s from the southern and central Plains to the upper Great Lakes region. Temperatures were in the 40s from eastern Iowa to southern Lower Michigan and northwestern Ohio. Seasonable temperatures warmed the West: 80s and lower 90s across parts of Southern California and southern Arizona. The nation's low Friday morning was 24 degrees at Trinidad, Colo., where 4 new inches of snow fell. Pueblo, Colo., received 9.4 inches of snow from the most recent storm, pushing the total snowfall for the winter season to 69.6 inches and surpassing the 1947-48 record of 65.8 inches. The snowfall total at Pueblo for the first three days of May was 10.6 inches, beating the previous record of 10.2 inches for May, set in 1917.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney: Lawsuit May Expose Details of Cargo Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: A pilot's relatives sought $3 million in a wrongful-death lawsuit filed Friday in the crash of a plane once rumored to be linked to covert shipments to Central America. The lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court alleges air traffic controllers in Houston misdirected pilot George Reti away from an airstrip as the DC-6A plane ran low on fuel on a flight from El Salvador. The July 20, 1988, crash in a Louisiana bayou killed Reti and two crew members. Some speculated at the time that the flight could have been involved in supplying Contra rebels in Nicaragua. No connection ever has been established, said attorney John Eversole, who represents ex-wife Regina Reti and her daughter. ``Maybe we'll eventually learn the truth about this flight,'' Eversole said. ``It seems the full story about this incident has never come out.'' The flight, which originated in Miami, left San Salvador and was scheduled to stop in New Orleans before returning to Miami. The plane was operated by TACA International Airlines, the Salvadoran national airline, and registered to Miami-based Universal Air Equipment Leasing Inc., the suit said. Speculation was prompted by the route, and fed by both companies' refusal to reveal details of the flight. Found amid the wreckage in the Mississippi delta was about $650,000 worth of electronic components, women's lingerie and iced fish, said Eversole. The crew reported to Houston air traffic controllers that the plane was running low on fuel and would be unable to reach New Orleans International Airport, according to Federal Aviation Administration records. The flight was directed to Leeville, La., about 50 miles south of New Orleans, and told there was a 3,000-foot runway for an emergency landing. But the airstrip actually was in Leesville, La., about 160 miles away near the Texas border. ``It's clear they said, `Leeville.' It was a mistake that cost the lives of three people,'' said Eversole. Killed along with Reti, 39, was his co-pilot, Keith LaFever, and flight engineer, Steven Herreros. There were no passengers. The suit names the U.S. government as defendant, claiming employees of the FAA were negligent and failed to follow proper procedures. A $3 million claim filed with the FAA by Mrs. Reti was rejected last year.

DOC.HEAD: Israel: Shots Fired Near Jordan King's Yacht Were Weapons Check
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf pvs `President Bush' with State Department comment; picks up 7th pvs, `Palace officials...'
DOC.TEXT: Israel's military command denied Friday that one of its navy boats opened fire on the yacht of Jordan's King Hussein in the Gulf of Aqaba. The military, however, admitted shots were fired while the monarch's craft was in the vicinity but said the shots were aimed in another direction and were part of a routine weapons check. An Israeli newspaper had reported an Israeli patrol boat opened fire on Hussein's yacht on Saturday as it sailed in international waters, accompanied by a Jordanian navy vessel, with the monarch on deck. The liberal daily Haaretz, citing sources, said the incident occurred in the Gulf of Aqaba, and resulted in no damage or injuries. The newspaper said Jordan had protested sharply to Israel and the United States, and that Israeli officials refused to apologize but assured Jordan it would not happen again. President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III expressed anger when informed about the incident, the newspaper said. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the U.S. ambassador to Israel, William Brown, had expressed deep concern to the Israeli government over the matter. Brown was told the Israelis have taken steps to avoid such another such incident, the spokesman said. Palace officials in Jordan declined to comment, and spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and the defense ministry could not be reached for comment. The newspaper account said after the first shots were fired, the king took over command of the yacht, ordering the vessel to turn and head for Saudi Arabian waters. The Israeli vessel accelerated and continued to fire as it ``tailgated'' the king's yacht, the report continued, halting and holding fire only when it reached Saudi waters. The king has a residence in the Red Sea port town of Aqaba, which abuts the Israeli resort town of Eilat and is near the Saudi border. The newspaper said neither the king's bodyguards nor the Jordanian navy vessel accompanying the yacht returned fire. The sources quoted by Haaretz also said the Israeli fire came from weapons mounted on the deck, ``not just shots from a pistol.'' The Israeli military command's account differed sharply from the newspaper's version of events. The military comment said in a statement Friday that ``no shots were fired by the Israeli navy at King Hussein's yacht and no chase was conducted.'' But it said its naval vessel did fire some shots toward empty waters in what it described as a check of its guns. It also said the Israeli craft was in Israeli waters. ``Israel naval units have long standing and clear orders regarding rules of conduct during the passage of King Hussein's yacht ... and in the incident noted, the Israel naval vessel acted in accordance with these instructions,'' the statement said. A military spokesman, who could not be named in accordance with regulations, said Hussein's yacht was to the east of the Israeli boat. The military statement said the Israeli shots were fired south. ``I speculate that they (the Jordanians) probably thought the gunfire was directed at them,'' the spokesman said. The spokesman said Hussein's yacht was easily recognizable, and that sailors almost certainly knew it was the monarch's. Israel television reported the naval vessel apparently approached the yacht and that the Jordanians probably interpreted this as a chase.

DOC.HEAD: Cracks Appear in East German Government Over Unification
DOC.TEXT: Dissension broke out in East Germany's first democratic government on Friday over the costs of unification with West Germany. The fragile coalition government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere appeared threatened as the left-leaning Social Democrats attacked what they said was the government's willingness to agree to West Germany's terms for unity. Experts from both countries met in East Berlin on Friday for ongoing talks on shifting East Germany away from a socialist economy as quickly as possible. Although the Social Democrats agreed to join the government of de Maiziere, who leads the conservative Christian Democrats, they complained Friday that the terms of the economic union would create hardships for East Germans. The Social Democrats hold important cabinet posts in de Maiziere's government but have begun distancing themselves from the agreements between the Germanys on merging their economies. ``In the East Berlin Cabinet stands a crack in the house, because we up to now cannot be held responsible for the outcome of the (unification) state treaty,'' said Richard Schroeder, head of the Social Democrat faction in Parliament. ``I am worried about a break in the axle on the way to unity,'' he said. Social Minister Regine Hildebrandt, a Social Democrat, criticized the decision between the governments to tailor East Germany's pension program to West Germany's. She said it would reduce benefits for East Germans. The economies and social institutions of the two nations are to merge on July 2 as a prelude to full unification next year. But Social Democrats have become increasingly critical of what they say is a willingness to accept Bonn's terms and the lack of guarantees to protect East Germans who will give up enormous social subsidies. De Maiziere, whose party finished first in the March 18 elections, formed a coalition with the Social Democrats to have the two-third Parliament majority needed to make constitutional changes that would make unification possible. West Germany says a quick move to a free market will create jobs and raise living standards and eventually eliminate the economic hardships that are expected in the early stages of unification. The dissent in East Germany came as the superpowers, France, Britain and the two Germany states prepared for talks in Bonn on Saturday on the role of a united Germany in the military alliances. Although the Christian Democrats, who finished first in the March 18 national elections, and the Social Democrats, who finished second, are part of the same government, many of their candidates are facing each other in Sunday's local elections. The two governments agreed on the general terms of an economic union on Wednesday. It would exchange salaries, wages and small savings accounts of East Germans for an equal amount of West German marks. Social Democrats are critical of a provision to keep the debts of East German factories, many of which are expected to fail. They are demanding that the debts be forgiven. Mrs. Hildebrandt also criticized the pension plan agreement that she said would reduce benefits to a third of the 2.9 million elderly and handicapped participants. Wolfgang Tierse, deputy chief of the Social Democrats faction, said his party would not endorse the economic and social treaty that is being negotiated as a basis for unification. He said it would bring ``massive poverty.''

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Reed Finally Home, Praying for `Mates Left Behind'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf: ``Moments after,'' to CORRECT hospital, base hospital sted Walter Reed
DOC.TEXT: Freed American hostage Frank Reed returned to his homeland Friday with a prayer that ``my mates left behind'' will quickly share his freedom and joy. ``God,'' he implored, ``make it soon.'' Drawn and unsteady despite several days' rest at a U.S. military hospital in Wiesbaden, West Germany, Reed was embraced by his family and another former hostage, Robert Polhill, who was released by separate captors in Lebanon just eight days before Reed was let go Monday. Reed, freed after 42 months, whispered in Polhill's ear: ``We're going to get the rest of them out, aren't we?'' In a brief formal statement that left his greeters shedding tears as a gentle rain fell, Reed said: ``Fellow Americans, because of all of you I'm alive.'' And in a special tribute to all hostage relatives, several of whom were on hand in a customary show of unity, he declared ``Because of Peggy Say, Kit and Joan Sutherland, the Keenan sisters, Pat McCarthy, and many, many others, I am unchained and unblindfolded.'' Moments after he boarded a bus which was to take himself and his family to the Malcolm Grow Medical Center at the base, the caravan was diverted down the tarmac where, to Reed's delight, he was greeted by Barbara Bush as she was about to board a flight to Kentucky. ``We're so glad you're home,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``I know the president wishes he was here to meet you.'' Bush was in Oklahoma giving a speech on NATO and the future of Europe. The release of Reed and Polhill left six Americans and nine other Westerners still held in Lebanon. Of those, Reed, 57, has said he shared moments in captivity with Terry Anderson, The Associated Press' chief Middle East correspondent who was kidnapped in March of 1985 and is the longest held hostage, as well as Thomas Sutherland, an American University of Beirut official, and Britons Brian Keenan and John McCarthy. Ms. Say, Anderson's sister, and Sen. Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, where Reed's family resides in Malden, were among non-family members to greet the former hostage as he stepped from the small Air Force jetliner. Two daughters by a previous marriage, Marilyn Langston and Jacqueline Reed, were the first to board the plane for a private reunion moments earlier. Reed told the airport gathering, ``Because Tom, Terry, John and Brian refused to give up, I am with you today.'' Reed was accompanied on the flight from Germany by his wife Fahima, known as Fifi, and their young son Tarek, who played on the tarmac with a live, lobster that Kennedy presented. In Germany, Reed had remarked that the first thing he wanted when he got home was a 3-pound lobster. ``Of course, I want every hostage released,'' he said. ``Let the world not forget that what me and my mates ... represent is something that transcends all geopolitical ideas and motives.'' That something, he added, is the right to ``freedom and life.'' ``I ask all of you today, tonight and tomorrow to send personal messages to every political leader involved in this terrible tragedy, asking for its end. ``I thank you for your love and concern and yes, for your tears. For I cry with you that this tragic affair will end soon. God, make it soon. That good men like my mates left behind never, never, never again have to go through what I have been through and what others are still going through. Amen, amen, amen.'' ``And finally,'' he added, ``let the people of Ireland and England never forget Brian or John. For God's sake, they are you and you are they. You can't let them down.'' Reed, while still in West Germany, had said Britain should be doing more to free its own citizens in Lebanon. He offered no such criticism of his own government. Reed likely will visit President Bush within days, as has Polhill already. Kennedy, who spent a few moments alone with Reed aboard the twin-engine executive jet, said ``I thought he was in superb spirits. ``I admire his personal courage,'' said Kennedy, adding ``We're hopeful and optimistic that we're in a new time and a new era'' in which all hostages will soon be freed. During his captivity, Reed's Islamic captors falsely told him that his aging mother, Leota Sprague, had died, daughter Marilyn told reporters. Friday, Reed said ``to every member of my family, and a very special 91-year-old beautiful mother of mine, who by example demonstrated to the world that we Reeds are not quitters, I love and thank you for your prayers.'' Reed lost 60 pounds in captivity during which he was kept blindfolded and bound, but is otherwise in basically sound health, doctors have said.

DOC.BYLINE: Observers Predict $34 Million Judgment Against Inquirer Won't Stand ^By MIKE OWEN
DOC.TEXT: A $34 million libel judgment against The Philadelphia Inquirer raises serious constitutional questions and will likely be overturned on appeal, a media lawyer and a reporter's group said Friday. A Common Pleas Court jury on Thursday awarded $2.5 million in compensatory damages and $31.5 million in punitive damages to former first assistant district attorney Richard Sprague. He sued the paper over stories published 17 years ago that questioned his actions as a prosecutor. ``It's unimaginable to me that a punitive damage award in this amount could or would be upheld,'' said Floyd Abrams, a prominent First Amendment lawyer. He represents NBC in appealing a $5.3 million libel judgment won by entertainer Wayne Newton. ``This is another example of libel law running amok,'' Abrams said. ``I think that this case and others will sooner rather than later lead the Supreme Court to address the constitutionality of punitive damages in libel cases.'' Henry Kaufman, general counsel of the Libel Defense Resource Center, a media-sponsored clearinghouse in New York, said the judgment was the largest ever against the news media. He said only two libel judgments of more than $1 million have been affirmed on appeal. Sprague, now a successful attorney in private practice, won for the second time before a jury in the case. The Inquirer had earlier successfully appealed a $4.5 million verdict _ less than one-seventh the amount of Thursday's award, which Sprague said gave meaning to the idea of punitive damages. ``I intend to fight to maintain it,'' Sprague said Friday. ``The whole theory of punitive damages is that it should not just be a little slap on the wrist. It's got to be meaningful.'' A tendency for juries to grant ever-higher punitive damages has come under scrutiny in other areas recently. Last month, the Supreme Court agreed to decide in an Alabama insurance fraud case whether punitive damage awards can be so great as to become unconstitutional. The court last year ruled large awards in civil suits do not violate the Constitution's ban on excessive fines, but the court did not address the question of whether such awards violate due process protections. ``Punitive damages in general are dangerous,'' Abrams said. ``In libel cases, they are perilous. Juries are given no standards, no limits, no bounds. And sometimes they act that way.'' In the Philadelphia case, jurors were given only the newspaper's net worth, $102 million, in determining how to set the punitive damages. The newspaper was not allowed to cite Sprague's income, which Forbes magazine estimated at $1.6 million in 1988. Common Pleas Court Judge Charles P. Mirarchi Jr. said the jury had to find outrageous conduct, and that it could set an award to punish the Inquirer and to send a message to the rest of the news media. ``My basic opinion is that the law is fair and the jury must make that determination, not the judge,'' Mirarchi said. Jane Kirtley, executive director of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, sees a First Amendment issue in such awards. ``All a punitive damage award is when it's awarded against a news organization is a fine for speaking,'' she said. ``But beyond that ... it doesn't have to bear any relationship to anything.'' Reed Irvine, chairman of Accuracy in Media, a conservative watchdog group, believes punitive damages do have a place in libel cases. But he also sees problems with the judgment against the Inquirer. ``The amounts involved here are almost ruinous in a sense,'' Irvine said. ``I think that's going too far myself. It's legitimate to give 'em a good hard rap across the knuckles, but it's another to take it out of their hide.'' The group's director of media analysis, former Philadelphia Inquirer staffer Joseph Goulden, said such awards are ``saying what the public's saying about the press. The only way to enforce a code of ethics is in the courtroom.'' Abrams said he was worried about the impact on news gathering: ``Punitive damages have the potential for so chilling speech that the public would lose a significant amount of the most important news that reporters present.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Runs into Soviet Wall on NATO Membership for United Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Baker fails to persuade Soviets to go along with NATO membership for united Germany, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BON7,9,16
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III ran into a stone wall Friday when he tried to persuade the Soviet Union to withdraw its objections to NATO membership for a united Germany. ``I can't say we heard anything different than we heard before,'' a senior U.S. official said after Baker met for 3{ hours with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Baker's hotel room overlooking the Rhine River. The official, who briefed reporters under rules guaranteeing him anonymity, said the two sides also made no dent in issues blocking treaties to reduce their long-range nuclear missiles and to lower troop and tank levels in Europe. Baker and Shevardnadze will meet in Moscow May 16-19 to try to close the gap on weapons cutbacks. But with the Washington summit less than a month away, prospects appear to be diminishing for presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev initialing a landmark arms control accord. Friday's meeting produced one tentative agreement _ a joint effort to assist the hungry in Ethiopia. The official said the idea is to fly American food to Ethiopia aboard Soviet planes. But on Germany and on arms control, the results were slim. Baker also brought up the issue of Lithuania, where an independence movement is being stifled by a Kremlin economic blockade. ``It's fine to talk about a need for dialogue, but one actually has to take steps to get to a dialogue,'' the senior official said of Soviet inability to reach a formula for talks with Lithuanian leaders. Baker and Shevardnadze were in Bonn for the ``two-plus-four'' German unification talks that open Saturday. The foreign ministers from Britain, France and the two German states also will take part. Baker meanwhile released a text of a statement he made to foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at a closed session in Brussels. In it, Baker said, ``The reform process in the Soviet Union will be called into question if self-determination in Lithuania is denied.'' He said the Bush administration did not wish to take any action that could escalate the situation. But he hinted U.S. patience is running out _ and that critics of the administration's soft approach could win out. ``We understand the pressures affecting the Soviet leadership,'' Baker said. ``They, too, must understand that we have our own principles and are subject to our own political pressure.'' At the start of Friday's talks, Shevardnadze told reporters, ``We consider a unified Germany as an important factor of stability and peace in Europe.'' But he added: ``For such a giant to belong to one bloc, one alliance, will not create conditions of stability.'' Shevardnadze seemed to want U.S. troops to remain in Germany, however, and offered no alternative to NATO membership, the senior official said. ``I think the Soviets are still wrestling with the problem,'' he added. Shevardnadze called his talks with Baker on arms control issues a ``very constructive and useful conversation.'' But he said they had not settled any of their differences over restricting long-range nuclear missiles. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany held separate talks with Shevardnadze and Baker on Friday. Kohl spokesman Hans Klein said Kohl offered Shevardnadze a significant expansion of bilateral ties, particularly economic cooperation. West German Foreign Ministry spokesman Juergen Chrobog said Thursday's U.S. decision to scrap deployment of new short-range nuclear weapons ``will be of enormous importance because the question of disarmament is very much linked with the develoment in Europe and also the German-German question.'' He said NATO and the Warsaw Pact were increasingly becoming political organizations rather than military alliances. Baker has said Germany's membership in NATO is not a decision for the Soviets to make, that it is up to the 16 Western allies. But he hopes to persuade Shevardnadze the powerful nation to emerge from the union of West Germany and East Germany will not menace neighbors that lost millions of people at the hands of the Nazis in World War II. Baker also hopes to overcome the slump in negotiations in Vienna to conclude a treaty to reduce troops, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner, a former West German defense minister, said Thursday in Brussels the allies agreed a united Germany would have no nuclear or chemical weapons in its military arsenal. He also suggested Soviet troops might be stationed temporarily in what is now East Germany. Shevardnadze suggested last week that a united Germany should belong to NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Vitaly Churkin, a Soviet Foreign ministry spokesman, told reporters Friday, ``It's very hard to see how Germany loses in that kind of situation.'' The U.S. announcement that it will not deploy any new short-range nuclear missiles in West Germany set a positive tone for the talks in Bonn. America also will not modernize nuclear artillery shells stored in Europe, and Baker offered to negotiate a reduction in the 88 Lance launchers that target East Germany with 700 nuclear missiles and 900 conventional rockets. Shevardnadze called the U.S. move a ``good decision.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Government, Noriega Attorney Square Off Over $20 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs to UPDATE with judge ordering prosecutors to come up with list of assets seized from Noriega, quotes, details. Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday ordered prosecutors to come up with a list of $20 million in assets seized from Manuel Noriega, saying some of the money must have come from the deposed Panamanian ruler's legitimate activities. During an hour-long hearing prompted by defense attorneys' request to withdraw from the case, lead defense lawyer Frank Rubino claimed that U.S. intelligence agencies paid $11 million to Noriega, with another $6 million coming from foreign governments. ``I don't know if you can call money from the CIA tainted or not, but it's certainly not drug money,'' said Rubino. U.S. District Judge William M. Hoeveler said while Noriega clearly could not use ``ill-gotten gains'' to pay his attorneys, the government could not arbitrarily seize money without proving he had earned it through drug trafficking or other illegal means. Defense attorneys have demanded the frozen accounts be released, saying they can no longer afford to represent Noriega in the complex and expensive case without being paid. But the government insists Rubino may have been paid $1 million or more and says it is under no obligation to turn over drug-tainted funds to the jailed suspect. The judge observed that Noriega had been a military officer for more than 20 years and said he must have acquired some money legitimately. ``It is all the more important, of course, because of who is being prosecuted,'' the judge said. ``And we have got to recognize that our justice system is on display.'' Hoeveler tentatively set a hearing for Friday for the government and the defense to discuss the confiscated assets. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan said the government did not object to such a list. But he said all the accounts, except one, were in foreign banks. ``Foreign governments will have some interest (in the money) and their laws will prevail over those assets,'' Sullivan said. Defense attorneys for two weeks tried unsuccessfully to negotiate with the U.S. attorney's office to release money before deciding Monday to file a motion to withdraw from the case. Rubino said the government already has spent $12 million and was prepared to spend $25 million more prosecuting his client. The attorney said the defense has the right to use Noriega's funds to hire more attorneys, investigators and secretaries. But Sullivan responded with an affidavit from another prosecutor who said Rubino told her he had received a retainer of ``seven figures'' from Noriega. Rubino has acknowledged the comment but said it was a joke. Along with the motion to withdraw, the defense has asked the judge to order the funds released because the government has failed to show, as required by law, that the money was illegally earned. ``We believe that at least $17 million frozen was derived from legitimate sources,'' said a defense motion filed Thursday. ``We will disclose the source of $11 million as directed by this court.'' The remaining $6 million is covered by federal classified information restrictions, limiting public disclosure, the motion said. Rubino noted at the hearing that $5.8 million confiscated by U.S. troops in Noriega's quarters in Panama had been handed back to the Panamanian government by the United States without informing the defense. He said the government had never established whether that money had been acquired illegally. In pleading the defense case, Rubino said attorneys learned ``the intelligence community is in possession of evidence that completely exonerates General Noriega as to a particular count of the indictment,'' but said the defense lacks the money to pursue the lead. The prosecution says the money at issue is held in 27 bank accounts, apparently including some in the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, which was at the center of a money-laundering conspiracy recently tried in Tampa. ``Only one of these accounts, located in Panama, is in the defendant's name,'' the government motion said, adding investigators are not even sure if it contains any money. Noriega was indicted here in February 1988 on charges of taking money from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to make Panama a safe haven for cocaine smuggling. Noriega surrendered to U.S. authorities on Jan. 4, two weeks after U.S. troops invaded Panama. He is being held at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Engineers Say Hubble Wobble Gone
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf: ``Harrington said,'' to give his affiliation, making graf bgn: ``Harrington, a,''
DOC.TEXT: A slight wobble detected in the Hubble Space Telescope has disappeared, engineers said Friday. ``We are not seeing anything of that right now,'' said Mike Harrington, who is directing the months-long checkout of the telescope. ``We are not sure exactly what we saw or what it was.'' Harrington had good news to report: Ground controllers received their first data from the telescope's science computer after sending commands. When the telescope is up and running, it will be that computer that sends the sophisticated science data. The slight jitter showed up Thursday, a motion of just 1-600th of a degree _ too much in an instrument that's supposed to be able to measure the width of a human hair at a range of five miles. Asked what caused it, Harrington said: ``Nobody really knows, it could be as simple as the fact that we weren't calibrated quite right as we started and that we overexcited the controls.'' Harrington, an engineer at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Alabama, said the telescope's pointing control system would be turned on Sunday morning and the jitter, if it's still there, will show up then. The series of problems experienced by the telescope since astronauts left it in space April 25 have put the checkout at least a week behind schedule, Harrington said. ``It's perfectly expectable,'' he said. ``This probably is the most complex spacecraft we've ever flown. You know you are going to have these kinds of things, unexpected and unpredicted little quirks of the spacecraft. You've got to take your time to figure them out and move on.'' The telescope's electronics have gone into a protective mode three times because of small glitches. The telescope's lens cover twice introduced too much motion and a primary antenna brushed up against a cable and could move no further. The first picture had been expected from the telescope by mid-week, but it's now expected no earlier than Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Memo Alleges Mexico City Police Chief Attended Kidnap Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Mexico City's police chief attended a meeting at which the kidnapping of murdered U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena was plotted, a government document says. Javier Garcia Paniagua, Mexico's secretary of state from 1976 to 1982 and a former president of its ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, has not been charged in the case. But according to a prosecution memorandum filed in federal court this week in preparation for next week's trial of four people indicted in Camarena's slaying, he was among 10 people who met in Guadalajara, Mexico, to plan the abduction. Mexican officials expressed surprise at the allegation. ``I have not heard the name of Garcia Paniagua in this case,'' Jose Angel Pescador Osuna, Mexico's consul general in Los Angeles, said Thursday. ``I don't know where they got this information. I am going to send this to Mexico.'' Camarena was abducted in Guadalajara in February 1985 and taken to a house owned by convicted drug trafficker Rafael Caro Quintero where he was interrogated and tortured. His mutilated body and that of his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, were found March 5, 1985, at a ranch 65 miles southeast of Guadalajara. The four who face trial in connection with his killing are Mexican businessman Ruben Zuno Arce; reputed Honduran drug kingpin Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros; Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican homicide officer; and Javier Vasquez Velasco, who is accused of killing two U.S. tourists. The documents, filed by Assistant U.S. Attorneys Manuel Medrano and John Carlton, say several high-ranking Mexican officials, including Garcia, joined reputed drug traffickers to plot the abduction of Camarena, an undercover agent for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. ``Corruption amongst Mexican high-ranking government and law enforcement officials was pervasive,'' a document said. ``Law enforcement officials were on the traffickers' payroll, and facilitated matters by providing protection for marijuana and cocaine loads, and escorting marijuana shipments being transported and smuggled into the United States.'' The documents did not cite any sources. The memo alleges four meetings were held to discuss what to do with Camarena, and that Garcia attended the second one. The meeting Garcia allegedly attended was at the home of Javier Barba Hernandez. Barba, a reputed chief lieutenant of the Guadalajara narcotics cartel, was killed last year in a shootout with Mexican federal police. Others who allegedly attended the meeting included Zuno Arce; Matta Ballesteros; Caro Quintero; Manuel Ibarra Herrera, former director of the Mexican federal security police; Armando Pavon Reyes, Ibarra Herrera's chief aide; Miguel Aldana Ibarra, a former director of Interpol in Mexico; reputed Mexican drug baron Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo; and reputed drug trafficker Manuel Salcido. All but Salcido, who remains a fugitive, and Garcia have been indicted in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Detectives Search For $1 Million In Stolen Art
DOC.TEXT: Detectives searched Friday for more than $1 million worth of stolen artworks, including Egyptian and Roman antiquities, still missing despite the arrest of three suspects in the robbery of a gallery. Four ski-masked bandits shattered the thick plate glass window of the Nahan Galleries in Manhattan's Soho district early Thursday, said Sgt. Dominic Rippillino of the Safe, Loft and Truck Squad, which investigates art theft. They got away with as many as 40 pieces, including ancient Egyptian vases and religious figures, and Roman glass treasures from the second and third centuries B.C. Three etchings by Max Papart, a 79-year-old contemporary of Pablo Picasso, were also taken in their frames, police said. ``They survived 3,000 years, but they didn't survive New York, that's the worst part of it,'' said Sherri Nahan, one of the owners of the private gallery, which offers works for sale. She valued the works at more than $1 million. Mrs. Nahan worried that the fragile antiquities, which measured as small as 3 inches to as large as 12 inches, might have been irreparably damaged. ``Putting them in a box and subjecting them to a 90-mile-an-hour car chase, it's as bad as I can think of handling them,'' she said. A team of detectives on a stakeout nearby heard a report of the robbery and chased the burglars through Manhattan and into the borough of Brooklyn at speeds up to 90 mph, but lost the thieves. Discovery of one of the stolen cars used in the burglary led to three arrests, but a fourth suspect and the art weren't found. Arrested were Robin Tellier, 29, Ronald Rescigno, 29, and Timothy Burns, 23, all of Queens. The three suspects were believed to be part of a gang responsible for several burglaries of fur and jewelry stores in Manhattan, Queens and on Long Island over the last three years, said Sgt. Dominic Rippillino of the Safe, Loft and Truck Squad, which investigates art theft. ``We're hoping that the art does surface, that we're able to track it down,'' he said. Mrs. Nahan said police theorized that the bandits were instructed on what pieces to steal. ``They came with boxes, they came prepared to take small pieces,'' she said. The three suspects were scheduled to be arraigned in Queens Criminal Court on charges of grand larceny, burglary, car theft, and conspiracy, said Dick Piperno, a spokesman for the Queens District Attorney. Tellier was also charged with criminal use of a firearm and criminal possession of a weapon.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Union Boss Stout Convicted in Racketeering Case
DOC.TEXT: A once-powerful municipal union boss was convicted Friday of embezzlement, racketeering and conspiracy for stealing more than $750,000 from the union treasury. A federal jury convicted Earl Stout and two co-defendants, including Stout's son, William. A fourth defendant, Frances Rooney, was acquitted. The 67-year-old Stout was ousted in 1988 after 14 years in control of District Council 33 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The union has 13,000 members, most of them trash collectors, who work for the city of Philadelphia. ``I still say I'm innocent, but that doesn't make any difference does it?'' said Earl Stout. ``But worst things than this can happen. That's the way it goes when you've been at the top.'' Prosecutor Seth Weber accused Stout of abusing his power even while he won benefits for his members. ``While his people were repairing streets and collecting trash he was picking their pockets,'' Weber said. ``Earl Stout believed he was so good for the union, and had done so much, that he believed he could take some of the money he was entrusted to protect.'' The elder Stout was convicted of conspiracy, racketeering, 32 counts of mail fraud and six counts of embezzlement involving a total of $750,000. His son was convicted of conspiracy, mail fraud and eight counts of theft. Cynthia Bullock, former director of the union's Legal Defense Plan, was convicted of 11 counts of mail fraud. Ms. Rooney, former union vice president, was acquitted on both counts against her, conspiracy and theft. Among the allegations against Stout were that he gave no-show jobs at a union-owned John F. Kennedy hospital, which is headed by his son. He also was accused of hiring consultants without permission from the union's governing boards, converting the beneficiary on two life insurance policies on himself from the hospital to his family, and using hospital employees to work on properties owned by his family or his friends.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Crews Report Everglades Fire Under Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with fire reported under control. Picks up 5th graf pvs. ^LaserPhoto staffing; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters backed up against the last natural barrier between a 4-mile wall of flames and a wildlife preserve said Friday they had controlled the fire, which has blackened 25,000 acres of the drought-crisp Everglades. Fire had raced across the dry grasslands and leaped a canal but was beaten back before reaching a levee, the last natural barrier between the flames and the sprawling Big Cypress National Wildlife Preserve, officials said. Shortly after 5 p.m. EDT, the fire was reported under control, said Peter Karayeanes, duty officer for the state Division of Forestry. The area would be monitored in case of flare-ups, he said. A heavy downpour around noon Friday missed the center of the fire but helped firefighters trying to control the last area of violent burning. ``With that rain it slowed it down a little bit, brought the humidity up so right now we have a whole lot of helicopters out here,'' said John Kern, of the state Division of Forestry. ``We're going to try to put it out with water.'' Although arson has not been ruled out, investigators believe the fire was sparked accidentally in an area frequented by people on motorcycles and all-terrain vehicles, said senior state forester Gene Dempsey. Despite the size of the scorched area about 25 miles west of downtown Miami, wildlife officials say the fire has had little effect on animals because the severe drought had already forced most of them to water. ``We have a few snakes and rodents scurrying away, but that's about it,'' Dempsey said. David Maehr, a biologist with the state Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission, said 17 panthers wearing the agency's radio-tracking collars were checked during a routine helicopter flight Friday and were ``nowhere near any danger from fire.'' ``That is panther habitat,'' he said. ``But the thing about the Everglades themselves is it's not as regularly used as more forested landscapes, so we don't have the number of cats using the Everglades, nor do we have the regularity of use.'' Only about 30 to 50 panthers are believed to live in the wilds of south Florida. No injuries have been reported from the fire, and no inhabited areas were threatened by the blaze, one of three west of Miami. Another fire in Everglades National Park about 25 miles southwest of the city scorched 10,500 acres by Friday, but firefighters were confident they could control it by Saturday, said park spokeswoman Darlene Koontz. Seminole Indian firefighters spent Thursday battling a smaller blaze on their reservation in Broward County near the Collier County line. The fire was contained after burning 800 acres. Fires are a part of the Everglades ecology, said park spokeswoman Pat Tolle. But this year's blazes worry environmentalists because the region's 20-month drought has left some normally damp grasslands so dry that they are threatened.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Vows No More Hostages Freed Until Israel Releases Lebanese
LaserPhoto HEL6
DOC.TEXT: Iran's foreign minister said Friday that his country will not work to free more Western hostages in Lebanon until Israel releases hundreds of imprisoned Lebanese. Meanwhile, the Iranian-backed Hezbollah on Friday said it held the U.S. government responsible for hindering the release of the remaining Western hostages. Hezbollah, or Party of God, is believed to be an umbrella group for the hostage-holding factions. ``The U.S. administration bears the responsibility for any complications in this issue,'' said a statement issued in Beirut Friday by Hezbollah's press office. It said ``the ball is now in America's court.'' The Iranian foreign minister, ending a two-day official visit to Finland, said Israel must free ``several hundred Lebanese hostages'' before any steps are taken to free any of the 16 remaining hostages. The minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, demanded that the United States and Britain put pressure on the Israelis and make goodwill gestures to reciprocate for the recent release of two American hostages. Frank Reed was released Monday after 42 months in captivity, and arrived in the United States on Friday. Robert Polhill was released April 22 after being held 39 months. ``The other side has to take practical steps ... to influence Israel and the Phalangists,'' Velayati said, referring to a Christian Lebanese group once allied with Israel. ``Especially the United States and Britain can persuade Israel to release these abducted people,'' the Iranian official said at a news conference. Velayati said the hostages are not in ``the hands of the Iranians'' and that Iran had to persuade the Lebanese groups to release Polhill and Reed. ``Of course, we played a key role, but we worked over months,'' he added. Velayati said ``no deals had been done'' for the release of the two Americans and said that Iran had not been involved in any talks with the United States. Among the remaining hostages in Lebanon are six Americans. The longest held is Associated Press correspondent Terry Anderson, abducted March 16, 1985. The Hezbollah statement also urged the Bush administration to help bring about the release of Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as well as tracing three Iranian officials and their driver who disappeared in Lebanon's Christian heartland in 1982. The four are widely believed killed. Hussein Musawi, who heads a pro-Syrian wing in Hezbollah, was quoted earlier Friday by the leftist Beirut newspaper As-Safir as saying ``We expect sharp complications in resolving the hostage question in the future.'' As-Safir quoted Musawi, interviewed at his headquarters in the Bekaa valley city of Baalbek, as saying that the United States had not responded appropriately to the release of Reed and Polhill.

DOC.HEAD: Gang Crime Falls on City's South Side; Police Volunteers Credited
DOC.TEXT: Reports of gang crime have fallen by more than a third in the section that accounted for half the city's gang violence a year ago, and police crackdowns and neighborhood involvement are being credited. During the first three months of this year, gang crime reported to the Police Department's South Bureau fell by 36 percent compared with the same period last year, police statistics show.
