Gang-related murders dropped 45 percent. In contrast, gang crimes jumped 34 percent in the Central Bureau and 18 percent in the West Bureau for the three-month period. Authorities said that in the past year a flood of staff members and volunteers from Community Youth Gang Services, Brotherhood Crusade, the Nation of Islam, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and other groups have painted over gang graffiti, developed job programs, and started street patrols in South Side neighborhoods. ``Up until this year, we had 50 percent of the city's gang problem in South Bureau. Now it's in the low 40 percent range,'' said South Bureau Deputy Chief William Rathburn. ``I think we are seeing a significant trend and I am optimistic that we can sustain it.'' But police and community leaders agreed that gang violence is still a major problem in the 58-square-mile area that is home to 550,000 people. ``We've made merely a good beginning,'' said Danny Bakewell, Brotherhood Crusade president. ``Now, it's up to all of us who give rhetoric to the problem to demonstrate our commitment on an ongoing basis.''

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Troops Battle Guerrillas as Emergency Rule Ends
DOC.TEXT: Afghan soldiers battled Islamic guerrillas around the eastern city of Jalalabad on Friday, hours after the government ended its 15-month state of emergency in the country, state-run radio reported. Kabul radio, monitored in Islamabad, said ``a number of political opponents'' were killed in the fighting and large amounts of weapons and ammunition destroyed. It said nothing of government casualties. The radio said forces loyal to President Najibullah recaptured key outposts around the city in an offensive that began Tuesday. Fighting has flared and faded since the guerrillas attempted a conventional assault on Jalalabad in March 1989, three weeks after the Soviet Union withdrew its troops from Afghanistan. The radio also said government forces pushed back guerrillas surrounding the southern cities of Kandahar and Khost, with heavy fighting and aerial bombardment under way. The guerrillas, known as mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors, said up to 165 soldiers at Khost were killed or wounded when government planes bombed the garrison Wednesday in the fear the soldiers planned to defect. The reports could not be independently verified. Emergency rule was lifted at midnight Thursday. Najibullah, who uses only one name, had promised it would end by May 20. The emergency was imposed just after Soviet troops ended nine years of direct involvement and pulled out of Afghanistan in February 1989. The decree gave Najibullah power to override Parliament and placed Afghanistan's defense under the control of a supreme military council. Lifting the emergency cleared the way for constitutional reforms aimed at ending the 12-year-old war, which has killed more than 1 million people, destroyed much of the country and ruined its economy. The president named a 15-member committee to call a loya jirga, or grand assembly, to adopt constitutional reforms. It will consist of an estimated 8,000 people representing different regions and tribal groups in Afghanistan. Najibullah reportedly wants guerrillas among the committee members. The former ``terrorists and bandits'' now are called ``opposition members.'' The seven Pakistan-based guerrilla groups, bankrolled by the United States and by Saudi Arabia and other sympathetic Arab states, tacitly offered to let Najibullah test his popularity in U.N.-run elections, provided he hands over power to a transitional government. Najibullah rejects this, and appointment of the council was seen as his response to the guerrillas. The mujahedeen control 80 percent of the countryside. The Marxist-style government controls the cities.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia's President Patching Up Ties With Reform-Wary Beijing
DOC.TEXT: The president of Mongolia, where fast-moving political reforms stand in contrast to the hard line in Beijing, arrived Friday for a visit aimed at forging a new relationship. Ties between China and Soviet-allied Mongolia have been strained the past three decades, and President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat is the first Mongolian head of government to visit China since 1962. Ochirbat, here at the invitation of Chinese President Yang Shangkun, is seeking greater economic exchanges and access to a Chinese port for landlocked Mongolia. Mongolia's ruling Communist Party has given up its monopoly on power and has promised free elections this summer. A number of opposition parties have sprung up since the reform movement, inspired by similar campaigns in the Soviet Union and East Europe, began last December. However, the reforms have sparked unrest, including a wave of protests reported in Mongolia as Orchirbat began his visit. China reportedly has stepped up surveillance of its 3.5 million Mongol minority out of concern the democratic impulses of Mongolia could spill across the border. Chinese Premier Li Peng indicated Friday that Beijing expects Mongolia to do what it can to keep that from happening. Li said the two countries should have ``non-interference in each other's internal and party affairs.'' In Mongolia, sit-ins demanding replacement of the Communist-dominated legislature were being staged in a half-dozen Mongolian cities and a hunger strike continued in the northern city of Moron, a foreign source in the capital of Ulan Bator said. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said five of the 17 hunger strikers, some of whom stopped eating last Saturday, had been hospitalized. The source also said talks between the government and opposition groups seeking a faster pace of democratic reform had stalled. Opposition activists on Thursday said no new talks were scheduled with the government. The official Chinese news agency, Xinhua, reported that Mongolian Prime Minister Sharavyn Gunjaadorg had accused opposition groups of causing ``political panic'' with their ``unbridled activities.'' It said the comments came in a televised speech Thursday night. The government has accused the opposition of refusing an offer to hold a national referendum on disbanding the legislature and replacing it with a provisional multiparty body that would govern until elections, the source said. About 25 to 30 people were taking part in the sit-in in the main square of Ulan Bator. The demonstration, which began May 2, attracted 300 to 400 people Thursday night. There were few police in view. Opposition leaders were criticizing Ochirbat for traveling to China when the country was facing a political crisis, the source said. At a banquet Friday night hosted by Yang, Ochirbat called his visit an important step in furthering political, economic, cultural and scientific cooperation. Other details of the talks were not available, but it was likely they discussed the easing of tensions along the Sino-Mongolian border as well as trade and other bilateral issues. China has long objected to the heavy concentration of Soviet troops in Mongolia, many stationed along the desert and grassland frontier that divides Mongolia and China. However, the Soviet Union last year began withdrawing its troops, and says the last of 60,000 Soviet soldiers will leave Mongolia by 1992. Mongolia, which has a population of only 2 million in a nation nearly as big as all of West Europe, became the world's second communist state in 1921. China, which in the past laid claims to all of Mongolia, did not recognize the Soviet-allied state until the Chinese Communists came to power in 1949. Relations were good during the 1950s, but from 1960 onward Mongolia joined the Soviet Union in splitting with China over ideological differences. Ties began to slowly improve as Sino-Soviet tensions eased from the mid-1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Still a Key Role for Nuclear Weapons in Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for final graf to UPDATE with Tulsa appearance.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday that nuclear weapons must continue to play a key role in safeguarding Europe from war, declaring, ``There are few lessons so clear in history as this.'' While offering an advanced timetable for negotiating with Moscow on reducing short-range nuclear arms, Bush declared, ``The United States is not going to allow Europe to become `safe for conventional war.''' Bush, discussing the changing face of Europe during a commencement speech at Oklahoma State University, hailed the sweep of democracy through Warsaw Pact nations. However, he cautioned, ``Our enemy today is uncertainty and instability.'' Bush said, ``It will be crucial to see ... whether Moscow chooses coercion or peaceful dialogue in responding to the aspirations of the Lithuanian people and nationalities within the Soviet Union.'' Bush's remarks were intended to offer the outlines of a new military and political mission for NATO as Europe is transformed by the reunification of Germany and the collapse of communist governments. Leaders of the 16 NATO nations will meet in London in late June or early July to chart a revised strategy for the 41-year-old alliance. Bush said the allies should accelerate work to determine ``the minimum number and types of weapons that will be needed to deter war, credibly and effectively.'' He said Moscow and Washington should open negotiations to reduce short-range nuclear missiles in Europe once a treaty is signed _ perhaps later this year _ to curb troops and conventional arms. Originally, Bush had insisted that a conventional arms treaty not only be signed but also implemented before talks could begin on short-range nuclear forces. However, Bush said that as the Soviet Union pulls back troops from Warsaw Pact nations, ``there is less need for nuclear systems of the shortest range.'' Acting on Bush's suggestion, NATO scrapped plans Thursday to deploy more powerful short-range Lance nuclear missiles and artillery shells in Europe. Even so, the United States and Soviet Union will still maintain sizeable short-range nuclear arsenals in Europe. ``We're prepared to negotiate the reduction of these forces as well,'' the president. Yet, Bush said he did not want to leave Europe vulnerable to conventional warfare. ``There are few lessons so clear in history as this: Only the combination of conventional forces and nuclear forces have ensured this long peace in Europe,'' Bush said. A senior administration official, briefing reporters on Air Force One under condition of anonymity, said, ``We think there needs to be some nuclear weapons in Europe. Deterrence has to have a nuclear component.'' In his speech, Bush said the United States ``should remain a European power in the broadest sense _ politically, militarily and economically'' and that ``militarily significant'' U.S. forces would be stationed in Europe. As the military threat in Europe fades, Bush said, NATO's political role will become more prominent. He said NATO leaders, at their summer summit, ``should look for ways to help our German friends sustain freedom and achieve unity _ something which we and our allies have supported for over 40 years. ``And we should reaffirm the importance of keeping a united Germany a full member of NATO.'' Bush said NATO also must develop a new strategy for its conventional forces, which include tanks, troops and non-nuclear artillery. ``If the Soviet withdrawal continues and our arms control efforts are successful, we must plan for a different kind of military presence, focused less on the danger of an immediate outbreak of war,'' the president said. Another objective for the summit, Bush said, is to determine how the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe could help spread democracy and facilitate the transition from government-control economies to free markets. The Oklahoma students, listening to Bush outdoors at a football stadium, gave him a warm welcome but sat silently throughout most of his address, which was laced with arms-control jargon and acronyms. From Stillwater, Bush flew to Tulsa to address the Oklahoma Foundation for Excellence as it honored 100 outstanding high school seniors and four teachers. He also attended a state GOP fundraising reception. ``Let's be honest. Our educational system isn't making the grade,'' Bush said, urging programs such as magnet schools and incentives for students to excel in science, math and engineering. After a late-night flight home, Bush was spending the weekend at Camp David.

DOC.HEAD: Former Navy Official To Plead Guilty In Procurement Scandal
DOC.TEXT: A former Navy official agreed to plead guilty to charges of conspiracy and conversion of government property for supplying confidential bidding information to competitors for a Marine Corps contract, prosecutors announced Friday. The defendant, George G. Stone, could be fined $250,000 on each count and receive a 10-year prison sentence for conversion and five years for conspiracy if the plea bargain is accepted in court. Stone becomes the 37th defendant to plead guilty or be convicted in the massive defense procurement investigation code named ``Ill Wind'' that began in 1986. According to the plea bargain filed in U.S. District Court by the U.S. attorney's office, Stone has agreed to cooperate with the investigation. Other counts, including charges of wire fraud, will be dropped, the government said. The government's statement of facts filed in support of the plea agreement said Stone arranged for Norden Systems, a subsidiary of United Technologies Corp., to make the cut in 1987 and 1988 when the Space and Naval Warfare Command was choosing finalists in a 10-company competition to supply a radar-based command system for tactical aircraft. Norden was not among the three finalists but was added at Stone's insistence, according to the statement. The government said Stone passed information about bid proposals to Mark E. Saunders, a private consultant, who in turn passed it to another consultant, Thomas E. Muldoon. Muldoon and Saunders also were charged with conspiracy in the case. At one time or another, Muldoon passed information to three companies _ Unisys, Litton Corp. and Norden _ the government said. At first he worked for Litton, but when Litton found out its proposal trailed the others, it released Muldoon and he signed on with Norden. Muldoon never had a contract with Unisys, the government said. Muldoon has been convicted of bribing an official in another case and sentenced to 27 months in prison. He is appealing that conviction. Last month U.S. District Judge Arthur Bryan dismissed an indictment against Muldoon he said appeared to have been ``vindictive,'' brought out of pique over the appeal. Three Norden executives have pleaded guilty to taking part in Muldoon's operation.

DOC.HEAD: New Explosion Threat Identified at Hanford
DOC.TEXT: Ethanol used in nuclear waste storage tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation could ignite, the U.S. Department of Energy said Friday. It was the third report of an explosive hazard there in nine months. But federal officials, state regulators and Hanford critics all played down the ethanol problem Friday, saying it was easy to fix. The air of calm was in contrast to earlier revelations about explosive threats from ferrocyanide and a hydrogen gas buildup. ``This will be resolved in the next few days,'' said Ken Morgan of the DOE's Richland Operations office in a telephone interview. Jim Thomas of the Spokane-based Hanford Education Action League said the ethanol danger is not as serious as the potential danger from the hydrogen gas buildup, but was another example of inept management by the Energy Department. ``They were introducing a potentially energetic chemical in tanks that have very dangerous wastes in them,'' Thomas said. ``This has gone on for years.'' The latest concern centers on the tubes that run the length of Hanford's giant nuclear waste storage tanks. The tubes contain probes that use sound waves to take readings of the contents of the tanks. The tubes are filled with liquid to better conduct the sound, Morgan said. Usually the liquid is water but during cold months an antifreeze, ethanol, is added, he said. There were six tubes recently tested and in one case the ethanol fumes were gathering at the top of the tube in a potentially explosive quantity, Morgan said. The suspect tube will either be diluted with water or pumped out, Morgan said. The tubes are about three inches in diameter and 45 feet long, and sealed at the bottom so nothing inside them actually makes contact with the waste, Morgan said. Ethanol has been used for years in the monitoring tubes of many tanks, said Mike Berriochoa of Westinghouse Hanford Co., the government contractor that operates the Hanford tank farms. Berriochoa said he was not sure how many tubes Westinghouse would need to remove ethanol from. The exploding tanks controversy began last October, when the staff of Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, released a 1984 report that concluded some storage tanks at Hanford contained ferrocyanide that could explode. A flurry of analyses has since concluded that the risk from ferrocyanide is quite low. But in studying that issue, DOE scientists uncovered a new threat from hydrogen gas that was building up underneath the hard crust inside about 20 waste storage tanks at Hanford. The Energy Department announced that hazard in late March, and said they could not guarantee an explosion would not occur. That produced a whole new round of tank studies, which so far have concluded that the explosion risk is low. But the Energy Department also admits it does not yet have enough data for a solution. Morgan acknowledged that extensive criticism focusing on the Energy Department in the recent controversies prompted officials to call reporters with the latest news. ``We're a little touchy,'' he said. Hanford has 177 nuclear waste storage tanks which contain the highly radioactive byproducts of more than 40 years of plutonium production for nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Open Talks With Government on Disbanding
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro began talks Friday with Contra rebels who are refusing to disband as promised, and pledged that the military role in Nicaragua's new government will diminish ``little by little and as soon as possible.'' The Contras, who fought a U.S.-backed war against the previous leftist Sandinista government, had said they would disband by June 10. But now they are indicating they will not meet that deadline. Mrs. Chamorro made her remarks as she began closed talks with the rebels. Their demands include a reduction of the Sandinista army, by far the largest in Central America. Members of Mrs. Chamorro's Cabinet and Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo of Nicaragua are also attending the talks. Contra leader Israel Galeano said the fact that the Contras are meeting with Mrs. Chamorro shows a willingness to work to rebuild ``a society that is destroyed.'' Many Contras are angry over Mrs. Chamorro's decision to keep Gen. Humberto Ortega as head of the army, although she said the post would be temporary. Ortega, brother of former President Daniel Ortega, had been defense minister under the Sandinistas. When Mrs. Chamorro took office April 15 she charged Gen. Ortega with coming up with a program for reducing the armed forces. She said Ortega would stay on as head of the army until the Contras were disarmed. ``What we want is to rebuild our country in peace, in reconciliation and also to demilitarize our country,'' the president said Friday. Mrs. Chamorro did not say if the army would be reduced at the same time the Contras were disbanded. Former President Ortega earlier promised that the Sandinistas ``will not at any time promote a policy of revenge with disarmed and disbanded Contra forces.'' Before turning over power the Sandinistas distributed thousands of weapons to their supporters, who have vowed publicly not to give them back. Aristides Sanchez, a Contra spokesman, implied Thursday that the rebels will not hand in their weapons to U.N. representatives by June 10, as they had pledged to do in an April 19 agreement. ``One doesn't have to be so airtight about it,'' Sanchez replied when asked if the rebels planned to meet the deadline. Roberto Ferrey, a spokesman for Mrs. Chamorro's government and himself a former Contra, said the government would not yield to the rebel demand. ``June 10 is the deadline: it's not possible to change it,'' he said. About 30,000 people died in the struggle between the American-backed Contras and the leftist Sandinista regime.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Ex-Playboy Model on Tax Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7, `Ms. Harris...,' with three grafs to UPDATE with attorney saying she will appeal, quote from testimony. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Kritzik, who died...
DOC.TEXT: A woman who once posed nude for Playboy with her twin sister was convicted Friday of evading taxes on money she allegedly got from an elderly millionaire in exchange for sex. Prosecutors contended Lynnette Harris and her sister collected more than $1 million in cash, real estate, furs and other goods from the late David Kritzik for spending alternate nights with him. A U.S. District jury found Ms. Harris, 35, guilty of two felony counts of tax evasion and two misdemeanor counts of failing to file income tax returns. The charges involve her failure to report as income $686,000 she received from Kritzik from 1984 to 1987. The taxes amount to $260,000, said U.S. Attorney Mel Johnson. She could be sentenced to a maximum of 12 years in prison and fined $626,000. Her identical twin sister, Leigh Ann Conley, is to be tried in June on similar charges involving allegedly unpaid taxes on $397,000. In testimony, Ms. Harris denied she was a prostitute and testified Kritzik cared for her ``as a husband takes care of a wife.'' Ms. Harris contended the money she received during the course of her relationship with Kritzik, a Milwaukee businessman, amounted to gifts rather than taxable income. Her attorney said the verdict would be appealed. Kritzik, who died in June at age 89, founded the General Merchandise Co. mail-order house and the Treasure Island discount chain. The blonde twins appeared nude together in two movies and in a 1981 edition of Playboy. In lawsuits seeking money from Kritzik's estate and damages from his son, Stanley, Ms. Harris said she and Kritzik had an oral agreement that she would travel with him and provide companionship in exchange for money. But in her testimony during the trial, she said there was no agreement, that she and Kritzik had a ``normal relationship between a man and a woman.'' Ms. Harris left the courtroom without speaking to reporters, one of her attorneys, Dave Geraghty, said she was ``very disappointed.'' ``She believes in her innocence and so do we,'' Geraghty said. U.S. District Judge Thomas Curran scheduled sentencing for July 25.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Troops Capture Palestinian Wanted in Six Murders
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers wearing civilian clothes entered a Palestinian refugee camp Friday and seized a fugitive wanted in the murder of at least six fellow Palestinians suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities, Arab reports said. The army said its soldiers shot and seriously wounded Nasser Muhammad Abu Ihmaid, 19, in the al-Amari camp in the occupied West Bank when he tried to flee, armed with a pistol. Arab reporters said the soldiers waited in a car across from the camp mosque for Ihmaid to come out. Camp residents knew him as ``the masked lion'' and said he was responsible for killing Arabs thought to be collaborators, the reporters said. The army accused Ihmaid of taking part in the murder of six Palestinians. At least 210 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, mainly on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities, during the 29-month-old revolt against Israeli rule in the occupied territories. Israelis have killed 681 Palestinians during the rebellion, and 43 Israelis have also died in the violence. Security forces on Friday demolished two houses in the refugee camp, five miles north of Jerusalem, belonging to Palestinians suspected of attacking alleged collaborators, Arab reports said. Police in Hebron detained two Israelis accused of stoning Arab cars from their vehicle as they drove through the West Bank, causing at least one wreck, Israel television reported. It said the two had in their possession stones, paint and leaflets from Rabbi Meir Kahane's extremist Kach movement.

DOC.HEAD: Seventeen Hurt in Military Helicopter Landing
DOC.TEXT: Seventeen Marines suffered injuries in the rough landing of a helicopter troopship at a desert training area Friday afternoon, a Marine Corps spokesman said. Medical personnel late Friday were examining the extent of injuries to the Marines hurt in the 2:15 p.m. accident at the Marine Air-Ground Combat Center, Capt. Timothy Hoyle said. The injured, most of them based at Camp Pendleton, flew in another aircraft for treatment at the Navy hospital at Twentynine Palms, about 140 miles northeast of Los Angeles, Hoyle said. The helicopter, a CH-46E Sea Knight, and its crew of three belong to the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing, headquartered at the Marine Corps Air Station in El Toro, Calif. Investigators searched for the cause of the accident, Hoyle said. The severity of damage to the aircraft was not immediately known. The 25-passenger Sea Knight, an assault helicopter in service since the Vietnam War, was participating in helicopter-borne assault training.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Manson Follower Denied Parole in 10th Bid
DOC.TEXT: Charles Manson ``family'' member Charles ``Tex'' Watson lost his 10th bid for parole Friday in the 1969 cult killings of actress Sharon Tate and six others. Watson, serving a life sentence at the California Men's Colony, was slow to express remorse and remains a threat to others, according to a psychiatric report cited by the parole panel that rejected his request. The three-member Board of Prison Terms panel ruled that Watson, 44, must wait the maximum three years to reapply for release. Watson was convicted of leading three women in the brutal killings on orders of Manson, leader of the self-styled family of outcasts. The pregnant Miss Tate was stabbed and hanged in her home in Los Angeles' Laurel Canyon Aug. 9, 1969. Also killed were her houseguests Jay Sebring, Abigail Folger and Voityck Frykowski and caretaker Steven Parent. The next night, grocer Leno LaBianca and his wife, Rosemary, were killed at their Los Angeles home. On hand to oppose Watson's release Friday was Miss Tate's mother, Doris Tate, who has worked to keep the Manson family members behind bars. ``I feel that she (Sharon) has to be represented in that hearing room,'' Mrs. Tate said before the hearing. ``If they're pleading for their lives, then I have to be there representing her _ how she lost her life and how she pleaded for her life, and how her pleas were ignored.'' Manson was convicted of masterminding the slayings, which prosecutors contended were part of a deranged plan to perpetrate a race war. Also convicted in the case were Patricia Krenwinkel, Susan Atkins and Leslie Van Houten _ in carrying out the killings. All five were originally sentenced to death but their sentences were reduced to life imprisonment when a 1972 Supreme Court ruling overturned the California death penalty law that existed at the time. All five have been rejected for parole repeatedly and remain in prison. In prison, Watson has studied data processing and office machine repair program. He served as assistant chaplain in the prison for 12 years before being removed from the post in 1987 because of complaints that he intimidated other prisoners.

DOC.HEAD: Maples Won't Follow in Madonna's Footsteps
DOC.TEXT: Marla Maples may have to wait a while longer to see her name in lights instead of banner headlines. The so-called other woman in the Trump marital split auditioned for Madonna's role in the national tour of the Broadway show ``Speed-the-Plow.'' But she didn't get it. ``Marla was actually quite good,'' Gene Wolsk, a co-producer, told The New York Times. ``But even before we came to any decision, her people asked about the length of the tour and she was hesitant about committing herself for that period of time.'' The model-actress has had a couple bit parts in movies. In ``Maximum Overdrive,'' she was crushed by a watermelon truck. Her most-talked-about modeling credit was as a bikini-clad pinup for Delta Air Lines' ``Fly Florida'' ad campaign. The rock star Madonna starred as an office temp working for two Hollywood producers in playwright David Mamet's ``Speed-the-Plow,'' a scathing look at greed and glory in the film industry. The upcoming tour will star Elliott Gould and George Segal. It is scheduled to last nine months. Brooke Shields has also been mentioned as a possibility for the role originally played by Madonna. But Wolsk told the Times the producers were now thinking about casting an actress who did not necessarily have ``a name.''

DOC.HEAD: `Ice Cream With Hot Fudge' Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Caryl Churchill doesn't make things easy for an audience. The proof is currently on stage at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater where a double bill of two short works by the English playwright is puzzling theatergoers. The title _ ``Ice Cream With Hot Fudge'' _ is deceptively sweet. The two plays are not. ``Hot Fudge,'' the shorter and more arcane of the plays, begins with a chorus of lower-class Brits plotting an intricate check-cashing scam. Their greed is similiar to the money-grubbing celebrated by the stockbrokers Churchill skewered in ``Serious Money,'' her last New York outing. Much of the dialogue in ``Hot Fudge'' is overlapping, making it impossible to understand clearly. You get the idea, if not the actual words. The avarice goes upscale in the next scene or two when Ruby (Margaret Whitton) pairs off with Colin (John Pankow) and meets his wealthy friends. People talk about their careers in ``global industry'' or their ``self-development vacations'' or their homes as ``investments.'' But there's a nastiness underneath the chic cocktail chatter that doesn't become apparent until Ruby is confronted by Colin's ex-wife (Julianne Moore). The confrontation _ and the play _ end in violence, and the bleak realization that nothing is as it seems. ``Ice Cream,'' composed of 20 short scenes, is the more substantial, dangerous dessert. The black, often bewildering, comedy illustrates Churchill's disenchantment with romantic notions of both England and the United States. Two innocent American tourists, Lance and Vera, find delight in everything British _ from the way the natives say ``ice cream'' to all those ancient buildings to even discovering distant cousins of Lance's. But these relatives are not Mr. Micawber and Mary Poppins. They are vindictive, uncouth, slightly menacing people who end up murdering their landlord. And they draw their American cousins into the crime. When the English brother and sister visit America, they are similiarly misinformed about the habits of the foreign land. But Churchill's scalpel is not nearly as sharp in her dissection of American life and culture. Her portrait of two rural bumpkins, for example, seems straight out of ``The Beverely Hillbillies,'' only not as funny. The violence the British couple committed in England follows them to America. And it dogs the American husband and wife, too. It's a chilly link between the two nations. The play ends weirdly, unexpectedly. In fact, many in the audience at a recent performance didn't know it was over until the actors came out to take their bows. The cast is competent rather than inspired except for John Pankow, who plays the disturbed Colin in ``Hot Fudge'' and a variety of very different small roles in ``Ice Cream'' with distinction. Director Les Waters certainly keeps the plays moving quickly, helped by the minimal settings of stark, sliding walls. Churchill's plays are just as stark, keeping the audience off-balance. But that may be her main goal. ``Ice Cream With Hot Fudge'' is more unnerving than entertaining.

DOC.HEAD: Three Ex-Lawmen Sentenced to Prison for Murdering Black Prisoner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `Ladner was...,' to UPDATE with quotes from victim's family. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Horton and ...
DOC.TEXT: Three white former lawmen convicted of murdering a black prisoner were sentenced Friday to prison terms ranging from 10 to 28 years. The prosecutor had sought life terms in the case, which drew wide attention in the state from activists who contend mistreatment of blacks by white police officers is common. Loyal Garner Jr., 34-year-old black man who has six children, died after being beaten in his cell following a drunken driving arrest 2{ years ago. The defendants _ former Hemphill Police Chief Thomas Ladner and former Sabine County sheriff's deputies Billy Ray Horton and James M. Hyden _ were convicted Thursday. Ladner was sentenced to 28 years, Hyden to 14 years and Horton to 10 years. ``I'm glad. I'm happy that they were convicted and they got time,'' said the victim's widow, Corrine Garner. ``I'm going to go home and raise my kids.'' Loyal Garner Sr. had hoped for longer sentences for the men who killed his son. But the victim's mother, Sarah Garner, said: ``I'm satisfied that some kind of justice has been done.'' Horton and Hyden were allowed to remain free on appeal bonds of $25,000 because their sentences were less than 15 years. Ladner was taken into custody. Prosecutor Jack Skeen had urged jurors to go to the limit in choosing among sentencing alternatives ranging from five to 99 years or life in prison and fines up to $10,000. The defendants will be eligible for parole because they had no prior convictions. The three were acquitted in 1988 of civil rights violation charges in Garner's death, and have appeals pending on grounds the murder trial constituted double jeopardy. Black activists have hailed Thursday's verdict as a victory for racial justice. They monitored the case, along with the slaying of a black Houston woman by a Hispanic police officer during a gunfight while the officer was off-duty. The officer was convicted last week of manslaughter. So emotional was the atmosphere in the courtroom Friday that the prosecutor wept along with some in the audience as he gave closing arguments in the punishment phase of the trial. ``Establish by your verdict the real meaning of Smith County justice,'' Skeen told the all-white jury in arguing for life terms. ``This is Loyal Garner Jr.'s last chance.'' Hyden was the only defendant to testify during the punishment phase. He pointed out that he has a wife and three children, and he believes he could live up to the rules of probation. Skeen later criticized Hyden's brief statement, saying ``Not one time did he indicate any remorse.'' Wagner's attorney, John Seale, compared Skeen's efforts to put the three former lawmen in prison to those of a lynch mob. ``On one occasion, these men got mad, lost their temper and overreacted,'' Seale said. ``We all lose our tempers.'' Defense attorneys said they fear for their clients' lives if they were imprisoned because of retribution by other inmates. Garner, from Florien, La., died Dec. 27, 1987, of severe head injuries. The former officers claimed they struck Garner in self-defense when he became unruly in the jail.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Children Removed From Unlicensed Boarding Home
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday ordered children removed from an unlicensed church boarding home for troubled teens after a youth testified he and others were beaten and forced to work long hours. But when authorities went to the Children's Home in Lucedale, there were no children present. The Rev. Herman Fountain, a fundamentalist minister who has been battling authorities for at least two years over allegations of beatings and other abuse at the home, refused to say where the children were. He said he would continue accepting children, despite previous court orders to the contrary, ``to keep them off the street.'' In 1988, authorities removed 70 children from the home. But efforts to keep Fountain from accepting boarders since have led to a long string of legal disputes. Prosecutors presently are seeking criminal penalties against Fountain for failing to register the home under a new state law covering residential care for minors. The minister refuses to seek a state license, saying he answers only to God's law. ``I'm through playing their games,'' Fountain said. ``I'm going to do what the Lord tells me to do and just go on.'' Friday's order to remove children was issued by youth court Chancellor Robert Oswald after a 16-year-old boy who ran away from the home testified about his 13 days there. They teen-ager said Fountain forced more than a dozen children at the 28-acre church campus to work nine or ten hours a day on various chores. Fountain disputed the accusations in a telephone interview. ``He's lying about most of it,'' Fountain said of the boy's testimony. ``He said he only got four hours of sleep a night, and that's a lie. He said he was going to get a spanking, and that was true. But I didn't get a chance to.'' The hearing was to continue May 15. Also Friday, Fountain failed to appear at a contempt hearing over his refusal to obey an earlier court order against operating the home. ``I know I'm justified in violating it,'' Fountain said of the court order.

DOC.HEAD: Protests Hit 3 Cities; Minister Predicts 10 Years to Fix Economy
DOC.TEXT: Anti-government demonstrators calling for radical reform and the resignation of interim president Ion Iliescu protested in three Romanian cities Friday as a top minister cautioned that real economic change would take 10 years. Romania needs at least a decade to switch from a centralized Communist economy to a free market system, the national economy minister Tudorel Postolache told a news conference. The transfer to a market economy ''should not be done by shock therapy, but gradually,'' Postolache said in an apparent swipe at those arguing for more radical change. About 500 anti-government demonstrators, meanwhile, protested for the 13th day in the capital's downtown University Square. They demanded that Iliescu resign and that he and all other former Communists be barred from political life. Similar demonstrations were reported by the state news agency Rompres from Brasov, Romania's second city, and from the western town of Timisoara, the birthplace of the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The Brasov demonstration has gone on since Sunday, Rompres said. On that day, about 40,000 people gathered in Timisoara to call for the resignation of Iliescu, the favorite in the May 20 presidential elections. Iliescu's National Salvation Front has dominated politics in Romania since the revolution. Opposition parties who have threatened to boycott the May 20 elections charge the Front is using public funds for electioneering and exploiting its access to television. Ion Ratiu, the millionaire businessman who returned from 50 years in British exile to become the presidential candidate for the National Peasants' Party, on Friday charged that the Front was attacking campaign workers from his party. Ratiu said at a news conference that 60 such attacks had occurred over the past week, including one on his British wife Elisabeth. He said the opposition may boycott the election unless Iliescu ``calls his troops to order.''

DOC.HEAD: Plan Proposed to Settle American Continental Bankruptcy Case
DOC.TEXT: American Continental Corp., the controversial savings and loan company, would be liquidated under a plan presented Friday by federal regulators and the company's unsecured creditors. The plan, which must be approved by a federal bankruptcy judge, calls for the ouster of American Continental's controversial chairman, Charles H. Keating Jr. It would require the company's failed savings and loan subsidiary, California-based Lincoln Savings and Loan, to pay $21 million to settle numerous lawsuits against it. The plan was proposed jointly by the unsecured creditors committee and the government's Resolution Trust Corp., the entity charged with cleaning up the nation's savings and loan mess. The RTC runs Lincoln Savings, which was seized by regulators in April 1989. An attorney for Keating complained he hadn't been consulted about the plan, which seeks to separate the affairs of Lincoln and American Continental. ``I think it's an end run around us,'' said Keating attorney James J. Feder, who learned of the plan at a bankruptcy court hearing. ``The government has refused to negotiate with us. ... This is the showcase, so they refuse to discuss it with us and instead go to the creditors committee.'' The settlement doesn't affect an RTC civil lawsuit against Keating. That suit accuses Keating and other Lincoln insiders of racketeering, alleging they conspired to buy Lincoln for the purpose of diverting federally insured deposits to their own use. Keating's contributions to influential lawmakers figure in an ethics probe of five U.S. Senators. The lawmakers met with regulators on behalf of Lincoln. The proposal was presented at a hearing before U.S. District Judge Richard M. Bilby, who is overseeing American Continental's Chapter 11 filing. That section of the federal bankruptcy law allows a company to reorganize under court supervision and remain a going concern. Details of the proposal are to be presented at a later hearing. All claims against Lincoln by the unsecured creditors would be dismissed under the settlement in exchange for $21 million. A majority of the creditors are investors who say they lost more than $200 million on ``junk bonds'' sold by American Continental. Lawsuits contend that as many as 23,000 people were persuaded to buy the risky bonds American Continental or Lincoln employees. The deal, negotiated by lawyers for the unsecured creditors, must be approved by a vote of the creditors themselves. ``Instead of the former adversarial relationship between the RTC and the creditors committee, both parties will now work cooperatively to unwind the corporate affairs of ACC and Lincoln and to investigate and pursue claims against various persons who ... may have injured Lincoln and ACC,'' RTC special counsel Rex Veal said in a news release.

Freed U.S. hostage Frank Reed left for the United States today, and just before taking off criticized the British government because two British citizens remain captive in Lebanon. ``They are my best mates, those guys, we're going to get them out,'' Reed said of Brian Keenan and John McCarthy, shortly before he left the U.S. Air Force hospital in Wiesbaden to begin his journey back to the United States. Asked if he thought the British government should do more to win the release of McCarthy and Keenan, Reed replied: ``You bet they should be.'' He did not elaborate. Reed, his wife and their 9-year-old son flew out of the Wiesbaden Air Base at 10:09 a.m. (4:09 a.m. EDT), heading for Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland aboard a C-20 aircraft. The founder of a private school in Beirut, Reed was the second American hostage to be freed in nine days. Robert Polhill, freed April 22, went through the same battery of medical tests and questioning at the hospital last week.

NATO has launched its drive to ensure the Western military alliance does not become a rusted relic but instead functions as a key component in new European security structures. NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner told a news conference Thursday that the group ``is taking advantage of the historic opportunity to move beyond confrontation to cooperation.'' He was speaking at the end of a special meeting of foreign ministers of the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. With reduced East-West tensions, NATO is under pressure to reduce its military role and increase its political one. The officials also insisted that a united Germany remain in the Western alliance, but Woerner said NATO does not intend to expand its forces into the current territory of East Germany.

West Germany is pushing East Germany to quickly open the door to private ownership and get out of the business of owning land and factories. With a self-imposed deadline of July 2 for merging their economies and social institutions, experts from both countries have been meeting this week to discuss the logistics of moving East Germany to a free market. Almost all property and enterprises were state-owned under the Communist system that once controlled the country. East Germany and West Germany on Wednesday agreed on a basic plan for circulating the West Germany currency in the country beginning July 2. On Thursday, several West German officials said that must now be followed by a quick conversion to private ownership.

Alaska is becoming a transit point for Asian heroin and South American cocaine being smuggled into the United States and Europe, authorities say. ``Possibly the couriers feel this is a less-traveled route,'' says Fred Thomas, chief agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration office in Anchorage. ``Once they clear customs in Alaska, that's it. Everything going to the Lower 48 is domestic. ``The amount of heroin seized here lately would indicate to me it's a transshipment point,'' he said. Customs agents have intercepted several drug shipments at Anchorage International Airport in recent months, but believe they have staunched just a fraction of the incoming flow of narcotics.

The opposition Labor Party has trounced Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives in local elections, making their best showing since she came to power 11 years ago, tallies showed today. However, the Conservatives avoided the rout forecast by opinion polls before Thursday's elections. The socialist Labor Party called the balloting a referendum on Mrs. Thatcher's third term in office and an unpopular new local tax that sparked massive protests. With results declared early today from 182 of the 201 local councils, Labor had gained 10 councils to control 89. The Conservatives, or Tories, lost eight for control of 36. The centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party took control of three councils and lost three. No party had overall control in the other councils.

The government and the African National Congress said Friday they will work together for the first time to stop political violence and clear the way for talks on ending white-minority rule. President F.W. de Klerk and ANC leader Nelson Mandela, looking relaxed and confident after the three days of talks, said the preliminary discussions were an important step toward giving South Africa's black majority a share of power. ``It is the realization of a dream for which we have worked patiently and consistently,'' Mandela said after the first talks ever between the ANC and government. In a joint communique, the sides said a ``working group'' will be created to try to end obstacles to full negotiations on changing the constitution.

Latvian lawmakers voted for independence Friday but plotted a more cautious break from the Soviet Union than neighboring Lithuania. Latvians greeted the declaration of independence with tears, a chorus of the republic's traditional anthem and dancing in the streets. The 138-0 parliamentary vote, 50 years after Moscow seized the three Baltic states on the Soviet's western border, put Latvia on a similar secessionist path with Lithuania and Estonia. However, unlike Lithuania's independence declaration of March 11, the vote by Latvia's Supreme Soviet called for a gradual break with the Soviet Union. Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov said he was already thinking about the next step: negotiations with Moscow.

Departing savings and loan cleanup boss L. William Seidman said Friday that ``real pain'' is yet to come in the bailout and urged patience with his successor. ``All the evidence to date is that the costs will exceed those originally estimated,'' he told a House Banking Committee task force on the S&L bailout. ``We are operating now in markets where interest rates are going up and property values are going down,'' he said. Panel members lavished praise on the 69-year-old regulator, who is often at odds with the administration and is being nudged out as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. The FDIC insures bank and thrift institution deposits; the RTC conducts the S&L bailout.

Trade ministers representing the largest industrial nations said Friday they had failed to resolve major disputes blocking an ambitious effort to overhaul the global trading system. Officials of the United States, Japan, the 12-nation European Community and Canada said at the end of a three-day negotiating session that sharp differences remained over such issues as a U.S. demand for the elimination of costly agricultural barriers. However, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and other delegation leaders sought to portray the talks in a positive light, saying the discussions had been useful in highlighting areas of disagreement and providing momentum to resolving disputes. Canadian Trade Minister John Crosbie praised the discussions for ``turning the heat up'' in the four-year effort to liberalize the rules governing world trade.

A conference touting therapy and ``healthy male bonding'' as the keys to overcoming homosexuality was attacked by gay rights activists Friday as naive and dangerous. ``There are too many tragic consequences of such treatments for this work to be ... tolerated,'' said Robert Austin, president of the Utah AIDS Coalition. ``Reorientation therapy is to psychiatry what bloodletting is to the healing arts.'' The two-day conference, ``You Don't Have To Be Gay,'' is sponsored by the Evergreen Foundation, a self-described group of former homosexuals dedicated to helping others move toward heterosexuality. In addition to psychotherapy, the group promotes development of athletic skills to spur the transition. Joe Dallas, a fundamentalist Christian therapist, told an opening session crowd of 120 that while not technically an illness, homosexuality is a ``symptom of inner conflict'' often stemming from a childhood devoid of proper male identity development.

DOC.HEAD: China's Biggest City Has Big Plans for Urban Renewal
DOC.TEXT: China's largest city has announced plans for an urban renaissance, but says it will take billions of dollars, lots of political savvy and about 40 years. The Pudong Development Project has won Beijing's qualified endorsement. Now, Shanghai must convince foreign investors there is hope in this troubled metropolis. Most of Shanghai's 12 million people and thousands of factories compete for land, air and water in teeming Puxi, on the west side of the Huangpu River. The development of Pudong, east of the Huangpu, would shift factories, homes and people to the 140-square-mile triangle of land between that river and the Yangtze. Among things the city plans to do in the next five years are: finish a third bridge across the Huangpu; start construction on a port, power plant and waterworks; open an export processing zone for foreign investors and complete a highway circling the city. Work on a subway linking the two sides of the river is to begin this year. Planners envision more highways, another bridge, a second international airport and apartments, hospitals and schools for 1.7 million people in Pudong. Finance and trade centers, high-tech industries and science centers are planned. Older factories in Puxi are to be moved to Pudong and modernized. Shanghai's planners say all that and 40 years to accomplish it will make a modern, efficient city of this former capitalist enclave, which has been the overworked draft horse of cCommunist China for the last 40. Zhu Rongji, Shanghai's energetic and ambitious mayor, told reporters the city will need the equivalent of $10 billion in the first decade. The national budget has allocated $1.38 billion over the next five years. Much of the rest will have to come from foreign investors and the city itself. According to the mayor, the climate for investment is ``better than at any time in the past and especially better than the time before last June.'' He referred to pro-democracy demonstrations and, in June 1989, the military crackdown that frightened off many potential investors and drastically slowed loans from the World Bank and other international lenders. The Asian Development Bank is backing the new Huangpu bridge and a West German consortium has extended credit for more than half the $500 million subway. Such lending, agreed upon before June, will be crucial for the Pudong project. A Western diplomat in Shanghai did not share Zhu's optimism about foreign money. He noted that foreign investment was down sharply so far this year and that Hong Kong and Taiwan businessmen were more interested in the special economic zones of southern China. ``International lending is blocked up and foreign banks are not exactly doing tricks to increase exposure in China,'' he said. Zhu offers major incentives. Foreign banks, now allowed to have branches only in the special economic zones, will be invited to Shanghai. Joint ventures will be given tax breaks like those in the zones. Businesses from abroad will be able to obtain leases of 50 to 70 years on large tracts of land for development, to issue bonds and stocks and conduct stock trading inside and outside China. Shanghai also is blessed, for once, with strong support from Beijing. Jiang Zemin, Zhu's predecessor as mayor, is general secretary of the Communist Party and Zou Jiahua, chief of the powerful Central Planning Commission, also is from Shanghai. Perhaps more important, the conservative politicians now on top in Beijing see Shanghai, with its large state industries, as a counterbalance to capitalism-tainted Canton and the special economic zones in Guangdong and Fujian provinces. ``Even without the fear of creeping capitalism, it would make sense for them to give fewer favors to Guangdong and try to help out the older industrial bases,'' the Western diplomat said. Shanghai formerly had to pay nearly 90 percent of its earnings to the state, providing about 10 percent of state revenues. That left too little to repair a rapidly deteriorating infrastructure. Last year, it was allowed to keep about one-third of revenues, still less than other provinces. The city ``made great contributions to the state in the past'' and it is time to return the favor, Zhu said. Premier Li Peng visited Shanghai in April and endorsed the Pudong project as ``an event of important strategic significance both to Shanghai and the whole country.'' He said the central government ``will provide necessary support and the whole country should give active support.'' Li added, however, that the city ``should rely on the support and efforts of the people of Shanghai.'' In his remarks to reporters two weeks later, Zhu said the city could gain $212 million a year just by making its antiquated industrial base more efficient. He noted that Shanghai's people ``have lots of money in their pockets,'' but also quoted a saying that they are ``clever but not too wise'' _ more concerned with short-term profit than long-term interests. Pudong will succeed, Zhu said, only if ``shortcomings in the general mentality'' of the city are overcome.

DOC.HEAD: Author Hailey Looks at Control of Television News Shows
DOC.TEXT: Arthur Hailey takes a look at what might happen when the news conflicts with the interests of a TV network's corporate owner in his latest novel, ``The Evening News.'' He concludes that corporate interests come first. ``I feel that I'm not alone in believing that the worst thing that could happen to television news was the takeover of the three networks by large corporations,'' Hailey said. ``The company that owns the network in my book is fictional, but there's a lot of reality in the influence of the news by the conglomerates. It's inevitable when people have power. ``I think, however, the competition between the networks will prevent a lot of it. NBC is now owned by General Electric, a major defense contractor. NBC used to do a lot of investigative report into defense spending. I wonder if they will continue to do that.'' At one time, the networks were not expected to turn a profit, said Hailey, a former television dramatist turned novelist. ``It was William Paley, who founded CBS, who pioneered the concept of a free and independent news department,'' he said. The manipulation of the news by the multinational corporate owner of the fictional network in Hailey's book is only a small part of ``The Evening News,'' published at $21.95 by Doubleday. It's essentially a thriller about the kidnapping of the family of an anchorman. The news department learns the kidnappers are terrorists from Peru, with which the corporation has just agreed to develop a major resort. The corporation moves to suppress unfavorable news about the country. Hailey's books include ``Airport,' ``Wheels,'' ``Hotel,'' ``The Moneychangers'' and ``Strong Medicine.'' ``The Evening News'' will be his last book to take on an American institution, he said. ``I'm now 70 and my health is not the best,'' he said. ``My publisher has offered me the same advance with no deadline for the next book,'' he said. ``But a book takes three years of hard work. I plan to write three novellas at my own pace and publish them in one book.'' Hailey, a Canadian citizen, lives in the Bahamas with his wife, Sheila. Much of the book was written aboard their motor launch while cruising among the islands. ``When I started the book all I knew was that I wanted to write about television news and terrorists,'' he said. ``I felt terrorists from the Middle East had been written about too much and one producer told me about Peru and the Shining Path, a group with ties to the drug traffickers.'' He visited Peru twice. At his island home, he has a satellite dish, so was able to keep up with news shows from U.S. networks while working on the book. All of Hailey's previous major novels have been made into movies or miniseries. But so far, he has rejected movie and miniseries offers for ``The Evening News.''

Elsewhere in television: OLD NEWS ... Coming this fall is a new nightly newsmagazine that takes an in-depth look at news of the past. ``Only Yesterday,'' with former NBC reporter John Palmer as anchorman, will be distributed beginning in September by King World Productions. Av Westin, a former executive of ABC News, is executive producer and creator.

DOC.HEAD: Local Heroes: PBS Series Shows Individuals Make a Difference
DOC.TEXT: Do not despair. The world is not coming to an end. Individuals can make it a better place. That's the good news these days from public television. Still, you're in no immediate danger of contracting that warm, fuzzy feeling from programs like ``Local Heroes, Global Change,'' a four-part documentary series opening on PBS tonight. ``What we have learned is that the world is extremely complex, messy, that simple solutions and slogans don't work,'' said Francisco Sagasti, head of strategic planning for the World Bank in Washington. ``Local Heroes'' is one of a number of programs on public TV trying to show what smart, committed people can do against hunger, poverty and pollution, especially in developing nations. Using these people, PBS programmers and independent producers can relate complex stories without oversimplifying them. ``There's been a lot of talk among programmers about doing news from the bottom up rather than the top down,'' said Harry Chancey, top programmer for PBS affiliate WNET in New York City. ``There's a sense of excitement about letting the unremarkable people tell the story.'' The first episode of ``Local Heroes, Global Change'' considers rice farming in Indonesia, where farmers learned that ecologically balanced insect populations could supplant the government's disastrous pesticide program. It also looks at a near-revolutionary loan program of the Grameen (Rural) Bank of Bangladesh, which targets women and the landless for loans to buy livestock and homes. The other episodes of the South Carolina ETV series will consider the influences of politics, psychology and the global economy on Third World development. The PBS series ``Profiles in Progress'' also focuses on local heroes. A recent episode profiled Nepal, where deforestation and infant mortality are interconnected issues of national survival. Nepal's infant mortality rate 20 years ago was 250 per 1,000 live births. Today, at 110 per thousand, it's still one of the highest in the world. Yet the decrease and a traditionally high birth rate have helped increase Nepal's population more than 50 percent since 1970, to 17 million people. That population puts pressure on the forests, the traditional source of fuel and fodder. Since 1970, Nepal has lost one-third of its forest, or 6 million acres of trees. Deforestation robs Nepal of soil, beauty and, ultimately, the tourism that is a main source of its foreign exchange. Its local heroes are Prabhakar Rana, a hotelier who pushes for national game preserves and local forest management, and Dr. Yagya Karki, a health official who produces videos on prenatal care and midwifery, and enlists village women as advocates for family planning. We can expect to see many more ``local heroes'' on PBS in the weeks and months ahead. In October, Boston's WGBH will be offering a 10-part series called ``The Race to Save the Planet.'' Another kind of ``local hero'' is naturalist Jane Goodall, whose 30-year study of the chimpanzees of Tanzania's Gombe National Park has expanded our understanding of human's closest relative. ``It's being there with the chimpanzees, being out of the rat race, that gives me the energy to travel around lecturing and meeting people,'' she says on HBO's documentary ``Chimps: So Like Us,'' which airs on May 9. It's a beautifully photographed documentary on her work and her deeply felt opposition to the inhumane use of chimps in medical research. On May 20, TBS and the award-winning ``National Geographic Explorer'' present ``The Life and Legend of Jane Goodall.'' A little good news never hurt anybody.

Elsewhere In Television ... THE DISMAL SCIENCE DEPARTMENT: ``Fear, Greed and the Madness of Crowds'' is a funny, insightful and visually delightful examination by ``Adam Smith's Money World'' at the irrational behavior of markets over the centuries. It covers such egregious examples of economic fancy as the tulipmania of 17th-century Holland, the South Sea bubble in 18th-century England and the Florida land boom of the '20s. Its droll, eye-popping graphics were designed on the Quantel Paintbox by Emmy Award-winning co-producer John Andrews, with artists Todd Ruff and Sharon Haskell. Its first PBS air date is May 11, but check local listings.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for May 7

DOC.HEAD: Gregory's Girl: Cecilia Peck Finds Her Way As an Actress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `When that gig...,' to fix typo in led. Movie opens May 25 in Los Angeles, June 1 in New York and Florida. Release elsewhere later.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY304
DOC.TEXT: Cecilia Peck recognizes herself in the character she portrays in the movie ``Torn Apart'' _ a woman struggling to follow her heart even if it goes against her father's wishes. Cecilia, whose father is the actor Gregory Peck, appears with Adrian Pasdar as star-crossed lovers, she an Arab schoolteacher, Laila, and he an Israeli soldier, Ben. During the course of the plot, Laila is forced to confront her father over the doomed romance. ``I really related to her having to go against her father to follow her own heart,'' Peck said in a recent interview. ``And that's the big conflict for Laila _ because she reveres him and adores him but she has to follow her own heart. And I admired her for that. ``That wouldn't happen with my dad because of the religious reasons, but there are those circumstances when a father loves and wants to protect his daughter and she has to find her own way.'' For Peck, finding her own way as an actress has taken a circuitous route. After earning a degree in English literature from Princeton University, she moved to New York in the early 1980s to manage a punk-new wave band called The Groceries. How did her parents react to their only daughter becoming a rock 'n' roller in New York? ``I think they kind of ignored the whole thing and pretended it wasn't happening,'' Peck said with a hearty laugh. When that gig ended, she became a story analyst for a film company, reading scripts and providing synopses. That led to writing plays, and studying acting to help the playwriting. Gradually, off-Broadway roles started coming her way. ``In retrospect, I think (acting) was something I wanted to do but I was always academic and didn't think of myself as a performer, but I think it was inside me,'' she said. ``When your parents are in the arts and you spend a lot of time in the theater and around artists, it really captures your imagination.'' Though her performance is strong in ``Torn Apart,'' the film is a flat redo of the ``Romeo and Juliet'' theme. Its characters are too shallow, and the script too tepid to hook the viewer into wanting to care about their worries and longings. The Israeli backdrop, however, is stunning _ the sweeping plains and the dusty burnt sienna sunsets _ and makes for pleasant viewing. She says she has fond memories of growing up with her famous father. ``I was always on his sets; I grew up on location with him; I saw all his films. And I remember when I was little, when he won the Oscar for `To Kill a Mockingbird,' I had given him a rabbit's foot to have in his pocket.'' Gregory Peck was careful to shield his four children from some of the artificial trappings of Hollywood, she said. ``I didn't grow up in a mansion and I think my father took a lot of care that we were normal. I think that's because they didn't want us to take things for granted.'' When she finally pursued acting, his advice was for her to get good training. But the famous name hasn't opened any doors. In fact, it sometimes works against her. ``I think us offspring are subjected to extra scrutiny, especially early on, that maybe other actors don't have to contend with,'' Peck said. ``And I know that in some situations and auditions, people are skeptical about whether I'm serious about it or well-trained or disciplined or really talented or whether I'm assuming that things are going to be handed to me. ``But it just makes you focus on what you're doing, and there aren't any short cuts. You can't get a job because of who you are, you can only get it if you're good and you're serious about it.'' Part of her aprenticeship has included studying with Herbert Berghof and Uta Hagen. She got her first big role playing in the cult movie, ``My Best Friend Is a Vampire.'' ``It's a comedy and I play this seductress vampire,'' said Peck, who refuses to give her age, saying only ``you know actresses never answer that question.'' She later got a role in ``Wall Street.'' She's hoping the starring role in the low-budget ``Torn Apart,'' filmed on location in Israel for under $2 million, will lead to bigger parts in bigger movies. ``I'd like to be on that level of actresses who are being considered for the good parts,'' Peck said. ``It's been a struggle. I've worked a lot in theater. I audition and I get close and my work is good and then someone more famous gets it. So I'm hoping (`Torn Apart') will help me out.''

DOC.HEAD: The Reality of the Dollar
DOC.TEXT: Everyone has heard the story in one form or another, since everyone has been affected in some way. It is the story of the variable dollar. A person bought a house in 1978 for $50,000, and now the house has a market value of $100,000. What an investment, the homeowner says. Or you find that a car worth $5,000 five years ago still sells for $5,000. What a car! You've been duped by the dollar. In the case of the house, divide by two, because the 1990 dollar's buying power is only one-half that of the 1978 dollar. The house is still a $50,000 house. In terms of the 1985 dollar, the car is worth only $4,135 or so. With some degree of inflation always present in the economy, it is difficult to make year-to-year comparisons of anything denominated in dollars, such as paychecks, prices, profits and gross national product. Everyone dupes himself to some extent. Uncle Sam, for instance, has thrown little celebrations every time the gross national product reaches another trillion dollar level, knowing full well that he isn't dealing with reality. In reality, the buying power of the dollar changes every day, every week, every month, every year _ and almost always downward. But perceptions are slower to change; perhaps there is even a slight reluctance to change. While the changes often are small year-to-year, they add up substantially after several years have passed. Ten years ago, for instance, the 1980 dollar bought $1.58 worth of goods or services as measured by the 1990 dollar. To determine where you stand financially in 1980 dollars you must multiply your current dollar amount by 1.58. By doing so you will find how many 1990 dollars and cents are needed to equal the buying power of one 1980 dollar. If you earned $25,000 in 1980, for example, you would have to earn $25,000 times 1.58 in 1990, or $39,500, just to avoid losing ground. Deflating, isn't it? Yes, and worse: It can be terribly misleading and confusing. In geography, for example, teachers often lament that if students cannot point to the place on the map where they live, they can't possibly relate to the rest of the world and its peoples. In economics, the lament is only slightly different: How can individuals relate to the economic world and their progress in it if they can't comprehend that the measuring stick changes every year? Would it make sense to measure snowfalls by a 12-inch stick one year, and a 9-inch stick another? Or change the value of the quart or pound, or time races by a 58-second minute, or change the gradations on a thermometer? With such thoughts in mind, Martin Lefkowitz, an economist for the National Chamber of Commerce Foundation, annually updates an index for calculating the impact of inflation all the way back to 1965. It's a shocker. The index for 1965 is 4.13, meaning you would have to have $4.13 in 1990 dollars to equal the buying power of just one 1965 dollar. The index for 1970 isn't much better at 3.36. Here are others at five-year intervals from 1990, which is 1.00: 1985, index 1.21; 1980, 1.58; 1975, 2.42. Multiply 1990 dollars against the index to determine how many 1990 dollars equal $1 in those years. It can be a deflating experience, but isn't it better to face reality than to live in fantasy?
DOC.NOTE: End adv PMs Monday, May 7

DOC.HEAD: The City Sidney Lumet Loves to Hate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, to add dropped letter in camaraderie.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Sidney Lumet has mixed feelings about a lot of things these days. New York City, for instance. ``It was a marvelous city in the '50s, '60s, '70s,'' said the 65-year-old filmmaker, a native New Yorker who has earned Academy Award nominations for such New York-based films as ``Dog Day Afternoon'' and ``Network.'' ``I think it's dreadful now; I'm surprised. The fish has gone belly up. That ethnic camaraderie has gone. It's separate wolfpacks.'' And New York cops. ``I've always been proud of the New York police force. The uniforms don't fit, and their hair's too long and they've got a bit of a belly. Still, they've never lost a hostage in a hostage situation. They've done some great things. ``But now, there's been 12, 14 shootings of blacks in the past few years. It's never happened before in this city.'' That ambivalence has been channeled into his films, into such characters as Treat Williams' disenchanted cop in ``Prince of the City,'' and Paul Newman's shady lawyer in ``The Verdict.'' Lumet didn't know how he felt about either character when he began filming, forming his opinions simply by calling ``print'' at the completion of a scene. And for his new film, ``Q&A,'' he had the same mixed feelings about the characters played by stars Nick Nolte, Timothy Hutton and Armand Assante. ``Q&A'' is based on a novel by Edwin Torres, a justice of the New York State Supreme Court. Nolte stars as Mike Brennan, a corrupt Irish cop who shoots a Puerto Rican thug and attempts to cover up the crime. Hutton is Al Reilly, a naive assistant prosecutor assigned to Nolte's case, and Assante plays Bobby Texador, another Puerto Rican underworld figure murdered by Nolte. ``I said at the beginning of rehearsal that if I do this movie well you're going to feel a kind of sadness when Armand gets blown up,'' Lumet recalled. ``There's something noble about him. ``With Nick's character, he's going on and on and on, and you think he's the most hateful thing that's ever been. Then, the thing at the end, when he talks about being a cop, about `our widows,' and `our orphans.' There's all of those facets.'' In ``Q&A,'' Lumet offers a bleak vision of New York, depicting a city that has heard Peter Finch's tormented call to arms in ``Network'' _ ``I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it anymore'' _ and adopted it as a way of life. Lumet presents a fallen rainbow coalition, with racism expressed in the harshest language or the slightest twitch of the face. ``There used to be a celebration of difference,'' Lumet said, ``and that feeling has completely gone. It's profound, and it's not just New York. I think it's happening all around. One of the reasons I wanted to make this film is that I sensed this `old boy' network was all bull.'' Lumet's mixed feelings even extend to location shooting. It began in the late 1950s as a necessity, when lack of studio space forced him outside. Proudly, the director recalled his years of location work, in ``Dog Day Afternoon,'' ``Serpico'' and the 1965 film ``The Pawnbroker,'' shot entirely in Harlem. But while Lumet and crew covered everything from Greenwich Village to Kennedy Airport for ``Q&A,'' the director admitted that after years of hitting the streets and never looking back, he now catches himself peering nervously over his shoulder. ``Tim and Nick went out riding in squad cars, riding in Washington Heights, one of the last integrated neighborhoods in New York. Nick said to me, `How come you don't go.' ``I said I can't do that anymore. I can't stand those domestic disputes. A cop getting shot or a cop shooting someone. Living like that, I don't know how the cops do it. It's a very ambivalent feeling.'' For Lumet, the blurring of right and wrong has been a mixed blessing: a feeling of loss over people and places he once revered, but also a challenge to become more open-minded. The director says he values forgiveness, in life and film, and always looks for three dimensions: even with people that exist only on screen. ``I think a big part of my own life, and my own concerns have had a lot to do with judging and not judging people. Rigid behavior versus behavior that flows with life. ``I think it's very Jewish. I'm not a religious person at all and I had to go to a Seder for Passover. I was reminded how stern Judaism is. How unforgiving, how tough. You can't get off the hook. You can't get confession. You can't do nothing. Once you've blown it, you've blown it.''
