DOC.HEAD: Which Number is Best: Raw or Cooked?
DOC.TEXT: Political power and billions of dollars are at stake in a battle over which final census numbers will be better: the raw or the cooked. It's an argument that's been obscured by the early problems plaguing the census count. But a year from now, the question of ``adjusting'' the results of the census could be the center of a crucial and bitter debate among the states and cities, in Congress and in the courts. ``They can't beat us out, so they want to count us out,'' John D. Rogers, a Republican floor leader in the Kentucky Senate, charged in a letter to the Commerce Department. Democrats and other advocates for minorities see the refusal to adjust as a method of disenfranchising their voters. New York City Mayor David Dinkins charged that the undercount of minorities will cost cities hundreds of millions of dollars and many seats in Congress. ``They have gotten away with statistical malfeasance for 200 years and figure they can get away with it for another 10,'' Dinkins said. ``A decision against adjustment is a decision against a more accurate census,'' Javier P. Guajardo, an assistant attorney general in Texas, wrote the Commerce Department. ``A decision against a more accurate census is a decision against fair representation of the American public, in particular those who need to be counted most _ minorities, the poor and the homeless.'' The sides already are staking out their positions in terms of language, with opponents referring to adjustment as ``fiddling'' with the numbers, while those in favor prefer the term ``correcting'' the count. Rep. Thomas C. Sawyer, D-Ohio, who heads the House subcommittee that supervises the census, seems to be leaning toward the idea of adjustment. When the billions are spent and the counting is all done, will we know how many Americans there are, he was asked. ``I hope so, when we add in the known error,'' Sawyer said. ``The question is, will we take that into account.'' The time, he said, may have come when the nation is just too large for current methods of counting. ``We may be seeing the point where we need to consider more modern statistical methods to bring the basic numbers closer to the truth.'' Why adjust the census? Because it isn't perfect. The bureau has never claimed it could count everyone. In 1980, a bureau analysis estimated that 1.4 percent of the population was missed. But the error wasn't uniform. Most white, middle-class folks got counted, while the poor and minorities were more likely to be missed. Young black men were undercounted by as much as 6 percent, officials have estimated. A decade ago the decision on adjustment was left to the Census Bureau. Statisticians there decided they weren't confident enough in their methods to make changes in the final numbers. By 1987, many census workers thought an adjustment could _ and should _ be made in 1990. The Commerce Department stepped in and, in late 1987, ruled that no adjustment would be made in 1990. The ruling cited statistical questions and contended that adjustment would erode confidence in the census. Barbara Bailar, who headed the census office studying adjustment, resigned. Some politicians and officials charged the decision was political, because the minorities who are undercounted are more likely to be Democrats. A group of local governments led by New York City filed suit. That suit was settled with a promise by the Commerce Department to reconsider, but was later reinstated. The Commerce Department has set a group of criteria that will be used to make a decision by July 15, 1991 _ several months after the numbers have to be delivered to state and local governments for reapportionment. Those criteria, opponents argued in reinstating their lawsuit, are so stringent that they virtually prohibit adjustment. If a decision is eventually made to adjust, it will not be until mid-1991. Because the first census reports will come out Dec. 31, that means there would be two sets of numbers _ providing easily identifiable winners and losers. The fact that there is a limited amount of money and only 435 seats in the House of Representatives means that every gain by one state requires a loss by another. While the 1990 census will likely mean movement of a dozen or so House seats from one state to another, the difference between raw and adjusted numbers should affect only two to four seats, Sawyer said. It will also mean a difference of billions of dollars in federal and state money distributed over the next 10 years based on population numbers. University of Wisconsin historian Margo Anderson, author of a book on the history of the census, said ``the framers of the Constitution knew that the orderly transfer of political representation is always disruptive to some groups or interests in society.'' ``The test of the new methods is not whether they are disruptive, but whether they are fair,'' she said, adding that the department's guidelines for adjustment ``conjure up an idealized history, the notion of a 200-year process of enumeration which cannot be tampered with.'' In fact, she noted, census methods have changed radically over the centuries. ``The premise that the actual enumeration is the best count possible has no factual support,'' John W. Tukey of Princeton University told the department. The Census Bureau launched its effort to count the estimated 250 million Americans in late March, a project expected to take the rest of the year. The tally was embroiled in controversy from the start, with millions of forms misaddressed. The public response was less than the bureau had hoped. The effort has moved to a door-to-door count, but that will cost considerably more than if people had all received their forms and mailed them back.

DOC.HEAD: Efficiency Important in Global Pecking Order
DOC.TEXT: No country is ready to knock the United States from its roost as the world's top poultry producer. But in the global game of chicken there is a beak-to-beak race to see who is the most efficient. Efficiency can translate into profits for producers and lower prices for consumers. Efficiency also is a big factor in one country's having an export advantage over another. The world's poultry trade is one of the many items under discussion in the current Uruguay Round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which is scheduled to conclude by the end of this year. According to Agriculture Department analysts, the GATT talks _ which are aimed at general liberalization of world trade _ could lead to greater traffic in poultry meat and lower consumer prices in many countries. Basically, the department's Economic Research Service says in a recent report, efficient producers such as the United States, Thailand and Brazil would reap benefits from successful GATT negotiations. ``Poultry is the fastest growing source of meat, representing about 22 percent of all meat production in 1988,'' the report said. ``The countries with industrial market economies accounted for about 54 percent of total world poultry production and 59 percent of world exports in 1988.'' The five major poultry importers in 1988 were Japan, Saudi Arabia, the Soviet Union, Hong Kong and Iraq. The five biggest exporters were the United States, the European Economic Community, Brazil, Hungary and Thailand. ``Poultry's relative share of total meat consumption after trade liberalization would probably continue to grow because costs of poultry production could continue to be lower than for other meats,'' the report said. The United States produced about 20.7 billion pounds of poultry in 1988, based on estimated ready-to-cook weight. That was almost double the output of 1970. Broilers make up most poultry. In 1940, U.S. broilers _ once called fryers _ required more than 4 pounds of feed for each pound of live weight gain. Today, the ratio is about 2 pounds of feed for each 1 of gain. Moreover, the report said, improved genetic stock and management have reduced the time to ``grow out'' a broiler from 14 weeks in 1940 to 6 or 7 weeks currently. Consequently, based on 1986 figures, U.S. broiler producers are able to turn out ready-to-cook birds for an average cost of 29.9 cents per pound. Given the great size of the overall U.S. chicken factory, that should rank American producers at the top of the heap for efficiency. Collectively, the No. 2 producer, including chickens consumed domestically and those exported, was the EEC, which produced 13 billion pounds in 1988. The Soviet Union was third at 7.02 billion pounds, followed by China, 5.29 billion; Brazil, 4.4 billion; Japan, 3.24 billion; and France, the leading EEC producer, 3.16 billion. Feed conversion rates and costs of production were not available to agency researchers for the EEC, although the 1986 cost of production of broilers in France was 34.8 cents per pound. In the Soviet Union, the third-ranked broiler producer, it required 3.6 pounds of feed to grow 1 pound of broiler, compared with 5.3 pounds in 1965. No costs were shown. Also, it takes a Soviet chicken 66 to 77 days to grow enough to be eaten, more than 40 percent longer than the U.S. broiler. ``Much of the differential between Soviet producers and producers in other countries can probably be attributed to the low protein content of Soviet poultry feed, because most protein meal must be imported,'' the report said. But U.S. broiler efficiency is being challenged by some other countries. Thailand, a relative newcomer to broiler production, turns out birds at a cost of 29.9 cents per pound of ready-to-cook weight, matching the U.S. cost. Feed conversion also is at the U.S. rate of 2 pounds of feed for each pound of live weight. New Zealand is producing broilers with 1.9 pounds of feed for each pound of growth, but its costs were reported at 33.6 cents per ready-to-cook pound. The report showed that consumer broiler prices in the United States in November 1988 averaged 85 cents per pound. Only Brazil was lower at 68 cents. Others included in a selected list of prices for broiler meat in capital cities in U.S. dollars, included Australia, $1.69 per pound; Canada, $1.24; France, $2.22; Japan, $2.90, and Mexico, 93 cents.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 6

DOC.SECOND: BC-US in Asia, Adv 13, 1st Ld - Writethru, b0690,1308
DOC.NOTE: $Adv13
For Release Sunday, May 13, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: End of Cold War, Philippine Nationalism May Cause Bases To Close
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 25th `In Vietnam' with more on Soviet forces; picks up 26th `Regional governments'
DOC.TEXT: A fading Cold War and growing Philippine nationalism may cause the United States to close its oldest and largest military bases on foreign soil. American and Philippine officials open talks Monday on whether the United States will be allowed access to Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations after Sept. 16, 1991, when the 1947 Military Bases Agreement expires. Because the bases have been the cornerstone of American defense of the Far East, the outcome of the talks will be a central element in defining the future U.S. role in East Asia. A new long-term agreement is far from certain. Soviet military retrenchment has led to demands in the U.S. Congress that the expensive network of foreign bases be trimmed. Filipinos question whether they can be truly independent while 40,000 American service personnel, Defense Department civilians and military dependents remain on their soil. President Corazon Aquino has refused to say whether she supports an extension of the agreement. U.S. diplomats and government sources say they believe she favors it, but has avoided a public commitment because the issue is so sensitive. Most Filipino politicians who have commented publicly want the bases closed next year or phased out by the end of the century. Opposition stiffened after Congress cut $96 million from an aid package the Reagan administration had promised Manila in order to keep the bases until the agreement expired. Since the end of World War II, Filipinos assumed the United States wanted to keep the bases at all costs and would pay handsomely for the privilege. In 1988, Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus demanded $2 billion in aid, but eventually accepted a two-year package of $962 million Congressional pressure to reduce defense spending as the Soviet threat recedes has raised doubts that the bases are worth such a price. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has announced plans to reduce the 120,000 U.S. troops in the Far East by 10 to 12 percent over three years as the newly prosperous nations of Asia assume greater responsibility for their own defense. ``My sense is that, if it looks too testy, the United States will simply tell the Philippines that we will close down,'' Paul H. Kreisberg of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said about the negotiations. U.S. policymakers and private researchers believe the bases still have an important role in projecting American military power and maintaining security in the Far East. The American military has been in the Philippines since 1898, when the United States seized the archipelago in the Spanish-American war, ending 350 years of Spanish rule. It has larger forces elsewhere in Asia _ 64,000 troops in Japan and 43,000 in South Korea _ but the Philippine bases allow the United States great flexibility in crises, including those far from Pacific waters. NATO agreements prohibit the United States from using its European-based forces outside the alliance area without allied permission. No such restrictions apply in the Philippines. Three-quarters of the U.S. warships that escorted oil tankers through the Persian Gulf during the Iran-Iraq War were from the Pacific Fleet. Most were supplied and outfitted at Subic, 50 miles west of Manila. Planes from Clark and the Cubi Point naval air station monitor shipping lanes and supply the large Indian Ocean air and naval installations at Diego Garcia. ``In a straight military sense, the value of the bases declines only slightly in a post-Cold War era,'' said Richard Fisher, a Heritage Foundation policy analyst. ``There will still be a requirement to deploy to South Korea or potential conflicts in the Persian Gulf.'' Some functions could be performed on Guam, Saipan and Tinian, more than 1,500 miles east, but experts say the Guam harbor is far smaller than Subic's. The islands also lack the skilled labor, especially ship repairmen, available in the Philippines. Despite official opposition to foreign forces, most East Asian governments privately support the bases. Fidel Ramos, the Philippine defense secretary, said there was little evidence of a major reductions in Soviet forces in Vietnam or in Vladivostok, headquarters of the Soviet Pacific fleet. In Vietnam, the Soviet navy uses the U.S.-built base at Cam Ranh Bay. The Soviets said in January they had reduced air strength at Cam Ranh Bay to no more than 10 planes. Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam says all Soviet forces will be gone by 1992. In recent years, U.S. officials have played down the Soviet presence as the reason for maintaining bases Philippine bases. Brent Scowcroft, now President Bush's national security adviser, told a news conference two years ago that trading Cam Ranh Bay for Subic ``would be very much in the Soviet interest, but not necessarily in ours. ... The Russians don't need (it) nearly as much as we do the Philippines.'' Regional governments fear a drastic reduction in U.S. forces would cause such nations as China, Japan, Vietnam and India to expand their forces. ``Without a persuasive U.S. presence, there will be a power vacuum which other powers would scramble to fill,'' said Lee Hsien Loong, Singapore's deputy defense minister. Such geopolitical concerns mean less than money and national pride in the introspective Philippines. Most surveys indicate supporters of the bases outnumber opponents, but Filipinos in growing numbers believe the American presence infringes national sovereignty. The installations pump an estimated $1 billion into the economy, however, and more than 270,000 Filipinos depend on them for a livelihood. ``Those people who say we have alternatives to the bases have to prove they can replace the considerable support given by the U.S. facilities to the city,'' said Mayor Richard Gordon of Olongapo, home of the Subic base. Opposition to the bases stems from complex, often-contradictory views of the United States, which ruled the Philippines from 1898 to 1946. Admiration of American culture borders on obsession among Filipinos, the most westernized Asians, but many believe this has created a psychological dependence that inhibits national development. The Philippine military relies almost entirely on the United States for external defense. Its navy often turns to the Americans for help in air and sea rescues. U.S. Air Force meteorologists warn their Filipino counterparts of approaching typhoons. On the other side, critics claim the bases encourage prostitution. The sleazy bars and nightclubs of Olongapo and Angeles, home of Clark Air Base, serve as evidence. ``The whole bases campaign is a quest for finding out who we are,'' said Socorro Diokno, chairman of the Anti-Bases Coalition. ``Can the Filipino stand on his feet without having to rely on America?'' Dependence on the United States was dramatized in December when American F-4 Phantom jets from Clark flew air cover for government forces during a coup attempt. The planes never fired a shot, but their presence stopped rebel air attacks on military and government buildings, including the presidential palace. Last year, Mrs. Aquino appointed a committee to study alternative uses for the bases if no new agreement was reached. Proposals include converting Clark to a civilian airport and establishing a commercial ship repair facility at Subic. Businessmen in Olongapo and Angeles are skeptical. ``We firmly believe that any conversion plan regarding alternative uses of the bases entails huge costs and implementation is doubtful,'' the Angeles Chamber of Commerce and Industry in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Rich-Poor Gap, Economic Crisis Spur Crime Wave in Rio
DOC.TEXT: Inside the luxury hotel was a conference on ``Tourism and Crime in Rio.'' Just outside, two tourists were mugged. Men with shotguns hold up airport buses. Valuables are stolen at the beach, from hotel rooms. Police booths sprout in every block. Cariocas, as Rio's residents are called, have special devices on their cars that cut off the fuel supply when a thief has driven a few blocks. Crime always has infested Rio's slums, but now it is common on the glitzy tourist beaches and the streets where money lives. Cariocas have little affinity for the police or justice system and often settle disputes themselves. Increasingly, guns are the arbiters of choice. Not long ago, Antonio Enrique de Oliveira sighted down the barrel of his new .38-caliber pistol and squeezed off a shot. ``That's my law,'' the husky, 26-year-old mechanic said as the report echoed off the hills overlooking the vast, poor suburb of Nova Iguacu. ``It's the only law that works in Rio anymore.'' Death squads, generally off-duty policemen fed up with the inefficient courts and turnstile justice, make another kind of law. They simply kill known criminals or suspects, often for pay from merchants. Among reasons for the crime wave are poverty, rarity of punishment, the example of official corruption, inflation that reached nearly 5,000 percent and forced harsh economic measures, and an ever-widening gap between rich and poor. The top 1 percent of Brazil's 150 million people have as much wealth as the bottom 50 percent. Police statistics say homicides in metropolitain Rio rose from 2,924 in 1983 to 7,654 last year. Residents and religious leaders say most killings don't get into the records. A city police official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there were nearly 20,000 in metropolitan Rio last year. ``Crime has never been this bad. We're fighting a guerrilla war,'' said Helio Vigio, a police inspector for 20 years. A sociologist, Helio Jaguaribe, said: ``The elite and the establishment can no longer control tensions between rich and poor. Crime is now seen by the poor as social retribution.'' Gun sales icreased from 15,520 in 1987 to 22,872 in 1989. Cariocas bar their windows, and buy burglar alarms and watch dogs. Neighbors often band together to hire armed guards. ``My sales are doubling every three months,'' said Mauro Cesar Martins, who displays eight models of .38 caliber revolvers in his downtown sporting goods store. ``People trust only their gun for protection. Can you blame them?'' Police say thousands of automatic weapons smuggled from Paraguay and Bolivia are bought and sold in illegal gun markets. For years, violent crime was largely confined to Rio's North Zone, a poor, densely populated area far from the beaches of the wealthy South Zone. Automatic weapons abound in the North Zone. Gang wars end in massacres. Citizens carry pistols in their shorts. Children as young as 5 run cocaine to customers in affluent neighborhoods. Bodies are dumped in the streets every day, sometimes outside police stations. One Sunday in January, 10 were found in a group, shot through the head. A month later, a record 57 corpses turned up in Rio in a single weekend. Gang leaders establish personal fiefdoms in the ``favelas,'' or hillside shantytowns, and organize residents into defense units. ``The slums are becoming armed fortresses of urban warfare,'' said Lt. Eide Trindade, director of Rio's task force on organized crime. ``On drug raids in the hills, you run into nests of machine gunners. When they open fire, it's like walking into lightning.'' City police, poorly equipped, trained and paid, are no match for the well-armed criminals. They are sent into the streets without nightsticks, holsters or bulletproof vests, and must buy their own uniforms. Each officer is given six bullets every three months. They patrol in 13-year-old Volkswagen Beetles, which often have broken radios. Rio has 12,000 municipal police and 27,000 state police in a metropolitan area of 10.5 million people. Death squads, which first appeared in the 1950s, are growing with the crime wave. Community leaders say they have more than 2,000 members, compared with 500 two years ago. A police inquiry made public in April said the chiefs of 15 death squads in greater Rio were active state policemen. ``The death squads are in complete control of the people; if anyone sees a murder and opens his mouth, he's as good as dead,'' said Azuleika Rodrigues, president of the Federation of Neighborhood Associations in Nova Iguacu. Low pay causes police strikes and corruption. A rookie cop earns the equivalent of $100 a month and a top-ranking inspector $335. ``You have to be a part-time crook or mobster to eat or have your teeth fixed,'' said officer Jose Quimonte, 33, who works 48 hours a week for $188. There is temptation for officers to break the law, and little incentive for them to enforce it. Police say lawbreakers are encouraged by a slow, understaffed judicial system and the belief that criminals will get light sentences or go free. ``If you bring someone in, chances are that, if he's rich enough, hid salespeople from The World's No. 1 Jewelry Company Serving The Sanitation Industry. The idea _ clear Hefty Cinch-Saks _ might seem a trifle mundane. But last month's Earth Day somehow has Americans excited about a mundane task _ throwing out trash. Slug AM-Waste Expo. New, will stand. By Robert Byrd. Moving on FFF- and AAA-level news wires.

DOC.HEAD: Death Squad Cemetery: Numbered Crosses For Nameless Dead
With Crime in Rio
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Marapicu cemetery in the impoverished Baixada Fluminense suburbs of Rio de Janeiro has been a burial ground for victims of death squads for nearly 30 years. Police officials admit knowing this, but have neither undertaken an investigation nor explained their failure to do so. Todd Lewan visited the graveyard.

The dead have no names in Marapicu cemetery. No one knows who they were or where they came from. Death squads killed them. That is all anyone remembers. Sebastiao Fernandez da Rocha, a sparrow-like man of 72, buries them. At first, it made him sad to think he was the last to see the victims. He was gentle in lowering the younger ones. After 17 years, pity no longer hangs on his features. He is a gaunt old man with thick calluses raised by the hoe and shovel. The bodies mean little more to him now than the dirt he throws over them. Each morning, before dawn, Rocha begins a two-hour walk to work, on a winding road through one of Brazil's most lawless regions, the Baixada Fluminense. Orange groves and cotton once flourished in the Baixada's lowlands, but the the plantations were divided into plots 30 years ago and sold to squatters. poverty is everywhere. Machine guns make the law. Death is judgment. When Rocha arrives in Queimados, which means Burned Ones, he whistles into the open doors of the shacks of two young helpers. They walk up the red dirt road together to the cemetery on the hill. So close are the graves that they nearly touch. Hundreds of white stone crosses, bearing painted numbers, jut crookedly from the rocky ground. There are no headstones. The task on this morning, presuming death squads attacked again in the night, was to dig six graves. When that was done, Rocha and the young men sat in the shade, painting crosses white while they waited. In the heat of the midday sun, a dust cloud rose on the ridge. A morgue van rolled up. Rocha put on his straw hat and went to it. The barefoot youths followed. ``Lots of meat today,'' said the driver, a big, sweaty man. He threw the rear doors open. Inside were the bodies of eight men and a small girl, in a sun dress, who had been shot in the stomach. Some of the men's faces were unrecognizable, nearly blown away. Rocha went into a small office near the gate, wrote the number 9 in a ledger and returned. They pulled the corpses out like sacks of beans and dropped them into plywood boxes. The boxes keep wild dogs from digging bodies up. The young men carried the boxes down the slope while Rocha dug three more holes. Fifty yards away was a single grave with flowers blooming on it. ``That's my son,'' Rocha said. ``I found his body about 10 minutes' walk from here on my way in one morning. They broke his neck and spine. Don't know why. No one ever finds out why they die.'' Rocha thrust the shovel into the earth. He was wheezing, ribs pressing against a torn blue shirt. ``He was 15,'' the old man said. ``His name was Luis. Luis Enrique.'' He and the others worked quickly, silently, to cover the graves. Only the rasp of their hoes on the crude coffins interfered with the sound of a rising wind. When it was done, they went out through the black gates and sat under a mango tree on a bluff, drinking rum from tin cups. ``Will there be more today, old man?'' one of the young ones asked. ``Yes.'' ``It is terrible, isn't it?'' Rocha grunted. ``This is the way things are,'' he said. ``I remember a proverb: The blame lies not only with the ax, but the tree as well. Yes, that is the proverb.'' The young men nodded and had another pull of rum.

DOC.HEAD: Decade of Healing Softens St. Helens' Volcanic Destruction
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos, AP Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Ten years. Time enough for a forest to spring from lifeless ash. Time enough for people in the shadow of a restless volcano to recover, even profit, from catastrophe. But never time enough to forget. Even as nature heals this shattered mountain with a blanket of green, the violence of May 18, 1980, remains seared in memory. That was the day Mount St. Helens exploded, killing 57 people, flattening a forest and spitting out an ash cloud that circled the globe. Don McElwain remembers. He was camping 20 miles away when hot ash engulfed him, turning his day to night. ``I'm a former Army Ranger and not much scares me,'' he said. ``But I'll tell you, I was doing some praying.'' McElwain and two camping partners barely escaped on horseback, breathing through rags torn from their shirts as they rode across ash that singed the hair on the horses' legs. But the ordeal did not destroy his love of Mount St. Helens. Like many of the volcano's neighbors, McElwain, 53, hopes to profit from a disaster that changed this region's economic life as surely as it rearranged the landscape. He's been scouting out land, thinking of starting up a small tourist resort. ``Someday,'' he said, ``this place will be beautiful again.'' Before it erupted, Mount St. Helens was a snowy, symmetrical, seemingly dormant volcano surrounded by tall evergreen forests. Thousands of campers experienced their first real wilderness along crystal-clear Spirit Lake, on the mountain's north side. The idyll couldn't last. Mount St. Helens, historically one of the Cascade Range's most active volcanoes, had not erupted since 1857. Geologists warned it was overdue. At 8:32 a.m. on May 18, 1980, after weeks of sputtering and rumbling, the volcano roared awake. An earthquake jarred loose a huge slab that slid into the lake, weakening the mountain's north side. Magma that for months had risen slowly up the volcano's vents suddenly let loose in a sideways explosion of gas, rock and ash 2,500 times more powerful than the atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima. A super-heated cloud of pulverized rock, focused horizontally by the misshapen crater, flattened 150-foot-tall fir trees like pieces of straw. Across Spirit Lake, a mammoth wave caused by the landslide sloshed over the opposite ridge, washing the slopes bare of the downed timber. Victims caught in the blast included U.S. Geological Survey scientist David Johnston, killed even as he monitored delicate measuring devices on a ridge 5 miles away. Photographer Reid Blackburn snapped a few pictures, then retreated to his car. He was found two days later, smothered by ash. Harry Truman, who had lived on the mountain 54 years, defied orders to leave his Spirit Lake lodge, declaring, ``That mountain is a part of Truman, and I'm a part of it.'' His words were prophetic. Truman and his lodge were buried under 120 feet of debris and 180 feet of the new, deeper Spirit Lake, a steaming cauldron of mud and water covered by a floating layer of uprooted trees scoured of bark. The volcano's heat melted glaciers and starting surging mudflows. One wall of mud 12 feet high swept down the Toutle River, destroying trucks, bridges and more than 200 homes. An ash plume rose 14 miles into the air and drifted eastward, darkening three states and choking towns with ashfalls up to 6 inches deep. To observers first returning to the mountain, the destruction seemed complete. But as weeks went by, scientists watched in amazement as life appeared amid the ruin. Pocket gophers burrowed up from their tunnels, poking their heads through ash. Colonies of ants went busily about their business. Even the most barren areas were soon invaded by ballooning spiders and beetles, scavengers that floated in on parachute-like webs and survived on the remains of other insects blown their way. The first summer, green shoots of fireweed and huckleberry rose through 10-inch layers of ash. Later, elk and deer wandered back, and the windblown seeds of alders and evergreens sprouted in fertile patches where water and wind had eroded the ash. Inside the Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument, a 110,000-acre preserve created in 1982 for watching natural regeneration, the pioneering evergreens now are 4 to 6 inches tall. Outside the monument, the U.S. Forest Service and logging companies gave nature a jump start, salvaging downed trees and planting seedlings in holes bored through ash. Today, some of those trees stand 25 feet tall. As nature heals, so do people. After the eruption, communities still grieving for victims started crawling out and slowly cleaning up. Fearing more floods, the Army Corps of Engineers dredged rivers, built levees and bored a drainage tunnel to Spirit Lake. This May 19, officials will dedicate a sediment retention dam on the Toutle River, finishing a decade of recovery work costing more than $560 million. Muddy rivers have grown clearer, and many residents now look to St. Helens in hope, not fear. They're staking their futures on the flood of tourists coming to see the only active volcano in the contiguous United States. More than a million visitors each year drive to viewpoints or stop at a Forest Service visitor center 30 miles from the volcano. Almost 50,000 have climbed the volcano's south side since entry restrictions were eased in 1987. Roadside gift shops specialize in volcano souvenirs, and the once-flooded town of Toutle sponsors an annual Volcano Daze Festival. Developers are preparing for 1992, when a highway will be extended to a new visitor's center peering into the volcano's crater. On sunny spring weekends, the mountain's southern flank becomes a playground for up to 400 climbers and skiers. There are higher Northwest mountains for climbing, more accessible mountains for skiing. But Mount St. Helens, its former 9,677-foot summit reduced 1,300 feet by the eruption, has a magnetic appeal. ``I think it's a morbid curiosity,'' said Martha Miller, peering into the barren crater from the rim after a grueling, six-hour climb on skis. ``It's the mystique,'' said her husband, Ben, who skied the volcano partly to impress friends back home in New Hampshire, where the mountains are more sedate. ``St. Helens is an an active volcano, and everyone's heard of it.'' Ten years is a blink of an eye in geologic time, and the volcano still sputters. The latest steam release occurred April 25. Scientists don't rule out more fireworks but say the possibility of an eruption is low. A 920-foot lava dome on the crater floor has not grown since 1986, and geologists, who have honed their predictive skills since 1980, are confident they can give days or weeks notice of significant eruptions. That's scant reassurance at the volcano rim, where the mountain's jagged wounds are still raw, its destructive power still overwhelming. Silent fields of snow and towers of rock dwarfed the skiers as they stared into the immense crater. Ten years later, Mount St. Helens still commands respect. ``It makes you feel pretty small,'' Martha Miller said. She turned her back to a chill wind blowing up from the crater, and the skiers headed down to the springtime warmth of the forest, far below.

DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Mount St. Helen's Ash, Memories Linger in Eastern Washington
With BC-Volcano's Recovery
DOC.TEXT: Tom Kadlec had just left church May 18, 1980 when the black clouds began rolling in. He doesn't remember if the pastor preached fire and brimstone that Sunday morning. If he did, it was fitting. ``About 3:30 in the afternoon it turned blackest dark, and the automatic street lights came on like the world was coming to an end,'' Kadlec said. ``We were all wondering what was happening.'' What happened was something residents of this farming town of 1,800 never want to experience again. Mount St. Helens, roughly 200 miles to the southwest, blew its top at 8:32 a.m. Within hours, tons of wind-carried volcanic ash and dust were being dumped on the eastern Washington towns of Ellensburg, Yakima, Moses Lake and Ritzville. ``I didn't hear any explosions or anything,'' recalled Terry Reed, owner of the 21-room Empire Motel. ``A little later on in the afternoon, people started coming in and saying, `We want to get in here and get a room before it hits.' And I said, `What hits?' Well, I found out.'' Overnight, Ritzville's population more than doubled. The five motels in town filled up within hours as roughly 2,200 stranded travelers abandoned their ash-clogged cars on roads and highways. Homes, schools and churches served as emergency shelters. The mail stopped, businesses closed and the city's vibrantly blooming hawthorn trees sagged and died. By Monday morning, 4 to 7 inches of pale gray ash blanketed Main Street, family wheat fields, the golf course. Drug stores had a run on dust masks. Grocery stores and restaurants ran out of supplies and food. ``It got so bad the mayor had to close the bars down, people got to fighting and stealing from one another,'' Reed said. For three days, nobody could get into town, or out. ``All this ash was everywhere, and it was just quiet. There wasn't a bird or anything, no sounds at all. It was just eerie, eerie,'' said Diane Keetch, co-owner of Colwell Motor Inn. Kirk Danekas, a funeral home operator who was mayor at the time, postponed a funeral scheduled for Monday. He trudged up a hill by the cemetery and looked forlornly down on the heart of the city he had governed for less than a year and a half. ``And there was this great gray mass. And I asked myself, are all these people going to leave? Is this the end of the town?'' It wasn't, of course. Nearer the volcano, 57 people were killed, many by the scorching blast of the eruption or the smothering ash. But few serious health problems or emergencies were reported here. More than anything, the tons of ash were an enormous mess. In the weeks that followed, the town dug out. Danekas said 36 of 39 counties sent equipment or other aid. Homeowners cleaned their roofs and yards and piled the ash along the street. Water trucks hosed it down. Earth moving machinery pushed it into piles. Scoop-loaders picked up hundreds of cubic yards of ash and dumped it in a gravel pit a quarter mile from town. ``It was just hard work for everybody,'' Danekas said. The abrasive ash wore out farm machinery but didn't seem to poison any crops. In fact, many wheat farmers suggested the ash was the reason for a bumper crop that year. ``When it rained, the ash seemed to seal the moisture,'' said Mike Bauer, adding that his crop was 20 percent above average that year. To this day, the ash remains in Bauer's soil, compressed in a quarter-inch layer. A whitish-gray film can also be seen along roadsides and undisturbed hillsides. And reminders of the fallout a decade ago will long rest in the hearts and minds of people like Janet Sanger of neighboring Lind, a town that beckons visitors with a sign that says: ``Drop in. Mount St. Helens did.'' ``It was amazing,'' she said. ``I hope I never live through anything like that again.''

DOC.HEAD: Ash Makes Everything From Gems to Jesus
With BC-Volcano's Recovery
DOC.TEXT: Entrepreneurs have turned the ash from Mount St. Helens into everything from gemstones to Jesus in the last decade, and volcano kitsch still is a hot seller. Ash is Washington state's answer to the velvet Elvises and straw cowboy hats that lure tourist dollars in other areas. When Sally Warren surveyed the ruined cucumbers in her Woodland garden that May day in 1980, she never imagined Mount St. Helen's ash would one day put money in her pocket. But 10 years after the eruption, Ms. Warren and a partner continue to make and sell porcelain figures containing some of the ash. It is one of several businesses born of the volcano. ``A little economy has definitely developed and grown from using this Mount St. Helen's ash,'' said Mary Mains, whose company makes jewelry from it. Inventive residents put the ash in everything from pottery to earrings to Christmas ornaments, paperweights and pens. There are even ash-colored volcanoes with little ash smoke plumes coming out the top. They sell to tourists and to Washington residents seeking gifts for out-of-state friends, said Kay Thomas, owner of a gift shop in this city about 100 miles east of the volcano. The lure is the volcano connection. ``I wish I had known you could do wonderful things with it,'' Ms. Thomas said of the ash that piled up on her roof. ``I would have sold it.'' Other people immediately saw the potential. Workers who went up the mountain to salvage the engines of destroyed logging trucks learned their cutting torches would melt the ash into a green stone. That discovery prompted Ms. Mains to found a new branch of her retail business, The Emerald Fox. She keeps five employees busy producing ``Emerald Obsidianite'' jewelry made by melting the ash at 2,700 degrees in an oxygen-free environment. The jewelry is sold over the United States, she said. The ash is not actually ash, but rock dust that is largely composed of silicon, aluminum, iron, calcium, sodium and at least 12 other elements, she said. Chromium and iron, when heated, give the stone its rich green color, making it a dead ringer for emeralds, she said. They are so close in appearance that New York City jewelry stories, concerned about security, use the stones in window displays as a substitute for emeralds. The jewelry, priced from $30 to more than $200, may indeed attract buyers because of its beauty. The same cannot be said for the $2 pens whose plastic bodies are filed with ash. Or what looks like a clump of wet sand in the form of a tiny smoldering volcano. Only hard-core ash enthusiasts could love those. And all ash is not created equal. The debris from different eruptions came from different depths of the Earth and reacts differently to processing. Ms. Warren and partner Fay Miller make their porcelain figures with ash gathered from the June 12, 1980, eruption, rather than the May eruption. ``It's more like sand,'' she said. ``The first eruption was more like talcum powder. It made it look muddy.'' Ms. Mains disdains the 1980 ash altogether, preferring for her jewelry a 1981 vintage believed to have come from 10 to 20 miles below the Earth's surface. Fred Ybarra, a gemologist in Yakima, said many people still come into his shop offering to sell their ash. He can't use it but said that items made from ash would eventually become more valuable as the ash supply runs out. Ms. Warren uses about 2 tablespoons of ash for every gallon of porcelain she mixes up. Her husband shoveled up a large amount of ash shortly after the eruptions, and they keep it in gallon jars at their home. ``We've got enough for another 40 years,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Decorated Soldier Returns from Self-Imposed Exile
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's most decorated soldiers has ended nearly two decades of self-imposed exile to fight for reform of a military establishment that he says lacks the moral courage to change. Col. David H. Hackworth broke with the Army in 1971, disillusioned and angered by its use of conventional tactics to fight a guerrilla war in Vietnam. Forced to retire from the service because of his public criticism of the Vietnam strategy, an embittered Hackworth built a a new life in Australia. It took 18 years before he put the bitterness behind him and returned to the United States. ``I was angry; I was vindictive,'' said Hackworth, author of the 1989 best-selling autobiography ``About Face.'' ``Writing the book was an incredible catharsis for me. I was able to heal myself.'' Now he is directing his energy toward a campaign to reshape a military bureaucracy that he says must ``change its mind-set and come up with fresh ideas.'' Hackworth said he is pressing for the merger of the Army, Navy and Air Force into an American Defense Force. He says the change would reduce waste and duplication and provide for a more streamlined command system. ``Our military is all wrong, has been all wrong since World War II,'' he said. The key to change is ``getting warrior leaders at the top, rather than manager-careerists,'' Hackworth said. ``All we need is leadership _ people who've got the guts, determination and the vision to turn things around, instead of those who live by the motto of `go along to get along.''' It's imperative that Congress and the Pentagon make reforms because ``the American people are tired of being ripped off,'' said Hackworth, who will make his case in a May 14 meeting with Army Secretary Michael Stone. Maj. Joe Pidilla, an Army spokesman, declined to comment on Hackworth's statements. Orphaned before he was a year old, Hackworth, 59, was raised in California by his grandmother and in foster homes. He lied about his age to join the Army in 1946 when he was 15 and received a battlefield commission in Korea five years later. At 40 he became the youngest full colonel in Vietnam, where he served for nearly six years. His many awards for valor include two Distinguished Service Crosses, nine Silver Stars, eight Bronze Stars, and eight Purple Hearts for wounds suffered in battle. Hackworth gained a reputation for blunt talk when, as a teen-age private in Italy, he told Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, ``The chow stinks.'' His unsparing criticism of tactics and doctrine continued throughout his 25-year career. It culminated in 1971 when he appeared on ABC's ``Issues and Answers'' show. He told a national television audience that the Army's Vietnam tactics were not unlike the food he had in Italy. That was too much for the Army, which unceremoniously retired the man who had been told a few months earlier that he was virtually assured promotion to brigadier general. ``I was brokenhearted because the Army was my family,'' he said. ``I loved it.'' Hackworth said he chose Australia as a new home because it was the farthest place from the United States where English was spoken. He bought a diner and two gas stations and later purchased a restaurant in Brisbane. He sold the restaurant a few years later for $1 million and took up farming. Hackworth decided to reconcile with his country during a May 1988 visit to turn in the manuscript of ``About Face'' to his publisher, Simon & Schuster Inc. It was then he realized that ``writing the book had driven the devil out of me.'' Last year he bought a home in Montana, where he will live about six months a year. The rest of the time he'll spend at his home in Australia. A major focus of his campaign for military reform has been the Vietnam War, from which the military has learned little, he said. ``We haven't conducted an honest postmortem. We are treating it exactly as we treated Korea. We were so humiliated by not winning in Korea that we took all the mistakes and swept them under the rug. Vietnam became the stepchild of the Korean War.'' Hackworth cautioned against reckless dismemberment of the military as the Soviet threat diminishes. ``We did it in 1918, 1945, 1953 and 1973. We went into World War II not prepared; we went into Korea not prepared.'' ``The contraction of the military has to be done carefully,'' he said. ``What I would do is have a moratorium on the acquisition of any goodies. We wouldn't buy any Stealths, we wouldn't buy any Midgetman'' missiles. ``We should use the money to keep our military personnel and build down through attrition,'' he said. ``If there's one lesson we learned in Vietnam it was that hardware couldn't win over dedicated men. One thing the Viet Cong had _ just like our revolutionary forefathers who beat a superior force in the field _ was fire in their bellies. Men win wars, not hardware.'' He also urged a return to the draft because ``a standing volunteer Army violates what our country is about. It becomes isolated from the values of our society. ... ``Our young people are couch potatoes. They're weak and their moral values are bad. At least the military can give them values.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 6

DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers agreed to cut the cartel's total crude output by 1.45 million barrels a day from April production of 23.5 million in an effort to help maintain oil prices at a minimum of $18 a barrel. But oil prices fell sharply after Thursday's announcement amid skepticism that the cut would actually materialize. Analysts noted that even if OPEC succeeds, the action wouldn't be enough to solve the current oil glut.

Sales of North American-made cars and light trucks edged up 2.8 percent in late April as rising sales of ``transplant'' cars from foreign-owned factories helped overcome a sharp sales drop at Chrysler Corp. North American-made cars and trucks sold at an average rate of 47,684 during the period, up 2.8 percent, while the average rate for Big Three vehicles was 41,543, up just 0.1 percent, the companies reported Thursday. Chrysler said its car sales in the April 21-30 period dropped 33.8 percent and light truck sales dropped 16.5 percent from that period a year earlier. Increases at General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. barely offset the declines.

Profits fell by 54 percent at General Motors Corp. and by 69 percent at Ford Motor Co. in the first quarter due to U.S. production slowdowns and problems with overseas operations. The figures released Thursday, combined with Chrysler Corp.'s 80 percent drop in first quarter net income, meant an overall 64 percent profit drop for the Big Three automakers during the period. But the results were not as bad as the 75 percent profit decline that analysts had expected for the companies, which are struggling with soft markets and intensified competition from foreign-based automakers.

The Easter holiday and spring weather lured consumers back into stores in April and gave apparel retailers a much-needed sales boost, according to results from several of the nation's big retail companies. Many retailers who had a disappointing March fared better last month as they sold more clothes, but those dependent on sales of more expensive items continued to lag behind, the results indicated Thursday.

Shareholders of Avon Products Inc., which has been under pressure to cut costs, sell assets or put itself up for sale, urged the cosmetics giant to drop a key takeover defense or put it to a vote. Shareholders approved two non-binding proposals Thursday at their annual meeting relating to the company's share rights plans, commonly known as poison pills, that can make unsolicited buyout bids prohibitively expensive. Both proposals were opposed by Avon management, which insists the company is not for sale and wants to proceed with plans to making its direct selling business more profitable.

A proposed deal that would give expansion-minded America West Airlines Inc. all of Trans World Airlines' domestic operations drew a large dose of skepticism from employees and analysts. The skepticism was expressed Thursday after the Chairman Carl Icahn said he had been negotiating for several weeks with the smaller, non-union airline based in Phoenix and brought the carrier's president, Mike Conway, to a meeting of pilot and machinist union representatives this week.

A flickering TV screen soon may be competing for attention with the trashy tabloids and candy bars in the supermarket checkout line. Cable television giant Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and ActMedia, a marketing firm specializing in promotions in the store, said Thursday they plan to design a new TV program service aimed at shoppers in the checkout aisle. The so-called Checkout Channel will feature news, sports and other specially-tailored programming _ plus advertising _ on TV monitors placed above each checkout aisle.

President Bush endorsed William Taylor, a low-key Federal Reserve veteran, to take over what many consider the toughest financial job in government _ boss of the savings and loan bailout. Bush told a news conference Thursday he is ``very high on'' Taylor, director of bank supervision for the Federal Reserve Board, to replace L. William Seidman as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp.

BMW, the West German maker of luxury cars, is entering an aircraft engine joint venture with Britain's Rolls-Royce PLC, returning to a business BMW left 31 years ago. Bayerische Motoren Werke AG said Thursday it would acquire an aerospace technology line of Kloekner-Humboldt-Deutz AG (KHD) and then merge the company into a joint venture with Rolls-Royce.

Stock prices rang up a moderate gain Thursday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 6.53 to 2,696.17. Bond prices finished higher. The dollar was mixed against major foreign currencies. Oil futures prices fell sharply; grain and soybean futures settled mostly lower; copper futures fell; precious metals advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Key Court Ruling Could Hamper Fraud Enforcement
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court decision striking down a key insider trading rule deals a sharp blow to enforcement of Wall Street's crime of the 1980s, lawyers say. The ruling by the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New York also renewed calls for Congress to pass a law precisely defining insider trading, which refers to the use of information not publicly available to buy and sell securities. ``This should put a little bit of fear into people who want to see a very strong enforcement program,'' Harvey L. Pitt, a top securities lawyer who helped draft failed 1987 insider trading legislation, said Thursday. ``It demonstrates again why the (Securities and Exchange Commission) would be better off if they had a definition of insider trading that was blessed by the Congress,'' said Pitt, who represented Ivan Boesky, the speculator who settled insider trading charges in 1987. The appeals court Wednesday overturned the conviction of former stockbroker Robert Chestman, found guilty of insider trading using fourth-hand information about the pending takeover of a supermarket chain in 1986. In a 3-0 decision, the court ruled there was no proof Chestman knew that information about the takeover of Waldbaum Inc., which trickled down to him through a family chain, was confidential. Also, the panel by a 2-1 vote slammed the door on a key Securities Exchange Act provision that makes any trading using confidential information a crime, even if the trader isn't violating a fiduciary responsibility to the company involved. That provision _ known as Rule 14e-3 _ was adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1980 to broaden its attack on insider trading. The government has relied on fraud rules and case law to prosecute insider trading, which became a household term during the boom years last decade via fraud rings run by figures such as Boesky and investment banker Martin Siegel. ``I think it's a very substantial blow to both the Justice Department and the SEC's enforcement efforts if the decision stands,'' said Robert L. Plotz, a former assistant U.S. attorney who prosecuted the Chestman case, now in private practice. SEC Enforement Director William McLucas declined to comment on the decision's impact, saying the commission was disappointed but still reviewing the case. The government could ask for a full appeals court review or appeal to the Supreme Court. Lawyers said the decision erodes some power investigators had gained over insider trading. They said without a statutory definition, the government was leaving the door open to future cases that will chip away at its authority. ``They ought to define it as a matter of criminal law,'' said Don Buchwald, who defended former Wall Street Journal reporter R. Foster Winans in a 1985 insider trading case. ``Fairness requires you have a definition, especially if you're going to put people in jail.'' But Congress repeatedly has resisted efforts to define insider trading on the theory that pinpointing illegal behavior would leave loopholes for abuse. A lack of consensus about a law also has been cited. Chestman was convicted by a jury on 31 counts of fraud last year and spent about 10 months in federal prison before his release Wednesday. Two congressional aides to committees that oversee the SEC said it was too soon to tell whether the Chestman case would resurrect a movement to define insider trading. The most recent attempt was in 1988, when Congress stiffened insider trading penalties. The appeals court nullified Rule 14e-3, which allowed prosecutors broad leeway to chase insider trading in a corporate takeovers, a situation that often caused a target company's stock price to jump. The rule was designed to attack wrongdoing that didn't necessarily involve a company directly. Other SEC rules already made clear that individuals with responsibilities to a company, including employees, management, directors, lawyers and other advisers, could not trade on market-sensitive information about it. Columbia University law professor John C. Coffee Jr. said that under the added rule it was ``enough to show that the individual had reason to believe the information came from a source either within the bidder or the target.'' The rule was used in key Wall Street civil and criminal fraud cases, including the original case against former junk bond financier Michael Milken, though not in his plea bargain admitting securities and tax fraud last month. Besides the Rule 14e-3 question, the appeals court ruled that Chestman heard no more than ``family gossip'' when the husband of the daughter of the sister of Waldbaum's family patriarch told him the company would be sold.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Pick Up in April
With BC-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Apparel retailers got a lift during April as the arrival of Easter and spring weather brought consumers back into the stores. Many stores that had a disappointing March fared better last month, according to figures released Thursday by several of the nation's biggest retailers. Woolworth Corp., whose sales had fallen in March compared with a year earlier, had an 18.2 percent sales gain in April at stores open at least a year, and a 21.1 percent increase overall. Results from stores open a year or longer _ known as same- or comparable-store sales _ give a more accurate reading of a retailer's performance. Sears, Roebuck and Co., the nation's largest retailer, reported a 3.1 percent same-store sales increase and 1.6 percent overall gain. Most of Sears' improvement was due to clothing sales, not the company's well-known line of appliances and other durable goods, said Monroe Greenstein, a retail industry analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. Consumers still burdened by high installment debt were again cautious about major expenditures, but they were willing to pick up new clothes. Greenstein said this trend, which has been in place for several years, would continue until later in 1990. Retail sales are closely watched not only as a gauge of the industry's health and that of individual companies, but also as an economic barometer. Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the gross national product. Changes in the calendar _ such as Easter falling on April 9 this year and on March 26 last year _ often have an impact on retail sales and affect year-to-year comparisons by inflating results in some months. However, after accounting for the shift, the industry's results in April were generally favorable, said Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co. Analysts consider March and April sales together in assessing how well a store has performed. Among other retailers announcing April results Thursday: _Wal-Mart Stores Inc. reported a 7 percent increase in same-store sales, while overall results were up 20 percent. _J.C. Penney Co. Inc. had a disappointing month after a much stronger March. Penney's same-store sales fell 2.8 percent, while overall sales were off 1.7 percent. Greenstein said Penney's sales looked bleaker than they actually were because they were compared against especially strong results in April 1989, when the company ran special sales promotions. _Melville Corp., which runs specialty chains including Thom McAn, Kay-bee and CVS, said its overall sales rose 21.9 percent. Melville did not release same-store figures. Other major retailers, including Dayton Hudson Corp. and May Department Stores Co., are expected to release their sales figures next Thursday. Analysts said it appeared these companies _ which own some of the country's biggest department store chains _ would report favorable results. K mart Corp., the nation's biggest discount chain, and Limited Inc., the largest specialty apparel retailer, also are expected to announce results next week. The figures released Thursday differ from the federal government's monthly retail sales report. Besides stores, the government's figures include sales at a range of establishments from auto dealerships and supermarkets to restaurants and movie theaters.

DOC.HEAD: Avon Shareholders Urge Company to Put Poison Pill Defense to Vote
DOC.TEXT: Cosmetics giant Avon Products Inc. is under pressure from its shareholders to either drop a key takeover defense or put it to a vote. Shareholders approved two non-binding proposals Thursday at their annual meeting relating to the company's share rights plans, commonly known as poison pills, that can make unsolicited buyout bids prohibitively expensive. The company has been in turmoil for more than a year as it found buyers for its health care business and a fragrance company while improving the profitability of the direct selling business on which it was founded. It struck a deal with a large investor group that resulted in putting two of the group's representatives on its board and the formation of a committee to explore the company's alternatives, which include more asset sales, a recapitalization or outright sale of the company. Avon management opposed both shareholder proposals on its share rights plans, and favors keeping the company independent while pursuing its own plan for sales and earnings growth by focusing on direct selling. One proposal urged the company to either drop the rights plan or submit it to a shareholder vote. The second urged a vote on the plan. Both passed with nearly 25.4 million shares in favor, more than 16.7 million opposed and more than 16.7 million abstaining. The United Shareholders Association, a Washington, D.C.-based advocacy group, said it was behind one of the proposals. ``Avon's management would be foolish not to implement proposals that so clearly expressed the will of the shareholders,'' said association director Ralph Whitworth. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Avon fell 75 cents a share to $36.37{. The shareholders also elected four directors to the Avon board, including two nominees representing the investor group Chartwell Associates LP. Chartwell owns 12 percent of Avon's voting stock and had planned to run a slate of candidates for the four open seats on the 11-member board. But under a settlement reached in late March, Avon agreed to support two Chartwell nominees along with two incumbent directors for the four seats that were up for election. Those nominees were elected Thursday. In addition, Avon agreed to set up a committee to consider ways of boosting value for Avon stockholders. The committee will include four Avon directors and executives and the two new board members from Chartwell, M. Anthony Fisher and Marc Leland. The settlement also called for the appointment of John P. Rochon, a principal in the Chartwell group, as an Avon advisor once he resigns as vice chairman of Mary Kay Cosmetics, Avon's Dallas-based rival. James E. Preston, chairman and chief executive of Avon, said negotiations are continuing on how much Rochon will be paid and said there was ``no financial settlement at all'' with Chartwell. Preston said he did not feel Avon had ``a hostile relationship'' with Chartwell, which also includes members of the Fisher real estate family of New York and Gordon P. Getty, the oil heir. Avon recently voted to lower the threshold of its rights plan to make one element of it effective when an outsider buys 12.5 percent of its stock rather than the previous 20 percent. The action came after Chartwell disclosed it had raised its voting stake in Avon to 12 percent from 7.5 percent. Chartwell won a court order against the Avon board on the threshold increase. Avon has appealed. Preston told about 400 people gathered for the meeting at the Museum of Natural History that Avon was making progress by focusing on its core business. He said Avon would push ahead with plans to sell its 60 percent interest in Avon Japan by the end of the year. An earlier proposal to sell the stake to Tokyo-based Friends of Freesia Ltd. for $450 million fell through. Asked why Avon was getting out of Japan while other companies were scrambling to get in, Preston said Avon Japan's market niche is in danger of being eroded by bigger companies and would require large investments to defend. ``We are better off selling that business and cashing out today ... and reinvesting in markets where we can grow faster,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Turner, Actmedia Plan Checkout Aisle TV Service
DOC.TEXT: Those supermarket tabloid headlines may have to get even wilder to hold their own against TV in the checkout aisle. Cable giant Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and ActMedia, a marketing firm specializing in promotions in the store, said Thursday they are teaming up to design a TV service for shoppers lined up to bag and pay for their groceries. The Checkout Channel will feature news, sports and other specially-tailored programming _ plus advertising _ on TV monitors placed above each checkout aisle. Turner and ActMedia plans to test the service this summer, launch it nationally in early 1991 and install it in 5,000 supermarkets by mid-1992. Wayne W. LoCurto, chief executive and president of ActMedia, said the service should help advertisers reach 30 million to 40 million people each week while making the wait in the checkout line more enjoyable for shoppers. If the plan works, it would be the latest commercial encroachment into places that formerly were beyond the reach of television advertisers. In recent months, media companies either have introduced or announced plans to develop commercial TV programs designed to reach teens in the classroom, women at the beauty salon and patients in the doctor's waiting room. ``There will be a few people to complain, but we believe the overwhelming majority of people will like it,'' LoCurto said in a telephone interview. ``It's informative, entertaining and it's going to make their wait seem to go quicker,'' he said. Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting has agreed to create specially-tailored programs of news, sports, business, weather and consumer information taken mainly from its Headline News cable network. Each eight-minute program will include 2{ minutes of commercials. The programs will be delivered by satellite 24 hours a day to participating stores which will be equipped with TV monitors above each checkout aisle. ActMedia plans to provide the TV sets and the satellite hardware. LoCurto said the sets will be designed so that the sound shuts off unless someone approaches within a half-dozen feet or so of the monitor. But once someone gets that close, there will be no way to shut the set off or adjust the volume, he said. He said the programs are being broken into eight-minute shows, roughly the same amount of time as the average wait in a checkout line. Turner and ActMedia plan to test the system from August through October in 12 stores in six cities, although they would not name the cities. LoCurto said plans are to begin a national service in the first quarter of 1991 and said he hopes to have the Checkout Channel in 5,000 of the nation's 30,000 supermarkets by mid-1992. LoCurto declined to give the cost of launching the system or the relative investments of Turner and ActMedia in the venture. ActMedia expects to generate about $100 million a year in revenue from the the two minutes of advertising time it sells on each eight-minute program, while Turner will get to keep proceeds from the ads in the remaining half-minute. LoCurto said Actmedia will share some of its revenue with supermarkets. Advertisers will be asked to pay rates roughly equivalent to those charged on daytime television. Ad time will be sold for terms of a year or more with an annual rate of about $12 million for a 15-second ad in each show once the system is in 5,000 stores. ActMedia, based in Darien, Conn., and a unit of Heritage Media Corp. of Dallas, Texas, was founded in 1973 and is the leader in in-store marketing programs. It operates couponing and sampling programs and places advertising on shopping carts, aisle directories and store shelves in 20,000 supermarkets.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Sales Edge Up Despite Chrysler Drop
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Mild revivals by General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. and strong gains by Japanese ``transplants'' helped boost sales of North American-made vehicles by 2.8 percent in late April despite a sharp drop at Chrysler Corp. Overall, North American-made cars and trucks sold at an average rate of 47,684 during the period, up 2.8 percent. The average rate for Big Three vehicles was 41,543, up just 0.1 percent from the same period of 1989. GM's total vehicle sales were up 5.2 percent in the April 21-30 period and Ford's gained 7.8 percent, but Chrysler reported a 25.4 percent decline. The nation's No. 3 automaker said car sales dropped 33.8 percent in the period and light truck sales were down 16.5 percent. ``Industry sales are still at a fragile pace,'' said Scott Merlis, auto industry analyst at Morgan Stanley & Co. in New York. Sales of the transplants, vehicles made a Japanese-owned factories in the United States, rose 16.5 percent for the period to a combined average sales rate of 5,135 a day. For the year through the end of April, transplant sales were up a sharp 39.4 percent. The latest figures may show the beginning of a rally for the world's No. 1 automaker, said analyst Jack Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. in New York. ``I have a feeling that GM's market share may have effectively bottomed out.'' And Kirnan said Ford may report stronger increases as its new Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer compacts, still scarce on dealers' lots, become easier for customers to find. He blamed much of Chrysler's plunge on the company's move to de-emphasize fleet sales, which he pointed out will hurt sales numbers but could help the company's bottom line. Chairman Lee Iacocca has said Chrysler would cut down on business with company, rental and other fleets. Though the high volume, low profit margin business helps sales figures, it adds little to earnings. For the year to date, Big Three car and truck sales ran 6.1 percent behind last year, with car sales lagging 8.6 percent and truck sales down 2.3 percent. That left total domestic car and light truck sales down 3.2 percent for the year. Sales of imported cars and trucks were down 10.7 percent for April and down 5.8 percent for the year, in part reflecting the substitution by Japanese car companies of domestically made vehicles. GM said its late-April car sales picked up by 4.1 percent from last year and truck sales gained 7.6 percent. GM car sales since January were down 4.8 percent, while truck sales for the year were up 2.8 percent. Ford said late-April car sales edged up 1.6 percent while truck sales gained 17.3 percent. For the year, Ford said car sales were still off last year's pace by 10.3 percent and truck sales trailed 2.6 percent. Chrysler said its year-to-date car sales were 18.6 percent behind last year's and truck sales lagged 6.2 percent.
