DOC.HEAD: Auto Cos. Coming Out of Own Recession?
DOC.TEXT: Higher-than-expected first quarter earnings for the Big Three automakers may mean they are coming out of a severe recession, analysts say. Earnings reported Thursday by General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co., combined with those released Tuesday by Chrysler Corp., were down 64 percent compared with the same three months of last year. The decline fell short of Wall Street analysts predictions of a cumulative drop of more than 75 percent. ``It's almost like the auto industry was going through its own inventory recession in the first quarter, and in a sense it's coming out of its own, self-created recession in the second quarter,'' analyst David Healy of Barclays-BZW of New York said. Analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan, Stanley & Co. said signs of recovery, although welcome, were relative. ``When you go from a depression to a recession it's a nice improvement,'' he said. Each of the Big Three laid part of the blame for lower profits on severe production cuts they instituted in January to help reduce inventories which had built to a high, 90-selling-day level at the end of last year. The production reduction, coupled with increased incentives, knocked inventories down to the 65-day range, considered good for this time of year. But the two-pronged attack, combined with economic and labor problems overseas, ate into profits. Ford's overseas earnings were hammered by strikes in Europe and economic problems in Brazil. ``I think we are going to see a material drag on Ford's earnings from Brazil in the second quarter largely because there has been no production there since the 15th of March,'' analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. said. On that day, Ford shut down its Autolatina plant after the government froze most savings in an attempt halt inflation that was running at an annual rate of more than 4,000 percent. The plant is back in operation, but it will take time for it to gear up production to pre-shutdown levels. GM, which declined to detail regional operations, said it set record overseas profits but also had been hurt in Brazil, although to a smaller extent than Ford. GM spokesman Terry Sullivan said the effects of Brazil's economic problems may show up later for GM. Chrysler has few overseas operations. The Big Three said they earned $1.29 billion in the quarter, down from $3.54 billion from the year-ago period. Combined revenues fell 11 percent to $61.27 billion. GM said it earned $710 million, or $1.02 per share of common stock, on revenues of $30.11 billion, compared with $1.55 billion, or $2.37 a share, on revenues of $33.24 billion in the year-ago period. Ford said it made $506.2 million, or $1.10 a share, compared with $1.64 billion, or $3.44 a share, a year ago. Revenues fell 9 percent to $23.6 billion from $25.87 billion. Earlier in the week, Chrysler reported earnings of $71 million, down 80 percent from the year-ago period. Through the first quarter of this year, Big Three car and truck sales were 3.6 percent behind last year's pace. Figures for January through April released Thursday showed sales of Big Three North American-made vehicles slid to 6.1 percent behind last year's pace. The companies also said increased incentive costs during the quarter chewed up profits.

DOC.HEAD: Production-cutting Agreement Meets Skepticism in Market
DOC.TEXT: An agreement by OPEC members to jointly curb overproduction won't provide a quick fix for the oil market, where prices continue to sag, analysts say. In fact, the market's initial reaction to the accord reached Thursday was to push prices decisively lower in fairly heavy trading. ``The market may have been looking for more than OPEC was willing to give,'' said Peter Beutel, an energy analyst for Elders Futures Inc. in New York. ``It came out looking like another of these vaguely unsatisfying agreements.'' The cartel's 13 members came out of a two-day emergency session with an accord to cut total output by 1.455 million barrels a day for the next three months. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries hope the cutback will help prices recover to the group's minimum reference price of $18 a barrel, set in November. North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, fell to $15.90 a barrel in London late Thursday after OPEC's anouncement. That was down 55 cents from late Wednesday. The markets' shaky confidence that OPEC would actually deliver the promised cut was undermined ``in one fell swoop'' by a comment from the United Arab Emirates oil minister, said Peter Gignoux, manager of the international energy desk at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in London. ``Selling then begets selling,'' Gignoux said of the market's reaction. The UAE minister, Mana Saeed Otaiba, said on leaving the meeting that his country would cut its oil production to 1.9 million barrels a day from 2.1 million barrels. The statement caused industry analysts to doubt the Persian Gulf country's commitment to lowering output because they estimate the UAE's actual production already is at 1.9 million barrels. At best, analysts predicted the cartel will muster a total reduction of 1 million barrels. Overproduction by the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait has caused a worldwide oil glut just as demand traditionally eases in the second quarter, analysts say. Since about mid-March, the price of West Texas Intermediate crude oil has seesawed above $20 a barrel, back down to nearly $16, up again to almost $19.50 and then back down again to $18. The June contract for WTI, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, fell 69 cents Thursday to settle at $17.99 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Although recent oil price movements have been ``violent,'' Gignoux said, ``We're not talking disaster and I don't think anybody in the marketplace feels we are heading for an '85, '86 situation.'' He was referring to the price collapse a few years ago that sent prices plunging to below $10 a barrel. ``This is simply an indication of second quarter weakness and oversupply,'' Gignoux said. Analysts say increased demand and a slowdown in production from the North Sea and Alaska should boost prices later in the year. ``I think we have to wait for winter restocking and winter demand to turn things around,'' said Geoff Pyne, an analyst with UBS Phillips and Drew in London. OPEC President Sadek Boussena said OPEC's quota violators were to contribute most of the cutback by returning to their official output ceilings. All members will participate in the reduction, though, he added. OPEC pumped 23.5 million barrels a day in April, Boussena said, well above the cartel's official ceiling of 22.1 million barrels for the first half of the year. The cartel postponed its regular midyear session for a month to July 25, when it will rethink its output and pricing policy for the remainder of 1990.

DOC.HEAD: America West Says No Deal Made With TWA
DOC.TEXT: America West Airlines says it has made no deal to take over some of the domestic business of TWA, but industry analysts say the young, lean carrier might have what it takes to make such a deal work. TWA Chairman Carl Icahn said this week that the smaller company might be just the cure his loss-making domestic airline operation needs. America West, which is non-union, may make profits where he cannot, Icahn said. The company, which was founded in 1983, has a reputation for low costs, on-time service, clean planes and a very aggressive business stance. America West Chairman Edward R. Beauvais and President Michael J. Conway said in a joint statement Thursday that there have been talks but no deals have been struck. ``It is well known that there are airlines in the United States that are considering the disposal of various assets, and we have been contacted to determine our level of interest,'' the statement said. ``As a matter of policy,'' it continued, ``we do not respond to speculation regarding potential transactions. Accordingly, we will not comment further on these or any other possible transactions until such time as there is relevant and concrete information to announce.'' Paul H. Nisbet, senior airline analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York, said America West had ``a very low-cost structure.'' He added, ``It may be able to capitalize on a motivated work force. It's bust or boom with that kind of an operation, and right now they are booming. They're aggressive as hell.'' Analysts also said the airline had a reputation for clean, new planes and customer service. America West ranks first in federal on-time performance tests. Icahn and officials of the TWA pilots' and machinists' unions met Tuesday with officers of America West at the Icahn & Co. headquarters in Mount Kisco, N.Y. At the meeting, Icahn said he would not need cash from the smaller airline. Instead, America West would simply take over his domestic operations, leaving him with TWA's international routes, which he considers much more valuable. America West has 12,000 employees and 92 planes. With gross revenue of $993.4 million last year, it was designated as a ``major'' airline. It has hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas, Nev. Nisbet said the airline was pushing hard for expansion into the Pacific Rim, narrowly losing a recent bid on a Hawaii-to-Tokyo route. It also bid on the Eastern Airlines shuttle between Boston, New York and Washington, which was sold to developer Donald Trump last year, and expressed interest in the shuttle again last week after Trump suggested he might sell it. ``So they are looking in every direction,'' he said. But, Nisbet cautioned, the company is highly leveraged, carrying a proportionately high level of debt. That means substantial cash investments could be difficult, he said. Still, Nisbet said America West could restore profitability to TWA's domestic operations. ``They are, I think, very well-managed. And they have a very smooth labor-management situation, something that Carl Icahn hasn't found out how to achieve,'' Nisbet said. News of the possible takeover by a non-union airline did nothing to improve those labor relations. Kent Scott, leader of the TWA pilots union, said his requests for financial details have gone unanswered. ``From what I see, the proposal doesn't make any sense,'' he said. He dismissed the negotiations as a ``pressure tactic.'' TWA lost $300 million last year and had to pay $366 million in interest on debts of $2.5 billion. Icahn has asked the pilots for wage concessions of 10 percent. He has promised to buy up to 100 new jets in return for the concessions. The alternative, Icahn said, is to ``shrink'' the airline through deals like one with America West.

DOC.HEAD: Conservation Steps in Senate Farm Bill Applauded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists are praising the Senate Agriculture Committee for toughening conservation efforts on farms through the 1990 farm bill. ``It's a major step forward,'' Ken Cook of the Center for Resource Economics said Thursday after the committee finished work on the conservation section of legislation that will set agriculture policy for the next five years. ``We're very pleased with the way the committee has responded to environmental concerns,'' said Cook, who lobbied for tougher standards. Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said the bill is good for both the environment and farmers. ``This new title significantly strengthens the conservation provisions of current law,'' he said. Leahy said the 1985 farm bill ``signaled a new attitude in Congress about the important role our farmers play in preserving the environment. They also set the standard by which the 1990 farm bill will be judged.'' Most of the provisions were approved Wednesday, but one of the stickiest _ the section on wetlands _ was passed out of committee Thursday. It actually eases up on farmers in some ways. Current law strips a farmer of his or her federal subsidies if wetlands are drained and planted with crops. If the new measure becomes law, violators would be fined $750 to $10,000 and required to restore the wetland. The farmer would be removed from federal crop programs after a second offense. The farmer would have his record expunged after 10 years and return to first-time violator status if wetlands are drained again. Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., voted against the wetlands measure because he felt farmers sometimes make innocent mistakes and the potential for abuse by regulators under the legislation was too high. The new measure also allows drainage of land that has been extensively farmed, but still has wetland characteristics, if the drainage would have minimal effect on wetland values. Most of the time, a farmer would have to restore another piece of property to prevent net wetland loss. A provision that toughens current wetland policy outlaws the draining of land if the intention is to make it available for planting at some time. Under the law enacted in 1985, a farmer has to actually plant on the drained land to be a violator. Enforcement of federal wetland policy is conducted by the Soil Conservation Service and the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service. Fish and Wildlife Service agents make reports when they see lands in use that are supposed to remain in a wet condition. Wetlands are important not only as habitats for wildlife, but as natural filters for pollutants. Only about half the country's original wetlands still exist and the government is fighting to save them. Conservation measures adopted by the committee Wednesday included: _Enrollment of at least 40 million acres by 1995 in a program that pays farmers not to plant, in order to protect highly erodible land, marginal pasturelands, windbreaks and vegetation planted for wildlife. _Payments to farmers who enroll in a new program to reduce water contamination by cutting back on fertilizers and chemicals that cause pollution. _Technical assistance from the Agriculture Department to help farmers meet state and federal environmental standards. _Purchase of wetlands from farmers. _Requirements that farmers keep records of pesticides they use. _Assistance to states that want to protect farms from being converted to other uses. The chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, introduced conservation legislation Thursday with many provisions similar to the Senate bill. Hearings on it will be held later.

DOC.HEAD: New Program Raises Concerns About Hidden Ads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Advertisers think a new program, ``Video Power,'' will keep kids glued to their television sets. A TV watchdog group thinks the show may be bending the law. Although ``Video Power'' is not on the air yet, Action for Children's Television, the Boston-based advocacy group, complained about the show to the Federal Communications Commission on Thursday. ACT's filing with the FCC was prompted by a report in Monday's Wall Street Journal that commercials would be inserted into ``Video Power'' so seamlessly that young viewers wouldn't be able to tell where the ads begin and the program leaves off. The Journal said the half-hour syndicated show, planned to air weekdays after school next fall, would be hosted by a 14-year-old named ``Johnny Arcade.'' Johnny, the Journal said, ``will rattle off `news' items, such as countdowns of top hits in video games. Sandwiched in the minute-long countdowns will be 10-second or 20-second commercials, without so much as a pause between the news and the commercial.'' ACT thinks the show as described violates FCC rules that require TV producers to clearly distinguish advertising in kids' shows and that prohibit a show's host from peddling products. ``We are requesting a public notice (from the FCC) to investigate the trend in children's TV which blatantly ignores existing FCC policy,'' ACT attorney Donna Lampert said in an interview. The show also will include interviews with video-game champions and will feature cartoons with characters from current video games. Some of those characters are based on video games from Acclaim Entertainment Inc., which is buying 20 percent of the show's commercial time, the Journal said. ``We're ecstatic about the format,'' Acclaim executive Anthony Williams told the newspaper. ``Children change channels during commercials. For one thing, their concentration span is shorter than that of adults. ... This, we think, is a good way for both producer and advertiser to sidestep that problem.'' Attempts to locate Acclaim Entertainment or the producers of ``Video Power'' were not successful Thursday. The FCC in 1984 lifted rules that limited the amount of advertising that may be shown during children's shows. At the same time, however, the commission reaffirmed its 1974 rules on host selling and ad-program separation in children's shows. In its 1974 ruling, the commission said ``young children lack the necessary sophistication to appreciate the nature and purpose of advertising.'' Efforts are under way in Congress to restore ad limits on kids' shows: 10{ minutes per hour on weekends and 12 minutes per hour on weekdays. The Journal also said corporations increasingly are promoting their products in movies or home videos. McDonald's Corp. has sold about 250,000 copies of a 30-minute ``McTreasure Island'' video in which Ronald McDonald and pals step into the Robert Lewis Stevenson classic, ``Treasure Island,'' to help save Jim Hawkins from Long John Silver and aid in finding the treasure, the newspaper said. Motion picture companies also reap substantial fees for using advertisers' products in their movies. The FCC does not regulate videos or movies.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Emerges as Big U.S. Chicken Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has emerged as a stunning new market for broilers and may edge out Japan this year as the traditional No. 1 foreign market for U.S. poultry, according to Agriculture Department analysts. More than 110 million pounds of broiler leg quarters were sold to the Soviet Union recently by U.S. companies, a sale worth an estimated $50 million. The Soviets began buying U.S. broilers last fall for the first time in years. According to the department's Economic Research Service, the 1989 sales involved about 26 million pounds. USDA economist Larry Witucki said in a telephone interview Thursday that Moscow has bought around 260 million pounds of U.S. broilers so far in calendar 1990. Those could have a value in the range of $100 million to $150 million. ``I would say (the Soviets) are going to surpass the Japanese this year,'' Witucki said. ``The Japanese market is growing, but not that fast.'' The Soviet Union has been buying U.S. grain for years and is apparently is committed to remain a major buyer for the long haul. Can broiler producers expect similar demand from chicken-hungry Kremlin leaders? Witucki said the Soviet broiler market is characterized by large potential and large uncertainty. It's hard to tell at the moment what may happen, he said. Japan topped the list of U.S. broiler markets overseas at 233 million pounds in calendar 1989, which Witucki said was a downward revision from 339.9 million pounds initially reported by U.S. Customs. The Soviets already have passed that mark for 1990. Witucki said 1989 U.S. Customs figures for broiler exports to Hong Kong, currently shown at 206.6 million pounds, are under review for possible errors. Other big foreign markets include Mexico, Canada, Singapore, Jamaica, Spain and French Polynesia. Overall, subject to revision, the USDA figures published in a current outlook report show broiler exports rose to a record value of about $441 million in 1989, up 15 percent from 1988. ``Another broiler export record is expected in 1990 because sales to Japan and other Pacific Rim markets will likely remain strong,'' said the report, which was written prior to the recent new sale to the Soviets. It added, ``Although exports could decline to Mexico and Canada, where production is expected to increase, the U.S.S.R. and some Eastern European countries will become a major new market.'' In a related report, the department's Foreign Agricultural Service says the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe represent ``substantial market opportunities'' for U.S. meat and poultry exporters. If goals for meat consumption are to be met, domestic and imported supplies will have to increase. A main thrust will be in rising demand for improved livestock breeding and technology. The report said average Soviet citizens spend 50 percent to 60 percent of their take-home salary of 200 rubles per month ($330) for food. ``Even so, strong demand for meat products persists,'' the report said. ``During the opening of the first McDonald's food franchise restaurant in the U.S.S.R., hundreds of Muscovites line up to pay three rubles and 75 kopecks _ about one-third of a day's wage _ to purchase a Big Mac.'' Meat consumption in the Soviet Union includes about 44 percent beef, 34 percent pork, 5 percent sheep, lamb and other meat, and 17 percent poultry, the report said.

Thailand is one of the few developing countries with a substantial food surplus, says an Agriculture Department report. And that is important to U.S. farmers. In the last 20 years, the Southeast Asian country of 56 million people has established itself as a strong competitor in world feed grain markets, the report said. Recent years have shown Thailand to be the world's largest rice exporter, the fifth-largest corn exporter and an important exporter of sorghum, all commodities that rank highly as U.S. exports. But Thailand also is boosting livestock output, according to the report by Sara J. Schwartz and Douglas H. Brooks of the department's Economic Research Service. Looking ahead to the turn of the century, that raises some possibilities. Under a ``moderate growth'' scenario developed for the study, Thailand's rice and poultry meat exports ``may increase substantially'' by the year 2000. Other livestock also are likely to increase. Thus, according to the report, Thailand's corn exports could decline significantly over the next decade as more feed is needed for livestock. ``Expectations of Thailand's falling corn exports and rapidly rising imports of oilseed meal (for high-protein animal feed) can create important market opportunities for U.S. corn and soybean meal exporters,'' the report said. ``However, the United States may face increasing competition in world rice and poultry meat markets.'' The projections showed Thailand's poultry meat production could more than double by 2000 as domestic and export demands increase. Pork production also could more than double ``if incomes continue to rise and marketing constraints are relaxed,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Investigating Genentech Stock Deal
DOC.TEXT: Genentech Inc., a biotechnology firm under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the probe won't affect its plans to merge with Swiss drug giant Roche Holding Ltd. But the deal, which shareholders will vote on next month, could be delayed by the Federal Trade Commission, which has requested more information. Genentech spokesman Jack Murphy said Thursday neither Genentech nor Roche has finished filing all the documents sought by the FTC. The SEC is investigating unusual trading activity in Genentech's stock on the Pacific Stock Exchange just before the disclosure of Roche's plan to buy 60 percent of Genentech shares in a $2.1 billion deal. Investigators are focusing on ``certain communications'' between Mollie Raab, wife of Genentech Chief Executive Kirk Raab, and an unnamed member of her family. Genentech said Raab had told his wife about the merger plans, which were announced on February 2. Although Mollie Raab is a subject of the SEC investigation, Genentech said that she did not purchase any securities herself. Genentech said Raab and his wife ``have cooperated fully with the SEC'' and that neither would comment on the situation because the inquiry was still open. The SEC probe was disclosed in a filing by Genentech of a proxy statement describing the proposed merger with Roche. In a move related to the merger, Genentech granted its six top officers lucrative ``golden parachute'' agreements under which they would receive an amount five times their salaries should they be terminated as a result of the merger, the Wall Street Journal reported in today's editiosn. Under the plan, Kirk Raab stands to receive about $6.6 million as well as stock options valued at $7.9 million should he lose his job in the deal, the paper said.

DOC.HEAD: State to Audit Trump; Taj Mahal To Audit Contractors
DOC.TEXT: State gaming regulators announced a routine audit of Donald Trump's financial empire while the tycoon's newest casino hired an independent auditor to examine bills of contractors angry about not getting paid. New Jersey Gaming Enforcement Director Anthony Parrillo said Thursday that such a review by his agency is ``normal,'' and that it hasn't looked at Trump's operations for a long time. ``This isn't to sound or signal that there are problems,'' he said. The review will include all the billionaire develper's holdings in and outside of Atlantic City, he said. About 100 contractors involved in the $1 billion Taj Mahal Casino Resort have gone to the state Casino Control Commission in an effort to get paid. The contractors, who claim Trump owes them $35 million, are angry because they pushed to meet the casino's April 2 opening date based on promises they would be paid in full. Some also charged that Trump has withheld payment he faces a cash-flow problem. The audit, announced Thursday, will examine labor costs, time and material payment requests, change orders and expense reimbursements. Ed Tracy, president and chief executive officer of Trump's three Atlantic City casinos, said the contractors are wrong, adding that their complaints come ``at a time when everybody is taking a shot at Donald Trump.'' Trump said last week he was considering selling some of his holdings, including Manhattan real estate and the Trump Shuttle airline, to raise cash. Tracy said withholding payment until completion of the audit is a common practice in the construction business. ``There's nothing unusual about this except the size of the project,'' Tracy said.

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Suburbs Lead, South Texas Trails List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf, Following the, to make it ``West Palm Beach-Boca Raton-Delray Beach, Fla., $22,824,'' sted ``both $22,824'' since Newark income is mentioned in previous graf.
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the Connecticut suburbs of New York City had a per capita personal income in 1988 nearly four times higher than those of a South Texas metropolitan area at the bottom of a new government list. The Bridgeport-Stamford-Norwalk-Danbury, Conn., area retained its top ranking with per capita personal income of $29,084, compared with $7,302 for the McAllen-Edinburg-Mission, Texas, area, the Commerce Department said Thursday. The Connecticut suburbs, with per capita income of $26,316, also were at the top of the 1987 list of 319 metropolitan areas surveyed by the department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. McAllen-Edinburg-Mission was last in 1987, too, at $7,001. For the nation as a whole, per capita income in 1988 was $16,490, up from $15,484 a year earlier. Per capita personal income is the annual total personal income of residents divided by the area population. New York City was the richest metropolitan area in terms of total personal income with $174.74 billion in 1988, the study found. Enid, Okla., was at the other end with a total personal income of $873 million. The total personal income in the United States in 1988 was $4.05 trillion. ``Nine of the 10 metropolitan areas with the highest per capita personal income in 1988 also ranked highest in 1983,'' the report noted. Newark, N.J., which ranked 12th in 1983, rose to ninth in 1988 with per capita personal income of $22,963. Anchorage, Alaska, dropped from first to 17th with per capita income of $21,840. Following the Connecticut suburbs of New York City were San Francisco, $26,309; Bergen-Passaic, N.J., $25,388; Middlesex-Somerset-Hunterdon, N.J., $25,140; Lake County, Ill., $24,009; Nassau-Suffolk, N.Y., $23,832; San Jose, Calif., $23,181; Washington, D.C.-Md.-Va., $23,175; and Newark, N.J., and West Palm Beach-Boca Raton-Delray Beach, Fla., $22,824. ``Eight of the 10 metropolitan areas with the lowest per capita personal income in 1988 also ranked lowest in 1983,'' the report said. Joining the South Texas area at the bottom of the list were Laredo, Texas, $7,452; Brownsville-Harlingen, Texas, $7,868; Las Cruces, N.M., $9,791; Provo-Orem, Utah, $9,993; El Paso, Texas, $10,008; Pascagoula, Miss., $10,892; Jacksonville, N.C., $11,262; Houma-Thibodaux, La., $11,264; and Lawton, Okla., $11,420. Anniston, Ala., moved up from 311 to 306 with income of $11,679 and was replaced by Houma-Thibodaux among the bottom 10; the Clarksville-Hopkinsville, Tenn.-Ky., area went from 312 to 305 with income of $11,796 and was succeeded by Jacksonville, N.C. Following New York at the top of the total personal income list were Los Angeles-Long Beach, Calif., $161.37 billion; Chicago, $118.48 billion; Philadelphia, Pa.-N.J., $91.05 billion; Washington, D.C.-Md.-Va., $86.54 billion; Boston-Lawrence-Salem-Lowell-Brockton, Mass., $83.11 billion; Detroit, $80.75 billion; Nassau-Suffolk, N.Y., $63.16 billion; Houston, $52.58 billion; and Anaheim-Santa Ana, Calif., $51.35 billion. Nine of the 10 metropolitan areas with the fastest growth in total personal income from 1983 to 1988 also were on the East Coast, five of them in Florida, the report said. Naples, Fla., led this list with total personal income of $2.99 billion, up 87 percent during the five years compared with the national average growth of 43 percent. Naples was followed by Fort Myers-Cape Coral, Fla., with $5.22 billion, up 75 percent; Portsmouth-Dover-Rochester, N.H., $6.45 billion, up 74.4 percent; Riverside-San Bernardino, Calif., $35.66 billion, up 71.7 percent; West Palm Beach-Boca Raton-Delray Beach, Calif., $18.68 billion, up 70.8 percent. Also, Orlando, Fla., $16.05 billion, up 69.6 percent; Ocala, Fla., $2.28 billion, up 69.4 percent; Manchester-Nashua, N.H., $6.98 billion, up 69.3 billion; Atlanta, $50.35 billion, up 68.7 percent, and Raleigh-Durham, N.C., $12.08 billion, up 68.3 percent.

Stock prices rose today as traders reacted to a big surprise in the government's latest report on employment. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 6.53 to 2,702.70 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 547 up, 177 down and 376 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 23.90 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. As the work day began on Wall Street, the Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point in April to 5.4 percent. The figures also showed an increase of 64,000 in nonfarm payroll employment, far less than economists had been expecting. Analysts said the news abruptly dampened recent speculation that the Federal Reserve might be planning to tighten credit in its campaign against inflation. Interest rates fell in the credit markets today. But stock traders did not take the news with unequivocal enthusiasm. Brokers said it raised some fresh doubts about the outlook for economic growth and corporate profits in the months ahead. Among the blue chips, General Motors rose ] to 45{; International Business Machines gained | to 108|; American Express added ] to 26~, and General Electric was up ] at 65[. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .83 to 184.80. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .47 at 345.44. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.53 to 2,696.17, bringing its gain over the past four sessions to 51.12 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 3 on the NYSE, with 902 up, 569 down and 497 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 145.57 million shares, against 141.61 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Stockbrokers Want Government Indemnity for Market Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Stockbrokers want the government to compensate them from the losses they expect to incur as a result of a planned reform of the Brussels stock exchange, officials said Friday. The Association for the Defense of the Stockbroking Profession, which represents about 75 percent of the Brussels exchange's stockbrokers, told the government in a memorandum that minimum capital requirements and other measures would ``inevitably entail the disappearance of a certain number of stock houses.'' In addition to setting minimum capital requirements for brokers, the reforms will open the exchange to banks and other financial institutions, tighten rules on insider trading and give more power to the Belgian Banking Commission, the stock exchange watchdog. ``The state, which has promoted this reform, must indemnify these stockbrokers for the loss of their profession and for the loss of professional revenues they will sustain,'' the memo states. The reforms are part of government's plan to update Belgium's antiquated financial markets to better compete once the European Community melds into a single market in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Cook to Step Down as Publisher, CEO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Tribune Co. chairman and chief executive officer Stanton R. Cook has announced he will leave his posts as publisher of the Chicago Tribune and chief executive of the newspaper's parent company in August. Cook will remain as chairman of the Tribune Co., he told shareholders at the company's annual meeting Thursday. Charles Brumback, president and chief operating officer, will succeed Cook as chief executive of the Tribune Co. John Madigan, president and chief executive of Tribune Co. subsidiary Chicago Tribune Co., will become the Tribune's publisher, Cook said. ``I will turn 65 years old in July, and for years I have felt it would be an appropriate time to step down,'' Cook, a former board member of The Associated Press, said in announcing the decision. ``I am confident in Charlie and John.'' Cook will leave his former positions Aug. 1. Cook, who earned $1.1 million in cash and bonuses last year, began his career with the Tribune in 1951 and was promoted to production manager in 1965. He became president of the newspaper in 1972, and became president and chief executive of the Tribune Co. in 1974. He was elected chairman last year. Brumback began his career with the accounting firm Arthur Young & Co. He rose through the ranks of the Sentinel Star Co., publisher of the Orlando Sentinel, to become president of the Orlando Sentinel in 1976. The Tribune Co. purchased the Florida newspaper in 1965. He became president and CEO of the Chicago Tribune in 1981 and president and chief operating officer of the Tribune Co. last year. Madigan, 52, a Chicago native, joined Tribune Co. in 1975 as vice president and chief financial officer. He was made a director of the company that same year.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 426.39 up 0.95 from the previous day's close.

Stock prices were mixed today as traders reacted to a big surprise in the government's latest report on employment. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 2.03 to 2,694.14 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 694 up, 493 down and 520 unchanged. Analysts said the news abruptly dampened recent speculation that the Federal Reserve might be planning to tighten credit in its campaign against inflation. Interest rates fell in the credit markets today. But stock traders did not take the news with unequivocal enthusiasm. Among the blue chips, General Motors rose ] to 45{; International Business Machines gained { to 108{; American Telephone & Telegraph was unchanged at 40, and DuPont lost [ to 37{. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .26 to 184.23. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .62 at 344.35.

DOC.HEAD: BAT Selling Ivey's to Dillard's
DOC.TEXT: BAT Industries PLC, which is divesting its U.S. retail holdings, said Friday it will sell its Ivey's department store chain to Dillard Department Stores Inc. for $110 million in cash. The sale of Ivey's, the last retail division to be sold by BAT, is expected to be completed in approximately six weeks, the British-American conglomerate said in a statement. Ivey's, founded in 1900, has 23 stores in the Carolinas and Florida. BAT acquired the chain in 1982. Dillard operates 166 department stores in 16 states in the South, Midwest and Southwest. The company indicated it would incorporate the Ivey's chain into its operations, keep the stores open and include all Ivey's employees in its benefit plans, BAT said. The sale of Ivey's is part of a restructuring plan announced by BAT in September to focus the company on its core tobacco and financial services operations. The restructuring was undertaken as a defense against a hostile $22 billion takeover bid from an investor group led by Anglo-French financier James Goldsmith. The group abandoned its bid late last month, but BAT said it would proceed with its plans. BAT has already announced the sale of its Saks Fifth Avenue chain for $1.5 billion to Investcorp, a group that acts on behalf of wealthy Middle Eastern, American, British and other European investors. BAT also has agreed to sell its Marshall Field's department stores in the Midwest to the retailer Dayton Hudson Corp. for $1.04 billion, and its John Breuner Co. furniture stores to Prism Capital Corp., a merchant bank, for $92.5 million in cash.

DOC.HEAD: Norton Profits Down In First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Takeover target Norton Co. said Friday its first- quarter profits fell 35 percent mainly because of losses stemming from its operations in Brazil, which suffered a severe recession during the period. Norton, a leading abrasives and engineering materials manufacturer, said net income totaled it $17.2 million, or 89 cents per share during the quarter, compared with profits of $26.3 million, or $1.25 per share a year earlier. Revenues totaled $414.4 million, up 7 percent from $388.2 million in the first quarter of 1989. Last month Norton agreed to be acquired by France's Compagnie Saint-Gobain, one of the world's leading glass makers, for $1.8 billion or $90 a share. The move successfully staved off a $1.6 billion hostile bid by Britain's BTR PLC. Norton declined to comment on how the successful battle against BTR would affect earnings for the year. ``We're not commenting on the takeover costs,'' company spokesman Francis Doherty said. The company said its Brazilian operations accounted for a 15-cent-a-share loss, compared with contributing 11 cents a share to earnings in the year-ago period. ``Brazil has experienced a severe recession during the first quarter ... due to the acceleration of hyperinflation for the first two months, followed in March by government-imposed deflationary measures,'' said Norton Chairman and Chief Executive John M. Nelson. Still, Nelson said he was pleased with the company's overall results considering the economic deterioration in Brazil. The Brazilian losses dragged down operating profit in the abrasives unit by 48 percent in the quarter, when compared to a particularly strong year-ago period. Operating profit increased more than 7 percent in the engineered materials unit.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Mixed After Strong Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade after opening stronger amid talk of a large sale of U.S. corn to the Soviet Union. There was no confirmation of rumors that the Soviets bought as much as 3 million metric tons of corn overnight. Grain traders have become extra-sensitive to talk of large export sales since the Agriculture Department on Wednesday offered to subsidize sales of 2 million tons of wheat to China. Analysts said prices retreated when the Soviet purchase was not confirmed and amid drenching rains in the Midwestern corn and soybean belt. The rain should be welcomed by farmers, who have had about two weeks of nearly unbroken dry weather in which to begin their spring planting. In early trading, wheat futures prices were unchanged to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.73{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to } cent lower with May at $2.85{ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to { cent higher with May at $1.67 a bushel; soybeans were 3\ cents lower to \ cent higher with May at $6.26{ a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures were lower. Live cattle were .25 cent lower to .12 cent higher with June at 74.42 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .08 cent higher with May at 83.75 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .27 cent lower with June at 63.65 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .03 cent to .42 cent lower with May at 69.25 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled higher on Thursday; pork futures were mixed.

DOC.NOTE: $adv07
For Release Monday May 7
DOC.HEAD: Dow Average Masks Market Woes
DOC.TEXT: It takes more than a rise in the Dow Jones industrial average right now to keep many a stock market investor from feeling low. If you use the Dow average as a gauge, stock prices have been holding their ground of late within about 5 percent of the record high they reached in the first session of 1990. But the picture looks less rosy if you examine it by the light of several other, less publicized statistical measures that take a broader sample of stocks into account. This ``divergence,'' in the parlance of Wall Street, makes for hard times in the trading rooms of money managers at investing institutions, where Mission No. 1 is often to try to beat the prominent market averages. It isn't much of a morale booster either for individual investors, when they see their own stockholdings losing value while the market is supposedly giving a good account of itself. What's more, some chart-watching analysts on the Street contend, divergences are a poor portent for the likely future behavior of the stock market in general. ``The overwhelming majority of equities are moving lower while the major averages are held up by just a few of the big-cap (large capitalization) names,'' says Joseph Feshbach at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``The current condition of the market continues to deteriorate, indicating that lower prices lie ahead.'' At the end of April, the Dow Jones industrials stood at 2,645, not a drastic distance below their peak reading of 2,810 on Jan. 2. Over the last trading week of April, by contrast, 296 issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange hit new lows for the past 52 weeks, compared with just 27 new highs. At the American Stock Exchange, the new lows outnumbered the highs 104 to 17. In the NASDAQ system for over-the-counter stocks, the margin was 416 to 136. ``It's very rare to see a long string of more new lows than new highs with the Dow close to its high,'' observed Stan Weinstein in his investment advisory letter The Professional Tape Reader. ``The few prior times that it's occurred (early September 1987, late June-early July 1981, and early January 1973) all foreshadowed serious market declines.'' Adds Martin Zweig in his Zweig Forecast letter, ``The divergences between the blue-chip Dow and the average stock keep yawning wider, ever increasing the risk.'' To explain why this kind of disparity troubles them so much, many Wall Streeters resort to a military metaphor: When the army of ``soldiers'' isn't enthusiastically keeping in step with the ``generals,'' the battle may well be lost. One historical precedent for just such a defeat occurred in the severe bear market of 1973-74, when the select few ``favorite 50'' growth stocks of that era came toppling down along with their more obscure counterparts. To at least a few resolute optimists, however, the outcome need not be so negative this time. After all, they contend, don't the present figures suggest that stocks are a lot cheaper than they might appear at a superficial glance? In the view of Martin Sass, chairman of the New York money management firm of M.D. Sass Investor Services, the circumstances have set up some potential bargains among small growth stocks and industrial companies considered sensitive to the ups and downs of the business cycle. The poor showing of the cyclical stocks in the past year or so ``was only partly justified by deteriorating fundamentals,'' Sass maintains. Furthermore, he says, ``there is growing evidence that the manufacturing recession has now bottomed out.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Mon May 7

DOC.HEAD: Zipper Ties, Water-Powered Engine Highlight New Product Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: David Cecil offered an irresistible guarantee to anyone walking past his display booth at what's billed as the world's largest convention of inventions. ``You'll never have to tie your tie again,'' he said. To demonstrate his claim, Cecil tugged at a knot in his silk tie as if to loosen it. But instead of one end of the fabric slipping out of the knot, the tie itself zipped open. ``Once you start wearing one, you'll never go back to tying a tie. It's the perfect tie-less tie,'' said Cecil, who represents Zippertie Enterprises, a Pittsburgh company marketing the tie for a Midwestern inventor he declined to identify. Cecil pulled again on his tie, this time on the short end, and the zipper hidden in the knot closed up. ``A perfect double-Windsor knot,'' he said. Cecil and hundreds of other promoters and inventors gathered Thursday at the Monroeville Expo Mart near Pittsburgh for the Invention-New Product Exposition, billed as the world's largest. Among other items displayed were a portable fire escape that can be anchored inside a window, a trap designed to lure fleas off a carpet and a device to repel mosquitoes with sound waves. The start of the three-day exhibition also included the unveiling of a water-powered engine created by Yoshiro Nakamatsu, who became known as the ``Edison of Japan'' after inventing the computer floppy disk and the digital watch. Nakamatsu said his pollution-free engine, called Enerex, runs on tap water alone and can create three times the power of a standard gasoline engine. ``It will generate electricity for any purpose,'' he said. ``Petroleum will exhaust in 100 years.'' He said he will modify the engine and build a special vehicle powered by it. Nakamatsu displayed some of his other inventions, including packages of ``brain food,'' which he said contains ``good elements'' to encourage clear thinking. The snack food, which tastes something like seaweed, is sold in Japan. Nakamatsu, 62, said listening to Beethoven's Fifth Symphony and swimming have helped him maintain the creativity that helped him obtain more than 2,000 patents in the United States and Japan. ``My best place to create inventions is under the water,'' he said. ``So I swim every day.'' Others said necessity is indeed the mother of invention. Ken Wittman said his sore left shoulder prompted him to invent a guitar strap that hangs on his right shoulder. The strap also allows the guitar to be worn by right- and left-handed musicians, and spins all the way around. ``And if you can't play at all, you can get their attention,'' he said. Kirk Renaud, vice president of DesignTech International Inc., exhibited several products, including the Quietwake alarm clock, which vibrates under a pillow. The product was designed for the hard of hearing and also works well for couples who rise at different hours, he said. DesignTech, of Springfield, Va., also markets a remote control device that activates a beeper in an automobile, helping drivers find cars in crowded lots. Also on display was a plastic gun that clears clogged drains with a blast of compressed air, golf shoes with playing tips stitched across the toes and a sand-laden trash can that won't tip over.

DOC.HEAD: Seidman Sees No Quick Fix for S&L Problems
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 10 grafs Seidman testimony today; picks up 8th pvs, bgng, Vento's panel...; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Outgoing savings and loan bailout chief L. William Seidman, showered with congressional praise today, cautioned legislators not to expect miracles from his successor. ``Don't be impatient. This is a long hard job. It isn't going to be accomplished anytime soon,'' Seidman told a House Banking task force on the S&L bailout. ``The real pain of what is taking place, on everything from increased government borrowing to the effect on real estate markets, is still being felt. I think it is very important that no one expect by this time next year we'll all feel great,'' he said. President Bush is turning to William Taylor, the Federal Reserve Board's director of bank supervision, to take over from Seidman, who recommended that choice. If nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate, Taylor would become chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. The FDIC insures bank and thrift institution deposits, while the RTC conducts the S&L cleanup. Taylor, 50, got a cautious welcome from task force members. They praised his experience and ability, but some questioned whether he would share Seidman's willingness to speak out independently about the rising cost of the bailout and other conflicts with the administration. ``I worry about the independence of the FDIC and the RTC. I worry about future policy decisions driven by political spin control,'' said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of the task force. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., called Taylor a ``superb choice,'' but told Seidman, ``I think the administration ... should be on its hands and knees begging you to stay.'' He said Taylor's talents will be wasted unless the president puts a higher priority on the S&L cleanup. In a statement Thursday, Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said, ``I'd like to see Bill Seidman finish his term (next year). ... Should he leave, any nominee would require the thorough assessment of a formal confirmation process.'' Vento's panel was conducting a hearing today, with Seidman as a witness, on the progress of the bailout. It is focusing on the slow pace so far in selling real estate, loans and other assets the government has inherited from bankrupt thrifts. Seidman has said he would leave sometime after the RTC achieves its ambitious goal of closing or selling 140 S&Ls by the end of June. However, Vento said a more important measure of progress will be whether the agency will avoid having to retain and warehouse most of the assets of the thrifts it is selling. Seidman, 69, had said for some time that he did not plan to stay until his term ends in October 1991. But he had not indicated his resignation was imminent. On Tuesday, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater indicated the administration would not resist Seidman's departure. However the president on Thursday disputed a newspaper report suggesting he had encouraged Seidman to go. ``It's his initiative,'' Bush said. ``I think Seidman has conducted himself with extraordinary grace and great ability.'' Although he scored points with Congress for his candor in revealing the bailout's soaring cost estimates, Seidman offended some administration officials, particularly White House chief of staff John Sununu and Deputy Treasury Secretary John Robson. On the other hand, Taylor reportedly is well-regarded by Treasury officials for his low-key style. Since mid-February, he has been on leave from the Federal Reserve, serving as chief staff officer of a Treasury-led policy panel overseeing the RTC. Taylor has a reputation as a conservative regulator and was one of the most vigorous advocates of toughening capital standards in the thrift industry. ``He's a safety and soundness man,'' said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America. Beyond the enormous task of directing the disposal of more than $300 billion in S&L assets, Taylor will find himself at the center of a clash next year between the administration and Congress when the two sides try to come up with a way to fund a second installment of the bailout. Taylor declined to respond to a request for comment Thursday. Government sources, asking not to be named, said Taylor wants the FDIC-RTC chairmanship, considered the nation's pre-eminent bank regulatory post. Early this year, he turned down an invitation to become director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, who serves under the Treasury secretary. The FDIC chairman, once appointed, serves independently and cannot be removed by the president. Seidman, in a telephone interview, said he backed Taylor because ``he's a very capable guy. He's familiar with the situation and I have a lot of confidence in him.'' ``The transition will take place in a very friendly manner when I think it's the appropriate time,'' Seidman said.

DOC.HEAD: Big Board Considering $25 Million Fine
DOC.TEXT: The New York Stock Exchange wants to fine the fallen brokerage Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. $25 million in connection with securities fraud and other crimes, sources said Friday. The fine would be the largest ever imposed on a securities firm, but whether the Big Board ever would collect is unclear. Drexel is liquidating after its parent company filed for bankruptcy court protection in February. The NYSE has the ability to levy fines against member firms and executives for violating exchange rules and securities laws. The exchange has been mulling whether to fine Drexel since the firm pleaded guilty to six felony crimes and agreed to pay $650 million in government penalties last year. The NYSE also is said to be considering brining separate disciplinary proceedings against Drexel Chief Executive Frederick H. Joseph and other top officers of the firm. Those charges would be in connection with the activities of the firm and its former junk bond leader, Michael Milken, who pleaded guilty last month to six separate felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. NYSE spokesman Richard Torrenzano declined comment on whether the NYSE was pursuing charges against Drexel. But he said: ``Drexel is the biggest regulatory problem by a member firm that we've had in the 200-year history of the New York Stock Exchange.'' The possible fine first was reported in today's editions of The Wall Street Journal. People with knowledge of the proceedings who asked not to be named confirmed the report. In a statement, Drexel defended its compliance mechanisms, saying its procedures were ``as good or better than other firms on the Street'' and its transgressions chiefly involved verbal agreements that weren't disclosed to the firm. ``It's clear that there were things that went wrong, but the firm and its shareholder-employees have already paid dearly for them,'' Drexel said. ``Any further penalties would be added, unnecessary punishment for creditors and shareholders and could be viewed simply as piling on.'' ``We understand the stock exchange's need to project an image of being a strong regulator,'' it said. ``However, that should be balanced with a sense of fairness in evaluting the company's and management's behavior.'' The Journal report said that the Big Board has stepped up its investigation of Drexel in recent weeks and has subpoenaed several individuals to testify about Drexel's and Milken's behavior. The charges against Joseph and other Drexel officials that are being considered were said to include failure to properly supervise Milken and others. Such charges could be important because they carry possible expulsion from the securities industry. Under stock exchange procedures, Drexel could challenge any sanction before an NYSE hearing board. The firm later could appeal any ruling to the NYSE board of directors, the Securities and Exchange Commission or a federal appeals court.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Mostly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with close
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed mostly higher Friday, buoyed by better-than-expected results for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party in local elections. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index finished up 27.3 points, or 1.26 percent, at 2,162.2. This was slightly below the day's high of 2,168.0 but well above the opening low of 2,146.4. Volume was 437.5 million shares, compared with 392.8 million Thursday. Dealers said the market reacted favorably to the Conservative's showing in Thursday's nationwide local elections. ``It's just been a relief that the Conservatives didn't do as badly as they were expected to do,'' said one trader, who asked not to be named.

For release Monday May 7
DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Figures Should Keep Rates Down for Treasury Auctions
DOC.TEXT: A weaker than expected employment report has stopped the drive for higher interest rates and should help the Treasury find buyers for its quarterly sale of notes and bonds this week, economists say. Fears that the economy was expanding too rapidly and threatening to drive inflation higher had gripped the credit markets in recent weeks, driving long-term bond yields above 9 percent for the first time in nearly a year. Economic data in the past few weeks had supported that bearish scenario. The consumer price index rose at an annual rate of 8.5 percent in the first quarter, the fastest rate since the inflationary spiral at the start of the 1980s. Orders for durable goods, a key benchmark for the economy, surged 6.7 percent in March, and purchasing managers reported that the manufacturing economy expanded for the first time in 11 months in April. Friday's jobs report from the Labor Department went a long way toward dissolving those fears, however, and should keep long-term rates below 9 percent, economists say. The nation's unemployment rate ticked up to 5.4 percent in April from 5.2 percent in March. The number of jobs grew by a slight 64,000 and would have shown a small decline if not for the temporary hiring of census workers. Factory payrolls fell by 22,000, the 12th drop in the last 13 months. ``The best you can say about the manufacturing sector is it's stopped shrinking,'' said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International Inc. As for the economy in general, ``maybe it's not on the brink of recession, but it's certainly not growing vigorously either,'' he added. Mitchell Held, chief economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said the figures were especially encouraging in showing a continued slowdown in the growth of service sector employment. That sector had been particularly resistant to the Federal Reserve's effort to slow the economy. What's more, average hourly earnings rose a mere 0.3 percent in April, or 3 cents, to $9.95 an hour despite the 50 cent hike in the minimum wage to $3.85 an hour. ``All those things together are really encouraging,'' Held said. They should dispel worries that the Fed might have to engineer a rise in interest rates to keep the economy and inflation in check. ``The Fed is probably going to keep policy steady,'' he predicted. Manufacturers have reported greater price pressure for labor and materials in the first quarter, as well as an increase in their selling prices, said John D. Walter, economist for Dow Corning Corp. and director of the National Association of Business Economist's industry survey. Nevertheless, Walter said consumer sticker shock and restrained growth in the money supply will cool inflation from the first quarter pace, while strong capital spending is raising industry's capacity. He sees the economy in a ``modest upturn'' with growth waffling between 1 percent and 3 percent over the next year. In short, the soft-landing scenario of restrained growth without recession is still on track, Walter said. That would be good news for a market that has to digest the Treasury's auctions of $30.5 billion in three- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds from Tuesday through Thursday. It's also good news for the government. Resler estimates the employment report will enable the Treasury to price the auctions at least an eighth of a percentage point lower than it otherwise would have, say between 8~ percent and 9 percent for the long bond instead of 9-9[ percent. That would save $250 million over the life of the three issues _ ``a nice little windfall for the Treasury.'' Held says long-term bonds should settle into a trading range of 8{ percent to 9 percent, down from a widely perceived 8} percent to 9\ percent before Friday.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
West German Union Reaches `Dream Goal' of 35-Hour Week
DOC.TEXT: The nation's most powerful labor union reached agreement Friday to cut its work week to 35 hours, signalling a broad move toward more leisure time for workers in one of the world's richest countries. Friday's pact, worked out during tense, all-night negotiations with an employers organization, immediately affects about 700,000 factory workers in the state of Baden-Wuerttemberg. The precedent is expected to be followed as the IG Metall metalworkers union negotiates contracts for the rest of the country. West Germans already have six weeks of vacation each year, a sprinkling of about 10 holidays and legally guaranteed work breaks on the job. For years, the mighty IG Metall union, which negotiates contracts for 4 million workers in the metal-working, automobile and related industries, has demanded a reduction to 35 hours. The current work week is 37 hours, compared with 40 hours in 1985. ``Our dream goal has been reached,'' said union president Franz Steinkuehler in Frankfurt. ``We wanted time and money and we got both.'' The cut will come in two stages, to 36 hours in April 1993 and 35 hours in October 1995, while the agreement also calls for 6 percent pay hike spread out over 12 months. In Frankfurt, the printers union immediately said that it also will be seeking to cut hours to 35 a week. ``I expect this compromise probably to be adopted nationwide,'' said Joerg Barzcynski, IG Metall spokesman. IG Metall had staged warning strikes involving more than 300,000 workers and temporarily halting production at a few hundred West German plants this week. Steinkuehler promised a round of strikes to keep up pressure on employers in other parts of the country to reach agreements. The compromise was reached in the key West German industrial area around the city of Stuttgart, which houses car and truck manufacturer Daimler-Benz, among other major companies. West German politicians reacted critically to the compromise. Economics Minister Helmut Haussman termed it a ``false signal'' ahead of German unification. The unions ``are artifically restricting our most important production factor,'' he said. Otto Lambsdorff, head of the coalition partner Free Democrats, called the accord on the 35-hour work week a ``speculative agreement about the future.'' West German employers' organizations repeatedly have said the trend toward less work and higher pay, combined with the nation's massive social security net, is driving more businesses to cheaper countries in southern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: TW Services Drops Pepsi-Cola From Hardee's, Canteen Operations
DOC.TEXT: TW Services Inc., one of the nation's largest food service companies, said Friday that it was dropping Pepsi-Cola Co. products from its 465 Hardee's restaurants. Coca-Cola Co. had been the primary supplier for those restaurants and will continue in that role, the Spartanburg, S.C.-based company said. TW Services is the largest franchisee of Hardee's Food Systems Inc., which owns or franchises 3,300 restaurants nationwide and already counts Coca-Cola as its primary soft drink syrup supplier. As a Hardee's franchisee, TW Services was free to make its own arrangements on soft drinks for its restaurants. Earlier this week, Burger King Corp. said it planned to switch to Coca-Cola as the soft drink supplier for its 5,400 restaurants, dumping Pepsi-Cola after an association of more than six years. Karen Randall, a spokeswoman for TW Services, said her company's 465 Hardee's restaurants have been offering several Coca-Cola drinks along with the Pepsi brand and, in some cases, Pepsi's Mountain Dew. But she said the company decided that consolidating its business with Coca-Cola would improve operating efficiency. She declined to say how much business Pepsi-Cola stands to lose as a result of the decision. The changeover will take several months. TW Services said it also had designated Coca-Cola as the primary supplier for its Canteen contract food service operations. The Canteen division has more than 1,600 accounts at sites ranging from school cafeterias to industrial vending machines, some of which had been serving Coca-Cola products along with other soft drinks. The decision means Canteen will be offering Coca-Cola products more often, the company said.
