DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mixed: Wheat Up, Soybeans Down
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade with wheat futures up strongly, soybeans lower and corn narrowly mixed. The corn market's performance was surprising in light of strong indications the Soviet Union bought up to 2 million metric tons of U.S. corn overnight or early Friday, analysts said. They said buying linked to the Soviet rumors was offset by heavy speculative fund selling. ``The fact that corn closed mixed against all that selling is good'' from a bullish perspective, said Victor Lespinasse, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``The fact that we couldn't rally corn more than we did is bad.'' Soybean futures extended the fairly steep losses posted Thursday, obliterating strong gains made in Wednesday's session. Wheat futures surged late in the session, possibly reflecting concerns about flood-related harvest delays and damage to the winter wheat crop in eastern Texas and Oklahoma. At the close, wheat futures were { cent to 4{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.77 a bushel; corn futures were } cent lower to 1} cents higher with May at $2.87\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to { cent higher with May at $1.66} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 4\ cents lower with May at $6.26{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Chief To Get $8 Million Contract
DOC.TEXT: The new head of Ames Department Stores Inc. could receive $8 million over three years if he can steer the troubled retailer through bankruptcy court, according to his contract. In addition to a $1.5 million annual salary and $500,000 signing bonus, chief executive Stephen L. Pistner will will receive a $3.5 million bonus if Ames wins court approval for a reorganization plan before Nov. 1, 1991. He would get a bonus of $3 million if the court approves a plan after Nov. 1, 1991, according to the contract, filed this week in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York. The Rocky Hill-based discount chain sought protection from creditors last week under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. Pistner's base pay is more than double the salary of Ames' last chief executive officer, Peter B. Hollis, who resigned effective Monday. In granting preliminary approval to Pistner's hiring, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard C. Buschman III agreed the company had to pay a generous salary to attract an executive willing to take on the job of rescuing Ames, a $5 billion company. Pistner _ the former chief of the Montgomery Ward, McCrory, Target and Dayton Hudson retail chains _ has more than 20 years of experience in retail management and a reputation for reviving troubled companies. A May 15 bankruptcy court hearing was scheduled to finalize the appointment. Ames said in court papers that its deal with Pistner was similar to compensation another troubled retailer, Allied Stores Corp., offered its new chief executive officer. Allied, the parent of the Bloomingdale's and Jordan Marsh store chains, filed for Chapter 11 protection in January. Pistner will receive his base salary and other benefits and expenses regardless of whether Ames emerges from bankruptcy court proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Two Directors Resign at Saatchi & Saatchi
DOC.TEXT: Two key directors of the troubled advertising and consulting giant Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC resigned Friday, the company said. Roy Warman and Terry Bannister served as joint chief operating officers of Saatchi's communications division with responsibility for worldwide advertising operations. Saatchi's deputy chairman Jeremy Sinclair was named to replace the men. The departures of Warman, 41, and Bannister, 44, are the first major executive departures since January when Robert Louis-Dreyfus was brought in as chief executive. Warman was a founding member of Saatchi's executive team, joining the firm at its beginning in 1970. Terry Bannister had been with the London-based company for 17 years. Louis-Dreyfus issued a brief statement, in which he said, ``I am sorry to see them go, but following the decision to redeploy as much of the central talent as possible within the operations, no role could be found for Roy and Terry which satisfied them.'' The company has been battered by an expensive diversification into consulting during the mid-1980s, weak financial controls and a period of slow growth in the advertising industry. Louis-Dreyfus, the Harvard MBA who turned around IMS International Inc., the New York-based pharmaceutical market research firm, has introduced cost-cutting measures and is trying to sell Saatchi's consulting businesses. A Saatchi spokesman said Friday's departures weren't totally unexpected. ``It's (the result) of a corporate decision by the chief executive. That's the chief executive's job,'' said the spokesman, who was not named in keeping with British custom. The spokesman added that Warman and Bannister have four-year contracts and may leave with 1 million pounds, or $1.64 million, each. Sinclair, 43, another founding member of the firm, has been chairman of Saatchi's international advertising operations since 1986, and the group's deputy chairman since 1987.
Stock prices staged a moderate advance today, capping off a week of slow but steady gains. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 13.51 at 2,709.68.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Receives $400 Million Contract From European Travel Network
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. said Friday it received a $400 million contract to supply up to 55,000 personal computers to a European travel agent network, one of IBM's largest such contracts ever. IBM's West German subsidiary will supply the computers to the Amadeus network over a three-year period, the Madrid, Spain-based travel reservation system said. The agreement is one of the largest volume-purchasing contracts ever received by IBM based on the number of computers involved, said Win Pierlo, assistant general manager of IBM Germany. Amadeus is a partnership of 21 European airlines, the French and West German national railroads and a West German tour operator. It describes itself as the largest travel reservation network in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Major Trade Conference Fails to Resolve Big Disputes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with final press conference; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `The Bush...
DOC.TEXT: Trade ministers from three continents reported today they had failed to resolve several disputes that are threatening to scuttle an ambitious effort to reform the global trading system. Officials from the United States, Japan, the 12-nation European Community and Canada said at the conclusion of three days of talks that they had a frank exchange of views but remained far apart in many areas, especially on the contentious issue of how to end expensive farm subsidies. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said the talks were in the ``home stretch,'' but she conceded that much work needed to be done. The ministers did report some progress on bridging differences on some low-level issues such as how trade disputes should be handled but said sharp differences remained in the two key areas of agriculture subsidies and barriers to textile imports. Hills spoke at a sun-drenched news conference held on the edge of a golf course at the resort where the talks were held. The Bush administration is counting on an agreement by the end of this year to lower America's huge trade deficit by expanding export opportunities for U.S. farmers and businesses. The American side is pushing to eliminate expensive farm export subsidies, to dismantle barriers to trade in services such as banking and to crack down on copyright and patent piracy, estimated to cost American firms $60 billion annually. Officials said they aim to draw up the general outline of an agreement during a bargaining session in Geneva in late July, and then work toward a final agreement in December. The talks, held under the auspices of the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, are known as the Uruguay Round of free trade talks, for the country where they were launched in 1986. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, who selected her home state of California for the meeting, expressed satisfaction with what she termed a ``quite constructive'' session. A senior U.S. official, briefing reporters on condition of anonymity, said the talks produced no major breakthroughs, although he said they helped define the opposing positions. All sides reported that the biggest dispute _ how to put an end to trade-distorting farm subsidies _ remained far from resolution as the European Community held fast to its desire to protect a subsidy system for its network of small farms. Frans Andriessen, trade minister for the European Community, termed the discussions ``frank,'' often a diplomatic code word for unfruitful talks. Many Third World nations, who were not represented at the Napa meetings, are battling the U.S. proposals, especially on lowering trade barriers for service industries. They contend that their fledgling service companies should be protected from foreign concerns invading their markets. Canadian Trade Minister John Crosbie said he would put the chances of successfully wrapping up the negotiations in December at little better than 50 percent. But he said he was still hopeful because ``the consequences of failure are so horrific. ... The alternative is the law of the jungle and only the largest beasts will survive and they won't survive very well.'' Hills sounded a similar theme, contending that without a strengthened trade agreement, both industrial and Third World nations would suffer declining standards of living as trade flows contracted behind protectionist walls. The administration is having to wage a dual war, seeking to convince the Europeans and developing countries to drop their opposition to the free trade proposals while fighting off efforts in Congress to erect barriers protecting threatened U.S. industries. Congress must approve any final agreement and the outcome of that debate is far from certain. Already, special interest groups representing the textile industry and peanut and sugar growers are working to build congressional opposition to changes in GATT rules that would strip them of trade protections they now enjoy.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 187.63 Friday, up 4.68, or 2.56 percent, from a week ago and down 9.65,or 4.89 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 176.03 Friday, up 4.51, or 2.63 percent, from a week ago and down 9.08, or 4.91 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 160.39 Friday, up 2.57, or 1.63 percent, from a week ago and down 7.92, or 4.71 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Back Plea To Allow Non-White Shirts; Company Doesnt'
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders at Safeco Corp.'s annual meeting didn't show much reaction to disappointing first-quarter profits, but they applauded a plea to allow male employees to wear non-white shirts. ``For 28 long years, I have been needlessly white,'' Jack Hepfer, a recently retired Safeco lawyer, said of the 67-year-old dress code. Hepfer cited Hawthorne Dent, founder of the Seattle-based insurance company, as having said in 1955 that there was ``nothing the matter with colored shirts.'' After all, Hepfer said, ``The Berlin Wall came down.'' But the white-shirts-only policy didn't. Safeco Chairman Bruce Maines defended the rule at Wednesday's annual meeting and company president Roger Eigsti refused to change it. ``The white-shirt rule is a plain, straight, pragmatic rule. It's a part of our thing. It's part of our personality,'' said Maines, who owns 30 white shirts. The company reported first-uarter profits of 89 cents a share, down from $1.04 a share in the first three months of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Whittle Names Turner Broadcasting Exec To Head New Education Division
DOC.TEXT: Whittle Communications said Friday it is consolidating its media systems designed for schools into one division and named a former executive of Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. to head the new unit. The Knoxville, Tenn.-based media company said it expects its new Whittle Educational Network division to generate annual revenue of $125 million by 1991, making it one of the company's largest operations. Whittle officials expect the company overall to generate more than $300 million a year in revenue by 1991, up from about $180 million this year. Whittle is 50 percent owned by Time Warner Inc. The new division will contain at least seven different media properties ranging from TV programs and magazines for teens to product sampling programs aimed at college students. Responsibility for each property previously had been scattered throughout the company. One source familiar with Whittle's plans said additional business divisions are expected to be formed within the company over the next few months. One of them could handle all of the company's health programs, for instance, or all of its foreign-language programs. Farrell Reynolds, former president of Turner Broadcasting Sales Inc., was named chairman and chief executive of the new division. Longtime Whittle executive Ed Winter will be president and chief operating officer of the unit. At Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting, Reynold's division was responsible for advertising sales on the Turner networks including Cable News Network, Turner Network Television, Headline News and the TBS Superstation. Falling under his jurisdiction at Whittle will be Channel One, the 12-minute daily television news show with commercials for teens in the classroom. Channel One was launched in March and has signed up 3,600 schools nationally. Winter has been responsible for getting the Channel One system going. By turning to Turner Broadcasting for the chief executive of its educational unit, Whittle raided one of its chief competitors in educational broadcasting. Turner's Cable News Network launched a commercial-free 15-minute daily news show for teens last summer and encourages teachers to use it in class. Along with Channel One, the new Whittle Educational Network division will have responsibility for six other media systems aimed at schools. They are The Classroom Channel, a noncommercial educational program; the wall media systems Connections, Big Picture and Campus Voice, which combine editorial material and advertisements on a poster-size billboard hung in school lobbies; the magazine Go! for teen girls and Good Stuff, a sampling program. Whittle offers more than 40 media properties, many of them designed to appeal to narrowly defined audiences such as mothers in waiting rooms, pet owners at the veterinarians or Hispanic households.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Gold Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell Friday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen after the government said the U.S. unemployment rate for April rose to its highest level in more than a year. Gold prices softened. Gold fell 50 cents a troy ounce to $370.90 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $371.30 an ounce, unchanged from Thursday. The government said the U.S. unemployment rate rose to 5.4 percent in April from 5.2 percent in March. ``That seemed to be what set it off,'' Mike Ballow, a currency market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said of the dollar's decline. Signs of economic weakness, such as higher unemployment, may induce the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates. Lower rates reduce the attractiveness of returns on dollar-denominated investments, compared with those for other currencies. ``Right now, people (traders) only are concentrating on interest rates,'' said Walter Simon, a vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Co. in New York. Also working against the dollar was a rise in bond prices, which sent bond yields lower, Simon said. In addition, traders said the dollar's fall was hastened when its price crossed certain technical support levels in relation to other currencies. Markets in Japan were closed for the Citizens' Day holiday. In London, the dollar traded at 158.25 yen, up from 158.10 yen late Thursday. In New York, the dollar bought 158.30 yen, up from 158.05 yen a day earlier. In London, the British pound moved higher, rising to $1.6595 from $1.6425 late Thursday. In New York, the pound cost $1.6635, more expensive than Thursday's $1.6410. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.6660 West German marks, down from 1.6828; 1.4430 Swiss francs, down from 1.4550; 5.5930 French francs, down from 5.6450; 1,221 Italian lire, down from 1,233.25; and 1.1629 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16625. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6710 West German marks, down from 1.6817; 1.4435 Swiss francs, down from 1.4540; 5.6060 French francs, down from 5.6315; 1.8782 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8910; 1,224.50 Italian lire, down from 1,232.50; and 1.1630 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1669. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $371.45 a troy ounce, from $370.65 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, gold closed at $371.00 an ounce, up from $370.25 bid late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.69 to close at a bid of $372.76 an ounce. Silver for current delivery rose to $5.00 a troy ounce from $4.998 late Thursday on the Commodity Exchange. Earlier, silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $5.05 a troy ounce, from $5.04 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices closed mixed on seasonal and technical factors Friday, a day after OPEC members agreed to cut their production by about 6 percent. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude oil, fell 1 cent to close at $17.98 a 42-gallon barrel. Subsequent contract months posted small gains. Among refined products traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange, home heating oil for June delivery dropped 0.05 cent to 49.95 cents a gallon. The July and August contracts also fell, but subsequent months edged higher. The June contract for unleaded regular gasoline rose 1.44 cents to 61.12 cents a gallon, and later-month contracts also advanced. Natural gas for June delivery finished unchanged at $1.575 per million British thermal units, as it did the previous two sessions. Analysts said traders largely were squaring their positions. Gasoline advanced as the summer driving season approached and amid reports of shortages on the Gulf Coast. Heating oil's decline was attributed to reduced demand during the spring and summer. On Thursday, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced it was cutting its production by 1.45 million barrels a day from 23.5 million barrels in April. The cartel's overproduction has brought oil prices down by 20 percent since January. Futures prices rallied briefly and then sank after the announcement Thursday because traders did not believe the cuts were substantial enough to relieve the glut of oil on world markets. The agreement had little effect on Friday's trading, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: State Agency Investigating Trump's Atlantic City Casinos
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's three casinos are being investigated in a financial review that state officials said Friday was routine and had nothing to do with disgruntled contractors or the Manhattan developer's desire to sell some assets. Anthony J. Parrillo, director of the state Division of Gaming Enforcement, said the review has been under way for two months. Such reviews are done periodically for each casino operator in Atlantic City, he said. Parrillo's division is the investigative arm of the state Casino Control Commission, which oversees the gaming industry. Parrillo said it was coincidental that the review coincided with statements from Trump last week that he was considering selling some of his holdings, which include Manhattan real estate and the Trump Shuttle airline. Also, a story published in Forbes last week lowered estimates of Trump's wealth by more than $1 billion to about $500 million, but Parrillo said that also was no factor. ``The information will not cloud our vision either negatively or positively,'' Parrillo said. ``It's based solely on the facts, not on estimates by Forbes or in the print media.'' Parrillo said his office has yet to receive a formal complaint from about 100 contractors who contend they are owed about $35 million for work on Trump's $1 billion Taj Mahal Casino Resort, which opened April 2. Any such complaint would be investigated, he said. Trump officials announced Thursday they hired an independent auditor to check the contractors' work before making final payment. Parrillo said he could not estimate how long the state review would take. He said past investigations of Trump's finances occurred when he first got his license in 1982, again in 1983 and in 1987. He said the review may include Trump's entire organization, including properties outside Atlantic City. The division produced a favorable financial report on the Taj Mahal's prospects before it officially won its license March 29. Ed Tracy, president of Trump's Atlantic City holdings, said the review is a ``non-issue'' because it is required periodically by state law. Last month, the Taj Mahal set an Atlantic City record, taking in $34.2 million from gamblers. Trump's other two casinos both saw drops in gross revenues last month, though both were hurt by unusually low ``hold'' percentages. Hold is what is kept by the house and is subject to the luck of gambling. Trump Plaza dropped from $26.6 million in April 1989 to $20.3 million last month. Trump Castle fell from $21.0 million to $18.5 million. ``We're doing great. The numbers at the Taj continue to be astounding,'' Tracy said. ``The numbers at Trump Plaza and Trump Castle were down but not significantly in terms of market share.'' Ron Grobeck, a gaming analyst with New York-based R.D. Smith, said Trump Plaza remains a strong property, but questioned the Taj Mahal's long-term potential for taking business away from Trump Castle. He also said the $34.2 million first-month figure for the Taj Mahal was not as good as might be expected given the ``hyped-up atmosphere.'' ``The Taj may not be as strong as Donald would have hoped,'' Grobeck said.

DOC.HEAD: Sugar Futures Collapse on Slack Demand, Technical Weakness
DOC.TEXT: Sugar futures prices collapsed Friday, plunging more than a penny a pound on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange amid heavy selling by frustrated speculators on signs of slack global demand. On other commodity markets, cocoa futures also fell sharply; copper futures retreated; precious metals were mostly lower; oil futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. World sugar futures settled .50 cent to 1.16 cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at 14.44 cents a pound, the lowest close for a near-month sugar contract since March 1. ``Everybody was bailing out of the market today,'' Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst Judith Ganes said. She said the market had been poised for a fall after repeated failures in the past week to sustain prices above 16 cents a pound. Speculators who had been holding out for higher prices finally gave up and began liquidating their positions, analysts said, triggering a sell-off of near-record proportions with an estimated 76,000 contracts changing hands. The decline was spurred on by a bearish supply-demand report by the London trading house E.D.&F. Man Ltd. The firm sharply reduced its 1989-90 sugar deficit estimate, predicting consumption would outstrip production by 258,000 metric tons instead of 1.46 million metric tons as previously forecast. Ms. Ganes said the Man report probably contributed to the bearish sentiment but that the revised deficit forecast was in line with other trade house predictions. She said the sharp rise in sugar prices from less than 13 cents a pound last December has stifled demand, which is the reason for the lowered consumption expectations. But Monday's sharp decline could stimulate new demand, Ms. Ganes said. Cocoa futures also fell sharply in New York amid skepticism about a plan by six major producer countries to curb excess production and encourage local consumption. Cocoa futures settled $23 to $29 lower with May at $1,261 per ton. Near-month copper futures fell modestly on New York's Commodity Exchange on news that employees of the Southern Peru Copper Corp. had returned to work, ending a seven-week strike that had disrupted Peruvian copper shipments. Copper settled 1.3 cents lower to .55 cents higher with May at $1.189 a pound. Also on the Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled 60 cents to $1.30 lower with June at $373.10 a troy ounce; silver was 0.9 cent lower to 0.2 cent higher with May at $5 a troy ounce. Crude oil futures were little changed on the New York Mercantile Exchange but near-month gasoline futures rose sharply, erasing Thursday's loss. The oil market is adjusting to OPEC's decision this week to reduce crude-oil production in an attempt to alleviate a global supply glut. World demand for oil is running about the same as last year, said Peter Cardillo, commodity trading adviser for Josephthal & Co. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 1 cent lower to 12 cents higher with June at $17.98 a barrel; heating oil was .13 cent lower to .29 cent higher with June at 49.95 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .05 cent to 1.44 cents higher with June at 61.12 cents a pound. After the close of grain and soybean futures trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, the Agriculture Department announced the Soviet Union had bought 600,000 metric tons of U.S. corn, partly confirming market rumors that the Soviets had bought as much as 2 million tons. Wheat futures settled { cent to 4} cents higher with May at $3.77\ a bushel; corn futures were } cent lower to 1} cents higher with May at $2.87\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to { cent higher with May at $1.66} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 3} cents lower with May at $6.26{ a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle futures finished .40 cent lower to .35 cent higher with June at 74.65 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .18 cent higher with May at 83.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .43 cent higher with June at 63.97 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .50 cent lower to .10 cent higher with May at 69.17 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Rise in Big Rally
DOC.TEXT: New evidence from April employment figures of an unexpectedly weak economy triggered a furious rally Friday in the bond market, sending interest rates sharply lower. The bond buying binge offered a marked contrast to the gloom that depressed the market for much of the month of April, hammering bond prices and pushing long-term interest rates bove 9 percent for the first time since last May. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond climbed 1| points, or $16.25 for every $1,000 face amount, in one of the year's biggest rallies. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, tumbled to 8.81 percent from 8.97 percent late Thursday. Analysts said the government's report that the unemployment rate rose to 5.4 percent in April from 5.2 percent in March was the catalyst for the big price rally. What caught most bond traders' interest was the report of a measly net gain of 64,000 jobs in April, well below what analysts had expected. Elliott Platt, fixed-income research director for Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp., said if the addition of 78,000 temporary census workers were excluded from the numbers, jobs would have fallen by 14,000 last month. He said analysts expected an increase of 150,000 jobs, not counting the census workers for April. In addition, he said wage inflation was up 0.3 percent in April when many analysts were expecting 0.5 percent growth, partly due to the April 1 boost in the minimum wage. But the minimum wage increase had minimal impact on overall wage growth, officials indicated. ``This report indicates a lot of weakness in the economy. People had thought the economy was stronger with a much deeper inflation problem,'' Platt said. The bond market benefits from a slow economic growth and low inflation because credit demand generally falls off during sluggish periods and allows interest rates to decline. Rising inflation and rapid growth, on the other hand, erodes the value of fixed-income securities such as notes and bonds and could prompt the Federal Reserve to encourage higher interest rates. ``There is nothing the bond market likes better than bad news,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist for Nikko Securities International. He said the bond market had overreacted over the past few months to indications that the economy was growing rapidly and inflation was accelerating. The market rally could not have been timed any better for the Treasury Department, which is planning to sell $30.5 billion in new securities next week. Barring a sudden reversal in market sentiment early next week, the government may find buyers at lower yields than had been expected only a few days ago. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments rose { point, intermediate maturities climbed by between 11-16 point and a full point and long-term issues advanced 1| points, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 9.15 to 1,140.76. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds climbed 7-16 point to 89|. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.68 percent from 7.72 percent. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 8.00 percent as the discount lost 10 basis points to 7.75 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.23 percent as the discount dropped 16 basis points to 7.81 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.39 percent as the discount fell 22 basis points to 7.82 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Progress Remains Elusive For Ministers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 new grafs to UPDATE with news conference. Picks up 10th graf, The talks... A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Trade ministers representing the largest industrial countries reported Friday they had failed to resolve major disputes blocking an ambitious effort to overhaul the global trading system. Speaking at the end of a three-day negotiating session, officials of the United States, Japan, the 12-nation European Community and Canada said sharp differences still remained over such issues as a U.S. demand for the elimination of costly agricultural barriers. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and the leaders of the other delegations sought to portray the talks in a positive light, saying the discussions were useful in highlighting areas of disagreement and providing momentum to resolving disputes. Canadian Trade Minister John Crosbie praised the discussions for ``turning the heat up'' in the four-year effort to liberalize the rules governing world trade. The officials said progress has been made toward narrowing differences in certain lower-level issues such as how trade disputes are handled. But they were unable to point to any breakthroughs in the major areas of dispute, including agriculture and barriers erected by the United States and other industrial countries to textile imports. With time running out on the four-year effort to reform the global trading system, Hills said the negotiators would appeal to President Bush and other leaders at the seven-nation economic summit in July to supply a ``political push'' to break the stalemates. Hills and Crosbie participated at the closing press conference with Japanese Trade Minister Kabun Muto and Frans Andriessen, top trade negotiator for the European Community. They spoke to reporters on the patio of a posh resort in the heart of California wine country, a site selected by Hills, a California native. The talks were intended to provide guidance so that lower level negotiators would be able to come up with at least the outline of a final agreement during talks scheduled for late July in Geneva. Hills said she remained confident that with intensive effort such a document could be produced in coming weeks. The Bush administration has made a successful conclusion of the complex negotiations, which are scheduled to end in December, its No. 1 trade priority. The administration believes the freer trade that would result would lower America's huge trade deficit by expanding overseas sales by American farmers and businesses. U.S. negotiators are pushing to eliminate all trade-distorting farm subsidies, to dismantle barriers to trade in services such as banking and to crack down on copyright and patent piracy, estimated to cost American firms $60 billion annually. The talks, being held under the auspices of the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are known as the Uruguay Round, for the country where they were launched in 1986. The United States has proposed a 10-year phaseout of the farm subsidies, estimating it would boost exports for more efficient American farmers by $11 billion annually. But the European Community, seeking to protect its wide network of small family farms, has refused to budge from its opposition. Many Third World nations, which were not represented at the Napa meetings, are battling the U.S. proposals to lower trade barriers on services and to toughen copyright protections, fearing harm to their infant domestic industries. Congress must approve any final agreement and the debate there is likely to be intense. Already, special interest groups representing the American textile industry and peanut and sugar growers are working to build opposition to changes which would strip them of trade protections they now enjoy.

DOC.HEAD: GM To Ask Employees To Talk Up Car Quality
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. said Friday it has begun a campaign to boost the image of its cars and trucks that includes asking current and retired employees to tell their friends that vehicle quality has improved. GM spokesman Harold Jackson said the advertising project is the automaker's most ambitious ever. He declined to say how much GM is spending, but The Wall Street Journal estimated Friday it would cost $40 million. The nation's Big Three automakers have stumbled badly in a industrywide downturn due to soft markets and intense foreign competition. GM on Thursday reported that first-quarter profits fell by 54 percent. Earnings declined 69 percent at Ford Motor Co. in the first quarter and 80 percent at Chrysler Corp. GM said it plans to contact each of its estimated 500,000 active U.S. employees, its 330,000 retirees and employees of its 9,700 U.S. dealers and urge them to tell friends and neighbors that GM's vehicle quality has improved. ``We're particularly concerned that people who haven't driven our recent cars are still judging us by the vehicles they bought in the early '80s, some of which perhaps weren't quite as high in quality as they are today,'' Jackson said. Chrysler has been airing a television commercial featuring its chairman, Lee Iacocca, telling top executives basically the same thing _ that the quality of the company's cars has improved, but no one knows it. ``Ours is not tied to Iacocca,'' Jackson said. ``Ours has been in the development stage since late last year.'' The GM program includes television, magazine and newspaper advertising, some of which began Friday, along with the individual mailings, which started earlier this week. Jackson said the program has no scheduled end.

DOC.HEAD: Breeden: Milken Testimony Before Congress Could Complicate Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, Rep. John... to UPDATE with comment from Dingell. Picks up 10th graf, On other...
DOC.TEXT: Congressional testimony by convicted junk bond financier Michael Milken before he is sentenced could complicate the securities fraud case, the nation's top securities regulator said Friday. The oversight and investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee voted unanimously Tuesday to subpoena Milken, who pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties last month. If Milken receives immunity from the panel, nothing he says at a congressional hearing could be used against him in state or federal courts. ``I think we'll try to work with Congress to make sure they understand the status of the case as they consider what hearings they wish to have and when they want to have them,'' Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said. Before Milken is called to testify before Congress _ something he refused to do two years ago _ the subpoena must be approved by the full House committee. Milken, once head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-risk, high-yield bond department, faces up to 28 years in prison when he is sentenced in New York on Oct. 1. Asked if the SEC would oppose having Milken testify before he is sentenced, Breeden said: ``If you had immunized testimony before a point in time that the plea agreement, and the settlement becomes irrevocable on the date of sentencing, then it does create potential for introducing complications into the case.'' Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of both the committee and subcomittee, replied in a statement issued through his office: ``We're aware of the concerns of the SEC and others and will work closely with them to avoid major complications. However, the subcommittee intends to continue to perform its duties and oversight with vigor.'' On other topics, Breeden said it was ``premature'' to say how an appeals court decision in New York this week overturning the insider trading conviction of ex-stockbroker Robert Chestman would affect SEC enforcement efforts. He added that the SEC was still studying the decision to determine whether to appeal it and what implications it has for pending cases and settlements already reached. ``We're certainly not get into renegotiating settlements at a preliminary stage,'' Breeden said during a meeting with reporters in his office. In settling civil and criminal charges with the SEC and the Justice Department, Milken agreed to testify truthfully before grand juries and at trials or court proceedings stemming from ``any Drexel-related activities.'' If Milken fails to comply with those rules he can be prosecuted for perjury and obstruction of justice and jailed for contempt of court under the settlement. The agreements do not specifically mention congressional testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Blames Strike for $55.8 Million Quarterly Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with details, quotes, additional layoffs; EDITS to conform; PICKS UP 15th graf pvs, `Greyhound has...
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. said Friday it lost $55.8 million in the first quarter and would miss millions of dollars in payments due in coming weeks because of problems related to a 2-month-old strike by bus drivers. Greyhound said it missed about $5 million in lease payments due in April and would not make a $9.75 million interest payment due May 15. Greyhound also announced layoffs of 172 administrative workers at its Dallas headquarters and elsewhere. The losses put Greyhound in technical default on some credit agreements, opening the door for creditors to force the company into bankruptcy. Officials say they do not believe that will happen. ``We won't pull the rip cord if nobody forces us to,'' Greyhound Vice President and Treasurer Don Seaquist said. ``Our assets have a lot more value as a going operation as a bus company that they would broken up.'' He said Greyhound's senior bank lenders were getting daily reports on company operations and cash flow and were expected to grant waivers on some interest payment requirements. The disclosures were the first indication of financial straits at Greyhound, which operates the only nationwide bus system. Greyhound blamed the losses and cutbacks in large part on $20 million in unanticipated expenses to cope with strike-related violence. Greyhound had maintained since bus drivers walked out March 2 that it had sufficient cash to withstand the strike and would make the May 15 interest payment. ``At the time, our cash projections showed a return to ridership that was higher than we've seen so far,'' Seaquist said. The company has been running at between 53 percent and 60 percent of last year's ridership in recent weeks, although spokesman George Gravley said the latest figures show an improvement. Greyhound said it is taking ``vigorous actions to return to profitability during the peak summer months.'' But the company said it expects to lose money in April, May and possibly June. The actions include the layoffs announced Friday and a new advertising campaign to take effect next week. Greyhound already laid off about 270 mechanics last month. In papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Greyhound said the first-quarter loss caused it to violate certain agreements with creditors. ``As a result, the company's major creditors will be in a position to accelerate payments due,'' Greyhound said. ``The company is developing a financial restructuring plan that it will begin discussing with its creditors and lenders in the very near future.'' Seaquist admitted the creditors could force Greyhound into involuntary bankruptcy, and that the company had briefly considered, but rejected, filing for voluntary bankruptcy. Although Greyhound said it had been prepared financially for the strike, it said it had not anticipated ``the excessive amount of violence directed at its buses and facilities.'' ``Violence caused the company to spend more than $20 million for additional security, legal fees and driver training,'' Greyhound said. There have been 46 shootings at Greyhound buses or terminals and more than 100 bomb threats, the company said. The company has sued union officials in a Florida federal court for $30 million, claiming they have supported violence. Greyhound had refused to return to the bargaining table until a week had passed without violence. That condition was met earlier this week, and talks are to resume in Washington on Saturday with a federal mediator. Gravley said the company would have no new proposal to present Saturday. Greyhound has said it cannot afford more than the $63 million, three-year contract it first offered. Union officials contend their own offer is less, but Greyhound values it at about $200 million. In the quarter ended March 31, Greyhound said it lost $55.8 million on revenues of $173 million. That compares to a $14.4 million loss on $224 million in revenue during the same period last year. The company, created three years ago in a leveraged buyout, lost $20 million its first two years before turning a small profit last year.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Hacker Sentenced to Three Years Probation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, ```We love...,' to CORRECT quote to `different' sted `difficult; Also on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: A computer expert who created a ``worm'' program that paralyzed thousands of computers nationwide was placed on three years probation Friday and fined $10,000 for the crime. U.S. District Judge Howard Munson also ordered 25-year-old Robert T. Morris to perform 400 hours of community service. Prosecutors had asked Munson to order the maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. They sought at least some jail time for the former Cornell University graduate student. Defense attorney David O'Brien said Morris was ``too decent a kid'' to be sentenced to jail. ``There is a world of difference between what Robert did and what others who have used this technology did,'' O'Brien said, noting that Morris did not benefit from his actions. Morris did not speak at the sentencing or talk to reporters after the hearing. He remained grim-faced through most of the hearing, then cracked a wide smile and hugged his mother when the sentence was announced. Morris' parents said they were pleased with the sentence. ``We love our son, he's a great kid,'' Anne Morris said. ``We wish that this last year and a half had been different for him, but we're weathering it and so is he.'' Mrs. Morris said the experience had made her son more responsible. In January, Morris became the first person to be convicted under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act for breaking into a federal computer network and preventing authorized use of the system. He created the ``worm'' program while at Cornell University in Ithaca on Nov. 2, 1988. The rogue program immobilized an estimated 6,000 computers linked to the Internet research system, including ones at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, military bases and major universities. Morris, formerly of Arnold, Md., and now living in Cambridge, Mass., testified during his trial that the worm was an experiment that went out of control because of a programming error he made. He admitted he designed the worm to invade the Internet system, but said it wasn't supposed to replicate wildly as it did. Prosecutors disagreed. During the trial, they described Morris' experiment as a ``full-scale assault'' that was methodically planned. They said Morris also took deliberate steps to make the worm difficult to trace and eradicate. U.S. Attorney Frederick Scullin Jr., however, said he thought the sentence was fair. The case was unique, and the sentence does not mean that future offenders will not face prison terms, he said. ``In case anybody had any doubt, these are serious crimes and will be prosecuted as such,'' Scullin said. Thomas Guidoboni, another defense attorney, said he thought the sentence was reasonable, but said he will file an appeal to challenge the law under which Morris was convicted. ``I don't believe Mr. Morris deserves to be a felon for what he did,'' said Guidoboni, who had asked Munson to consider a sentence of no more than six months in jail and a $500-$5,000 fine.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT S&P industrials to 394.20 sted 349.20. ^By CHET CURRIER
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices capped off a week of slow but steady gains with a broad advance Friday, responding to a big surprise in the government's latest report on employment. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 14.19 to 2,710.36, stretching its gain for the week to 65.31 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by better than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,020 up, 465 down and 480 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 140.55 million shares, against 145.57 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 168.14 million shares. As the day began, the Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point in April to 5.4 percent. The figures also showed an increase of 64,000 in nonfarm payroll employment, far less than economists had been expecting. Analysts said the news abruptly dampened recent speculation that the Federal Reserve might be planning to tighten credit in its campaign against inflation. Interest rates fell sharply in the credit markets. Prices of long-term government bonds rose about $15 for each $1,000 in face value, reducing their yields to the 8.82 percent-8.86 percent. Just a few days earlier, Treasury bond rates surpassed 9 percent for the first time in nearly a year. But stock traders did not take the news with unequivocal enthusiasm. Brokers said it raised some fresh doubts about the outlook for economic growth and corporate profits in the months ahead. Among the blue chips, International Business Machines climbed 2{ to 110{; General Motors | to 45}; American Telephone & Telegraph ] to 40], and American Express ] to 26~. Financial and utility stocks were notable gainers, benefiting especially from the sudden shift in view of the interest-rate outlook. In the financial sector, for example, Federal Home Loan Mortgage rose 2[ to 66| and Federal National Mortgage was up 1[ at 34~. Dow Jones's average of 15 utility stocks climbed 2.27 to 208.38, for a 1.10 percent gain that more than doubled the percentage rise of the industrial average. Texas Utilities, up { at 35], and Panhandle Eastern, up { at 26], both made the active list. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $23.38 billion, or 0.73 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.40 to 185.37. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 3.08 to 394.20, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.82 at 338.39. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 3.17 to 428.61. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 345.73, up .76.

The nation's unemployment rate climbed in April to 5.4 percent, its highest level in more than a year, the government said. Friday's report triggered a huge rally in bond prices that sent interest rates skidding as analysts said the figures indicated the economy could slip into recession. There was little growth in the number of U.S. jobs for the second straight month, and the total would have declined if not for the hiring of temporary census workers.

Trade ministers representing the largest industrial countries reported they had failed to resolve major disputes blocking an ambitious effort to overhaul the global trading system. Speaking at the end of a three-day negotiating session, officials of the United States, Japan, the 12-nation European Community and Canada said Friday that sharp differences still remained over such issues as a U.S. demand for the elimination of costly agricultural barriers.

In an attempt to avoid a ``crippling nationwide rail strike,'' President Bush named an emergency board to help settle bargaining disputes between 11 unions and most of the nation's major railroads. Rising health care costs had been a major holdup in contract negotiations, which had been going on for two years. Nearly 300,000 trackmen, engineers, signalmen and other railroad workers at about 15 of the nation's largest freight railroads are affected. Bush's move Friday was hailed by organized labor as a sign that the administration is concerned about workers' medical coverage.

Congressional testimony by convicted junk bond financier Michael Milken before he is sentenced could complicate the securities fraud case, the nation's top securities regulator said. Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said Friday the commission will ``try to work with Congress to make sure they understand the status of the case as they consider what hearings they wish to have and when they want to have them.'' The oversight and investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee voted unanimously Tuesday to subpoena Milken, who pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties last month.

Departing savings and loan cleanup boss L. William Seidman said that ``real pain'' is yet to come in the bailout and urged patience with his successor. Seidman told a House Banking Committee task force on the S&L bailout Friday that rising interest rates and falling property values indicate ``the costs will exceed those originally estimated.'' At Seidman's suggestion, President Bush is turning to William Taylor, the Federal Reserve Board's director of bank supervision, to take over the position.

Greyhound Lines Inc. said it lost $55.8 million in the first quarter and would miss millions of dollars in payments due in coming weeks because of problems related to a 2-month-old strike by bus drivers. The disclosures Friday were the first indication since the strike of the financial condition at Greyhound, which operates the the only nationwide bus system. Greyhound in large part blamed $20 million in unanticipated expenses to cope with strike-related violence.

Donald Trump's three casinos are being investigated in a financial review that state officials said was routine and had nothing to do with disgruntled contractors or the Manhattan developer's desire to sell some assets. Anthony J. Parrillo, director of the state Division of Gaming Enforcement, said Friday the review has been under way for two months. Parrillo said it was coincidental that the review coincided with statements from Trump last week that he was considering selling some of his holdings, which include Manhattan real estate and the Trump Shuttle airline.

Whittle Communications said it is consolidating its media properties designed for schools into one division and named a former executive of Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. to head the new unit. The Knoxville, Tenn.-based media company said Friday it expects its new Whittle Educational Network division to generate annual revenue of $125 million by 1991, or about 40 percent of the company's expected revenue of more than $300 million by 1991.

Two key directors of the troubled advertising and consulting giant Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC have resigned. Roy Warman and Terry Bannister served as joint chief operating officers of Saatchi's communications division with responsibility for worldwide advertising operations. Saatchi's deputy chairman Jeremy Sinclair was named Friday to replace them. Saatchi is trying to sell the consulting business.

Stock prices staged a broad advance Friday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 14.19 to 2,710.36, stretching its weekly gain to 65.31 points. Bond prices staged a furious rally that sent interest rates sharply lower. The dollar fell against every major currencies except the Japanese yen. Sugar futures prices plunged; cocoa futures fell sharply; copper futures retreated; precious metals were mostly lower; oil futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Reports $293 Million Quarterly Loss
DOC.TEXT: Columbia Savings & Loan Association said Friday it lost $293 million in the first quarter, as the value of its junk bond portfolio declined by $274 million. But Edward G. Harshfield, Columbia's president and chief executive, said the thrift had received several bids to purchase ``substantially all'' of its $3 billion junk bond portfolio in a single transaction. The quarterly loss, equal to $14.62 per share, contrasted with a profit of $7.9 million, or 20 cents per share, in the same 1989 period. Columbia had bought more high-yield, high-risk junk bonds than any other thrift, in large part due to close ties with convicted Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. financier Michael Milken, whose junk bond network involved major thrifts. Columbia said that as of March 31 it was $338 million short of federal requirements for minimum capital. The thrift said it had sold or redeemed $254 million in high-yield bonds and preferred stock and $19.5 million of equity and equity-equivalent securities. Columbia said its financial adviser, First Boston Corp., had received several bids to purchase nearly the entire portfolio of junk bonds. The bids are being discussed by Columbia, First Boston and the potential buyers, the thrift said. Harshfield described the thrift's relationship with regulators as ``positive, constructive'' as the thrift tries to sell of its junk bond portfolio. ``We are also encouraged by the wide interest in the high-yield portfolio that First Boston has received so far, and have a greater degree of confidence that a favorable transaction can occur,'' he said. Columbia's junk bond portfolio was worth $4.3 billion at the end of 1988, and has declined in large part because of the sharp decline in the high-yield bond market that began last fall due to several prominent defaults. The thrift has been forced to carry the junk portfolio on its books at market value because of accounting changes required under the government's bailout program for the nation's saving and loan insurance fund. Columbia is seeking to unload the portfolio to meet net capital requirements for insurance. The thrift is expected to receive a better price if it can sell the portfolio whole rather than piecemeal. Junk bonds are a form of debt security that offer high yields in exchange for their perceived high risk. Thrifts in the 1980s bought billions of dollars in the bonds, which were used to finance small companies and hostile takeovers. Columbia also said it set aside $192.7 million for credit loss reserves _ which reflects the declined junk bond portfolio _ earlier in the quarter when it announced it was insolvent. The thrift's accounting loss from the reserve for the quarter was $80.9 million. Due to the first-quarter loss, Columbia had a stockholders' deficit of $215.6 million, compared with shareholders' equity of $77.6 million as of Dec. 31. Columbia said its net interest income fell to $12.7 million from $60.2 million.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied Post Huge Annual Losses; Campeau Poses Business Plan
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and sister Allied Stores Corp. posted net losses totaling more than $2.1 billion in their fourth fiscal quarters, largely because of a write-down stemming from their bankruptcy reorganization. The companies, which own nearly 260 U.S. department stores such as Bloomingdale's, Rich's and Lazarus, also reported that excluding non-operating charges, they posted operating profits for both the fourth quarter and full fiscal year ended Feb. 3. ``I believe we have turned the corner on stabilizing the business, and that we are well into a period of operational recovery,'' chairman Allen Questrom said in a prepared statement. Separately, the companies' parent Campeau Corp. said it had proposed a business plan to its bondholders that includes the sale of real estate assets and a temporary halt in its interest payments. Federated and Allied sought federal bankruptcy court protection from creditors on Jan. 15, citing the burden of paying off $7.7 billion in debt. Much of the debt was incurred when Campeau acquired the companies, Federated in 1988 and Allied in 1986, largely with borrowed funds. Worsening the companies' condition was a sluggish retailing environment, which forced price-cutting and other competitive moves that cut into profits. Federated said it lost $1.34 billion during the fourth quarter on sales of $1.59 billion, compared with a profit of $27.6 million and sales of $1.49 billion in the year-earlier quarter. The results were sharply affected by a $1.15 billion writedown of goodwill _ the amount over Federated's book value that Campeau paid to acquire the company in 1988 _ an accounting move made to reflect the deterioration of Federated's financial situation during the year. Federated's earnings also were reduced by $126.5 million in deferred financing and reorganization costs and by $516.1 million in net interest expense. The company had operating income of $48.6 million, down from $175.9 million a year earlier. Allied said it lost $836.8 million on sales of $892.2 million, compared with a profit of 37.6 million on sales of $869.8 million a year earlier. Allied's earnings were reduced by non-operating charges of $660.3 million for its equity in Federated, $290.6 million in net interest expense and $138.8 million in income tax expense. The company's operating income was $25.2 million in the quarter, down from $86.2 million a year earlier. For the full year, Federated posted a net loss of 1.5 billion, compared with a loss of $156.3 billion a year earlier. Sales rose 7.2 percent to $4.87 billion from $3.57 billion. Allied's net loss on the year was $925.2 million, compared with a profit of $51.4 million the previous year. Sales rose 5.2 percent to $2.7 billion from $2.57 billion. At the end of the fiscal year, Federated had $367 million in cash on hand and Allied had $185 million in cash, the companies reported. Both also showed positive cash flows, $372.4 million for Federated and $199.7 million for Allied for the full year, although the companies are not making interest payments while in bankruptcy court reorganization. Federated owns the Bloomingdale's, Lazarus, Abraham and Straus, Rich's and Burdine's chains. Allied's chains include Jordan Marsh, Stern's, Maas Brothers and The Bon Marche. Campeau, which spun off its department store businesses shortly before they entered bankruptcy court protection, is attempting to work out of its own financial problems. In a business plan proposed to holders of $184 million of its debentures, Campeau said it would ask bondholders to waive any defaults and defer interest payments through Dec. 31, 1991. In return, the company would sell assets from its real estate holdings to make a ``major reduction'' in its secured debt. Campeau also would pay secured loans with cash flow from the properties used as collateral. Bondholders would consider the plan at a previously scheduled June 1 meeting in Toronto. Campeau's real estate holdings consist primarily of shopping malls and office complexes and business in the United States and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Awards Fox Network Waiver to Continue Growth
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission ruled Friday that the Fox Broadcasting Co. will be able to grow as a network while its parent company continues selling television shows into syndication. The decision, which grants Fox a one-year waiver to FCC guidelines, allows the network to show up to 18{ hours of programming a week. But Fox will be prohibited from acquiring any financial interest in or syndication rights to new programs while the the waiver is in effect. Before the ruling, networks showing more than 15 hours of programming a week were forbidden by the FCC from participating in the television syndication business. Fox asked for the waiver in January, saying the television market had changed substantially since the rules were adopted in 1970 when the three major networks dominated the television market. Shows syndicated by Fox Inc., the parent company of the network, include ``A Current Affair,'' ``Mr. Belvedere'' and ``MASH.'' The ruling comes as the three networks are fighting to repeal the 1970 financial interest and syndication rules. The rules forbid the networks from owning programs sold into the lucrative television syndication market. The networks contend the prohibition unfairly limits their access to viewers. The 3-year-old Fox network was awarded the limited waiver, the FCC said, because the commission wants to encourage new national networks, help supply programming for the 112 Fox-affiliated stations on the UHF band, and advance children's programming. The Fox network plans to introduce a 2{-hour daily block of children's shows this fall. Fox also plans later this year to add programming on Wednesday and Friday night and on Saturday morning. ``The interim waiver announced today will permit the continued growth and development of Fox Broadcasting Co. as we all strive to achieve a global resolution of the financial interest and syndication issues,'' Barry Diller, chairman of Fox Inc., said in a statement. The ruling was opposed by the Motion Picture Association of America and the Walt Disney Co., among others. Those opposing the decision fear the three established networks and Fox will force other production companies out of business if they enter into syndication. Joe Rutledge, vice president of corporate communication for NBC, said the network feared the ruling ``removes the immediate pressure on Fox and the studios to reach a settlement'' on the issue of the financial interest and syndication rules. He did say, however, that NBC applauded the FCC's inclination to remove anti-competetive barriers from television networks. Preston Padden, senior vice president for affiliates for Fox Broadcasting, said the network will continue to battle against the financial interest and syndication rules. ``We are prepared to see the fight through and get appropriate regualatory relief for the three networks as well.''
